DOC.TEXT: Millonario norteamericano perseguido en Costa Rica desaparece en Nicaragua Por Rodolfo GarcDia MANAGUA, 7 (AP) - John Hull, millonario norteamericano prDofugo de la justicia costarricense descubierto el lunes residiendo en una ciudad del sureste nicaraguense, ``desapareciDo misteriosamente'', dicen hoy diarios locales. ``Estamos apresurando los trDamites a travDes de nuestra embajada en Managua para solicitar la extradiciDon de Hull, que tendrDa que enfrentar la justicia costarricense'', dijo el miDercoles por telDefono a un diario nicaraguense el asesor legal de la cancillerDia de ese paDis, Alvaro JimDenez. Hull estDa acusado en los tribunales de justicia costarricense por ``actos hostiles contra el estado, homicidio calificado y trDafico ilegal de drogas y armas''. En la dDecada de 1960 Hull llegDo a Costa Rica y comprDo una finca de mDas de 607 hectDareas, muy cerca de la frontera con Nicaragua. SegDun versiones periodDisticas, Hull se naturalizDo costarricense en 1984, ``para burlar la enmienda (del congreso norteamericano) Boland que prohibDia al gobierno de Estados Unidos y sus ciudadanos apoyar, financiar o trabajar con los rebeldes antisandinistas conocidos como `contras'''. En marzo de 1984 se mencionDo a Hull como contacto directo de agentes de la Central de Inteligencia de Estados Unidos en Costa Rica, que asesoraban a los jefes de la Resistencia Nicaraguense. Posteriormente, en mayo de 1984 se le involucrDo en la explosiDon de una bomba en el campamento La Penca, desde donde el jefe militar de la antisandinista Alianza Revolucionaria DemocrDatica (ARDE), EdDen Pastora, dirigDia las acciones contra el rDegimen sandinista de Nicaragua. En ese atentado murieron cinco personas, incluso dos periodistas norteamericanos, y resultaron 27 heridos, incluso Pastora. Hull huyDo de Costa Rica cuando se le investigaba sobre su presunta participaciDon en el trDafico de armas y narcDoticos y su vinculaciDon con la Resistencia Nicaraguense. El lunes, un periodista del diario prosandinista Barricada, lo descubriDo en la ciudad de Juigalpa, 137 kilDometros al este de la capital y al preguntarle sobre su situaciDon con la justicia costarricense, Hull contestDo: ``AquDi no hay nada, no pueden hacer nada'' e inmediatamente partiDo en su camioneta. Las autoridades de migraciDon confirmaron a los periodistas que Hull se encontraba en el paDis desde el 31 de agosto en ``calidad de turista'', pero no podDian arrestarlo mientras el gobierno costarricense en forma oficial no lo solicitara. DespuDes de la publicaciDon de Barricada, Hull y una hija adoptiva que le acompaInaba desaparecieron y no han sido vistos en Juigalpa, donde sostuvieron entrevistas con autoridades locales y lDideres de la antigua resistencia nicaraguense, segDun se informDo.

DOC.HEAD: Painter Jean-Paul Lemiuex Dies
DOC.TEXT: Jean-Paul Lemieux, a painter whose work was exhibited widely across North America, has died after being hospitalized for a week. He was 86. The artist's death Friday was announced by L'Hopital Laval de Sainte-Foy. The cause of Lemieux's death was not disclosed. Lemieux, born in Quebec City, was particularly known for his landscapes, reflecting the appearance of Quebec in the 1950s. He received the Order of Canada in 1968. His work is in the prime minister's residence in Ottawa. In 1985, he published a limited edition French-English collection of prints - one for each Canadian province and territory.

DOC.HEAD: Elaine Hooker Named General Executive in AP Membership Dept.
DOC.TEXT: Elaine Norton Hooker, deputy director of corporate communications for The Associated Press, has been named general executive in the newspaper membership department at AP headquarters in New York. The appointment was announced Thursday by Wick Temple, vice president and director of newspaper membership. Hooker, 46, joined the AP as a newswoman in Hartford, Conn., in 1974. She also served as Hartford news editor, correspondent in Springfield, Mass., and Boston news editor before returning to Hartford as chief of bureau in 1984. She left in 1988 to study at Andover Newton Theological School and returned to the AP in New York in January 1990. Hooker, who grew up in Sharon, Pa., worked at weekly newspapers in Connecticut and Massachusetts, and as a reporter and editor at The Hartford Courant before joining the AP.

DOC.HEAD: New Pikeville Correspondent Named
DOC.TEXT: Allen G. Breed, a newsman in the Louisville bureau of The Associated Press, has been named correspondent in Pikeville. The appointment was announced Thursday by Kentucky Chief of Bureau Ed Staats. Breed, 26, joined the AP in Louisville in 1988. A Lynn, Mass., native, he received his bachelor's degree from Denison University and master's degree in print journalism from Boston University. He succeeds Rob Wells, who transferred to AP Bsiness News in New York.

DOC.HEAD: For Young Black Males, A Homicide Explosion
With PM-Deadly Year, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Homicide among young black men and teen-agers in America is rapidly worsening, federal health officials said. In 1988, 2,741 black males from 15 to 24 were slain in homicides in the United States, CDC epidemiologist Dr. Robert Froehlke said Thursday. The killings, based on preliminary figures, would translate to a homicide rate of 101.1 for every 100,000 black males 15-24, up 67 percent from the 1984 rate of 60.6. While homicides decreased among young black men in the early 1980s, the rate has skyrocketed since, the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease Control said in a report Thursday. Rates for females and white males of that age ``have either stayed essentially the same, or in fact decreased a little bit,'' Froehlke said. ``The disparity between black males and other groups has widened even more.'' In 1987, the latest year for complete statistics have been compiled, the homicide rate for young black males was 84.6, some six times higher than the rate for all Americans 15-24, which was 13.8. Overall, the nationwide homicide rate in 1987 was 8.5. Homicides accounted for 42 percent of the deaths of black males 15-24 in 1987. It was the leading cause of death for the group. The homicide problem is getting worse faster for black teen-agers, the CDC said. The 1988 homicide rate for black males 15-19 was 76.8, up 99 percent since 1984. The rate for black males 20-24 was 127.2, up 53 percent from 1984. Firearm homicides accounted for virtually all the 1984-87 explosion in killings of young black males - more than 95 percent, the CDC said. And six areas with rates of greater than 100 - California, Florida, Michigan, Missouri, New York and the District of Columbia - accounted for more than half the deaths of young black males in 1987, 51 percent. Those six areas have 29 percent of the nation's black male population 15-24, the CDC said. In its weekly report, the CDC called for more research into ways to stop the killings. ``Research and evaluation efforts have not demonstrated effective programmatic approaches to prevent homicide,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Deadly Year, Bjt, PM-Deadly Year-List
DOC.TEXT: Statistics don't lie, but neither do they tell the whole truth. Behind the soaring numbers of homicides in some of America's largest cities lie the bodies and broken dreams of real people, real families and real neighborhoods. Here is a sampling: --- Rayvon Jamison was trying to learn how to walk when he died in his family's New York City apartment in July. Rayvon, who was 9 months old, was one of four New York children who were caught in the line of gunfire in a week's time. Rayvon was in a walker when he was struck in the shoulder by two of seven shots fired into the apartment, police said at the time. Nine adults, including his mother, were home at the time. Three young men were arrested and charged with murder in the case. Police said they had been involved in an argument with Rayvon's uncle and some other neighborhood men. Mayor David Dinkins issued an anguished plea for federal gun control after Rayvon's death. ``Our children are dying. These young people, these babies, had the right to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness, but their rights have been blown away. And for what?'' he said. --- On Monday, 10-year-old Willie Lawrence became the year's 60th homicide victim in Bridgeport, Conn. He was shot in the head in the inner-city apartment building where he lived. His cousin, Ramon Pagan, 18, said he believed he was the gunman's target and that Lawrence was an innocent bystander. --- Kimberly Rae Harbour was 26 years old, a crack user and sometimes prostitute. For that reason, some people in Boston say, police didn't make a big deal out of her death on Halloween night. It was, however, a horrifying death - one that has since captured far more attention than Harbour ever received in her life. According to police, Harbour was chased into a park in the city's Dorchester section by a group of teen-agers who proceeded to rape her, bludgeon her and stab her more than 100 times. She also was robbed, police said, of $1. Eight youths have been charged in her death. --- Police called it a case of ``utterly senseless violence.'' Were it not for the victim's last name, Bias, the shooting on Nov. 20 in a shopping center outside Washington, D.C., probably would have been quickly forgotten. Police in Maryland's Prince George's County said 20-year-old James Stanley Bias III, also known as Jay, was shot in the parking lot of the Prince George's Plaza Shopping Center in Hyattsville following an argument in a jewelry store a few minutes before. Jerry Samuel Tyler, 24, of Temple Hills, was charged with first-degree murder in the case. Bias was pronounced dead of two gunshot wounds to the back at Leland Memorial Hospital in Riverdale, the same hospital where his brother Len Bias was pronounced dead in June 1986. Len Bias, whose death shocked the sports world, died of a cocaine induced heart attack just two days after his first-round selection by the Boston Celtics in the National Basketball Association draft.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Noriega Tapes
DOC.TEXT:
The following are selected portions of transcripts of CNN tapes of Manuel Noriega's prison telephone conversations prepared by a federal court and ordered released Thursday. Many of the conversations appear to use code words. The first segment comes from a conversation between Noriega and his defense attorneys' office that sparked the judge's order to CNN to cease telecasting the tapes. It involves Noriega speaking to lead attorney Frank Rubino's legal secretary Cristina Machin.
Noriega: ``There is a name I just saw in the newspaper, a person named Alfredo Sanchez.'' Machin: ``A...Alfredo'' N: ``Sanchez.'' M: ``Sanchez'' N: ``And Felipe Camargo.'' (he repeats, she checks with Rubino investigator Jim Hawkins) M: ``I have Jimmy here ... he says they were both arrested.'' N: ``Uh huh.'' M: ``And it is anticipated they will fully testify.'' N: ``uh huh.'' Hawkins: (Unintelligible.) M: ``This is only the newspaper.'' N: ``Uh-huh.'' M: ``We don't known anything definite yet, from the government.'' N: ``O.K., but you do have the article from the paper, right?'' M: ``Yes, he suggests you run these names through your mind.'' (Noriega says he has known Camargo as an officer, but not Sanchez.) N: ``It's the last part, ah ah ... it's the, the last part, the article is interesting because, well, it's showing their strategy, it says that they are trying to offer them deals, right, so they will testify against me.''
In the following excerpt, Noriega appears to discuss frozen funds with his mistress Vicki Amado's mother, Norma Amado. She asks if ``the man'' has arrived and Noriega says no. Amado: ``No, I ended up without lunch because ...'' Noriega: ``Yes, yes yes.'' A: ``Too cold is also a hassle.'' N: ``Ah, uh-huh, the weather there is bad?'' A: ``Yes, yes, yes, uh?'' (She says her ``namesake is going farther.'') A: ``Because there, well, it's not frozen there.'' N: ``Uh-huh...'' A: ``Since we are all frozen here and over there it wouldn't be a problem.'' (They continue) A: ``It occurred to me...'' N: ``Yes.'' A: ``That at a given moment there we have'' N: ``Yes.'' A: ``A good towel.'' N: ``Ah, perfect.'' A: ``And the important thing is that it shouldn't be a hand (towel.)'' N: ``Yes.''
The following excerpt involves a conversation betwen Noriega and his daughter, Sandra. Noriega: ``Because I was thinking, you know, that, well, that changing the thing, see, if he leaves on Sunday, well, since the food guy will be in Panama on Sunday...'' Sandra: ``Uh-huh.'' N: ``That he gives it to him and he brings it to Santo Domingo to your mother.'' (They discuss when he would arrive) S: ``The one with the food.'' N: ``The one with the food goes there Sunday.''
The next excerpt involves Noriega and an unidentified man, possibly a lawyer who belongs to a pro-Noriega political party. Unknown man: ``If it is going to be this way, have someone do it who is, is one of ours.'' Noriega: ``Yes, there will be a hell of a headline, they well, they will, (expletive), there will be a hell of a mess.'' U: ``No.'' N: ``And besides, they have a lot of information.'' (They continue) N: ``And this, that is the first time, that the (expletive) will be spelled out, without fear.'' (Later, they talk about politics.) U: ``We must continue our path based on history.'' N: ``And that is what we must explain to the people, that before, that, that one must unite, that there are people with ambition that are now going to take over the party, uh, because one must also think of those who are still in the jails, those who have died, the, the family, those that have been fired, those out canvassing and looking for sponsors for the party and the people who are suffering.'' U: ``Maybe that is the point we must strive for, and keep ourselves now, uh, in terms of future elections.'' N: ``Yeah.''

DOC.HEAD: Author Says Oil Was `Linchpin' of Japanese War Strategy
DOC.TEXT: The attack on Pearl Harbor 49 years ago today was linked more closely than commonly believed to Japan's thirst for secure oil supplies, according to a new book that draws haunting parallels to the Persian Gulf crisis. In ``The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money and Power'' published this week, author Daniel Yergin called oil the ``linchpin'' of Japan's strategy for Asian conquest and the trigger for its stunning attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941. The assault on the U.S. Pacific Fleet killed 2,335 American servicemen and 68 civilians. Yergin's book, which was seven years in the making, cites the Pacific campaign as one of many examples from the 20th century of oil's crucial and painful role in global and regional conflict. It draws parallels to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, calling it a high-stakes gamble by a militaristic ruler bent on capturing new oil wealth in order to widen his regional domination. Saddam Hussein, like Japan's leaders five decades earlier, coveted oil and gave in to ``the inevitable and irresistible temptation to grasp for its rewards,'' Yergin writes. Historians for years have drawn a connection between oil and Japan's Indochina campaigns. Yergin, however, says oil not only played a central role in the broader Japanese war strategy but also was the driving force behind Operation Hawaii, as the Japanese military called the Pearl Harbor plan. Yergin, an international oil specialist and president of the consulting firm Cambridge Energy Research Associates, argues that the militaristic Japanese leaders saw oil - in particular, Japan's lack of indigenous supplies - as a vulnerability that could spoil their imperialistic ambitions in Asia. ``They went to war over oil,'' Yergin said in an interview. So worried was Adm. Isoroku Yamamoto, commander-in-chief of Japan's Combined Fleets, about insecure oil supplies to power his ships that he even sponsored experiments by a ``scientist'' who claimed he could change water to oil, Yergin writes. Japan also considered sinking large sums into a crash program to produce synthetic fuel from coal, although this never yielded results. Yergin concludes that Japan's main focus in the Asia campaigns was to secure access to the oil fields of Borneo and the Dutch East Indies, now Indonesia. At the time, Japan got 80 percent of its oil from the United States, and it feared the consequences of a possible American cutoff of supplies. In July 1941, President Roosevelt did sever the oil lifeline, a move that Yergin says hardened the Japanese leadership's resolve to strike at the U.S. Pacific Fleet, which Tokyo believed was the only serious threat to its success in Asia. ``The operation against Pearl Harbor was meant to protect the flank - to safeguard the Japanese invasion of the Indies and the rest of Southeast Asia by incapacitating the American fleet and, thereafter, to protect the sea lanes, particularly the tanker routes from Sumatra and Borneo to the home islands,'' Yergin writes. Strangely, considering the important role that oil played in Japan's decision to attack Pearl Harbor, the Japanese navy failed to understand the importance of the oil supplies on the Hawaiian island of Oahu, Yergin says. They did not strike at the more than 4 million barrels of oil stored on the island for the U.S. ships. ``If the Japanese planes had knocked out the Pacific Fleet's fuel reserves and the tanks in which they were stored at Pearl Harbor, they would have immobilized every ship of the American Pacific Fleet, and not just those they actually destroyed,'' he writes.

DOC.HEAD: Shipping a Rare Vase? Here's How to Make Sure it Arrives Safely
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Worried about how to send fragile gifts? Take some tips from curators of The Corning Museum of Glass, who just shipped more than 120 priceless treasures to Washington without a chip or crack. ``We do it very, very carefully,'' said museum official David Whitehouse. ``The secret is to pack an object so it is held gently but firmly into place, with enough packing materials around it and a sturdy container to resist the bumps and knocks,'' he said. Whitehouse supervised the installation of a new exhibition titled ``The Art of Glass: Masterpieces from The Corning Museum,'' which will be on display at the National Gallery of Art from Sunday through March 17. The delicate objects that traveled from Corning, N.Y., to Washington span 35 centuries of the glassmaker's art, from a perfume bottle made by Egyptian artisans in about 1400 B.C. to brilliantly colored glass filament sculptures fashioned by a Dutch artist in 1988. Among the most famous pieces in the show are the ``Disch Kantharos,'' a 4th Century Roman goblet contained in a clear glass cage, and a rare ``Hedwig beaker'' from the 12th century that was discovered in Cologne, Germany. From one of these carved glass tumblers, only 14 of which are known to survive, the patron saint of Silesia supposedly drank water that turned into wine. To pack a treasure like these, Whitehouse said, the Corning museum began with a stout cardboard box. ``We would fill the box with two foam bricks, cut to fit inside the box exactly when placed one on top of the other. Then we would carve out of the two bricks a nest as close to the shape of the object as we can make it, and a tad bigger,'' he said. ``We would wrap the object in acid-free tissue paper and set it into the bottom half of the nest. Then we'd fit the other brick on top, so the object is gently but firmly trapped inside its own foam shock absorber. ``Then we put the box inside a custom-built wooden crate about a half-inch thick. The crate will contain usually eight cardboard boxes with little thin foam sheets to separate them. Then we screw the lid down on the crate. ``What you've got is a stout crate of eight boxes instead of a carton of eggs,'' he said. For the 280-mile trip to Washington, the boxed glass objects traveled in two customized commercial trucks built with an air suspension and long wheel base to minimize the shocks of hitting an occasional pothole. The trucks were climate-controlled to protect the glass from the damaging effects of sudden changes in temperature and humidity. A half-dozen Corning museum employees packed the objects, traveled with the shipment and unpacked and mounted them at the National Gallery. Several objects in the show are so fragile that they were carried personally to Washington by the Corning curators, nestled safely under their car or plane seats. Whitehouse said one was an ``incredibly thin'' pitcher made in Persia in 1000 A.D. that previously had been ``broken into a million pieces'' and painstakingly glued back together. ``Another secret is never to let these objects get out of your sight,'' Whitehouse said. ``There is absolutely nothing you can do to stop a cowboy driving a forklift except to tell him to back off.''

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Amazon Road Makes News Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: To Brazilian industrialists, an Acre-Peru Road is the path to a brighter future. To ecologists worried about the Amazon, it is the devil's own highway. Such a road would fulfill a centuries-old vision of a land route across northern South America, but it probably won't be built soon because the continent has a huge foreign debt and concern for the environment is growing. Mere mention of the Acre-Peru Road causes headlines in Latin America, mobilizes environmentalists in Europe and the United States, and starts up the diplomatic teletypes. Mario Amato, one of Brazil's most influential industrialists, was the latest catalyst. ``Brazil must have an outlet to the Pacific,'' said Amato, who is acting president of the National Confederation of Industry and organized a seminar to promote the highway. He said it would be a direct export route for Brazilian forest products to the U.S. west coast and Japan, bypassing the Panama Canal. ``Opposition to this road is mostly political demagoguery,'' he said in an interview, and environmentalists ``have a morbid aversion to progress. Real ecological degradation is that which destroys human dignity, through misery and isolation.'' Amato said ecological problems ``can be worked out while the highway is being built.'' His campaign has produced a flood of newspaper articles, with maps and dotted lines showing how to link Brazil's far-western Amazon region, as yet undestroyed, with the Pacific. There are two possible routes for the road, both starting at Rio Branco, the capital of Acre, Brazil's westernmost state. One would run northwest and hook up with the Peruvian highway system about 700 miles away in Pucallpa, on the eastern slopes of the Andes. The other, about 300 miles long, would go southwest, cut through part of northern Bolivia and meet the Peruvian road system at Puerto Maldonado, a jungle outpost. Jungle tracks and muddy ruts already exist along sections of both routes, but building the highway would involve massive clearing of forest and the uprooting of rubber-tree tappers, Brazil nut harvesters and native Indians. On the Peruvian side, the road would run through country controlled by cocaine gangs and the Maoist guerrilla group Shining Path, both deadly to intruders. The main opposition in Brazil comes from President Fernando Collor de Mello and his internationally known environment secretary, Jose Lutzenberger. ``I'm against the highway for ecological reasons,'' Lutzenberger said in an interview. ``The president guaranteed it will not be built.'' Brazil plans to host a huge U.N. world environment conference in 1992 and has been working to change its image from destroyer of the Amazon jungle to its protector. Peru's director of roads, Hector Rosales, said in an interview in Lima: ``We are not in a condition to finance this road, but if Brazil or somebody else offered us money to build it, we would probably accept.'' For environmentalists, the most convincing argument against a highway west of Rio Branco is the one called BR-364 that was opened east and south of there in the 1980s. Hundreds of thousands of homesteaders, prospectors and ranchers followed the road into Acre's neighboring state, Rondonia, and in a few short years chopped down or burned 20 percent of the virgin rain forest. Rondonia is the size of Oregon. When the Inter-American Development Bank proposed to finance the paving of BR-364, such groups as the National Wildlife Federation, Sierra Club and Environmental Defense Fund mobilized a global campaign against it. At one point, pro-environment U.S. senators threatened to block all U.S. financing for the Inter-American Development Bank because of BR-364. Brazil agreed to impose strict protections for the jungle and Indian tribes. When the Acre-Peru proposal emerged at the end of the decade, President Bush entered the picture, at least in the view of the Brazilian news media. They were convinced Bush personally opposed the highway and had pressured Japan not to finance it. Brazilian environmentalists applauded the U.S. leader and the pro-highway faction accused him of meddling in Brazilian affairs. ``The president, while aware of the controversy, has never voiced a position on the road,'' Stephen Hart, deputy White House press secretary, said in Washington. He said the administration would follow State Department guidelines on the Acre-Peru Road. A State Department official who works on Brazilian affairs said, on condition of anonymity: ``We're not helping anybody who's building a highway in which there is no environmental plan.'' Japan also is cautious. Shintaro Sasaki, second in command at the Japanese Embassy in Brasilia, said his government was ``unaware of any plan to finance such a highway.'' He agreed Brazilian exports to the East now must travel through the Panama Canal or around Cape Horn, but said that made sense for iron ore, the main export to Japan, because the mines are in eastern Brazil. ``Therefore,'' he said, ``Japan has no interest in shortening trade routes from Brazil by building a highway to the west coast of South America.'' Proponents are not giving up. ``What we're talking about is the need to physically link Acre to the rest of the world,'' said Marco Antonio Mendes, the state's environment secretary.

DOC.HEAD: Colonel Tom Collection Joins Elvis Memorabilia at Graceland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The displays of sparkling jumpsuits, gold records and shiny motorcycles at Elvis Presley's house are about to get a bit flashier, managers of the estate say. Tom Parker, who directed Presley's career for 30 years, has sold his personal collection of rock 'n' roll memorabilia to the residence known as Graceland. The collection includes about 70,000 pounds of business documents, photographs, clothes, newsreels and other items, Graceland managers said Thursday. It also includes more gold records, acetate recordings of Presley's early studio work and promotional tapes of Elvis messages passed out to radio stations in the early days of the singer's career. One acetate recording is of Presley's first appearance on the ``Louisiana Hayride'' radio show in 1954. Presley's famous gold lame suit will join his other outfits on display at Graceland, as will the 1976 Cadillac he gave Parker as a present. The gold suit will go on display in January during annual festivities surrounding Presley's birthday. Jim Jaworowicz, Graceland's specialist for rock 'n' roll artifacts, said the collection covers Parker's 65 years as a music promoter and offers a clear paper trail on the business side of creating a star. ``It's so well kept, it's like a time capsule from the `50s,'' Jaworowicz said. Parker, 81, who generally avoids reporters, said he had several would-be buyers for the collection, including an eager Japanese bidder who offered the top price. Parker, known as Col. Tom Parker or just ``the colonel,'' said he wanted the collection at Graceland. He said he expects there to be an ``Elvis and the Colonel'' museum at Graceland one day. ``Someday when I'm not around, it will always be `Elvis and the Colonel,''' Parker said by telephone from his residence near Nashville. Jack Soden, executive director of the Graceland Division of Elvis Presley Enterprises Inc., would not reveal the purchase price for the collection. Niether would Parker. Graceland, which draws more than 600,000 visitors annually, already includes extensive displays of clothes, vehicles and mementos that once belonged to Presley. The estate also has a 36,000-square-foot shopping center devoted primarily to Elvis souvenirs. His body racked by drug abuse, Presley died at Graceland in 1977. He was 42. Parker said there was nothing he could do to keep Presley from abusing drugs. ``He did it on his own. Elvis, you could not tell Elvis anything what to do,'' he said. ``He made his own decisions and you could not change them.'' Parker said he was unaware of Presley's drug use when it began. ``I found out later that Elvis told the boys, `Don't tell the colonel,'' Parker said. Parker, who has been involved in legal disputes with the Presley estate over the years, said he was pleased for his name to become a bigger part of the Elvis displays at Graceland. ``No one but myself and Elvis and his father knew how close we were,'' Parker said.

DOC.HEAD: Silent Cal: Broadcast Pioneer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Decades before the sound bite became the parlance of politics, Calvin Coolidge doffed his ``Silent Cal'' image and stepped up to the mike, delivering his annual Message to Congress to a spellbound nation. Historians on Thursday remembered the anniversary of the president's first broadcast, hailed by critics of the day who said Coolidge's Yankee twang cut admirably across the crackle of early radio. ``Apparently his high-pitched nasal whine really penetrated the static,'' said Kelly Buckley, curator of the Coolidge collection at the Forbes Library in Northampton, the western Massachusetts town where Coolidge got his political start. The speech, delivered Dec. 6, 1923, on a hookup of seven radio stations, sent neighbors flocking to the homes of those who owned new radio sets, said Buckley, also a historian at the University of Massachusetts. ``Out on the prairie, picking up these little signals on crystal radio sets, it really must have given people a sense of connection that they never had before,'' he said. The speech was a lengthy discourse on several topics including foreign affairs, with Coolidge taking a wishy-washy stand on the League of Nations, and endorsing continued restricted immigration. ``America must be kept American,'' Coolidge said in a broadcast heard by stations as far away as Missouri and Texas, said Michael Kittross, a professor at Emerson College in Boston. ``Coolidge was the master of the platitude,'' Buckley said. ``What he said was comforting and full of cracker barrel wisdom.''

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Says Saddam Put More Troops in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: A new buildup of Iraqi troops in and around Kuwait is enabling Iraq to extend its line of multi-layered defenses well to the west of the occupied emirate, the Pentagon says. Bob Hall, a Pentagon spokesman, said Thursday that Iraq has moved an additional 30,000 troops into Kuwait and southern Iraq, raising the total to 480,000. That is more than four times the number Iraq used in its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Hall also announced that 10,000 U.S. reinforcements had arrived in the Persian Gulf area, raising the total American deployment to more than 250,000. About 180,000 additional U.S. troops are scheduled to join Operation Desert Shield over the next several weeks. On Thursday, the Army said it ordered to active duty 1,521 National Guard and Reserve members for Operation Desert Shield. The Army call-up raised to 118,834 the number of U.S. reservists put on active duty in all services for Desert Shield since the operation began in August. In announcing the further Iraqi buildup at a news briefing, Hall said most of the extra Iraqi troops were shifted from the Iranian border. Their redeployment has enabled Iraq to extend its line of defense further west from Kuwait, he said. The apparent purpose of extending Iraqi defensive fortifications to the west would be to block any flanking movement by American and allied ground forces in the event of an offensive campaign to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait. U.S. military officials have said they would look for ways of avoiding a frontal assault on the Iraqi forces inside Kuwait, which are aligned in an elaborate and deep defensive position surrounded by land mines and anti-tank ditches. The Bush administration, in arguing against waiting indefinitely for United Nations economic sanctions to compel Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, has argued in recent days that delay would give Iraq more time to strengthen its defenses in and around Kuwait. It is unclear, however, whether the extended defensive line Iraq reportedly is building west of Kuwait actually would make it harder for a U.S. attack to succeed. One Army official, speaking privately, said the stretching of its defenses would make Iraq's supply lines more vulnerable to air attack. Hall said the addition of 30,000 Iraqi troops to the area seemed to indicate that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein did not intend to withdraw from Kuwait, even though Iraq announced Thursday that it was preparing the release of all foreign hostages. A hostage release would not affect Pentagon plans for Desert Shield troop deployments, Hall said. He declined to provide more information about the latest Iraqi reinforcements, which apparently have been detected by U.S. intelligence in recent days. In testimony before the Senate Armed Services Committee, Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said Monday there were 450,000 Iraqi troops in and around Kuwait, along with 3,800 tanks. Hall said there now are 4,000 tanks. He also said the Iraqis have 2,500 armored personnel carriers and infantry fighting vehicles in the Kuwait area of operations, an increase of 300 from the total Powell reported to the Senate committee. The number of Iraqi artillery pieces was reported by Hall to have increased by 200, to 2,700. The Pentagon, citing security, won't provide figures on specific U.S. weapons in the gulf area. The latest U.S. troops to arrive in the gulf apparently are the lead elements of a huge reinforcement effort under way at U.S. bases in Germany and the United States. About 430,000 American troops are expected to be in the gulf area by late January.

DOC.HEAD: 1990 Was Deadliest Year In Many Big Cities
With PM-Deadly Year-Vignettes, PM-Deadly Year-List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Americans in the nation's biggest cities killed each other in record numbers this year, a rise in carnage police blame on guns, drugs and a declining reverence for human life. Not all cities had increased killings, but the number of homicides in the 20 largest cities in 1990 has surpassed the 1989 total by 3 percent, and the year is not yet over. Police in those 20 cities have recorded 7,698 homicides so far this year. New York City recorded its 2,000th violent death of the year last weekend, when seven people were killed in one night. The city had long since surpassed its old record of 1,905 homicides, set just last year. Washington, D.C.'s, mark of 434 homicides fell late last month, making it likely that the nation's capital, which has the highest per-capita homicide rate, would remain the murder capital as well. Homicide records have been set in Dallas, Phoenix, San Antonio, Memphis, Milwaukee, Boston and New Orleans, according to the latest statistics compiled by police in those cities. New marks also were set in Richmond, Va., in Providence, R.I., Bridgeport, Conn., and Oakland and Fresno, Calif. In most big cities, police say young black men are causing - and bearing the brunt of - the increase in violence. In 1990, young urbanites killed for drugs, for clothes, for pittances of cash, for love, for hate and just for the hell of it. They killed friends, relatives and innocent bystanders. They turned poor neighborhoods into virtual prisons for law-abiding citizens. ``They just don't care,'' said Lt. Joe Hladky, acting commander of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department homicide division. ``It's that disregard for the value of human life that makes you wonder what direction we're going.'' James A. Fox, co-director of the National Crime Analysis Program at Northeastern University in Boston, has been tracking homicide statistics dating back to 1976, and believes the current upsurge in homicide can be traced to a ``baby boomerang'' - the coming of age of the children of baby boomers. The last big peak in homicides occurred in the early 1970s, when baby boomers reached prime murder age - late teens and early to mid-20s. Now, Fox said, their children are beginning to reach that age. These young people, Fox said, ``have drugs and weapons and a much more casual attitude about human life than their parents a generation ago.'' ``This year will pale in comparison to years to come. It's going to get a lot worse,'' he said. ``It's often said that Americans have a love affair with violence, but in reality it's more like a marriage. And if we don't watch out in the next few years, it may be a marriage in which death does us part.'' Ask Clifton Waters, a 36-year-old Milwaukee man. A 21-year-old man was shot to death while sitting in a car in front of Waters' home in October. With 156 homicides so far this year, Milwaukee has far exceeded its previous high of 116, set in 1989. ``When I was young, you could play football in the street,'' Waters said. ``If you bumped into someone's car, you said, `Excuse me.' Now, if you touch someone's car, you get killed.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Gary Coleman, star of the TV sitcom ``Diff'rent Strokes,'' left an Arizona hospital after treatment for problems stemming from kidney disease. The 22-year-old actor was hospitalized last week and released Thursday, said his spokesman, Michael Gerety, who declined to reveal where Coleman was treated. A Tucson University Medical Center source who requested anonymity said Coleman was admitted under the name Milos Shea. Coleman lives in Tucson. Born with kidney defects, Coleman underwent two unsuccessful kidney transplants. --- SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) - M.C. Hammer showed up in person at a high school, surprising about 1,000 students who had just finished watching an anti-drug video featuring the hot rapper. ``I just want to tell everybody here today to do all they can to not be caught up in a substance problem or with dealing drugs,'' said Hammer, known for his hit album ``Please Hammer Don't Hurt `Em.'' Hammer answered questions Wednesday from McClatchy High School students after the premiere of the video featuring his hit, ``U Can't Touch This.'' He was in town for a concert Wednesday night, but the students did not expect to see him at school. --- PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Mayor W. Wilson Goode, who this week imposed a gag order on his administration, will write a newspaper column starting today. The Philadelphia Tribune, the nation's oldest continuously published black newspaper, will publish the column biweekly on its editorial page, editor Paul A. Bennett said. Goode will not be paid for the column. Goode, Philadelphia's first black mayor, addresses the city's fiscal crisis in today's column. The city may not meet its payroll this month. The mayor on Wednesday ordered city officials not to talk to reporters about Philadelphia's fiscal crisis ``without direct clearance to do so from me personally.'' --- NILES, Mich. (AP) - The chance to appear on the big screen with John Candy and Ally Sheedy drew nearly 3,000 would-be movie stars who lined up in 20-degree weather for a chance to be one of 100 extras in the filme. Some footage for the romantic comedy ``Only the Lonely'' was shot Thursday night, with more scheduled for tonight. ``It's a big scene of holiday travelers at a train station with John Candy and Ally Sheedy on the train,'' said Mark Ridge, a casting director. The movie also features Jim Belushi, Maureen O'Hara and Kevin Dunn. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Soviet spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov, known for his quick wit and understanding of the United States, is the first foreigner to win a government group's ``communicator of the year'' award. Gerasimov, 60, formerly chief spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry, lost much of his visibility earlier this year when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev named his own presidential spokesman. The National Association of Government Communicators, whose members include public affairs employees of federal, state and local governments, will present its annual award today. Gerasimov rose to prominence as the Kremlin emerged from the Cold War in the 1980s. His frequent press briefings, fluent English and acerbic wit made him a frequently cited source in news stories about the Soviet Union. --- POMPANO BEACH, Fla. (AP) - From the totally bald Telly Savalas to the merely thinning Bruce Willis, the Hair Farming Co. can't pay a celebrity to promote its product. Company founder Jacqueline Sabal said she's also approached Frank Sinatra, James Caan, Corbin Bernsen, Julio Iglesias, Jackie Mason and George Carlin without success. ``I'm having a heck of time getting these movie stars to admit they're losing their hair,'' said Sabal, who invented an herbal scalp cleanser called Foli-Kleen 2000, which she claims helps slow hair loss. ``Everyone on that list there, I've either spoken to them or to their agents,'' Sabal said. ``They laugh at us.''

DOC.HEAD: Economic Slide May Push Jobless Rate to 6 Percent, Analysts Say
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Will be led with 8:30 a.m. EST release of report
DOC.TEXT: The nation's economic slide, which has pushed the American unemployment rate up dramatically in recent months, threatens to send the jobless rate to 6 percent or higher by the end of the year, analysts say. ``As the outlook becomes more dire ... the entire pipeline (of jobs) will slow,'' said Elliott Platt, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. Private analysts will get their first comprehensive look at the nation's economic activity for November with today's release of the Labor Department's unemployment report. In advance of the report, many predicted the jobless rate shot up to 5.9 percent in November, an increase of 0.2 percentage points from the October rate of 5.7 percent. That would be the highest jobless rate since October 1987, when it was 6 percent. Analysts also expected the Labor Department's report to show that the nation's industries lost between 45,000 and 160,000 jobs in November. Last year, the nation's economy was producing nearly 200,000 new jobs a month. Higher unemployment and widespread job losses in November would back up many analysts' belief that the nation is in a recession, even though government data backing that up or refuting it won't be out until January. ``The recession deepened in November, the lull continued - that would be the basic message,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. If American businesses posted big job declines in November as predicted, Platt said, it won't be a surprise because many companies have announced large-scale layoffs in recent weeks. `It's not just a matter of people not adding on workers; it's now a matter of laying them off,'' Platt said. Many analysts believe the jobless rate will be at least 6 percent by the end of the year. ``The trend is toward 6 percent. If it isn't there by the end of the year, it will be only because the labor force is growing more slowly than we think,'' Dederick said. Before July, the jobless rate had held steady for months at 5.3 percent or within a tenth of a percentage point of that level. In July, the jobless rate shot up from 5.2 percent to 5.5 percent, then rose again in August and September before holding steady at 5.7 percent in October. The nation's manufacturing sector, which has been in a slump for months, probably continued that slide in November, analysts said. But now the slump is also affecting the services sector as well, they said. The only industry that has been spared in recent months and continued to boom is health care, which has been adding about 50,000 jobs a month.

DOC.HEAD: Falling Gasoline Prices Won't Be Felt Quickly At Pump
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For professional petroleum traders, prices for unleaded gasoline have tumbled to the level they stood at just before Iraq invaded Kuwait, but for motorists, prices at the pump are still near all-time highs. If past pricing trends hold true, ordinary consumers will find that the law of gravity doesn't necessarily apply in the energy business. One consumer activist group said Thursday that for the next few weeks at least, customers of the friendly neighborhood filling station likely will get gouged. ``When prices go up, they raise prices immediately,'' said Edwin S. Rothschild of Citizen Action in Washington. ``When prices in these futures and spot markets go down, it takes a long time for the savings to be passed on. That's the way the companies take advantage of changing market conditions.'' The oil industry, which maintains that prices are set by supply and demand, says pricing is not such a simple thing. The American Petroleum Institute has acknowledged there are times when savings have not been passed along promptly to consumers, but it has also pointed out trends in which crude oil prices were rising at the same time the pump price of gasoline was falling. ``If the price of crude oil goes down and stays down, then the price of gasoline will undoubtably follow,'' API spokesman Gus Ensz said. ``It's difficult to analyze each and every situation, because thousands of people are running service stations, and the people who run those service stations make the ultimate decision.'' The industry has asserted that all recent investigations into petroleum pricing cleared oil companies of gouging. But Rothschild said a comparison of recent prices shows that consumers are paying too much. ``From the beginning of November to December, there's been a 20-cent-a-gallon drop in the spot price of gasoline, and yet there's been barely any decrease at all in the (pump) price of gasoline,'' Rothschild said. ``My suspicion is, if anything, we should now be much more concerned about oil companies ripping consumers off.'' On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the leading market for petroleum contracts, wholesale gasoline prices fell below 65 cents Thursday, to the approximate level they were at right before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and caused a spike in the price of oil. But the latest nationwide survey by the American Automobile Association found the average price of a gallon of self-serve regular unleaded to be $1.387. That's 31.2 cents higher than the price on Aug. 1, and just .1 cent less than AAA's highest recorded price of $1.388, just before the Easter holiday in 1981, the AAA said when the survey was released Tuesday. Gasoline was up 2.1 cents for the week, and AAA pointed out that it probably would have fallen a few cents for the week had it not been for the imposition of an additional 5.1-cent federal tax, which took effect Saturday. Rothschild agreed that the tax had an impact and that otherwise pump prices could be coming down, although he insisted any decrease will take too long.

DOC.HEAD: War Artist Commissioned for Gulf Waits and Wonders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Britain's official war artist, with sketchbook at the ready, has been anxiously waiting for three months to start drawing the troops in the Persian Gulf. The Imperial War Museum has commissioned him and is eager to get him there. But a Ministry of Defense spokesman said Wednesday: ``There is no delay - we haven't got a war yet.'' John Keane, still waiting in his north London studio, says the commission is ``an extraordinary opportunity and I've been keyed up to be going.'' ``The fact of my going doesn't depend on there being a war and I sincerely hope there won't be one,'' said Keane, who has worked in zones of conflict in Northern Ireland and Nicaragua. ``The reason for my going is to portray the British troops committed to the area; war would be an extra dimension.'' The museum set aside almost $20,000 in August for the Keane commission - a quarter before he goes and the balance on completion of his studio paintings from on-the-spot sketches and photographs. ``I haven't had a penny yet so I have been getting on with other work,'' said Keane, 36, a respected artist who receives up to about $30,000 for an oil painting. The Imperial War Museum in south London has 12,000 works recording battles and the home front in both world wars, as well as lesser campaigns like the 1982 conflict to regain the Falkland Islands. ``We want John to go to the gulf now, as when serious fighting takes place he can't do much. He can't wander about with his sketchbook and camera if shells are falling,'' said Angela Weight, curator of the museum's art collection. The defense spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the ministry won't sanction an official war artist ``when there is no war at this time.'' ``There has to be a conflict for him to be employed. If something happens he could expect to go,'' the spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Developments Following U.N. Resolution
DOC.TEXT: Here are some of the fast-moving diplomatic developments in the gulf crisis that preceded Thursday's annoucement by Iraq on freeing foreign hostages. --- Nov. 29 - The U.N. Security Council authorizes the use of force to push Iraq out of Kuwait unless Iraqi President Saddam Hussein withdraws by Jan. 15. --- Nov. 29 - Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze says the Soviet Union ``will not hesitate to use force'' to protect Soviet citizens in Iraq. --- Nov. 30 - President Bush invites Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to Washington the week of Dec. 10 and says he will dispatch Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Baghdad before Jan. 15. --- Dec. 2 - Iraq warns the Soviet Union not to send troops to the gulf, and tells Bush not to use proposed talks ``as a pretext with the American people to justify his aggression against Iraq.'' --- Dec. 4 - Iraq says it will allow almost 3,300 Soviets stranded in Iraq to leave, but demands that Moscow pay compensation for canceling their work contracts. --- Dec. 4 - Britain's Sky television, citing a source close to negotiations mediated by the Soviets, reports that Saddam had proposed relinquishing all of Kuwait but the southern end of the Rumailah oil field. --- Dec. 5 - The BBC, quoting diplomatic sources, reports that the United States had proposed a Middle East conference. The White House denies the report, but a senior U.S. official at the United Nations says the Security Council was considering a draft resolution which made ``a nod'' in the direction of an international Mideast peace conference. --- Dec. 5 - The U.S. State Department announces that Iraq has formally accepted talks between Bush and Aziz and Saddam and Baker. Though the State Department says dates for the talks are still being determined, diplomats in Baghdad say Aziz will meet Bush on Dec. 17. --- Dec. 5 - Cable News Network quotes an Iraqi source as saying ``all issues'' would be on the table during talks with the United States. --- Dec. 6 - Saddam urges his rubber-stamp parliament to allow all foreign hostages trapped by the gulf crisis to leave.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Congressman Says FBI Out to Get Him
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Albert Bustamante, reportedly under investigation by the FBI in Texas, says agents have threatened people with jail time if they refused to provide damaging information about him. The San Antonio (Texas) Light reported Thursday that the FBI had confirmed it was investigating Bustamante and his longtime friend, Eddie Garcia, as part of a probe into an Indian bingo parlor deal. But chief FBI spokesman Thomas F. Jones refused to confirm or deny that the men were being investigated. ``We are not going to comment on a pending investigation,'' Jones said. The newspaper reported that a source said the FBI was investigating whether Bustamante or Garcia spent or received money illegally in pursuing a bingo parlor agreement with the Kickapoo Indians in Eagle Pass. ``They've been looking but they can't find anything; it's garbage,'' said Bustamante, a Democrat. ``They've tried to persuade people to say things against me, even to the point of threatening them that they'll face jail time,'' Bustamante said. Bustamante said the investigation is the latest twist in a long-running effort by the FBI to ``get'' some ``Hispanic scalps,'' particularly a Hispanic politician. Bustamante said that he wrote a letter introducing Garcia to leaders of the Kickapoo tribe, whose reservation is in his district. Garcia was lobbying them for a bingo contract. An unidentified source told the newspaper that FBI agents are checking whether Garcia offered any inducements to the tribe - including bribes - to cement the bingo deal. Garcia, who told the San Antonio Express-News earlier this week that the case is before a federal grand jury, denies any impropriety. Garcia said the investigation was ``strictly political.''

DOC.HEAD: Freedom of Hostages Aims Toward Peace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's decision to free all foreign hostages appears to be an Iraqi gamble to avert war. It also seems aimed at bolstering opposition in the United States to a Persian Gulf conflict. In asking Iraq's National Assembly to free the hostages, Saddam cited ``positive changes'' in the Persian Gulf crisis, including sentiment in the U.S. Congress for a non-military solution. He also said ``any measure that could delay war at the time was appropriate. ...'' There are strong indications that Saddam failed to get what he wanted from the hostages and that they had become a burden, analysts said Thursday. ``Now, I think, he is divesting himself of the burden, and also taking away the biggest reason, in the minds of public opinion, for confronting him,'' said Philip Robins, an analyst with the Royal Institute of International Studies in London. From the beginning, the hostages have been a public relations nightmare for Saddam. The world reacted to the detention of thousands of foreigners at least as harshly as it did to the invasion of Kuwait itself. The way they were labeled ``guests of Iraq'' was ridiculed in the West. So was Saddam's attempt to portray a kindly image by appearing on television ruffling the hair of a frightened looking child. In responding to Saddam's announcement Thursday, President Bush mentioned the world's reaction: ``No single hostage should have been taken in the first place, and I hope ... Saddam understands that his hostage policy has incurred the hostility of the whole world.'' For weeks, Saddam had said he would release everyone in exchange for guarantees against an attack - which he never received. On Nov. 18, he said he would free all the hostages by March 25. The only condition then was if ``nothing mars the atmosphere of peace.'' But that step was followed by U.N. Security Council's approval of the use of force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait if Saddam does not withdraw by Jan. 15. ``I think it increasingly becomes clear that the hostages have been a problem for him,'' Robins said. ``They have not been able to deliver to him what he wanted, which was immunity from attack, or breaking up the international consensus against him. ``I think having failed to achieve that, the hostages have become a burden because they depict him as a tyrant in the West,'' he said. Shahram Chubin of the Graduate Institute for International Studies in Geneva said there seemed to be two main reasons for Saddam's latest move: ``U.S. domestic division on the use of force, weakening the credibility of the Jan. 15 deadline, and that the sanctions are working.'' Allowing more time for the sanctions to work was one of the strongest themes from experts testifying in hearings before the U.S. Senate's Armed Services Committee. Right after sanctions were imposed, Bush himself voiced confidence they would succeed in forcing Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait. But his administration has shifted to the opposite view in recent weeks. The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin Powell, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Secretary of State James A. Baker III have left no doubt that administration policy would not depend on ecomomic sanctions to force Saddam to leave Kuwait. ``As we wait, he will continue manipulating hostages, attempting to break the coalition,'' Baker said. On Tuesday, Democrats in the House of Representatives voted 177-37 for a non-binding resolution that said Bush should not order and attack without prior approval from Congress. ``I think the Iraqis will try to use this to try to find an accommodation, some sort of agreement with the United States,'' Robins said. Saddam's releasing the hostages now puts the United States in the position of having to negotiate seriously when Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz goes to Washington and Baker goes to Baghdad later this month, analysts said. ``The psychological pressure (on Saddam) has been kept up both ways,'' said Don Kerr, a military analyst at the Institute for Strategic Studies in London. First came the U.S. approach for talks, ``followed up by Gen. Powell's indications and indications from Mr. Baker that the United States was prepared to go to war and was prepared to make it sudden, bloody and successful,'' Kerr said. ``I think that this is probably a response by Saddam in the same vein, to throw off balance, to obfuscate,'' Kerr said. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter C. Putnam covers Middle Eastern affairs as an AP correspondent based in Cyprus.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts of Saddam's Letter on Hostages
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following are excerpts of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's letter to his National Assembly on the release of foreign hostages as reported by the official Iraqi News Agency. The excerpts were translated from the Arabic by The Associated Press: --- In the name of God, the merciful, the compassionate, Mr. National Assembly speaker, members. Peace be upon you. In difficult conditions, the strength of the believers' commitment is put to the test. Their action in the service of principles is also put to the test. Iraqis in general, and you amongst them, have proved that on very dark nights, the spark of faith glows much brighter than on ordinary nights. Adherence to the supreme principles governing the relation between man and the creator and his duty toward him, as well as the relation between the Iraqis and other nations, becomes stronger in the more difficult circumstances... On the basis of these principles and what we desire - that the influence of the believers expand, and that the knowledge of mankind in general expand with the believers' principles and the truth of their mission - we deem it necessary that our National Assembly convene to take a final and irrevocable stand toward a humanitarian issue which you and the rest of the world are aware of... National Assembly members, the thing that worries the faithful mujahid, the honorable struggler, and the brave fighter ... most is when the trenches in the battle arena get mixed and when some people, who do not want to fight and who are not among the evildoers, get trapped in the space between the two trenches. This worry becomes deep grief when that kind of people are harmed because of the level and type of the conflict. Some people with no confrontational or evil intentions were caught in the middle. Some of the foreigners who have been prevented from travel fall under that category in the battle between right, led by Iraq's great people and valiant armed forces, and evil, whose failing mass is led by Bush, the enemy of God. As you and my brothers in the leadership know, I recognize that, despite what they had to put up with, denying those people the freedom to travel has rendered a great service to the cause of peace. And, because God has taught us that forbidden things should never be resorted to except in very urgent cases and without any excesses, we must not keep these emergency measures, especially this measure, any longer... For instance, our valiant Iraqi forces had not completed their mobilization in Kuwait to confront a potential military aggression. Any measure that could delay war at the time was appropriate, although it may have not been correct from the humanitarian standpoint, so that we use the opportunity to complete preparations for that possibility. But now our forces, with the blessing and care of the Almighty, are fully prepared to defend our values and principles against the traitors and infidels and also in defense of the great national, regional and humanitarian gains. Gentlemen: good people, men and women of different nationalities and political trends have come to Iraq. Dear brothers from Jordan, Yemen, Palestine, Sudan and the Arab Maghreb have also consulted with us on this issue, as on others. We had suggested a different timing to coincide with Christmas and New Year, the two holy occasions which are of special importance to Christians all over the world, especially in the West. However, the appeal by some Arab brothers, the decision of the Democratic majority in the U.S. Senate, and the European Parliament's invitation to our foreign minister for dialogue; all these have encouraged us to respond to these positive changes - changes that will have a major impact on world public opinion in general, and U.S. public opinion in particular, in restraining the evil ones who are seeking and pushing for war as the option they have chosen out of their evil tendencies and premeditated intentions to do harm. In view of all this, we have found that the reasons for which the foreigners were prevented from travel have diminished and have been replaced by something more powerful - a change in the American public opinion which will impose restrictions on the decisions and intentions of the evil ones, led by Bush, the enemy of God. Therefore, I urge you to take a just decision to end the travel ban imposed on foreigners and to restore to all of them the freedom to travel, apologizing to those who may have been harmed, and seeking forgiveness from God, the Almighty. Brothers, I ask you, and through you I ask the Iraqi people to maintain your alertness and vigil. Iraqi armed forces should maintain the highest degree of alert and vigilance because the forces of aggression remain on our sacred soil in Saudi Arabia, fanning the flames of fire. Bush's call for dialogue is still concealing war intentions and we must be aware not to fall into such traps... God is great, cursed be the infidels and traitors, who gave the oppressors and infidels the opportunity to invade the holy land...''

DOC.HEAD: Failing Economy, Rude Men Create Rush of Soviet Mail-Order Brides
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Galina is tired of Russian men who expect her to do all the cooking and shopping, plus work a full-time job. She has an idea that with an American man, ``things might be a bit more equal.'' So she sent three photographs and an application to Nakhodka, or Godsend, the first ``mail-order bride'' service matching Soviet women with North American men. ``Of course, if I met a very sweet American man, I would be willing to cook and clean for him, too,'' Galina, 36, explained in an interview. ``But at least I would be living in America.'' The lure of love in a land of prosperity has hooked many Soviet women this year. More than 1,500 have paid 50 rubles (about 880) apiece to join Godsend since it was founded eight months ago. The company is part of a new Soviet bride industry that includes an Italian marriage service, an international video introduction firm and half-a-dozen magazines packed with personal ads. Behind the industry are two recent phenomena: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's political reforms, which have made it easier to meet, marry and move abroad with foreigners; and the worsening Soviet economy, which has cut into the quality of many women's lives and set them to dreaming about life in the West. ``Soviet women have a lot more respect for American men than for Soviet men,'' said Sergei Kurochkin, 39, a former computer software designer who founded Godsend last April. ``They say Soviet men are lazy, unfaithful and rude. They want someone who will hold doors open for them.'' Again and again, those sentiments are reflected in the seductive short letters that women who join Godsend write about themselves. ``I'm kind and sensitive and I want to marry a gentleman,'' wrote Maria. ``I want to look after him.'' ``For me, the ideal husband is an American man,'' wrote Galya, 28. ``I would like someone 30-35 years old, intelligent, who ... wants to start a family on the basis of mutual respect, tenderness and love.'' Many letters also brim with frustration over the competing demands of working full-time, shopping and keeping a home. Kurochkin said the choice of most Soviet women is clear: ``They love their homes. They want to be in their kitchens.'' For $25, an American man can receive a packet of a dozen such letters and photographs from a Los Angeles-based agency called American-Russian Matchmaking. After corresponding by mail, the would-be American groom can arrange through Godsend to come to the Soviet Union for 10 days to meet his prospective mate, a trip that costs between $1,500 and $4,000. If he ends up marrying one of the women, the price rises even more: by contract, he's obligated to pay the matchmakers $3,000. Still, there seems to be plenty of interest. After the U.S. Army magazine Stars and Stripes published a picture of some of the women, it got phone calls from U.S. servicemen in Saudi Arabia, asking for the matchmaking firm's address. Kurochkin said he's still working out the bugs in his system. Originally, he offered to link American women with Soviet men, but found little demand and dropped the service. Some Soviet men shake their heads at their American counterparts who change diapers and share household chores. Recently, Kurochkin began requiring Soviet women to say whether they smoke, because bean-sprout-and-whole-wheat types from California were appalled to be matched with chain-smokers. So far, no marriages have resulted from Godsend's efforts. Kurochkin said the first may be in late January or early February, when a Soviet woman plans to fly to the United States to join an American man she met through the agency in November. --- EDITORS: Russian-American Matchmaker address is P.O. Box 1384, Studio City, California 91614.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Chief Raps Treasury Plan to Boost Bank Insurance Fund
DOC.TEXT: The government's top auditor says a Treasury Department idea for increasing the dwindling insuranc fund for bank deposits looks like an accounting gimmick. Charles A. Bowsher, head of the General Accounting Office, told the House Banking Committee on Thursday that requiring banks to purchase preferred stock from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. ``gives us great concern.'' Bowsher's statement came in response to a question from Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the committee, who called the proposal ``highly unusual.'' ``Does this pass the auditor's sniff test?'' Gonzalez asked. ``It worries us,'' Bowsher replied, explaining that the plan allows both the government fund and banks to count the same money as an asset. Currently, banks support the fund by paying deposit insurance premiums, which are treated as an expense and deducted from bank earnings. Under the preferred stock proposal, the insurance fund would get the banks' money - $14 billion to $28 billion over five years - and the banks would get a dividend-earning preferred stock certificate that would count as an asset, rather than as an expense. ``We start to fall into the trap of what I call accounting gimmicks,'' Bowsher said. The problem would arise if the bank fund sinks deeper into trouble. If accountants doubt the FDIC stock could be redeemed at face value, they would probably force banks to write it down and take a loss. In a speech last week, FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman said the preferred stock plan was among three options being studied to shore up the dwindling Bank Insurance Fund. By year end, the fund is expected to have only about $10 billion protecting insured deposits of nearly $2 trillion. One option would be another increase in deposit insurance premiums, on top of the more than 60 percent increase taking effect Jan. 1. Another is a one-time assessment on banks. Both would burden the industry at a time of declining profits. However, critics of the preferred stock plan say it would only postpone recognition of the burden. Bowsher said he was considering telling Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady that the GAO, as auditor of the FDIC, would ``look very closely'' at the preferred stock proposal. Brady has acknowledged the Bank Insurance Fund may need a cash infusion and has pledged that the money will come from the industry, not taxpayers.

DOC.HEAD: Human Blockades By Malaysian Natives Preventing Logging, Says Official
DOC.TEXT: Native groups have formed ``human blockades'' to stop logging on Borneo island, idling hundreds of timber workers since last month, an official says. Logging camps in the Kapit, Ulu Belaga, Baram and Limbang areas of Sarawak state were forced to close, causing substantial losses to timber companies, Lau Hui Kang, chairman of the Sarawak Timber Association, said Thursaday. Some of the nomadic Penans and other natives, who live off the jungle, say logging has prevented them from hunting and finding food. Friends of the Earth and other environmental organizations have sided with the Penans over the past four years. The government of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad claims only 1,000 of the 10,000 Penans are nomadic and they too should settle.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Domestic Demand for Rice Making Up for Export Drop
DOC.TEXT: Domestic use of rice, including large quantities to make beer, is rising enough to take up some of the slack caused by a drop in exports, the Agriculture Department says. Total U.S. production, at an estimated 154.4 million hundredweight, is about the same as last year, although yields dropped sharply in Arkansas and some other areas. All told, the U.S. rice stockpile by the end of the 1990-91 marketing year next summer may be about 23.7 million hundredweight, the smallest in a decade and only a fraction of the carryovers - up to 77.6 million in 1986 - in some previous years. Recent supply-and-demand figures show domestic use and ``residual'' will be around 88.8 million hundredweight in 1990-91, up from 82.4 million last season. Residual includes unreported uses, processing losses and statistical errors. Exports are projected at 73 million hundredweight, compared with 76.8 million in 1989-90 and 85.9 million in 1988-89. The December issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine said world rice production this year is expected to be at a record level. And that is making export competition tougher. ``Iraq, the fourth largest importer in 1989, accounted for 4 percent of global imports,'' the report said. ``Further, Iraq was the largest market for U.S. rice last year, taking about 13 percent of U.S. exports.'' The analysis said the United Nations embargo is expected to reduce Iraq's total rice imports by about 44 percent in 1991. But ``the embargo had a smaller impact on 1990 imports because most of the rice had already been delivered before the embargo was imposed,'' the report added. Rice is grown mostly in six states: Arkansas, California, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri and Texas. Arkansas, with production estimated at 60 million hundredweight, accounts for nearly 40 percent of this year's crop. Martha R. Evans of USDA's economics management staff said rice is grown on about 12,000 farms in the United States and is ``the most expensive of the major commodities to produce on a per-acre basis. It is completely dependent on irrigation and its production is highly mechanized.'' Evans, writing in Farmline magazine, said rice is a major food for more than half the world's people. Rice in the United States was first produced in Appalachia and the Southeast. After the Civil War, however, Louisiana and Texas become more competitive because they had plenty of level, fertile, cheap land and not as many trees. ``Expansion continued into Arkansas and eventually into California, Mississippi and Missouri,'' Evans said. ``Recently, rice production has increased in Florida.'' She noted the increase in rice yields, from an average of 1,144 pounds per acre in 1895 to 3,061 pounds in 1955. This year's harvest is estimated at 5,499 pounds per acre. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Once the goal of breeding new plants was to increase their yields of food and fiber needed for survival of the human species. An Agriculture Department report shows how times have changed. Henry L. Shands of the department's Agricultural Research Service said in the report Thursday that about a hundred times a year agency researchers release new plant varieties that have special traits to let them thrive even if there are viruses, bacteria, fungi, insects, bad weather and poor soils. Shands is the agency's national program leader for research on germplasm - the genetic material in seeds, cuttings and live plants. Even during the 1960s, he said, the primary aim of more than half the new plant strains released by the agency was to boost yields. Not today. ``The research strives to customize a crop to withstand diseases, pests and environmental stresses such as drought, while preserving traits for high yield,'' Shands said. In a five-year period, 1984 to 1989, the USDA research agency made 599 germplasm releases that had improved resistance to some pest or disease. ``These releases consisted of 147 actual plant varieties and 452 germplasm lines - strains of plants with useful traits that breeders can transfer into existing varieties,'' he said. Approximately 80 percent of the releases over the five years had improved disease resistance, 30 percent had improved insect resistance and about 10 percent had improved resistance to nematodes, tiny worms in soil. Some releases contained more than one kind of resistance, which Shands said pushed the total to mcent. The current U.S. germplasm collections include nearly 400,000 plant introductions, cultivars and germplasm releases, he said. The core than 100 perollections are a source of a steady supply of new crop varieties. ``In the United States alone, farmers grow more than 200 varieties of wheat, 85 varieties of cotton, 200 varieties of soybeans and many kinds of fruit, vegetables and ornamental crops,'' Shands said. ``Disease and pest resistance must be bred into each of these varieties, which often thrive only in specific growing areas.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Agriculture Department says farmers who participated in the 1990 wheat, barley and oats program will receive more than $1.7 billion in cash payments. Keith Bjerke, executive vice president of the department's Commodity Credit Corp., said Thursday that the subsidies would be paid by county (AP) - As President Bush nears the end of his South American tour, he is encouraged by the promised release of hostages from Iraq and Kuwait but says this is no time to relax military pressure on Saddam Hussein. After concluding a 24-hour visit to Chile, Bush was heading today for Venezuela, a longtime U.S. friend and major oil producer and the last stop on his five-nation swing to promote democracy and free trade. Bush has praised Venezuela for increasing oil production after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The Venezuelan move has helped to ease inflation in world oil prices. The price of oil has fluctuated wildly since August, rising when Persian Gulf tensions increased and receding when peace prospects seemed to improve. Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Peres has called for talks among consumers and producers to see if a way can be found to stabilize prices. Officials said Venezuela advocates creation of a hemispheric oil reserve for emergencies, but that the United States has so far shown little interest in the idea. In Chile, there was a spate of bombings and anti-Bush demonstrations Thursday, but the overall reception seemed friendly. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater called the welcome ``terrific.'' Bush hailed Chile's return to the democratic fold in March and praised the government for a reform policy that has led to a surge in economic growth. Once again, the gulf crisis intruded on Bush's activities Thursday. He was flying to Chile from Buenos Aires, Argentina, when word came of the prospective release of about 900 American hostages. Fitzwater called the Iraqi announcement ``a hopeful sign.'' Release of the hostages has been a key demand of the United States and the global coalition against Iraq, along with the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait, the restoration of the exiled emir and a guarantee of security in the gulf. But, at a news conference Thursday, Bush said Saddam's show of flexibility will not affect his gulf policy. Bush said Saddam ``must leave Kuwait without reservation, without condition.'' ``We've got to continue to keep the pressure on,'' said Bush, who has authorized the deployment of more than 400,000 Americans to the gulf. The president promised there would not be any secret deal with Saddam to end the gulf crisis. ``There are no secret negotiations, direct or indirect with Iraq over this question,'' he said. ``None. And there will be none.'' Bush's Chilean visit was the first by an American president in 30 years. The welcome was not uniformly friendly. Before Bush arrived, the guerrillas exploded a half-dozen bombs overnight at sites with U.S. ties, including four Mormon chapels, a new McDonald's restaurant and a downtown park outside a hotel where some officials in Bush's advance party were staying. The president's limousine was hit by an egg thrown from the crowd as his motorcade passed through Santiago streets. Police reported no injuries. Police used tear gas and water cannon to scatter scores of university students who staged an anti-Bush protest at a campus in the southern section of the city. The students threw rocks at police and blocked traffic for two hours in front of the campus. They burned at least two U.S. flags and waved several Cuban flags. Later, shortly before Bush's arrival for a dinner at the presidential palace, police dispersed demonstrators who were shouting anti-American slogans. Bush also visited Brazil and Uruguay, and he returns to Washington Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Arrests 7,000 Alleged Drug Smugglers, Addicts
DOC.TEXT: Iran says it has arrested 7,000 drug addicts and smugglers, only days after Amnesty International condemned such arrests and said Iran had killed more than 1,100 alleged drug traffickers in 1989. Tehran radio, monitored in Nicosia, quoted the director of the anti-drugs squads of the Islamic Revolutionary Committees as saying Thursday that 6,247 addicts, and 651 drug smugglers were arrested in the crackdown. The official, identified only as Yabu, said 350 pounds of drugs were confiscated in raids over the past month. He warned that a massive follow-up operation would be launched today to ``wipe out centers where addicts and smugglers congregate.'' Yabu said 715 checkpoints were to be set up to catch traffickers today.
