Iranians generally mock such operations, which are announced in advance. ``If I were a drug smuggler, do you think I would be stupid enough to transport my goods on a day when everybody is out looking for me?'' said an Iranian businessman in Tehran last week. Iran has executed more than 1,500 alleged drug smugglers, and jailed over 70,000 so-called addicts since December 1988, according to official figures. Possession of even small quantities of drugs, with intent to sell, carries a mandatory death sentence under Iran's laws. Iranian opposition groups say the drug-related killings and arrests mask a crackdown on political opponents. Amnesty International, the London-based human rights organization, said in report Tuesday that Iran executed 5,000 political opponents in the past three years. The Amnesty report coincided with a resolution passed by the United Nations Third Committee condemning human rights violations in Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Major to Meet with Bush at Camp David
DOC.TEXT: British Prime Minister John Major will hold a brief visit with President Bush later this month at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Major's office says. Major and his wife, Norma, will travel to Washington on Dec. 21 and spend the night at the retreat outside Washington, D.C. a spokeswoman at 10 Downing Street said Thursday. The Majors return to London on Dec. 22, she said.

DOC.HEAD: New Contraceptive Implant Expected to be Available in February
DOC.TEXT: A new contraceptive is expected to be available in the United States beginning in February, giving women their first major new option in decades, the manufacturer says. Norplant consists of six match stick-size silicone rubber capsules that are implanted in a minor surgical procedure under the skin of a woman's upper arm. For five years, the capsules release a hormone to prevent pregnancy, but they can be removed - and fertility restored - at any time. The Food and Drug Administration is expected to approve the contraceptive within days. ``It offers them a new choice which is long-lasting and convenient, uses the lowest dose of hormone that's used in any (hormone-based method) and it doesn't contain estrogen,'' said C. Wayne Bardin, vice president and director of medical research for the New York-based Population Council. The council began researching the method in 1966. Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories of Philadelphia will market the contraceptive. Norplant has been approved in 16 countries. Half a million people in those countries have used Norplant, according to the council's data. ``It's the most effective, reversible method of contraception,'' with a failure rate of less than 1 percent, said Dr. Samuel A. Pasquale, a principal investigator in the Norplant studies and an associate dean at Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in New Brunswick, N.J. ``Norplant is one of the most significant advances in contraception we've had in the last 30 years,'' since the birth control pill and intrauterine device became available, Pasquale said. The major side effect is menstrual irregularities, including spotting between periods and prolonged periods. This causes about 15 percent of women with the implant to have it removed, Bardin said. Wyeth-Ayerst officials were reluctant to talk about Norplant on Thursday without FDA approval of their product yet. Company spokeswoman Audrey Ashby said that assuming approval comes shortly, the company expects Norplant to be available commercially in February. Wyeth-Ayerst plans to train physicians how to implant the capsules, but ``there will be some lag time,'' she said. ``Obviously not every physician will be trained to do it'' by the time it is available. Ashby said the price of Norplant was being evaluated but she said it ``will be priced significantly below oral contraceptives over five years.'' Birth control pills cost around $15 to $20 per month. Bardin said he had been told the price would be about $200 to $300 for Norplant, which does not include the price of having the implant. The price worries Lisa Kaeser, a policy analyst for the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a research and education group that deals with reproductive health issues. ``I'm not sure it's going to be available for low-income women,'' she said. That will depend largely on Wyeth-Ayerst's price of the contraceptive to family planning clinics. Bardin said Norplant fits the needs of many women but is particularly well-suited to those who have completed their family size but don't want to become sterilized and for women who want to delay pregnancy for a fixed time. It also is a good choice for women who don't want to take estrogen, which is in most birth control pills and is a risk for women with a family history of breast cancer, he said. The capsules are implanted in a minor surgical procedure with local anesthesia. Generally, they are not noticeable. When they are removed, the contraceptive effects are reversed and the woman is as fertile as she was before the implant. It's not clear yet how Norplant will be accepted by American women. The contraceptive is popular in the countries where it has been approved, Bardin said. ``It's a matter of public education, of people recognizing that they can have it taken out when they wish,'' Kaeser said.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators: Other Pilots Were Confused in Same Area as Fatal Collision
DOC.TEXT: Airline pilots told investigators they had become confused while taxiing in the same runway area where two Northwest Airlines jets collided in heavy fog this week, killing eight people. The unidentified pilots, not involved in the fatal collision, volunteered the information in interviews with the National Transportation Safety Board team looking into Monday's crash, head investigator John Lauber said Thursday. Previous confusion among pilots at Detroit Metropolitan Airport was reported ``and not necessarily under low visibility conditions,'' Lauber said at a news conference held before most of the team left Detroit. Investigators used a DC-9 jet Thursday to reconstruct the errant path taken by a Northwest DC-9 through heavy fog onto runway 3-C, where a Northwest Boeing 727 was thundering toward takeoff for Memphis, Tenn. Lauber said reconstructing the events leading up to the crash helped investigators document what the cockpit crew may have seen, including ``all taxiway markings, runway markings, the lights, the signs.'' Eight people were killed and 20 were injured when the Pittsburgh-bound DC-9, carrying 39 passengers and four crew members, apparently made two wrong turns and ended up in the path of the other jet. The 145 passengers and eight crew aboard the Boeing 727 jet escaped injury. Investigators have said poor visibility, inadequate runway lighting and pilot and control-tower error could have contributed to the crash. ``We wouldn't, at this stage, rule out anything,'' Lauber said. About 70 NTSB workers have been conducting interviews and investigations. Remaining investigators hoped to finish field work over the weekend. ``We've gotten to the point where the factual part of this is starting to wind down. Now it's all analyzing the data,'' agency spokesman Brent Bahler said. A final report could take as long as a year to complete. On Wednesday, Milio Rinna, 60, of Allen Park, a passenger on the DC-9, filed a lawsuit against Northwest in Wayne County Circuit Court, the first suit filed against the airline after Monday's crash. Rinna, a health and safety official with the United Steelworkers union, suffered burns and other injuries after using his bare hands to extinguish flames on another passenger, said his lawyer, William L. Martens of Southfield. Martens and Northwest spokesman Bob Gibbons said Rinna's suit probably would be the first of many. ``It seems inconceivable to me, given the number who were injured and the number of deaths, that there will not be other lawsuits,'' Martens said. Gibbons agreed, but declined further comment on legal action. Five passengers remained hospitalized today, listed in conditions ranging from good to serious.

DOC.HEAD: General Strike Protests Law Limiting Strikes
DOC.TEXT: More than a million workers staged a one-day strike to protest an anti-strike law, and the capital was engulfed in one of its worst traffic jams as cars flooded the streets due to the lack of public transport. The strike Thursday by government workers and the country's largest labor group, the General Confederation of Greek Workers, included employees of public transit and utilities. In Athens, a city of 10 million, people fought for taxis and traffic doubled as authorities abandoned an odd-even license plate system that usually limits the number of private cars downtown. The new anti-strike law will allow the state to operate utilities with skeleton staff during walkouts and make it easier to fire strikers. The bill is due to become law on Saturday after passing Wednesday. The governing conservative party holds 152 seats in the 300-member Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Higher
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 23,522.49, or up 969.39 points or 4.30 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Uprising Has Made 42 Percent of Israelis More Hawkish
DOC.TEXT: The Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories has made 42 percent of Israelis more hawkish, but opinion on how to solve the problem is deeply fragmented, according to an opinion poll. The uprising is 3 years old on Saturday. The survey published Thursday said 45 percent had experienced no change of opinion, and only 6 percent had become more dovish. Seven percent had no opinion. The sounding of 1,200 adult Israeli Jews was conducted by the Smith Research Center for the Jerusalem Report, a weekly news magazine. No margin of error was given. On the question of how to solve the conflict, 25 percent favored some sort of statehood for the 1.7 million Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, the poll said. Twenty-one percent wanted to expel all or some of the Palestinians from the occupied territories, and 20 percent thought Israel should withdraw from the Gaza Strip, regarded as the most troublesome occupied area. Only 6 percent of those questioned favored annexing the West Bank, 9 percent opted for preserving the present situation, and 19 pecent had no opinion, it said. ``People are very confused about where to go,'' the Jerusalem Report quoted pollster Hanoch Smith as saying. ``Antagonism toward Arabs is at an all-time high,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: American U. Trustees Rescind $1 Million Offer to Ex-President
DOC.TEXT: American University trustees rescinded their $1 million buyout offer to former President Richard Berendzen, who pleaded guilty to making obscene telephone calls, and will allow him to return to campus as a faculty member. Board Chairman Edward Carr said all 27 trustees present at a special meeting Thursday agreed to withdraw the initial settlement offer. He said the board supports the alternative agreement spearheaded by interim President Milton Greenberg in consultation with faculty committees and agreed to by Berendzen. ``I hope today's events will allow us to put the turmoil of the past month behind us,'' said Carr. Carr met with reporters after the two-hour trustees meeting during which student, faculty and staff groups voiced strong opposition to the initial settlement. The school's alumni association called for Berendzen to sever all ties with the university. Berendzen, 51, resigned as president abruptly last April, citing fatigue. The next month, he pleaded guilty to two misdemeanor charges of making obscene telephone calls from his university office to a woman living in a Virginia suburb of Washington. He was sentenced to two 30-day jail terms, which were suspended provided he stays out of trouble for one year and continues psychological treatment. Although Carr declined to discuss specifics, the initial offer reportedly would have reached $1 million and included more than $600,000 in appreciation for Berendzen's contributions in raising the university's image and prestige. Under the alternative agreement, Berendzen will be on administrative leave with pay at his faculty salary, for the 1990-91 academic year and the fall 1991 semester. The salary will be in the range of $70,000, officials said. Berendzen, who throughout the ordeal had continued to draw his annual salary of about $140,000 since resigning as president in April, will return in the spring of 1992 as a full professor of physics. In rescinding the offer, Carr said the action does not affect severance payments to Berendzen provided for in his presidential contract. He estimated the amount at slightly less than $400,000. Testifying before the board, alumni association president Gayle Abbott said her group felt strongly ``that the best interests of American University mandate that AU sever all ties with Dr. Berendzen as expeditiously as possible.''

DOC.HEAD: Unification Brings More Traffic Deaths, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Germany is paying a price for unification in increased traffic casualties, with the number of fatal accidents nearly doubling in former East Germany, the federal statistics office says. Traffic deaths in Germany's five new eastern states and former East Berlin are expected to reach 3,330 for the year, compared to 1,784 in 1989, a statistics office news release said Thursday. Since the opening of German borders and the fall of the Berlin Wall last fall, many eastern Germans have switched from two-stroke Trabant cars to powerful Western models that can exceed 100 miles an hour. The Western cars and inexperienced drivers on crumbling roads have proven to be a deadly combination, according to news reports. Traffic deaths for the western two-thirds of the newly united nation are expected to increase by only 1.3 percent this year, or 100 over last year's 8,000 fatalities, the statistics office said.

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners Still in Iraq and Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Here is the latest breakdown of the number of foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait. ---= AUSTRALIA - Before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait there were 127 Australians in the two countries. There are now 26 in Iraq and 50 in Kuwait, including diplomats. ---= AUSTRIA - Before the invasion there were 70 Austrians in Iraq and the same number in Iraq. One remains in Kuwait and three or four in Iraq, all of Arab background. ---= BANGLADESH - About 110,000 Bangladeshis were in Kuwait and Iraq when the invasion occurred. About 15,000 remain, including 2,000 reported to be working as ``forced labor'' at Iraqi military camps in Kuwait. ---= BELGIUM - Before the crisis there were 38 Belgians in Iraq and 21 in Kuwait. Five remain in Kuwait. ---= BULGARIA - There were more than 690 Bulgarians in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion. The Iraqi parliament voted Nov. 3 to allow all to leave. By Nov. 29, 370 had left. The others had been expected to leave in early December. ---= BRAZIL - There were 450 Brazilians in Iraq and Kuwait at the time of the invasion. About 40 remain in Iraq and Kuwait because they are married to citizens of those nations. ---= BRITAIN - Before the invasion there were about 3,000 Britons in Kuwait and 1,000 in Iraq. There are now 590 in Kuwait, most of them in hiding, and about 720 in Iraq. About 350 are held as human shields in Iraq and 60 in Kuwait. ---= CANADA - Of the 600 Canadians in Kuwait and 200 in Iraq before the invasion, 11 remain in Kuwait and 31 in Iraq. ---= China - There were about 10,000 Chinese in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. About 4,800 Chinese remain. About 150 citizens of Hong Kong and Taiwan have been evacuated from Kuwait and Iraq. ---= CYPRUS - There were 35 Cypriots in Iraq and Kuwait before Aug. 2. Twenty remain voluntarily. ---= CZECHOSLOVAKIA - Of the 470 Czechs in Iraq and Kuwait Aug. 2, only six women married to Kuwaitis remain in Kuwait. Around 40 remain in Iraq. ---= DENMARK - Sixteen Danes remain in Iraq out of a pre-invasion total of 100. ---= EGYPT - About 363,000 Egyptians have left Iraq and Kuwait, out of more than 1.3 million inIIraq and 300,000 in Kuwait before the invasion. ---= FINLAND - There were 23 Finns in Iraq and 23 in Kuwait before Aug. 2. Three, including diplomats, remain in Iraq and two remain in Kuwait voluntarily. ---= FRANCE - Before the invasion, there were 270 French citizens in Kuwait and 290 in Iraq. Most have been allowed to leave. On Oct. 29, Saddam allowed 257 to go, including 67 who had been held as human shields. ---= GERMANY - Of the pre-invasion total of 1,000 in Iraq and Kuwait, about 15 remain in Iraq voluntarily. There are none in Kuwait. ---= GREECE - All 127 Greeks in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion have been allowed to leave, except two embassy personnel and one man who is said to have a U.S. passport. ---= HUNGARY - There were 178 Hungarians in Kuwait and Iraq before Aug. 2. Now, 32 remain in Iraq and none in Kuwait. ---= INDIA - There were about 170,000 Indians in Kuwait and 20,000 in Iraq before the invasion. Between 16,000 and 18,000 remain in Kuwait and 6,000 in Iraq. ---= IRELAND - Of the 380 Irish citizens in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion. There are now about 130 in Iraq and 34 in Kuwait. Twelve have been told they can leave. ---= ITALY - Before the invasion there were 160 Italians in Kuwait and 380 in Iraq. About 200 remain in Iraq. There are six with dual nationality in Kuwait who do not want to leave. ---= JAPAN - About 790 Japanese were in Kuwait and Iraq at the time of the invasion and more than 200 are still in Iraq - with an estimated 78 as human shields - and eight in Kuwait. ---= LEBANON - Of the estimated 50,000 Lebanese in pre-invasion Kuwait, about 5,000 have left. None of the aproximately 10,000 in Iraq are reported to have left. ---= NETHERLANDS - There were 200 Dutch nationals in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion, and 150 remain. More than 100 were working on dredging project in southern Iraq. Baghdad said Nov. 17 that they were free to leave, but none has so far been allowed to go. ---= NEW ZEALAND - Nine New Zealanders remain in Iraq and Kuwait out of a combined pre-invasion total of 36. ---= NORWAY - One Norwegian remains in Kuwait and five in Iraq, out of a pre-invasion total of 46. All have been told they can leave. ---= PAKISTAN - About 130,000 Pakistanis were in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion, and 90,000 remain. ---= PHILIPPINES - About 90,000 Filipinos were in Kuwait and 3,000 in Iraq before the invasion. Some 2,300 remain in Iraq, with an estimated 3,500 in Kuwait. Some 430 were scheduled to be flown home soon. --- POLAND - There were 3,300 Poles in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. Now there are now 473 in Iraq, mainly workers fulfilling industrial project contracts, with 90 refused exit visas. Four remain in Kuwait voluntarily. --- PORTUGAL - More than 40 Portuguese have left Kuwait and Iraq, mostly stonemasons who had been working on Saddam Hussein's new palace in Baghdad, leaving about eight in Iraq. --- ROMANIA - There were 3,055 Romanians in Iraq before the invasion. Three hundred remain and Iraq has said they can leave. --- SOUTH KOREA - Some 1,327 South Koreans were in Kuwait and Iraq; 140 remain in Iraq and nine in Kuwait. --- SOVIET UNION - Nearly 10,000 Soviets were in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. There are now around 3,232 in Iraq, mostly oil workers and construction specialists and some 40 military advisers. There are none in Kuwait. Iraq said Dec. 4 that all could leave after Moscow threatened to send troops to the gulf. --- SPAIN - There were 183 Spaniards in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. Six diplomats remain in Baghdad. --- SRI LANKA - About 150,000 Sri Lankans were in Kuwait and Iraq. Some 65,000 remain in Kuwait, including 20,000 women. There are 125 Sri Lankans in Iraq. ---= SWEDEN - Out of a pre-invasion total of about 200, five remain. --- SWITZERLAND - Before the invasion, there were 97 Swiss nationals in Kuwait and 71 in Iraq. None remain in Kuwait, with eight in Iraq. --- THAILAND - There were 7,000 Thais in Kuwait and some 1,150 in Iraq before Aug. 2, with 300 still in Iraq and 20 in Kuwait. --- TURKEY - There were 3,000 Turks in Iraq and 1,000 in Kuwait at the beginning of the gulf crisis. Most have returned home, leaving about 60 in Iraq and about 40 in Kuwait, mostly women married to Kuwaitis. --- UNITED STATES - Of the pre-invasion total of about 3,500 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait, 600 remain in hiding or are held in Kuwait and 305 in Iraq, including an estimated 88 men held as human shields. --- VENEZUELA - There were 38 Venezuelans in Kuwait and Iraq Aug. 2. Twenty-eight remain. --- VIETNAM - There were about 15,000 Vietnamese in Iraq before the invasion. Around 1,000 have left and the others are trying to leave. There are no figures available for Kuwait. --- YUGOSLAVIA - There were 9,000 Yugoslavs in Iraq and about 1,000 in Kuwait Aug. 2. Some 300 remain in Iraq and about 10 in Kuwait, most of them married to Kuwaitis.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Tape Transcripts Show Codes, Political Interest
With PM-Noriega Tapes-Excerpts
DOC.TEXT: Some of Manuel Noriega's taped prison conversations were in code, including passages in which the deposed Panamanian dictator apparently discussed frozen funds, court transcripts show. Many of the conversations included in transcripts released by a federal judge Thursday dealt with family affairs, but some apparently involved money transfers and others showed Noriega followed Panamanian politics after he was ousted during a U.S. invasion in December 1989. Among the apparently coded calls was one by Noriega to the Cuban Embassy in Panama. The government tapes, some of which were broadcast by CNN last month, triggered a battle pitting freedom of the press against Noriega's right to a fair trial. After first ordering CNN to halt the broadcasts, U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler ruled last week that the tapes were harmless to Noriega's defense, and allowed the network to resume the broadcasts. This week, the judge agreed to a request by media organizations to release court transcripts of the tapes, over the objections of CNN. The network dropped its objections Wednesday. In one transcript, Norma Amado, mother of Noriega's mistress, talked in apparent code with him about why ``the man'' had not arrived. The conversation appeared to be about frozen funds. Amado said the man would go elsewhere because ``it's not frozen there ... since we are all frozen here and over there it wouldn't be a problem.'' She also discussed the need for ``a good towel ... and the important thing is it shouldn't be a hand (towel.)'' CNN has said that conversation also included coded discussions about the transfer of $4 million. In a call to the Cuban Embassy, Noriega said he would send a facsimile transmission ``so you can grab it and pass it on to the grandfather.'' Another transcript had Noriega urging an unidentified man to encourage opposition to the new Panamanian government. ``We must explain ... that one must unite, that there are people with ambition that are now going to take over the party,'' he said. The transcripts included five tapes, most containing several conversations. In one previously telecast conversation, Noriega speculated about two potential government witnesses with his lawyer's secretary, who was translating for a defense investigator. That conversation triggered the original objection by Noriega's attorneys, who said broadcastingit would violate lawyer-client privilege and hurt his chances of getting a fair trial. The transcripts showed that Noriega was commenting on an article in El Nuevo Herald, the Spanish-language edition of The Miami Herald, about the arrest of the two men, Alfredo Sanchez and Felipe Camargo. The news organizations that went to court for the transcripts were The Miami Herald, The Associated Press, Post-Newsweek station WPLG-TV of Miami and Gannett Co. Inc. and USA Today, which Gannett owns. They argued that the public has a right to examine the content of tapes that ignite a free-speech controversy. Noriega's defense team claims the Panamanian government gave the tapes to CNN after receiving them from the U.S. government. Taping prisoners telephone callsis legal. Noriega is awaiting trial on drug trafficking charges the he took $4.6 million in payoffs to protect the cocaine trade passing through Panama from Colombia to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Survivor Says She Saw The Jet Coming Slowly
By PIERO VALSECCHI
DOC.TEXT: In a nearby classrom some students were singing Christmas carols while Federica Tacconi took notes about some homework at the end of a German lesson. ``Looking through the window I suddenly saw it coming. It was coming slowly, silently, as if it was pushed by the wind, its wings tilting. ... I was paralyzed by dread. I heard someone screaming, then a rumble and the wall collapsed,'' she recalled in tears. Federica, 16, was one of the four Italian students of a class of 16 who survived the crash of a flaming military jet into a classroom in a suburban high school Thursday. Pulled free from the wreckage of a wing, she suffered a crushed pelvis and burns but was not in danger of life, doctors at Bologna Maggiore hospital said. Twelve of her classmates were killed instantly when the pilotless jet plowed into a high school at Casalecchio, three miles outside Bologna. The engine had caught fire, forcing the pilot to bail out. At the time of the crash, 285 students, 28 teachers and four monitors were at the Gaetano Salvemini vocational high school, authorities said. The teacher who had just completed a German lesson was hospitalized in nearby Parma with critical burn injuries. In nearby classrooms panic spread because of the flames and heavy smoke but many did not immediately realize what had happened. ``It's an earthquake, some of my friends shouted. I thought of a bomb, or the explosion of a heating boiler. I could not believe it had been a jet,'' said Federico Bonanni, 18, who reached the ground safely, from a third floor classroom, on ladders quickly brought by firefighters. Many survivors panicked and jumped from the windows before arrival of firemen, a few minutes after the accident. In total those injured were 87, including a firefighter and the jet pilot, who bailed out shortly before the crash. The prosecutor's office and a military commission are investigating the crash. The cause of the engine fire was not immediately known. Gen. Carlo Brandini said the plane was on a mission to test the effectiveness of an anti-aircraft radar system and had taken off from Villafranca military airport near Verona, 55 miles north of Bologna. He said the MB-326 Aermacchi was flying at about 280 mph when trouble developed in its single engine, which then burst into flames. Italian Air Force officers said the pilot, 2nd Lt. Bruno Viviani, stuck to the emergency procedure as he tried to land his stricken craft into the fields after unloading most of the fuel. But the fire forced Viviani to bail out, paramilitary officers reported. Several eyewitnesses saw the military jet, painted in bright orange, coming down slowly in flames and hit the three-story school after grazing a five-floor condominium complex. Officers reported that the pilot was not immediately told of the high death toll claimed by the crash. Federica also did not know that 12 of her classmates were killed. ``I hope Carmen and Laura managed to jump from the window, or flee through the corridor,'' she said. Carmen Schrinzi and Laura Corazza, both 16, were listed among the known victims.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Stock Prices Rally
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the Japanese yen Friday, while share prices rose sharply. The dollar closed at 132.17 yen, down 1.88 yen from Thursday's close at 134.05 yen. After opening at 132.58 yen, it ranged between 132.10 yen and 132.80 yen. On the stock exchange, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues ended at 23,522.49 points, up 969.39 points or 4.30 percent from Thursday's finish at 22,553.10 points. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.02 points as of 3 p.m. (1 a.m. EST) from Thursday's close of 86.68.Their yield fell to 7.270 percent from 7.345 percent. News of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's announcement Thursday that he will free all foreign hostages by Christmas brought the dollar down and sent share prices higher, traders said. Market players sold the dollar as prospects for war dimmed with the report. The U.S. currency is regarded as a safe investment in times of international tension, while the possibility of a peaceful resolution of the gulf crisis tends to strengthen the yen because of Japan's near-total dependence on oil imports. Currency dealers said the dollar's fall followed its overnight decline in New York to 132.14 yen. But additional news confirming the United States' firm demands for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait made nervous market players buy back the dollar, said a dealer at Sumitomo Bank, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, said the U.S. currency was oversold earlier. ``I think the dollar will regain strength now that market-affecting news has come out,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Liz Taylor Keeps Control of `Passion' Perfume in Out-of-Court Settlement
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: The courtroom stink over Elizabeth Taylor's Passion perfume evaporated when the legendary actress reached an agreement with her former boyfriend. Miss Taylor retains control of the Passion perfume line, which has earned $70 million, under terms of the agreement announced Thursday. Her ex-boyfriend Henry Wynberg will drop a lawsuit against the actress in which he claimed he developed the fragrance, and Miss Taylor will drop a countersuit against Wynberg. ``It means I'm vindicated and it proves the perfume, Passion, is something I worked a year and a half for,'' Miss Taylor said after Superior Court Judge Coleman Swart announced the settlement. Both sides will pay their own legal fees and no money will change hands, said Miss Taylor's attorney, Neil Papiano. Swart said the settlement was made ``with prejudice,'' meaning neither Wynberg or Miss Taylor can raise the issue again. Wynberg and his attorney, Quentin Kopp, refused to confirm that Wynberg won't get any money. In his lawsuit, he asked for nearly three-quarters of Passion's profits. The settlement was reached during jury selection for a trial that had promised to be embarrassing to both sides. Attorneys for Wynberg, a former used car salesman who was Miss Taylor's boyfriend between her two marriages to actor Richard Burton in the 1970s, said they would bring up the Academy Award-winning actress' highly publicized bouts with alcohol and obesity. Miss Taylor's attorneys said they would bring up Wynberg's guilty pleas to charges of statutory rape, providing underage girls with drugs in return for sex and taking pornographic photos of young girls. Miss Taylor acknowledged she was glad to avoid the trial. ``It's not something I was looking forward to, but I was willing to fight as long as I had to,'' she said. Jury selection was highlighted Thursday by a prospective juror's statement that he had seen most of Miss Taylor's silent films, which brought laughter from the actress and others in the packed courtroom. Miss Taylor, 58, wasn't born until after the silent movie era ended. Her more than 50 films include ``National Velvet,'' ``Who's Afriad of Virginia Woolf?,'' ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' and ``Butterfield 8,'' for which she won an Academy Award as best actress. Wynberg claimed he was the creator of Passion, and said Miss Taylor breached a contract with him to develop the popular fragrance. The pair signed an agreement in Burton's presence in 1975 for Wynberg to market cosmetics under Miss Taylor's name. But the actress said Wynberg breached the contract by not following through and developing a product.

DOC.HEAD: Cat Chews Baby's Fingers Off
DOC.TEXT: A cat chewed two fingers off a 2-month-old infant girl's hand and authorities are considering whether to charge a baby sitter with child neglect. Sara Elizabeth Culler's fingers were retrieved from the cat's stomach Tuesday, but they were too badly damaged to reattach, said the girl's father, Tom Culler. ``She's a good baby,'' Culler said. ``When she cries, you know something's wrong. The question is where was the baby sitter? From the damage done, it is obvious that cat was working on her for a while.'' The baby sitter, whose name was withheld pending any formal charges, operated a day care center from her home in Pittsfield Township. The license for the child care operation lapsed in September. ``Chances are I'm going to send it back ... to investigators, for further investigation,'' Washtenaw County assistant prosecutor David Lady said Wednesday. ``No decision will be made in the immediate future.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Noriega Aide Pleads Guilty, Ties Ousted Dictator to Drug Cash
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government gained a key ally in its prosecution of Manuel Noriega when a former aide admitted delivering drug money to the deposed Panamanian dictator and agreed to testify against his former boss. ``The admission is significant,'' U.S. attorney's office spokeswoman Diane Cossin said Thursday. ``The defense attorney has asserted that his client is very knowledgeable.'' Luis del Cid, 47, a lieutenant colonel under Noriega, admitted Thursday that he was a ``liaison, courier and emissary for Manuel Antonio Noriega in his transactions with drug traffickers.'' He had faced a possible 70-year prison term if convicted on four racketeering counts. In exchange for the guilty plea to one count, the government dropped the other three and recommended a 10-year sentence. Prosecutors said they would consider reducing that to three years if del Cid cooperates fully. That could mean he would leave prison by early 1992, defense attorney Sam Burstyn said. The plea bargain boosted the government's drug case against Noriega after months of disputes over frozen bank accounts, attorneys fees and leaked tapes of Noriega's prison phone calls. Prosecutors said del Cid gave Noriega $100,000 in cash from drug pilot and star prosecution witness Floyd Carlton Caceres in November 1982. Del Cid received an envelope with $150,000 cash from Carlton in 1983, and also picked up a suitcase stuffed with cash - both of which were delivered to Noriega. ``Yes I transported the money, but, well, I am repentant at having done so,'' del Cid told U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler. ``What I was doing was following orders of a superior officer.'' Plea negotiations had stalled in March because del Cid feared he would be sent back to Panama for criminal prosecution after pleading guilty in the United States. Burstyn said the agreement eliminated that problem: ``He will never be sent anywhere that he does not want to go.'' Del Cid will testify against Noriega, his lawyer said. He could back up testimony by Carlton, who served 4{ years in prison and is now under federal protection, and of Panamanian businessman Enrique ``Kiki'' Pretelt, who has pleaded guilty in a parallel Tampa marijuana case against Noriega. Noriega is accused of taking $4.6 million in bribes to ship cocaine through Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Study Reveals That Straying Blackbird Males Father Many Chicks
DOC.TEXT: Redwing blackbirds form bonded pairs withing a defended territory, but neither partner appears to care much about remaining faithful, a researcher says. Genetic tests show that up to a third of all redwing blackbird chicks are fathered by lusty males that cuckold their neighbors. ``It's clear that there is mating outside of the socially bonded pairs,'' said H. Lisle Gibbs, a biologist at Queen's University in Ontario, Canada. But just which bird is untrue - the male or the female - is still not clear, he said Thursday. Whatever the case, Gibbs said, genetic tests run on blood samples taken from 36 redwing blackbird families in a Canadian marsh showed that about a third of all chicks were fathered by males that lived in neighboring territories. In effect, a male often is defending a nest that contains another bird's offspring. A report on the study was to be published Friday in the journal Science. Gibbs said earlier studies of blackbirds tried to determine reproductive success by counting the number of chicks in nests within a territory defended by a specific male. ``Our work shows that is clearly an inaccurate measure of success'' because so many of the chicks are actually fathered by males from other territories, he said. Redwing blackbirds spend virtually all spring and summer trying to assure their personal success at reproduction. Males, Gibbs said, stake out a territory in March or April and spend the rest of the season defending it. ``To get any mating success, a male redwing has to hold a piece of turf,'' he said. ``They will spend days fighting, defending their territory. There is a long period of conflict even before the females show up.'' When the females do arrive, ``the males put on quite a show trying to attract the ladies,'' Gibbs said. A male is successful when one or more females chooses to build a nest in his territory. The pair mate and, except for a little home defense, the male's job is over. Over the course of a season, a successful male may lure up to five females to nest in his territory. He will defend each nest but won't help raise any of the chicks. ``It's not like other monogamous species where both act to feed the young,'' Gibbs said. ``That's the difference in this mating system.'' Biologists believe males in many species are driven to have as many offspring as possible and, often, to defend their mates from reproductive success of other males. But among the redwing blackbird, Gibbs said, ``there's a definite conflict between the sexes'' because such a high percentage of the young are fathered by outside males. ``The key question is whether females are going out and seeking other males, or are males going out and coercing females,'' he said. ``It could be a combination of both. But who's running the show - the males or the females?'' Though the answer must await more research, Gibbs noted: ``If I had to guess, I would say it's the females.'' Gibbs' team of researchers in the study included Peter T. Boag, Lisa M. Tabak and Bradley N. White, all of Queen's University, and P.J. Weatherhead and Drew J. Hoysak of Carleton University in Ottawa. Science is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Group Pushing for Apology on Pearl Harbor Anniversary
With PM-Pearl Harbor Book, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 50 years after Japanese planes bombed Pearl Harbor, some Japanese are trying to persuade their government to apologize for the attack. Atsuyuki Sassa, a former government official, said Thursday he hoped Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu would make a statement today, the 49th anniversary of the attack that drew the United States into World War II. With that possibility dimming, ``I am trying my best to get him to make a comment on Jan. 1. We must do something before (President) Bush's visit in the spring,'' said Sassa, who has worked in the prime minister's office. Kenichi Takemura, a social commentator, called for a ``mutual forgiveness week'' for the two countries in an interview with the newspaper Sankei Seiron earlier this year. The paper quoted him as saying U.S.-Japan relations are bad enough because of economic frictions, and could worsen next year if the Pearl Harbor anniversary brings more bad feelings. Japan has apologized to South Korea and China for its military actions in the 1930s and 1940s. No official apology has been issued to the United States. A Foreign Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he was not aware of any effort to promote an apology. Sassa said he is part of an informal group of about 30 government officials, diplomats and journalists who meet every month to discuss a ``national grand design of Japan.'' Sassa said other members of the group are cautious about voicing their views for fear of retaliation by right-wingers, who have staged violent attacks against critics of Japan's role in the war. Sassa said the apology idea occurred to him in 1985, when Richard von Weizsacker, president of then-West Germany, included an apology for World War II in a speech on the 40th anniversary of the Nazis' surrender. ``Japanese are afflicted with collective amnesia about the war, but those who suffered at our hands cannot forget,'' Sassa wrote in an article that appeared in the Yomiuri Shimbun, the most widely circulated Japanese newspaper, in September. Richard Armitage, former assistant secretary of defense, said in a speech in Tokyo last month that Bush and Kaifu should make reciprocal apologetic gestures. He said Kaifu should place a wreath on a memorial to the dead at Pearl Harbor and Bush should pay homage to those who died after the United States dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima Aug. 6, 1945. Japan surrendered six days later.

DOC.HEAD: Lung Cancer Rates Keep Rising Faster Among Women
DOC.TEXT: The death rate from lung cancer keeps increasing the fastest among American women, but more men still die from the disease. The national Centers for Disease Control said Thursday that lung cancer incidence and death rates for 1987 continued a pattern of increasing steadily for women, while fluctuating or holding steady for men. The national lung cancer death rate rose slightly from 1980 to 1987, from 42.5 per 100,000 people to 47.9. The death rate for men rose by less than 5 deaths per 100,000 people, from 71.6 to 75.0, while the rate for women increased by more than a third, from 20.9 per 100,000 in 1980 to 28.2 in 1987, the CDC said. The Atlanta-based federal health agency also concluded that the increase among women would continue into the next century. Lung cancer incidence nationwide increased from a rate of 52.4 per 100,000 people in 1980 to 55.5 in 1986 - the latest year available - and increased faster for women than for men. Previous studies have said the increasing lung cancer death rate among women may stem from their reduced willingness to quit smoking, as compared to men. But researchers aren't sure that is the only reason. ``I don't think it's fully understood why you have some more rapid growing cancers for some people, and not for others,''said Dr. Ronald Aubert, a CDC epidemiologist. CDC researchers estimate 85 percent of lung cancer cases are caused by smoking, not counting cases caused by secondhand smoke, Aubert said. The statistics ``are consistent with historically increasing trends in smoking,'' the Atlanta-based CDC reported. Researchers said that because peaks in smoking are historically followed by peaks in lung cancer as much as 35 years later, the rate among women will likely increase for decades. ``Based on these trends, the increases ... for females are not expected to plateau until after the year 2013,'' the CDC said. In general, lung cancer death rates in the 1980s have been higher for black men than for white men, but did not differ significantly between white and black women. Surveys have shown that black men are more likely to smoke, and to smoke cigarettes higher in tar and nicotine, the CDC said.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Panel Calls for More Research on Female Biology
DOC.TEXT: Treatment of breast cancer and other women's diseases is still hindered by ignorance about female biology, two researchers say. ``There's no research on the normal breast,'' said Dr. Susan Love, an author and professor of surgery at Harvard. ``Therefore, we don't have a clue when carcinogens are acting.'' Yet breast cancer will strike one woman in 10 in her lifetime, and will kill 44,000 this year, she said. ``It is appalling that in 1990 we have little or no information on the natural course of the endocrine and tissue changes that occur during menopause,'' said Barbara Sherwin of McGill University. The two medical experts were among more than 100 physicians and other scientists who gathered for a symposium on ``Forging a Women's Health Research Agenda.'' They spoke Thursday. Although panelists looked specifically at breast cancer, menopause, cardiovascular disease and clinical pharmacology, there were many common threads and a common set of recommendations. A key recommendation was that medical professionals consider closely but also look beyond the biological factors unique to women - such as the menstrual cycle, pregnancy and hormonal differences. They said professionals also need to gather data on individual patients' social and economic status as risk factors - poverty, raising children alone - and on ``psychosocial'' factors such as depression, occupational stress and the multiple demands on women as mothers, workers and spouses.
DOC.HEAD: Woman Given 20-Year Sentence in Capitol Bombing
DOC.TEXT: One of two women described by a prosecutor as terrorists has been handed a 20-year prison sentence for bombing the U.S. Capitol and conspiring to set off seven other explosions. Laura Whitehorn, 45, was ordered jailed along with co-defendant Linda Sue Evans. For her role in the conspiracy, Evans, 43, was sentenced to five years after completing a 35-year sentence she is already serving for illegally buying firearms. The two women, who pleaded guilty in a plea bargain Sept. 7, were sentenced by U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene at a proceeding punctuated by the cheers and applause of supporters who packed the courtroom. ``You have committed acts of violence which are not excused by good purposes or political purposes,'' Greene said. ``The effect of these kinds of violence are just as devastating to the victims and to society at large as if they were motivated by greed.'' ``The defendants Linda Evans and Laura Whitehorn are terrorists,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Margaret Ellen told the judge. ``They are people who by their actions have souht to coerce others by means of threats or violence.'' The Nov. 7, 1983 bomb blast that blew a hole in the wall outside the Senate chamber and the explosions at seven other locations in Washington and New York City ``were not symbolic gestures; they were distinct acts of terrorism,'' Ellen said. ``Only chance prevented serious harm'' to people, she said. Whitehorn received the maximum term for each of three charges to which she pleaded guilty: conspiracy, malicious destruction of government property and possession of equipment to make false documents. In sentencing Evans, Greene said he was taking into account the fact that she was already serving a 35-year prison term.
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official Accuses Japan of Hoarding Oil
DOC.TEXT: Japan has hoarded crude oil in the months following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, despite agreement among most consuming nations to draw down stockpiles and ease supply problems, a senior Energy Department official claims. The matter will likely be raised next week at a meeting of the governing board of the International Energy Agency said Linda Stuntz, an Energy Department deputy under secretary for policy and planning. The Paris-based agency is responsible for coordinating responses by oil consuming nations in an oil supply emergency. ``If everybody in the world did what Japan is doing we would have a much more serious problem than we do. Prices would be a lot higher,'' said Ms. Stuntz in remarks to a group of reporters. She later said in an interview that she did not want to overstate the concern, but added that Japan's actions raise questions about the success of future cooperative activities among consuming nations in response to oil supply shocks. Ms. Stuntz said that in the months after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last August, U.S. oil companies and most companies in Europe drew down crude oil stocks in order to keep supplies adequate without having to dramatically increase imports. But, she said, the Japanese, rather than drawing down crude oil stocks after the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil, elected instead to continue importing at high levels and, in fact, increased imports to meet additional demand.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Weakened, Stocks Up in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's surprise announcement that all foreigners can go home helped weaken the dollar today in Tokyo and sent share prices up, traders said. The dollar closed at 132.17 yen, down 1.88 yen from Thursday's close at 134.05 yen. After opening at 132.58 yen, it ranged from 132.10 yen to 132.80 yen. The day's spot trading totaled some $9.33 billion, compared with $8.68 billion the previous day. Market players sold dollars as the news of the hostage release dimmed prospects of military action in the Middle East, said Ikuo Ikenaga, a dealer at the Security Pacific National Bank. In recent weeks, the dollar has tended to rise over speculation of increasing international tensions as investors seek a safe-haven currency. On the other hand, the likelihood of a peaceful solution in the gulf is favorable for the yen because of Japan's almost total dependence on oil imports. Dealers said subsequent technical adjustments prevented a drastic decline of the dollar. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average ended at 23,522.49 points, up 969.39 points or 4.30 percent from Thursday's finish at 22,553.10 points. Brokers said optimism about peace in the Middle East was the biggest market-affecting factor on an active trading day. Volume on the first section totaled 570 million shares. ``This is big news because no one had been buying, but there was buying today,'' said Masahiro Umemori, a researcher at Nomura Securities Co. He said the timing of the news was good because it came when everyone was pessimistic and lethargic, and share prices were heading toward hitting bottom. If it had come when the market was rallying, the news would not have had the same impact, he added. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.31 points from Thursday's close of 86.68. Their yield fell to 7.210 percent from 7.345 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Lightning Detectors to Protect Jetliners from Volcanic Ash Clouds
DOC.TEXT: Lightning detectors will be used to track ash clouds spewed by Alaskan volcanos, allowing jetliners to bypass the clouds and avoid clogged engines, which nearly caused an airline disaster last year. ``The lightning-detection system will help us warn the airline industry so they can divert airplanes and prevent crashes,'' said Tom Miller, scientist-in-charge of the U.S. Geological Survey's Alaska Volcano Observatory. Volcanic ash plumes generate lightning bolts. Scientists don't know why, but it means lightning detectors can be used to find and track ash clouds from Redoubt Volcano and others in Alaska. ``That's useful information at a volcano you can't see most of the time because of bad weather and short winter days,'' said Rick Hoblitt, the USGS Cascades Volcano Observatory volcanologist who dreamed up the idea of using the detectors to protect jetliners. The new $100,000 system of sensors will be installed in February to protect heavy traffic at Anchorage International Airport, Geological Survey researchers said Thursday at the American Geophysical Union's fall meeting. The detection system consists of direction-finding antennas and radio receivers that sense radio signals from lightning, and a central computer that uses the information to pinpoint the lightning. The sensors will be installed at Palmer, Homer, Lake Iliamna and Squentna, Alaska, not at the Anchorage airport itself. Even in good weather, the pilot of a KLM Boeing 747-400 jumbo jet failed to detect an ash cloud from Redoubt Volcano last Dec. 15, a day after the 10,197-foot volcano started erupting for the first time since 1968. The plane, traveling from Amsterdam to Tokyo via Anchorage, flew into the cloud and all four engines stalled. For nine terrifying minutes, the plane and its 245 passengers and crew members plunged in a powerless glide from 28,000 feet to 13,000 feet. The engines were restarted just in time to prevent the jet from hitting 11,000-foot-tall mountains in the area. Redoubt, 110 miles southwest of Anchorage, repeatedly spewed ash up to 40,000 feet since last December. A snow-covered lava dome in its summit crater threatens to trigger steam eruptions and send more ash skyward any time, Miller said. After the KLM jet's near-crash, a Boeing 727 and two 737s also flew into Redoubt's ash clouds and sustained minor damage last December and February. Three jumbo jets had close calls similar to the KLM incident when they flew into ash clouds from Indonesian volcanos during the 1980s. Thunderstorms are rare around Anchorage in winter, so there won't be a problem of confusing storm lightning with bolts from the volcanic clouds, Miller said.

DOC.HEAD: Florida's Worst Outbreak Of Encephalitis Since the 1960s Winds Down
DOC.TEXT: Golfers in Palm Beach County can tee off at the driving range at night again, but some Boy Scouts still can't camp under the stars as the state's worst encephalitis outbreak since the 1960s winds down. Health officials have recorded 203 cases of St. Louis encephalitis, a potentially deadly illness, in 27 central and south Florida counties since it was first reported in mid-August. Eight people have died. State health officials say the outbreak of the flu-like viral disease will likely end with winter. Cold weather slows down and begins to kill the night-flying mosquitos that carry the virus. ``I can almost guarantee you that there won't be any more transmission by January,'' Dr. Diana Wells, the state's assistant epidemiologist, said Wednesday. Camping, high school football and Halloween trick-or-treating were some of the evening activities canceled in many areas as the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services advised residents and visitors to stay inside after dark. The outbreak was worse than in 1977, when 110 cases were reported and eight people died. Officials said another severe outbreak occurred in the late 1960s, but figures for it were not available. Health officials in Tallahassee said last week that nighttime activities could begin again, but that people going out at night should still cover up and use mosquito repellant. Palm Beach County health officials lifted their medical alert Monday. ``You could almost hear the sigh of relief,'' said Cam Freedlund, a state health agency spokeswoman in West Palm Beach. ``People can go back outside on the driving range now and not worry about it.'' Alerts remained in effect in several other counties, but were expected to be lifted soon, Wells said. In Tampa, Mark Griffin, an official with the Boy Scouts of America, said a camping ban was still in effect for troops in eight counties. Bill Toth, a spokesman for the Orange County Public Health Unit, said activities were also being restricted there. Toth said his office has fielded calls from people around the world who were concerned about visiting Florida during the outbreak. ``We have accepted phone calls in this building from Australia to Hawaii to Alaska to Canada to the United Kingdom and all points between, questioning whether it was safe to come here,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``Definitely, we would like to see everyone with his family by Christmas, because that is a very joyous and happy occasion, and it is time for family reunions.'' - Iraq's ambassador to the United Nations, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, as Saddam Hussein announced that hostages in Iraq and Kuwait will be released. --- ``He's packed and ready to leave. I warned him it might take some time to get out ... but he's still just so thrilled. We've got all our Christmas presents wrapped and ready.'' - Marie Butcher, in Johnson City, Tenn., after speaking by telephone with her son-in-law, Guy Seago, at the military installation where he's being held by Iraqi troops. --- ``We've been waiting and waiting, trying and trying to get him out and hitting brick walls. So this first ray of hope is like a gift.'' - Sue Iliff, in Stover, Mo., whose brother is among the holdouts at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. --- ``He said, `I'm ready to come home ... I'm really, you know, I'm really tired. I just want to get home. Get back to work.''' - Marjorie Walterscheid, in Jacksboro, Texas, after talking with her husband who is one of a group of American oil workers taken off their rigs and into the custody of Iraqi troops.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Says It Is Rethinking Sanctions
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela says his organization is rethinking its support of economic sanctions but wants present measures kept in place for the time being. Mandela, in a letter Thursday to European Community leaders, called on the group to delay any new decisions on sanctions until early next year. The EC leaders are to meet next week in Rome. There have been indications some member countries may support a relaxation of the sanctions imposed to protest apartheid. The ANC, South Africa's leading black opposition movement, has been the leading proponent of comprehensive sanctions to put pressure on the white-led government. It has repeatedly said sanctions should be maintained until there was ``irreversible'' change toward dismantling apartheid. Manela said the ANC was reviewing its sanctions policy to reach a ``position common to the majority of anti-apartheid forces in the country.'' The ANC is to hold a major conference Dec. 14-16, and re-evaluating sanctions was expected to be a leading issue. ``It is too early to begin celebrating the lifting of sanctions,'' said Business Day, an anti-apartheid newspaper that opposes sanctions. But the ANC ``could be on the brink of moderating it uncompromising support of sanctions,'' the newspaper said. Business Day reported Thursday that sports and cultural sanctions supported by the ANC could be lifted first, followed by economic sanctions. Western European nations and the United States have maintained limited economic sanctions against South Africa in recent years. But the countries have praised President F.W. de Klerk's reforms and said sanctions would eventually be lifted if he continued with his stated plans to end aparthied. The government says that blacks suffer the most from the economic hardships caused by sanctions. Despite economic damage from the sanctions, South Africa still has the continent's strongest economy and its main trade partners are Western Europe, the United States and Japan. South Africa also says it trades with every African country, mostly in secret. It also has established trade links with several East European countries that used to be leading backers of the ANC.

DOC.HEAD: $100,000 Reward Offered After Stabbing of Daily News Truck Driver
DOC.TEXT: The publisher of the strikebound Daily News accused New York's mayor and police of ignoring evidence that strikers conspired to destroy the newspaper with violence and intimidation. The allegations by James Hoge came Thursday after a replacement driver was beaten and stabbed about 12 hours after he was summoned to testify before a grand jury investigating strike violence. ``I submit that the police need to face up to what is clearly the reality today in this community: the gangsters are running free, and nobody is willing to say what is really occurring,'' Hoge said. ``Instead, we have public officials that are hiding behind technical and innocuous statements - and that is not living up to the full responsibility of officials who have sworn to uphold the law.'' Hoge urged Mayor David Dinkins to speak out more forcefully. Dinkins earlier called on all parties to denounce violence and a mayoral spokesman said police and Dinkins had responded fairly to complaints from both sides. The newspaper offered a $100,000 reward for information about the attack early Thursday in Irvington, N.J. Police said 15 men armed with baseball bats, bottles and a knife attacked replacement driver Carlos Chacon, 45, of Harrison, N.J. He was stabbed in the buttocks and abdomen and a helper, Derrick Foster, 27, of Newark, N.J., was cut and bruised, police said. Chacon was hospitalized Thursday in satisfactory condition. Foster was treated and released. Police said the victims heard one attacker say: ``These people that work for the Daily News are taking my job. I'm going to kill you.'' Hoge stopped short of saying the grand jury summons and the stabbing were directly linked. Chacon was called as a potential witness for an investigation into an Oct. 27 incident in which a striking Daily News driver allegedly smashed a delivery truck's headlights and windows, Hoge said. Nine of the newspaper's 10 unions have been on strike since Oct. 25. Union officials decried the stabbing and denied Hoge's accusations. ``The highest police officials of this city have refuted these charges. Jim Hoge repeating something over and over like a parrot doesn't make a conspiracy,'' said Newspaper Guild head Barry Lipton. ``This is meaningless babble from a desperate man.''

DOC.HEAD: Songwriter-Singer Sues Milli Vanilli for Alleged Copyright Infringement
DOC.TEXT: Pop posers Rob Pilatus and Fabrice Morvan of Milli Vanilli were stripped of their Grammy because they synched when they should have sang. Now they face a $120 million lawsuit for allegedly stealing music from the 1960s-era band Blood, Sweat and Tears. Singer David Clayton-Thomas said in court papers filed Thursday that the melody of ``Spinning Wheel,'' which he wrote in 1968, was used without his permission on the Milli Vanilli album, ``Girl You Know It's True.'' ``This suit is about the song they didn't write on the album they didn't sing,'' said Clayton-Thomas' lawyer, Robert Marcus. ``The words may change but the melody lingers on.'' Pilatus and Morvan were forced to give back a Grammy they won for best new artist after it was revealed they did not sing the album's songs and were lip-synching the words in concerts. At at news conference in Manhattan, Marcus played tapes of ``Spinning Wheel'' and the Milli Vanilli song ``All or Nothing.'' The lawyer said the melody lines of the choruses are identical. The Milli Vanilli record does not credit Clayton-Thomas. On the album, group producer Frank Farian and two others are credited with writing the song. The suit named Pilatus, Morvan, Farian and EMI Music Publishing Inc., which holds Clayton-Thomas' music copyrights in trust. EMI executive vice president Harold Rosenbloom did not immediately return a call seeking comment. The whereabouts of Farian, Pilatus and Morvan were not immediately known. A call to Arista Records, where the album was recorded, was referred to lawyer Michael Pollock, who did not immediately return messages.

DOC.HEAD: Rising Prices Bring Frayed Tempers, Strained Budgets
DOC.TEXT: Filipinos are stocking up on necessities in anticipation that oil prices driven up sharply by the Persian Gulf crisis and government subsidy cuts will spark inflation across the board. The government of President Corazon Aquino this week ordered a 30 percent increase of the gas price to $2.81 a gallon. Other fuel prices also increased, by an average of 45 percent. The increases announced Wednesday and Thursday are expected to double the cost of public transport and lead to sharply higher prices for food, electricity and other essentials. It now costs more to fill the tank of a mid-sized car than a public school teacher earns in a week. Thousands of shoppers jammed Manila supermarkets following the fuel hikes to stock up on canned goods, cooking oil and other basic supplies before prices on those items go up. Spot checks of several markets showed prices for fish, chicken, and pork had increased about 7 percent since the fuel price hike. Sen. Orlando Mercado, chairman of the Senate commerce committee, called the increases ``an act of national suicide'' and joined Sen. Ernesto Maceda and opposition Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile in calling for Mrs. Aquino to resign. Communist rebels threatened to bomb gas stations that increase their gas prices in the city of Cagayan de Oro, 500 miles south of Manila. About 4,000 students of the Bukidnon State College, southeast of Cagayan, staged a one day walk-out to protest the new prices. The government said the fuel price increase was brought on by higher crude oil prices since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August. The Philippines imports most of its crude oil. World oil prices have fallen since the invasion. But the government has subsidized the oil products it refines for years, and the price increase was also due to measures included in an austerity program pushed by the International Monetary Fund. Stunned by the increases, dozens of angry Filipinos have been telephoning call-in shows on Manila radio stations to vent their anger. ``Cory Aquino is like a doll - a puppet of her advisers,'' caller Loy Trinidad told radio station DZRH. One supermarket shopper, Ria Teves, said she had to wrestle a can of cooking oil away from a clerk who tried to remove it from her shopping cart to mark a higher price. ``I scolded her and told her off,'' Mrs. Teves said. At another supermarket, housewife Rosalinda Mundo said she had planned to do the monthly shopping next week but changed her mind after fuel prices were increased. ``If I wait, my budget will get me only half as much,'' she said. ``They're trying to take the food right out of our mouths.'' Taxi driver Exquiel Valenzuela was refusing to pick up passengers unless they agreed in advance to pay more than the metered fare. He said drivers could not earn enough money to buy gasoline at the new prices and still clear a profit. ``The government has dug our graves for us and is just waiting for us to jump in,'' said Valenzuela, a father of four.

DOC.HEAD: Neighbors Say Whistling NYC Skyscraper is Driving Them Nuts
DOC.TEXT: As if life in the big city wasn't tough enough, neighbors living near a Manhattan skyscraper say a high-pitched whistle coming from it is driving them crazy. ``I've been all over the street trying to follow the noise,'' said Anthony Mazzola, who lives about a block away from the 72-story Cityspire. ``You think you're in a loony bin. You can't get away from it.'' Department of Environmental Protection inspectors blamed the noise on wind blowing over louvers on the midtown building's green, eight-sided dome, which is about 800 feet above the ground. At its worst, the whistle can be heard 10 blocks away, although its intensity depends on wind conditions, said Jerome Ross, an environmental protection enforcement officer. The building's developer, Ian Bruce Eichner, has been issued a summons for allegedly violating noise regulations, Ross said. If found guilty, Eichner would have to mute the whistling and pay a fine of up to $880, Ross said.

DOC.HEAD: Poles Learn That in a Democracy, It Pays to Look Twice
DOC.TEXT: Stanislaw Tyminski returned to Poland two months ago presenting himself as a successful technocrat who would use Western business acumen to reverse the nation's economic crisis. But the picture that emerged of Lech Walesa's surprise challenger in the country's first popular presidential election turned out to be something different: a vague ideologue who has ties to the former Communist Party, believes in ESP and threatens political opponents with secret documents. ``Nobody knew the truth about Tyminski,'' said Emilia Bargiel of Jastrzebie, saying she was ashamed to have voted for him in the first round Nov. 25. She said she will cast her vote for Walesa in the runoff Sunday. ``Finally the journalists found out - too late for many people.'' Tyminski's come-from-nowhere bid - which eliminated Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki from the race - was so fast and unexpected in this new democracy that some feel like they just missed getting hit by a train. Now three opinion polls show Walesa with a widening lead two days before the 27 million Polish voters make their choice. If the Tyminski surge has been stopped, it is because a gradually sharper picture has emerged of the man once referred to as a ``Polish Indiana Jones'' when he strode into the political arena early in October. Labeling himself the campaign's ``only independent candidate,'' he told a rags-to-riches story. According to Tyminski, he left Poland in 1969 with the equivalent of $5 in his pocket, worked as a gardener in Sweden, emigrated to Canada where he made his first after-tax million in computers by 1980, then removed himself to the Amazonian city of Iquitos, Peru, to find spiritual rebirth in the jungle, returned to Canada in 1986 and is now ready to share his knowledge with his compatriots. ``Financial success put him in one of the higher places among Canada's wealthy,'' his campaign literature boasted. In a country where the rich uncle from America is part of the national folklore, Tyminski's campaign soon found believers. He was among only six out of 14 would-be candidates able to collect the required 100,000 nominating signatures by Oct. 25. His campaign meetings around the country drew the curious and sent away the converted. High-quality color posters splashed his clean-cut face on buses and walls. While Walesa and Mazowiecki were slinging mud at each other, Tyminski said he was not a politician. But he also told voters that Mazowiecki was guilty of treason for economic policies that had destroyed Poland's best industries. After his election, he said, the economy would improve in one month. Polls showed his support doubling week-by-week. Days before the first round, he passed Mazowiecki, setting off alarm bells. The prime minister's campaign, which had been gunning only at Walesa, now turned to take aim at Tyminski. But it proved too late. About this time, however, contradictions began to appear in Tyminski's statements and suspicions about his background: -Leaders of the Polish community in Canada said Tyminski was not known even to fellow Polish emigres. The reported his company employed only 14 people. And his Libertarian Party of Canada has 3,500 members and never won a seat in either a provincial or federal parliament. -Tyminski for a time asserted that he had not returned to Poland in years. Then the Interior Ministry confirmed he had been back seven times between 1980 and 1989, arriving on visas issued by the Polish consulate in Tripoli, Libya. Tyminski then admitted coming back, but said he never was in Libya. The climax may have come at a raucous nationally televised two-hour news conference last Saturday. There many Poles heard for the first time the names and ranks of former Communists and secret police operatives who had been active in the Tyminski campaign, that he had been married once before outside the Catholic Church and that he claimed to have had spiritual voyages in the Peruvian jungle. They also saw him coolly warn Walesa, in a style reminiscent of the hated Security Service, that he had damaging ``personal materials'' about the Solidarity chief in a black briefcase at his feet. Since then Tyminski's campaign has been dogged by chants of ``K-G-B.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were higher. Traders predicted the dollar would fall further as tensions eased in the Middle East and amid concerns about the U.S. economy. ``I see the dollar going down...before year-end, because we're expecting still more negative U.S. economic news,'' said a trader at an American bank in Frankfurt. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 1.88 yen to a closing 132.17 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 131.80 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: -1.4852 German marks, down from 1.4890 -1.2670 Swiss francs, down from 1.2725 -5.0347 French francs, down from 5.0540 -1.6745 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6805 -1,118.75 Italian lire, down from 1,122.25 -1.1625 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1621 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9440, up from $1.9390 late Thursday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $371.10 per ounce at midmorning, up from $370.25 bid per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $370.60, up from $369.50 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.41 to close at a bid $371.83. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.15 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $4.16.

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Quake Jolts Anchorage; No Damage Reported
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake strong enough to ``shake dishes'' jolted residents of Anchorage and Palmer, but no damage was immediately reported, a geophysicist said. Thursday night's quake measured 5.0 on the Richter scale and its epicenter was in unpopulated areas, said Bob Hammond of the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer. An earthquake of 5.0 magnitude ``can shake dishes ... if you're located right in the epicenter it could potentially crack dry walls, things like that,'' he said. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus, a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5. In 1964, an Alaska quake measuring 8.4 killed 131 people.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition, Students Demand Trial Of Ershad and Ministers
DOC.TEXT: A day after their protests brought him down, the enemies of ousted President Hussain Muhammad Ershad demanded today that he and his ministers be tried for human rights violations and corruption. Ershad was replaced by Supreme Court Chief Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed, who will preside over an interim government until parliamentary elections are held within 90 days. Political analysts doubt the interim government will initiate any case against Ershad and his colleagues. Ahmed has only one mandate - to conduct the elections. But the demands for score-settling, official or otherwise, are unlikely to abate. A mob in Dhaka on Thursday beat to death a man they accused of being an Ershad supporter, witnesses said. Otherwise, life in the capital was returning to normal after nearly two months of almost daily protests and violence. Many shops opened today, on Sabbath in this overwhelmingly Moslem nation of 110 million people. Traffic was moving normally as barricades were taken down. But the opposition was doing its part to keep the political flames burning. ``We definitely want a trial of those who have committed crimes and atrocities in the past eight years,'' said opposition leader Khaleda Zia. Mrs. Zia, as leader of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, and Sheik Hasina, of the Awami League, joined forces in a series of protests that brought down Ershad. ``Ershad and his ministers have amassed millions of dollars by cheating the nation. The criminals must stand for trial,'' said Amir Hossain Amu, a leader of Hasina's party. ``If there are complaints of corruption and misuse of power against someone, the government should take appropriate actions in accordance with the laws of the land,'' the army chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Nooruddin Khan, said during a televised interview Thursday night. Ershad was the army chief when he took power in a bloodless coup in March 1982. He resigned from the army after winning presidential elections in 1986, which the opposition claimed were rigged. Charges of vote fraud also dogged the 1988 parliamentary elections, won by Ershad's Jatiya Party. The opposition made vote fraud the focus of their protests when Ershad announced he would be a candidate for re-election in June 1991. Ershad's resignation capped a dizzying reversal in his political fortunes. The fraud claims and protests had been little more than background noise during Ershad's eight years in office, and three weeks ago he was confidently predicting success in next year's election. But once Sheik Hasina and Khaleda Zia were able to overcome longstanding political differences, their campaign gained new life. It quickly spread even after Ershad declared a state of emergency Nov. 27. The opposition claims at least 100 people were killed by troops during the emergency, which was withdrawn Wednesday. The government said only six people died.

DOC.HEAD: Man Indicted in Alleged Plot to Kill Bush, Destroy Military Installations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Terence in 7th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: No evidence has been found linking a foreign government to a former U.S. soldier indicted for allegedly plotting to kill President Bush and other top officials, the U.S. Attorney for New Jersey said. U.S. Attorney Michael Chertoff said it does not appear Jamal Mohammed Warrayat, a naturalized U.S. citizen born in Kuwait, had outside help in the alleged plot to kill Bush, Secretary of State James A. Baker III, unspecified members of Congress and to attack military installations in three states. Warrayat, 32, was indicted Thursday on three felony charges. He could be sentenced to 15 years and fined $750,000 if convicted of all counts. Warrayat has been held without bail since his Nov. 27 arrest. An arraignment is expected within two weeks. Court papers said Warrayat wanted to kill the officials because they were against the interests of his group, but the papers did not describe the group or its interests further, and prosecutors would not elaborate. According to the court papers, Warrayat told an undercover FBI agent that his group was ready to attack Bush and the others, as well as attack unspecified military installations in North Carolina, Texas and Kansas. He allegedly said the group was looking for help obtaining explosives, money and technical training. Warrayat's attorney, Terence Scott, was not available for comment Thursday, his secretary said. Scott has previously said Warrayat was born in Kuwait, came to the United States in the early 1970s and served about four years in the Army until 1979. Scott said that until recently his client worked as a taxi driver but was unemployed at the time of his arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Suspends Bail for Zionist Activist's Alleged Killer
DOC.TEXT: The judge who set bail at $300,000 for the alleged killer of Rabbi Meir Kahane suspended it a day later, and the district attorney said the original motion granting bail was made over his objections. State Supreme Court Justice Alvin Schlesinger, who approved the $300,000 bail for El Sayyid Nosair on Wednesday, suspended it on Thursday and scheduled a new bail hearing for Monday. District Attorney Robert Morgenthau said Thursday that his office had requested Nosair be held without bail. ``We pointed out to the court that he is accused of committing a number of exceptionally serious crimes, including both the murder of Rabbi Kahane and the wounding of a federal police officer,'' Morgenthau said. Nosair, 35, of Cliffside Park, N.J., is accused of shooting the Zionist activist last month as Kahane finished a speech at a New York City hotel. He also is accused of wounding two other men as he fled. One of the two, a postal service police officer, wounded Nosair. In a statement to police, attached to a disclosure form filed in court, Nosair told police Kahane was actually shot by another person and that he was framed. He said he went to hear Kahane's lecture because he agreed with much of the rabbi's philosophy.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Waiting for the Hostages
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 7th graf pvs, ``The Iraqi ambassador ...'' with 4 new grafs to UPDATE with Al-Mashat comments from televised interview
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Given Saddam Hussein's record, the Bush administration is offering a subdued response to Baghdad's surprise announcement that all 900 Americans held in Iraq and Kuwait will be freed.
