The hostages' release is one of the three principal U.S. demands made of the Iraqi president since his lightning takeover of Kuwait in August. President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III still insist on fulfillment of the other two - a total withdrawal and restoration of the overthrown Kuwaiti government. Freeing the hostages, including 88 held as human shields at strategic locations, could serve Saddam's purposes by contributing to the rising opposition among Congress and the public to a use of military force. With the Iraqi leader capitulating to one demand, why not wait for the worldwide trade embargo and other economic sanctions to squeeze Saddam into giving up Kuwait? But before that argument can get very far, the American hostages have to be freed. And they are not out yet. The State Department, through broadcasts on the Voice of America, advised the Americans to remain where they were until arrangements are made for their rescue. The Iraqi ambassador, Mohamed Sadiq Al-Mashat, said he expected the release within days. In a televised interview today, he said Iraqi officials are arranging for flights and exit visas for the hostages. ``We are speeding the process of their departure,'' Al-Mashat said on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America.'' The envoy said Iraq was willing to release the hostages because ``there is more hope for peace'' and because of planned talks with U.S. officials. He said Iraq was expecting ``absolutely nothing'' in return. An additional 2,250 U.S. citizens and foreign-born family members have been allowed to leave since the takeover of Kuwait, so it may simply be a matter of making arrangements over a few days before the 900 are liberated. And yet, the hostages are an extremely valuable bargaining chip, especially those being used as human shields to deter U.S. attack. Administration officials have denounced their detention - and the sporadic release of other Americans - as a cruel manipulation of people and their families. Bush has said many times that in deciding whether to attack Iraq or take other actions to liberate Kuwait, he would not be held hostage to Saddam's hostage policy. Even so, it would be difficult to imagine the president ordering an assault on an installation where Americans were held prisoner. Throughout the five-month crisis U.S. hopes have been boosted and dashed by various statements from Iraq. Early on, there were pledges to leave Kuwait if the United States promised not to attack, but Kuwait remains under Iraqi occupation. U.S. diplomats eager to visit American hostages were told it was only a matter of making proper arrangements. But they applied and were denied access anyway. ``Mercurial'' is a cliched adjective commonly applied to Saddam. Another is ``unpredictable.'' He fought a bloody war with Iran for eight years and then suddenly relinquished all his territorial gains and agreed to a cease-fire. Saddam appeared to be moderating his policies, inducing the Reagan and Bush administrations to be a little friendlier. And then, with dramatic suddenness, came the Aug. 2 blitzkrieg invasion of Kuwait. Bush welcomed the announcement Thursday that the hostages would be released. But he said the United States must not let its war footing in the Persian Gulf slip. ``We've got to continue to keep the pressure on,'' he said while traveling in South America. Hopeful but cautious, Bush also cited the easing of Iraq's pressure on the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait and said: ``It seems to be a little movement here, a little movement there.'' But the president and others in the administration are not cheering yet. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid heads the AP's State Department staff.

DOC.HEAD: Military Personnel in Gulf Will Have Extra Tax-Filing Time
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military personnel who are stationed in the Persian Gulf area on the April 15 tax-filing deadline will have an an extra 60 days to file their 1990 federal tax returns. In announcing the automatic extension, the Internal Revenue Service said Thursday that interest will be charged as usual on any tax not paid by the regular deadline. The agency said it has no authority under the law to waive that requirement. The IRS noted, however, that most military personnel will be due a refund and so would not face the interest charge. The agency said it will work closely with the Defense Department in providing tax-return assistance to members of the armed forces. The IRS left open the possibility that a further filing extension would be granted if conditions warrant.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Attempt to Calm Flood Victims About PCB Levels
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials attempted to calm worried residents evacuated from flood-ravaged housing that tests showing the presence of high levels of cancer-causing PCBs don't necessarily mean they are in danger. Milton Clark, a PCB specialist with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, told residents attending a public meeting that while long-term exposure may be harmful, brief exposure poses little hazard. ``In the short term, you're not at risk,'' he said Thursday. The residents of about 120 homes were barred from returning to their houses after the PCBs were found Wednesday. Residents in the 270-home Wicker Park subdivision had begun returning Monday to gather personal items from homes damaged last week when 6 inches of rain caused flooding. Test results shared by the EPA led the state to declare the houses off-limits. The EPA said it found double the acceptable levels of PCBs. Tests for PCBs were conducted after Highland officials reported seeing a sheen on floodwaters. The cause of the contamination had not been determined. Jim Lynch, a spokesman for the Indiana Department of Environmental Management, told reporters that officials were researching the history of the area. He said there were indications the neighborhood had been a ``dumping area,'' but did not elaborate. PCBs, once commonly used as insulation in electrical transformers, were banned by the federal government as a cancer-causing substance in the 1970s. Residents of Wicker Park Estates in Highland and other areas hit hard by flooding last week did get some good news Thursday when President Bush declared Lake County a disaster area. The disaster declaration will enable Lake County's flood victims to get low-interest loans and other assistance on a case-by-case basis.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Vows hhe Wouldn't Keep Brain-Damaged Lesbian Lover From Parents
DOC.TEXT: A woman seeking guardianship of her brain-damaged lesbian lover says she would never keep her from seeing her estranged parents. Karen Thompson, a professor at St. Cloud State University, said Sharon Kowalski, 34, has already suffered enough after a 1983 traffic accident left her without the use of her limbs and barely able to speak. ``I never want to put her in the position that she has to choose between her biological family and chosen family,'' Thompson told St. Louis County District Judge Robert Campbell on Thursday. The hearing, scheduled to end today, is expected to cap a five-year guardianship struggle that has pitted Thompson against Kowalski's parents. Don and Della Kowalski of Nashwauk have since said they lack the energy and the money to keep fighting for their daughter, whom they sequestered from Thompson for 3{ years. Since last year, she has been cared for at a nursing home in suburban Robbinsdakem, pending Ms. Thompson's petition. The dispute has been followed closely by gay rights advocates who maintain Thompson is best suited to care for Kowalski. The two lived together for four years before the accident, Thompson said, and considered themselves secretly married. A physician said Thursday that Kowalski's emotional and physical well-being are on the line if Thompson is barred from becoming her guardian. ``Sharon communicates with Karen in a way no one else does,'' said Dr. Gail Gregor, a rehabilitation consultant. ``Karen is the key to her past self and the window into who she is now. ... She chooses not to interact unless Karen is with her.'' On the subject of Kowalski's parents, Gregor said they have had such infrequent contact with their daughter since they gave up guardianship that it may make little difference if they never see her again.

DOC.HEAD: Onetime Witness in NYC Racial Killing Acquitted of Murder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Vento was...' to recast garbled background.
DOC.TEXT: After a white mob cornered and fatally shot a black teen-ager, prosecuters had counted on John Vento to talk. He was part of that gang and agreed to be a witness in exchange for immunity. But he backed out of the deal and fled the city before ultimately deciding to surrender and face trial rather than testify against pals from Bensonhurst, the predominantly white Brooklyn neighborhood where the black teen was killed. Prosecutors called Vento's move a double-cross and said his change of heart hurt the cases against other defendants. Two were cleared this week on all major charges. On Thursday, Vento, 22, was acquitted of murder and manslaughter in the August 1989 slaying of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins. Vento was convicted of riot. ''Yes, yes, yes!'' he bellowed, slamming his hands on the defense table as the verdict was read. Crying and screaming, he grabbed and hugged his lawyer before he was restrained by court officers. The riot conviction carries a maximum term of one and one-third years to four years in prison, which could run concurrently or be added to a longer term he received from prior convictions in the case. Reached by telephone, juror Gay Fallows said: ``All I will tell you is, it was a very, very difficult case and very difficult decision.'' The trial was the second for Vento. In July, a jury convicted him of unlawful imprisonment and menacing, but acquitted him of the most serious charge he faced, intentional murder. ``It's always hard to convict someone when he was not the trigger man,'' prosecutor Paul Burns said. Prosecutors were able to retry Vento because the jury deadlocked on two of the charges in July, and a few weeks later, a grand jury added a second-degree manslaughter count. He is serving a sentence of two and two-thirds to eight years in prison for the first two convictions. JJoseph Fama, convicted of murder and other crimes, is serving 32 and two-thirds years to life. Keith Mondello, the organizer of the mob, was acquitted of murder and manslaughter, but was sentenced to up to 16 years in prison for convictions of other crimes. Three other defendants are scheduled to stand trial early next year.

DOC.HEAD: Las Vegas' Mirage Hotel Evacuates Two Floors Briefly After Fire
DOC.TEXT: Smoke from an electrical room fire triggered alarms at the luxury Mirage Hotel, prompting dozens of guests to evacuate. There were no injuries. Guests, many clad in pajamas, fled the second and third floors of the west wing of the 30-story hotel Thursday night as smoke drifted through hallways. The cause of the fire was under investigation. About 35 Clark County firefighters extinguished the blaze at 9:30 p.m., 45 minutes after it began. The fire was confined by sprinklers to the power room on the mezzanine level, said hotel Chairman Steve Wynn. Smoke was reported up to the 18th floor, and water flooded small meeting rooms. ``There was a ton of smoke,'' Wynn said. ``The damage was contained. The damage is going to be water - a few thousand dollars.'' The $630 million casino hotel opened Nov. 22, 1989, and is owned by Golden Nugget Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Front Brings Rain, Snow to East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf to CORRECT `east' to `west'. Other minor editing.
DOC.TEXT: After a day of mild weather, storm systems are bringing rain and snow to much of the country, although the West is basking under clear skies. A cold front stretching along the East Coast will bring heavy thunderstorms to the Southeast and South tonight and Saturday and snow to the Appalachians, forecasters said. Cloudy weather prevailed in much of New York state and New England early today. Temperatures were to reach the 40s, with lows in the 20s and 30s. Cloudy skies also prevailed in the Midwest, with increasing clouds expected Saturday. Most of Iowa, Wisconsin, eastern Nebraska, southeast Minnesota and northwest Illinois remained covered with snow today. Low temperatures tonight will be in the 20s and 30s. A cold front will also bring more snow to the western Great Lakes region. Clear skies prevailed in much of the West, from Texas west to California, with temperatures in the 60s, 70s and 80s, although temperatures in mountain areas were much cooler. There were scattered showers today in the Pacific Northwest, with high temperatures forecast in the 50s. San Juan Capistrano, Calif., was the hot spot in the nation Thursday, with an afternoon high of 88 degrees. DOC.HEAD: Crews Begin Transfer of Crude from Cracked Tanker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Scot is cq in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Crews expected to finish transferring 35 million gallons of Alaska crude oil from a damaged tanker to another ship by tonight as long as seas remained calm, the Coast Guard said. The transfer from the 815-foot Keystone Canyon, which had a cracked ballast tank, to the 669-foot Kenai about 150 miles west of San Francisco began Thursday afternoon. No oil had spilled from the tanker, but the transfer was necessary because the 20-foot vertical crack in a starboard ballast tank in the midsection compromised the ship's stability, said Quartermaster Dennis Krumel. No oil was in the ballast tank, which is filled at varying levels with water. Crews had planned to start moving the oil by Wednesday evening but were delayed by 15-foot ocean swells, Coast Guard Commander Scot Tiernan said. The transfer finally began Thursday in calmer seas with 10- to 12-foot waves and wind about 10 mph, the Coast Guard said. The ship-to-ship transfer was a ``reasonably rare'' occurrence, said Tiernan, chief of port operations at the Marine Safety Office in San Francisco. ``In general, you don't offload 120 miles offshore,'' he said. ``It shouldn't be a big deal, but they're taking all the precautions they can.'' Crews, unloading up to 35,000 barrels an hour, expected the transfer to take 30 hours. The Kenai's capacity, 835,000 barrels or 35 million gallons, is about 15,000 barrels smaller than the Keystone Canyon, and all but that amount will be transferred, Tiernan said. The Kenai will take the cargo to refineries in El Segundo, Calif., he said. The Keystone Canyon is owned by the Connecticut National Bank of Hartford, Conn., and operated by the Philadelphia-based Keystone Shipping Co. The crude oil load is owned by BP Oil.

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Families Welcome Saddam's Promise of Freedom By Christmas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf: `Saddam called ...' to UPDATE with parliamentary approval of Saddam's directive.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of about 900 American hostages were waiting today for Iraq's Saddam Hussein to follow through on his promise to release all ``foreign guests'' in time for Christmas. ``All we can do now is live in the hope that he really is coming home,'' said Shirley Carroll of Augusta, Ga., whose husband is among holdouts at the U.S. Embssy in Kuwait. ``It's more or less a wait-and-see game,'' said Elsie Lucille Hughes of Albuquerque, N.M., whose husband and son are hiding in Kuwait. ``We're waiting to see ... whether it's got conditions attached to it or not.'' Family and friends of American captives were elated by the Iraqi president's turnaround, but they were also wary of tricks. For those with loved ones in hiding, such a prospect was especially fearsome. ``If you take (Saddam) at face value, then they're going to be released,'' said attorney David McDonald Jr., whose client and friend is among those in hiding. ``The question then becomes when? Is this a ploy to draw everyone out?'' Doubts aside, the promise brought new hope to families. ``We've been waiting and waiting, trying and trying to get him out and hitting brick walls,'' said Sue Iliff, whose brother is among holdouts at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. ``So this first ray of hope is like a gift.'' Saddam called for the release of all hostages in a directive approved overwhelmingly today by the Iraqi parliament. The government said foreigners could start applying for exit visas immediately. ``We're really emotional about this because Christmas is a big holiday with our family ... a very special time of year,'' Mrs. Iliff said from Stover, Mo. ``But we're being careful.'' Marie Butcher spoke with her son-in-law, Guy Seago, Thursday by telephone from the military installation where he has been held by Iraqi troops. ``He's packed and ready to leave. I warned him it might take some time to get out ... but he's still just so thrilled,'' Mrs. Butcher said from Johnson City, Tenn. ``We've got all our Christmas presents wrapped and ready.'' Marjorie Walterscheid received a similar call from her husband, Rainard Walterscheid, one of a group of American oil workers taken off their rigs and into custody by Iraqi troops. ``He said, `I'm ready to come home ... I'm really, you know, I'm really tired. I just want to get home. Get back to work,''' she said from Jacksboro, Texas. ``And I said, `Well maybe we'd go on a honeymoon or something.' He just kind of laughed.''

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Developments at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis: ---

The Iraqi parliament on Friday overwhelmingly endorsed Saddam Hussein's decision to free thousands of Western hostages, meaning the 900 Americans held captive in Iraq and Kuwait might be home for Christmas. The more than 8,000 Westerners, East Europeans and Japanese stranded in Iraq will be allowed to leave beginning Saturday, Iraqi officials said. The captives will be flown out on special Iraqi Airways flights to Amman, Jordan, the officials said. ---

U.S. officials said Iraq has sent 30,000 more troops to the Arabian desert in recent days, indicating Baghdad has no intention of abandoning Kuwait. Pentagon spokesman Bob Hall said on Thursday the troop reinforcements brought the Iraqi buildup in Kuwait and southern Iraq to 480,000 soldiers. ---

President Bush, touring South America, dismissed a U.N. proposal circulating Thursday for a Middle East peace conference, renewing his rejection of Saddam's attempt to link resolution of the crisis with the Arab-Israeli conflict. U.N. Security Council ambassadors discussed a draft resolution that approves a world conference on the Palestinian problem. ---

Defense Ministry sources in Cairo said on Friday that Egypt will increase its military forces in Saudi Arabia and in the United Arab Emirates this month, bringing the total to 27,000 men. They said the 7,000 new troops will begin moving to Saudi Arabia in the coming week. Egypt and Saudi Arabia have led Arab opposition to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Man To Stand Trial in Alleged Attack on Goodyear Blimp
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of steering his radio-controlled model airplane in a kamikaze-style dive that punched a hole in a Goodyear blimp has been ordered to stand trial. The blimp Columbia was carrying six passengers when it sustained the damage on Sept. 30. Compton Municipal Judge Morris B. Jones on Thursday ordered John William Moyer, 28, to trial on charges of assault with intent to commit great bodily injury, vandalism and damage to an aircraft. Jones scheduled the trial Dec. 20 in Superior Court. Prosecutors say Moyer's plane ripped a square-foot hole in Columbia's fabric skin, allowing non-flammable helium gas to leak out. Veteran pilot Nick Nicolary guided the 192-foot airship to a safe landing in Carson. Moyer claims he lost control of the plane, which he was flying in a vacant lot frequented by radio-controlled airplane buffs.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Members Agree on Outlines of Post-Cold War Strategy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 17 grafs to UPDATE with Cheney, Woerner comments, ADDS background on Lance missiles. Pickup 12th pvs, `The allies...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NATO defense ministers agreed in principle today on a post-Cold War defense strategy of reduced U.S. presence in Europe, smaller forces and a continued mix of conventional and nuclear arms. ``Our future force posture will be based on smaller, more mobile and flexible active forces, able to respond to aggression from any quarter,'' the ministers said in a communique. They said the Persian Gulf crisis served as an example of ``continuing risks of aggression'' from outside NATO territory that have a bearing on the vital security interests of the allies. The NATO allies pledged to maintain military and other pressures to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The gulf crisis ``presents a fundamental challenge to the vision of a peaceful world order,'' the ministers said. The communique said a draft resolution on NATO's future was discussed during the two-day meeting at NATO headquarters in Brussels and would be adopted next year. ``Nuclear weapons ... play a key role in the prevention of war and the maintenance of stability,'' the communique said. It restated NATO's desire for U.S.-Soviet negotiations on reducing short-range nuclear missiles in Europe. U.S.-Soviet negotiations begin next year on reducing short-range missiles, which have a range of up to 310 miles. NATO chief Manfred Woerner and U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the allies remain committed to reduce NATO's short-range nuclear arsenal - free-fall bombs, ground-launched Lance missiles and artillery - through negotiations with Moscow. German Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg said earlier he saw a consensus emerging that the allies were ready to remove all of these arms. NATO has said it will not modernize the Lance missiles and nuclear artillery but deployment of a new tactical air-to-surface missile remains under study. Cheney said on Thursday that the threat of a massive Warsaw Pact invasion had been replaced by new dangers for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. These include lingering threats from the Soviet Union, potential instability in Eastern Europe, the spread of chemical arms and ballistic missiles in the Middle East and possible threats to energy supplies, he said. Officials said the new strategy - to be finalized early next year - will provide for a continued presence of nuclear arms in Europe, albeit in greatly reduced numbers. On the gulf crisis, Cheney and British Defense Secretary Tom King asked their allies for more help in moving troops and equipment to the Middle East. Cheney said he asked the allies for more help in providing ships and planes for transport of U.S. troops to the gulf. He said he also asked for additional ``heavy combat'' and air defense forces to help push Iraq out of Kuwait. He reported a ``generally favorable response'' but no specific pledges of help. He added that Saddam's decision to free all foreign hostages altered neither American deployment plans nor its insistence that Iraq withdraw. ``The only acceptable outcome is for Saddam Hussein to withdraw all his forces from Kuwait and to allow the restoration of the legitimate government of Kuwait,'' he said. The allies reiterated their readiness to go to war unless Iraqi President Saddam Hussein pulls his forces out of Kuwait by Jan. 15 as required by a Nov. 29 United Nations resolution. The United States has about 250,000 troops in the gulf region, and plans to increase its force to more than 400,000. Britain, with the second-largest foreign army in the area, plans to bring its force to over 30,000 in the next few weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Making Pilgrimage To View Daily `Miracle'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, 'Staring at...', to correct description of rosary, which includes quoted phrase but doesn't begin with it. SUBS penultimate graf to correct spelling of Dominic's.
DOC.TEXT: Hordes of Roman Catholic faithful are flocking to see an image on the wall of a church in California that many believe depicts the Virgin Mary. ``I think it's a miracle,'' said Marie Cammarota, 60, of Sacramento after filing through St. Dominic's Church on Thursday. She waited with about 5,000 others in a line that extended a quarter-mile at its peak and turned the chief of the small police force into a traffic cop. Competition for parking in the Sierra Nevada town of 1,000 was fierce. A Christmas tree lot next door charged $5 per car. Church representatives said a few people slept overnight in the church parking lot to be near the front of the line that begins taking shape more than two hours before the hourlong appearance of the image, starting at 9:30 a.m. Some visitors took the day off from work and parents kept their children out of school to witness the image. Many prayed as they passed through the 250-seat church. Some wept. Staring at the image, the seated congregation - the first 250 in line in this case - recited the rosary, which includes the phrase, ``Holy Mary, mother of God.'' Some weren't so sure it was a miracle. ``It was weird. I think it's what you want it to be. If you're into religion, then you see the Virgin Mary,'' said Tyler Palacio, 13. The Rev. Patrick Joseph of Chicago, who was among those who have traveled the farthest, said he thought the miracle was outside the church, among the faithful. ``People aren't coming together because they are sure it is a miracle,'' he said. ``They're coming here to pray that it might be.'' Everyone agreed they had seen something. It started as faint, curved lines of mostly red, blue, green, purple and pink light. The lines darkened and extended into a shape that looked like the top half of a figure. Then it gradually faded away. Some of the lines were sharp, others fuzzy, leading some observers to describe the image as forming on the wall and others to say it stood out from the wall like a holograph. The image appears above a statue of Jesus on a wall that faces the sun. Therefore, the image cannot be directly cast by sunlight filtering through a stained-glass window. But a light fixture hanging from the roof is possibly in position to reflect the colored light coming through the window back onto the wall. The reflection theory was discounted by those who said the image has appeared on cloudy days. Bishop Francis Quinn of the Sacramento Diocese, which includes the town about 45 miles east of Sacramento, said if the image continues he will establish a commission to investigate. Police Chief Bill Mintline said the effects of the crowd are brief because most visitors leave shortly after the image fades at about 10:30 a.m. And those who come, don't cause any trouble, he said. ``It's not like a rock concert crowd,'' Mintline said. St. Dominic's refuses to commercialize the apparition. ``The church is trying not to capitalize on this. We're not accepting any donations,'' said Bernie Molloy, a volunteer helping his father, Ed, the church administrator.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Blacks Killed in Township Violence, Gunmen Fire Into Homes
With PM-South Africa-ANC
DOC.TEXT: Eight blacks died in township violence around Johannesburg, including three men killed when shots were fired into their homes, police said today. Unidentified gunmen, believed to be using AK-47 rifles, fired through the doors of homes, killing the three men in Evaton, south of Johannesburg, police said. Seven people also were injured in overnight clashes. Police reported today that five hacked and stabbed bodies were found in the Bekkersdal township west of Johannesburg, the site of sporadic clashes in recent months. Also, a man was stabbed to death in eastern Natal Province, police added. Fighting between black factions linked to the African National Congress and the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party has killed about 5,000 people in Natal in the past five years. It spread to Johannesburg-area townships in August, and about 1,000 people have died. Meanwhile, a race relations group said attacks on black policemen and black township councilors occurred an average of twice daily and killed 28 people from January through July. Many blacks consider black policemen and township leaders to be collabrators with the white-led government and the apartheid system of racial segregation. Under apartheid, blacks live in segregated areas that lack the amenities and services of white areas. The independent South African Institute of Race Relations said the 409 incidents it counted in the seven-month period included 309 attacks on homes of black policemen and town council members, usually with firebombs or other forms of arson. More than 400 town councilors resigned, most of them citing intimidation by township residents, the group said Thursday. It also said Johannesburg's English-language newspapers neglected to report the nature of the attacks. ``Many articles said `pressure' caused the councilors to resign,'' the group said. ``Quite a number failed to mention that this pressure has frequently been so violent that the term `pressure' is a euphemism.'' The group said six black policemen and 22 councilors had been killed in the attacks. It cited the killing of one councilor by the necklace method, in which the victim has a tire placed around the neck, gets doused in gasoline and set on fire.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Corey Feldman Arrested Again - This Time for Unpaid Tickets
DOC.TEXT: Corey Feldman has been arrested, again. The actor was nabbed for money owed on traffic tickets and fines, police said today. The 19-year-old actor, who appeared in ``The Lost Boys,'' ``Gremlins'' and ``Stand By Me,'' was released this morning after paying $528 in outstanding tickets and fines, said Sgt. Pat Findley of the Los Angeles Police Department's Hollywood division. He was to appear in Los Angeles Traffic Court on Jan. 2, the sergeant said. Feldman was arrested Thursday night when officers spotted his 1989 BMW blocking a driveway and discovered there was an outstanding traffic warrant for his arrest, Findley said. Officers also allegedly determined that Feldman had a suspended driver's license, Findley said. It was Feldman's third arrest this year. He was taken into custody March 9 during a traffic stop when officers allegedly found balloons containing heroin and cocaine in his car. Feldman was also arrested Sept. 20 in connection with unpaid traffic tickets. Officers allegedly found a small amount of heroin on him during a search at a North Hollywood police station and the actor underwent drug treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Queen Honors Former Prime Minister and Her Husband
DOC.TEXT: Queen Elizabeth II appointed Margaret Thatcher a member of the Order of Merit today and the former prime minister's husband became Sir Denis, Buckingham Palace said. The former prime minister will remain in the House of Commons representing her north London constituency, and although she could be called Lady Thatcher, she said she will be known as Mrs. Thatcher. ``That is how I have been known throughout my 31 years as a member of Parliament, and that is how I would like to continue to be known,'' she said. ``I have done pretty well out of being Mrs. Thatcher.'' Her successor, Prime Minister John Major, recommendeded her husband for a baronetcy, Major's Downing Street office said. The baronetcy, the first created since 1964, is hereditary and Mark Thatcher will take the title when his father dies. Mrs. Thatcher said through a spokeswoman that she was ``delighted and thrilled with the honor conferred on her husband who has given such tremendous support to her and been very active in the life of the country, especially over the last 11 years.'' Mrs. Thatcher, 65, resigned Nov. 22 after 11{ years as prime minister. The Order of Merit, founded in 1902, outranks all other royal honors and is a personal gift of the queen. Only the monarch and 24 others can be members of the order at one time. Mrs. Thatcher takes the vacancy caused by the death of Lord Olivier last year. Other members include Mother Teresa of Calcutta, musician Yehudi Menuhin and novelist Graham Greene. Former members include former President Dwight D. Eisenhower and former British Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Message: Hostages Should Be Free And So Should Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Spartanburg in last graf, `I think...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American soldiers had a message for Saddam Hussein today: It's great the hostages may be home for Christmas, but the GIs aren't going home until Kuwait is free. Air Force Staff Sgt. Chester Smolarczyk, who said Iraq appears to be stalling for time but stumbling toward peace, said he's willing to wait. ``Which is cheaper, blood or oil?'' asked the 28-year-old Polish-born cargo handler from Jacksonville, Ark. News of Saddam's surprise promise to free the hostages was only filtering into Saudi Arabia this morning. From the newest arrivals to soldiers who've been in the desert for nearly four months, there was a feeling that something was happening that might affect them, but they weren't sure exactly what it was nor did they trust Saddam. ``He's saying it, but whether he does it or not is a different thing. You can never trust a guy like that,'' said Air Force Sgt. David Klunker, 25, of Salt Lake City, who was playing backgammon during a break from unloading cargo at an air base. Saddam's announcement came as advance parties and the first combat units of the 200,000 U.S. reinforcements for Operation Desert Shield were arriving in Saudi Arabia. They will give the 240,000 troops already in place enough strength for an offensive against Saddam if he refuses to pull out of Kuwait. ``If he didn't want to back down, he wouldn't be freeing the hostages so quick,'' said Air Force Staff Sgt. William Briggs, 52, of Columbia, S.C., whose 169th Service Battalion in the National Guard was mobilized for the buildup. ``One way or the other, he is going to give in because we'll see to that,'' he said. ``Then again, everything will be determined Jan. 15.'' A U.N. resolution set a Jan. 15 deadline for Saddam to pull out of Kuwait without facing the possibility of military action by the U.S.-led multinational force which includes 100,000 other troops from about 25 other countries. First Sgt. Jerry Carlton, 37, of Warsaw, N.C., whose 82nd Airborne unit landed in Saudi Arabia on Aug. 9, said the hostage release could signal that Saddam was caving in or trying ``to buy additional time.'' ``I think it's great they're going home,'' said 1st Lt. Brian Ratchford, 26, of Spartanburg, S.C., from the 39th Tactical Air Squadron. ``But it's not about the hostages. I think the hostages were a bad side effect of this whole thing,''

DOC.HEAD: Defendant in Racial Slaying Sentenced to 15 Years
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager who was at the wheel of the the car when two ``skinhead'' friends picked a black person at random and killed him was sentenced to 15 years in prison for her role in the 1988 murder. Angela Stanley, 18, sat motionless through most of Thursday's 90-minute hearing, but wept quietly as Washoe District Judge Brent Adams handed down the sentence. Stanley pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in the Dec. 10, 1988, shooting of Tony Montgomery, 27, in his sister's front yard. She had testified against her two passengers, avowed racist ``skinheads'' Matthew Faessel, 19, and Michael Stringer, 18. Faessel and Stringer were convicted of first-degree murder and face two consecutive life prison terms at their sentencing Dec. 20. Trial testimony showed that Stringer rolled down the window of the car Stanley was driving, and Faessel fired the fatal shot. ``In my view, Angela Stanley was the least culpable of the three,'' said Assistant District Attorney Ed Basl. Witnesses said the three white teen-agers became enraged at a party attended by skinheads when a woman told them she had been raped by a black man. At her hearing, Stanley denied having the white supremacist, neo-Nazi beliefs some skinheads have embraced in recent years. Basl said Stanley has made substantial progress toward changing her life but urged the court to impose a long enough sentence to ensure a prolonged supervised parole. Stanley, who has already served two years in custody, will be eligible for parole in three years. Her lawyer, Fred Pinkerton, said that at the time of the murder, Stanley was a ``16-year-old street kid who sought the affections of those who were not good.''

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Argue Fairness Of Buchwald's Deal With Paramount
DOC.TEXT: Art Buchwald's suit against Paramount Pictures entered its second phase with the humorist's attorneys arguing the studio gave him a ``raw deal.'' The Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist won the first part of the case when Superior Court Judge Harvey Schneider ruled the 1986 Eddie Murphy blockbuster ``Coming to America'' was based on a Buchwald work titled ``King for a Day.'' Thursday's proceeding was to determine the fairness of the contract Buchwald and Bernheim signed with Paramount in 1983. Schneider must determine the amount of money Buchwald and his partner, producer Alain Bernheim, should receive in the case during a third phase of the trial. The blockbuster film grossed more than $300 million in box office receipts, but Paramount says it still hasn't earned a profit and is actually $18 million in the red. Therefore, the company argues, Buchwald and Bernheim's share of the profits amounts to nothing. Buchwald attorney Pierce O'Donnell told Schneider the contract showed how Hollywood's net-profit agreements are unfair. ``Paramount says a deal is a deal, we say (Buchwald and Bernheim) got a raw deal,'' O'Donnell said. Net-profit agreements grant individuals a share of a film's net profits after the motion picture company recovers its costs and an agreed-upon rate of return. Critics say that the arrangements can result in unfairness if the studio artificially inflates the cost of a film and thus reduces or eliminates the profit. Paramount attorney Charles Diamond said the studio was to receive approximately 1.75 times its costs before sharing profits from ``Coming to America.'' Paramount has not disclosed the cost of making the film. Buchwald and Bernheim were to receive a combined $265,000 and up to 40 percent of net profits under the contract. In court papers, Buchwald and Bernheim contended their share of the movie's profits should be between $6.9 million and $14.6 million. ``We don't have to pay these gentlemen until we have recouped all our costs from the revenue,'' Diamond said. ``Courts in this country ought not to be remaking deals for parties,'' Diamond said. Buchwald, who attended Thursday's session, said he was pessimistic about the outcome of the suit. ``I'm always prepared for the worst,'' he said. ``I can't believe I'll win.''

DOC.HEAD: Some Former Political Prisoners to Get Advance Compensation
DOC.TEXT: Some former political prisoners, already rehabilitated but waiting for financial compensation, will get an advance payment of $417 before Christmas, a Finance Ministry official said today. However, the measure will only apply to those rehabilitated in the Czech lands, not in Slovakia, he added. Under a law enacted earlier this year, former political prisoners are entitled to about $100 for each month spent in jail and to compensation payments for impaired health and legal costs incurred. The federal government has earmarked millions of dollars for cash payments to be made to former political prisoners and millions of dollars to be set aside in bonds. ``The list of those who applied for the advance payment includes some 1,400 people,'' said Hynek Rasocha of the Czech Finance Ministry. ``It is a good thing, because many of them are very old and poor,'' he said, indicating that some of them may not live long enough to be able to collect their full financial compensation. Indemnification of former political prisoners falls under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Justice, which does not have sufficient personnel for the swift processing of applications. Some 70,000 people unjustly sentenced in political trials in over four decades of Communist rule have been rehabilitated already in the Czech lands and 20,000 in Slovakia. Only 430 of them have received financial compensation.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders Welcome Hostage Release; Opinions Vary on Whether War Threat Eased
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with new Major, Churkin quotes. Pickup 9th graf, `Israeli Prime ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: World leaders welcomed Iraq's decision today to free all foreign hostages but demanded it take the next step and withdraw from Kuwait. Only Iran and the PLO failed to temper their applause by urging Iraq to undo the damage done by its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. European stock and oil markets were quiet following the Iraqi parliament's approval today of Saddam Hussein's decision. Dealers said the markets had already reacted to the Iraqi president's announcement Thursday and noted the parliament has never vetoed one of his recommendations. British Prime Minister John Major said: ``Saddam Hussein has a lot more to do in terms of U.N. Security Council resolutions and the international community will require him to do it all.'' The whole world believes that Saddam should ``disgorge Kuwait, release hostages and make reparations for what he has done,'' Major told BBC radio. President Bush also said Saddam's announcement ``would be welcome if true, but it will not change my thinking on his need to comply 100 percent, without condition, to the U.N. resolutions'' that demand an Iraqi pull out from Kuwait. Bush spoke in Chile, one stop on his South American tour. Last week, the U.N. Security Council authorized the use of force against Iraq after Jan. 15 if a pullout does not occur. An estimated 900 Americans and 1,300 Britons are among the more than 3,000 Westerners still in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Iraqi officials said the foreigners could begin leaving Saturday. Nearly 250 Soviets freed from Iraq arrived aboard an Aeroflot jetliner in Moscow today. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin welcomed the release and Saddam's promise Thursday. The decision ``helps eliminate one of the burning issues that arose as a result of the gulf conflict,'' Churkin said. But he hoped ``the Iraqi leadership will take futher steps toward ... the implementation of all provisions of the U.N. Security Council's resolutions.'' Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, speaking in London, said Iraq should not be rewarded for releasing hostages. ``The taking of hostages was an outrageous act of a dictatorial power and now he (Saddam) is maybe going to release them and he wants to be paid for it,'' Shamir told BBC radio. In Oslo, Norwegian Foreign Minister Thorvald Stoltenberg said the release ``is an acknowledgement that taking of hostages does not aid the solving of conflicts.'' Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati, speaking in Paris, welcomed the release of hostages and said Iran is still opposed to the presence of foreign troops in the region. ``We think that the security of the region should be assured by the countries of the region.'' Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat, speaking in Tunis, said Iraq's ``courageous decision will create a favorable atmosphere to a peaceful and political solution to the gulf crisis.'' Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said he hoped Saddam's move was a first step toward a peaceful resolution of the crisis. But the London newspaper The Daily Telegraph commented today: ``The tone of his (Saddam's) remarks gave little cause for hope that the likelihood of military action had significantly receded.'' Some military analysts said a decision to attack Iraqi forces would be made easier with all the foreigners out of Iraq. Michael Dewar, deputy director of the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies, was quoted by The Daily Telegraph as saying: ``It allows airmen to strike (Iraqi) targets with a totally clear conscience.'' Some of the foreign hostages had been held as ``human shields'' at strategic sites in Iraq and Kuwait in order to deter any attack by the U.S.-led multinational force in the gulf. In Baghdad, as news spread of Saddam's announcement, the mood turned to elation among the hostages and some family members who had come to the Iraqi capital to plead for their loved ones' release. ``I feel delirious that I can leave,'' said David Farington, a British worker trapped in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Officials Deny U.S. Charge of Stockpiling Oil
DOC.TEXT: Japanese officials today denied accusations by a senior U.S. Energy Department official that Japan has been hoarding crude oil in defiance of an agreement among major consuming nations to draw down stockpiles. ``This is a complete misunderstanding,'' a senior government official said. ``We are not stockpiling.'' Linda Stuntz, a U.S. Energy Department under secretary for policy and planning, told reporters in Washington that in the months following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Japan increased imports to meet additional demand instead of drawing down stocks. She noted that Japan imported 33 percent more oil in October than it did in July, and said such actions raised doubts about future cooperative activities among consuming nations in response to oil supply shocks. The United States and other consumer nations have sought to ease the immediate shock of losing 4.3 million barrels of oil a day as a result of the Iraqi invasion by minimizing imports. Stockpiling oil would contradict such efforts and would put upward pressure on oil prices. Officials in Japan's Foreign Ministry and the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said that instead of increasing stocks as planned, Japanese oil companies had actually drawn down stocks. Increased imports, however, were needed during cool winter months to compensate for higher demand for heating fuel. ``The amount of oil imported by Japan fluctuates by 20 to 30 percent every month, depending on seasonal factors. Every year it's exactly the same pattern,'' said the government official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Stuntz's charge that Japan was betraying other oil consuming nations by not drawing down its 142-day emergency supply disregarded the fact that the United States is the only country that has tried to rely on existing stocks, officials said. ``No other country has drawn from its emergency stock, and there's no reason why Japan should,'' the government official said. ``I can't imagine why she's saying that. It's a complete mistake,'' he said. ``Since August, our stocks have been kept at a 142-day supply.'' In fact, the level of the stockpile increased slightly between June and October, the most recent month for which statistics are available. But the growth, from a total of 33.7 million kiloliters to 33.9 million kiloliters, or about one-third of Japan's daily consumption, isn't considered significant. Japan also has increased crude oil imports to a certain extent to compensate for shortfalls in supplies of refined oil products due to the loss of Kuwait's refining system, industry sources noted. ``We've brought in more oil, but less product,'' said Naoki Kuroda, director general of the international trade and industry ministry's petroleum department. Japan imports nearly all the oil it uses, and 70 percent of its oil imports come from the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Governor Defends DeConcini
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: Arizona Gov. Rose Mofford defended Sen. Dennis DeConcini before the Senate Ethics Committee today, describing him as a tireless worker for constituents who tried to help an important employer in his state. Mofford testified as a character witness in the ethics panel's hearings into the so-called Keating Five senators. The Democratic governor said she had known DeConcini since he was a 10-year-old church altar boy. As a three-term senator, she said, he has built a reputation for getting things done for constitutents with problems. ``Dennis, better than any official I know, works at making the system work for constituents,'' she said. ``Many people in Arizona, I'd say tens of thousands of people with problems in government, they'd say, `Call Dennis','' she said. Mofford testified for less than 20 minutes, and the ethics panel adjourned its hearings for the weekend following her appearance. DeConcini and the other senators face allegations they improperly intervened with regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., an Arizona businessman with a savings and loan based in California. Keating donated some $1.3 million to the campaigns and poltical causes of the five. Mofford said that at the time DeConcini helped Keating, Keating was running a large business that was an important employer in the state. ``He was considered a very successful businessman and very charitable,'' she said of Keating. His business, she said, seemed to be ``a secure investment.'' On Thursday, William K. Black ended two days as a witness, standing firmly by his allegations of political pressure by the so-called Keating Five senators in the face of skeptical questioning from members of the panel. Black said he and three other regulators, in a meeting with the senators, used definitive statements to describe practices at Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan. He said the lawmakers were told the Irvine, Calif., thrift had made massive loans without credit checks, was ``flying blind,'' had ``incompetent'' management and was courting failure. But, he said, the senators would not accept their warning that Lincoln was an institution they should avoid. ``They were listening and were coming back with defense after defense after defense of Lincoln, despite us laying out in starkest terms ... exactly what was wrong,'' Black said in response to questions by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. ``It didn't impress them,'' Black said. After a two-hour closed session Thursday, the committee disclosed a new schedule that could prolong the hearings into January. The panel plans to offer limited use immunity to compel the testimony of Keating's former lobbyist and top aide, James Grogan. Committee Vice Chairman Warren Rudman, R-N.H., said Grogan would produce documents in private next Wednesday and would undergo questioning in closed session on Dec. 17. The senators under scrutiny could begin testifying the next day, but delays could push that after Christmas or into January. Besides DeConcini, the senators under investigation are Arizona Republican John McCain and Democrats John Glenn of Ohio, Alan Cranston of California and Donald Riegle of Michigan. Under cross-examination by attorneys for the five senators, Black blamed the lawmakers' pressure for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's decision in 1988 to take San Francisco-based regulators off the examination of Lincoln. The exam would have disclosed phony transactions and a ``tax-sharing scam'' that sent false profits to Lincoln's parent company, he said. ``This is the most likely explanation for this completely unprecedented and grossly improper action of halting the examination that would have blown all of these thing so wide open,'' said Black, allawyer with the bank board. Black was questioned by members of the panel about an earlier meeting he and the San Francisco-based regulators held with the senators on April 9, 1987. He testified the regulators said, in effect, ``This is not the place you want to touch, not with a 10-foot pole, not with a 20-foot pole.'' He said that by the end of the meeting, Riegle ``had gotten the message,'' but that Cranston and DeConcini appeared not to have. Both later made contacts with regulators on behalf of Keating's effort to avoid some regulatory controls and eventually to sell his thrift rather than have it taken over by the federal government. Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., the Ethics Committee chairman, questioned Black about notes he took of the meeting. He suggested that the regulators' references that Lincoln's problems could be worked out could be viewed as an invitation to negotiate. ``We're talking about improper conduct,'' Heflin said, ``and one of the things about improper conduct is the senators should not go in and try to negotiate with you, and then it appears to me the regulators originate that.'' After similar skeptical questioning by Helms and Sens. David Pryor, D-Ark., and Terry Sanford, D-N.C., another member of the panel offered support for Black. Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., told Black he had been an impressive witness, adding, ``You're obviously very capable and I have been greatly influenced by what you had to say.''

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Campaign Officially Ends
With PM-Poland-Unraveling Stan
DOC.TEXT: Poland's first popular presidential campaign officially ended today with Lech Walesa sitting on a big lead in the polls and his challenger looking for votes among Walesa's rivals. The free-wheeling foray into democracy by law had to close at noon - allowing voters a day and a half to make up their minds. Businessman Stanislaw Tyminski, who had threatened to reveal compromising documents about Walesa, refused any such disclosures at a Thursday night news conference despite hammering questions by Polish and Western journalists. He said he would reveal what he had only at a rally today in the Baltic port of Szczecin, ``among friends.'' However, no such disclosure occurred. As he did Thursday night, Tyminski opened the now-infamous black briefcase in which he has said he carries the materials and pulled out a copy of a western news magazine interview with Walesa, Solidarity's chairman. He said: ``I cannot show all the documents because it would be harmful for our country. I have got more. This (magazine interview) is the most important document, our country's future depends on it.'' Walesa has denied that any such documents could exist, while demanding that Tyminski make known anything he claims to have. In the magazine interview, he warns civil unrest, possibly including a coup, would likely develop when Tyminski was unable to fulfill his promises for speedy economic improvement. Tyminski, who defeated Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki in the first round of voting, also said he would not leave the country regardless of the outcome of the election, and that the 1981 Communist martial-law repression of Solidarity was ``necessary.'' Also today, Poland's powerful Roman Catholic Primate Jozef Glemp said after meeting with Polish-born Pope John Paul II in Rome: ``The Polish church will side with Walesa. ... This is not a political decision but a decision based on the certainty of being in the best interests of the common good for the whole country.'' Polls open at 6 a.m. Sunday and close at 8 p.m. for the country's 27 million eligible voters. Exit surveys by state television in partnership with the German polling service Infas are expected to give reliable projections within minutes after voting stops. Full unofficial returns are expected Monday. Tyminski, duplicating his first election round pattern of campaigning to the last minute, attended a 10 a.m. rally in Szczecin, the formerly German city in extreme northwest Poland 325 miles from Warsaw. The emigre Tyminski was greeted by chants of ``Lech Walesa!'' and ``Back to Peru!'' when he arrived at the rally attended by 4,000 to 5,000 people in a sports hall. Supporters' applause was mixed with boos and whistles from the several hundred Walesa fans present. ``Tarzan from Peru for president of the Polish People's Republic,'' said one tongue-in-cheek banner carried by the Walesa camp, referring to the former Communist name for Poland. Outside the arena, some young people dressed up in ``pseudo-Peruvian'' style collected donations ``for the protection of sacred dogs,'' the PAP news agency said. It was a spoof of ``Sacred Dogs,'' Tyminski's self-published book of political and economic philosophy co-written with a longtime Communist Party journalist. Polls released as the campaign ended gave Walesa commanding majorities. The last state television poll, conducted Monday and Tuesday, said Walesa had a 73 percent to 16 percent advantage. Two other polls put the margin at 58 percent to 23 percent and 61 percent to 20 percent. Pollsters advised, however, that the surveys be treated cautiously because they felt many were reluctant to admit even in an anonymous poll that they support Tyminski.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Awaits U.S. Reply on Mideast Conference
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with postponement of meeting, Pickering still in discussions with U.S. officials. Pickup 6th pvs, `The draft...' Security Council meeting expected around 4 p.m. EST, no vote expected.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Security Council ambassadors today awaited a U.S. reply on a draft resolution approving of a peace conference on the Palestinian problem - Iraq's key demand for solving the Kuwait crisis. American officials said U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering was still consulting with other ambassadors and with Washington this morning. The timing of the introduction of the resolution, after meetings among U.N. ambassadors Thursday, promised to complicate U.S.-Israeli relations. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, flying to the United States today to start an American tour, said in London that ``Israel will not agree to any foreign body deciding its future and fate.'' ``Precisely because of our consistent position that we will not link the gulf crisis and the Arab-Israeli dispute, this is certainly not an appropriate time for an international conference,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said. The United States will not give Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``some face-saving way out of something he shouldn't have gotten into in the first place,'' Bush told reporters in Chile. The council was supposed to meet late this morning, but postponed the meeting until the afternoon, with no explanation. There was no assurance that the meeting would actually be held later. The draft resolution was approved in principle Wednesday by the permanent five Security Council members - the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France and China. But President Bush's spokesman said Washington was making changes in the language of the resolution. U.S. officials said the changes did not alter the basic thrust of the draft. ``We're trying to work out language that is acceptable, that meets our policy. Obviously the U.N. wants to speak to this issue,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, in Santiago, Chile. In Baghdad, the parliament today approved Saddam's request to free all foreign hostages. His request made on Thursday came just hours after the text of the draft resolution was widely reported, but it was not clear he was aware of it. Baghdad wants to send all the hostages home by Christmas, Iraq's U.N. ambassador said Thursday. ``Definitely, we would like to see everyone with his family by Christmas, because that is a very joyous and happy occasion, and it is time for family reunions,'' said Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari. The release of hostages has been a main demand of the Security Council, which has passed 12 resolutions condemning Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and authorizing economic sanctions and force to end the occupation. The ``working paper'' agreed to Wednesday by the permanent Security Council members ``considers that the convening at an appropriate time of an international peace conference on the Middle East.'' The paper says talks that are ``properly structured, with the participation of the parties concerned, would facilitate the achievement of a comprehensive settlement and lasting peace in the Middle East.'' The problem of a homeland for the Palestinians would be central to any such peace settlement. But the text contains numerous loopholes that would allow Israel to delay or abort the process. The clause requiring ``the participation of the parties concerned'' gives Israel virtual veto power over the conference. Saddam proposed on Aug. 12, 10 days after his troops conquered Kuwait, that he would link a solution of the Palestinian homeland question to any withdrawal of his army from the emirate.

DOC.HEAD: Brilliant Predawn Flash Of Light In Sky Seen Over Michigan, Kentucky, Ohio
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of people in southern Michigan, Kentucky and Ohio say they saw a bright green and blue light flash across the sky this morning before the thing, possibly a meteor, seemed to explode. ``Whatever it is, it could have been 200 miles south of us, but it was huge,'' Mike Dennis of Rockford, north of Grand Rapids, told WCUZ radio after spotting the light about 5:45 a.m. EST. ``I've never seen anything like it.'' Dennis Dixon, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service in Ann Arbor, said there were no reports of meteor showers or other activity that could account for the sightings. He said the weather service was unaware of the incident. But Maj. Thomas Niemann, a spokesman at the U.S. Space Command in Colorado Springs, Colo., said the agency believes the object was of ``other-than-Earth origin.'' He said the center tracks about 6,700 satellites, none of which was responsible for the flash. He said it probably was a meteor. ``It's been our experience that when you get that color it's of other-than-Earth origin,'' he said. ``That's what astronomers around the country have told me.'' William Spencer of Southfield, a Detroit suburb, said he saw the light on his way to work in Wayne County's Plymouth Township. ``It was a big bluish-green ball of light and it had a train of yellow sparks behind it. I thought it was a helicopter, it was moving fast. ``It was coming down at a high rate of speed. Then it just disappeared. I thought it had crashed.'' In Ohio, the flash was reported by callers from Cincinnati to Toledo. Reports also were received in Louisville, Ky. Officials at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., and the U.S. Naval Observatory in Washington said they had no information about satellites or other manmade space objects crashing to Earth.

When the Chicago Bears had to look elsewhere because Neal Anderson couldn't gain ground up the middle last week, they didn't turn away from their star halfback. Instead, Anderson showed how important he is to the Bears' offense by lining up as a wide receiver and catching a 50-yard touchdown pass that beat the Detroit Lions in overtime. He doesn't get the attention some other backs receive, but Anderson has quietly become the star of Chicago's offense, as important to his 10-2 team as Walter Payton and Gale Sayers were to the Bear teams of the past. ``As far as complete backs go, I think I have to be ranked at the top,'' Anderson said this week as the Bears prepared to play the Washington Redskins (7-5) Sunday at RFK Stadium. The game is more important to the Redskins, who are in the thick of the NFC's wild-card race. Chicago has already clinched the NFC Central Division title and is playing for the home field advantage in the playoffs. ``I hope everybody's professional and knows we've still got to go out and play,'' said Anderson, who is 34 yards short of 4,000 yards rushing for his career. ``Nobody feels like we're going to ease up. There are a lot of things still on the line.'' Anderson, in his fifth year in the NFL, hasn't eased up yet this season. He is second in the NFL with 1,298 total yards from scrimmage, leading a rushing attack that has gained a league-best 1,972 yards and is one of the chief reasons Chicago has rebounded last season's 6-10 mediocrity. The Bears are averaging 164.3 yards a game rushing, well above the league average of 112.7. While other ground games are faltering, Chicago is the only team to have more yards rushing than passing. In these days of run-and-shoot offenses, the Bears hand the ball off 37 times a game, control the ball for more than 34 minutes a game and pound out wins in what coach Mike Ditka calls a ``blue collar'' way. The Redskins have had trouble against the run all year, at least until they held Miami to 34 yards rushing in a 42-20 victory last week. Holding Anderson to 27 yards on 13 carries was key to the Redskins' 38-14 win over the Bears last year. ``Chicago pounds at you until they hit a big play,'' said coach Joe Gibbs. ``If you can't stop the run, it's going to be a long day.'' Anderson has been just about the whole story of the Bears' offense. He is second to fullback Brad Muster with 37 receptions and leads the team with 445 yards receiving. Second to Detroit's Barry Sanders with 853 yards rushing on 216 carries, he is 147 yards short of his third straight 1,000-yard year on the ground. He is fourth on the Bears all-time rushing list and 14th on their all-time receiving list. When the going got tough against Detroit last week, it was Anderson who shouted on the sidelines in overtime that he could get open from a wide receiver's slot. ``It doesn't take a rocket scientist to know we like to run,'' said Anderson. ``Teams have stacked things up trying to stop the run, but we expect to get our yards. Teams are putting eight men on the line, but we're spreading things out.'' There were doubts around the league that Anderson could carry the load as the successor to the legendary Payton in the Chicago backfield. He was a first-round draft choice after setting collegiate records at Florida (since broken by Cowboy Emmitt Smith), but he was the next-to-last pick in the first round. Other backs went before him and younger players like Smith and Sanders get more press. ``I feel fortunate to have come here,'' he said. ``I have other friends who have been in losing situations and that's not fun. ``I just go out and play like Neal Anderson can play. The guys in this organization know what I can do. They made me the highest paid running back in the league in the off-season, so I'm content where I am,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Black Movements Hold Major Conferences
DOC.TEXT: Two black anti-apartheid movements, the conservative Inkatha Freedom Party and the militant Pan Africanist Congress, opened separate meetings today to respond to rapid political changes. The Pan Africanist Congress has said it opposes negotiations with South Africa's white-led government, but is expected to review that policy at the weekend conference, its first inside South Africa in three decades. The group has said that it will only negotiate the handover of power from whites to blacks, and wants no part of talks on black-white power sharing as proposed by President F.W. de Klerk. The Pan Africanists, who advocate black self-reliance in the struggle for political rights, were banned in 1960 and legalized in February by President F.W. de Klerk. Some Pan Africanist members chanted ``Down With Negotiations!'' before the party opened its meeting at a recreation center in Soweto, the huge black township outside Johannesburg. Zeph Mothopeng, leader of the Pan Africanists, died in October. The group plans to select a new leader this weekend. Clarence Makwetu, the acting president, is considered the favorite. In his opening address, Makwetu said reforms by de Klerk's government were of ``no consequence.'' ``They are merely intending to reform apartheid,'' Makwetu said of the government. ``We say apartheid cannot be reformed but must be totally destroyed.'' The Inkatha Freedom Party met in Ulundi, the capital of the KwaZulu black homeland, to adopt a party constitution. Of the major black political groups, Inkatha is the most conservative. Its leader, Mangosuthu Buthelezi, supports capitalism, opposes economic sanctions against South Africa and has never supported violence against the government. The National Party, which has ruled South Africa since 1948, has hinted it may seek an alliance with Inkatha. Buthelezi says he is ready to participate in talks with the government on ending apartheid. The country's largest black political movement, the African National Congress, is scheduled to hold a major conference Dec. 14-16. De Klerk wants to open talks early next year on a new constitution that will extend political rights to blacks and allow the 5 million whites and 30 million blacks to share power.

DOC.HEAD: Burma Arrests 48 for Allegedly Planning Parallel Government
DOC.TEXT: The military junta has arrested 48 members of the opposition National League for Democracy in recent days for planning to establish a shadow government, a senior military official said today. The opposition movement overwhelmingly won popular elections in May, but the military has refused to turn over power. The senior official, Maj. Gen. Khin Nyunt, also said 77 Buddhist monks in Mandalay, the nation's religious center and second largest city, have been arrested for anti-government activities. He said documents seized from the National League for Democracy's headquarters in Rangoon showed it planned to hold a meeting of at least 250 of its members in Mandalay or the capital. At that meeting, he said, the League planned to adopt a national constitution and declare a temporary, parallel government that would seek recognition from the United Nations, the United States, European nations, Australia, India, Thailand and Singapore. The documents also show the League planned to organize a strike to disrupt transportation and paralyze the government, Khin Nyunt told a news conference. He showed reporters photographs of 48 party members arrested in connection with the plan. Fourteen others remain at large, he said. The government came to power in September 1988 by killing hundreds of unarmed pro-democracy demonstrators. It already has arrested dozens of opposition figures, and international human rights groups have accused it of rights abuses. The National League for Democracy's two main leaders, Aung San Suu Kyi and Tin Oo, have been detained for more than a year. On Wednesday, the state press said seven opposition members had fled to avoid prosecution for having discussed forming a shadow government. Five of the seven were members of the National League for Democracy, it said. All had won parliamentary seats in the May election. Khin Nyunt also said 80 members of the outlawed Burma Communist Party had been arrested. He did not say when. The government frequently has alleged Communist connections to activities by other opposition groups. The general alleged without elaborating that one monk, known as Yewata, had met with a U.S. Embassy official to discuss organizing nationwide protests. The government often accuses embassies of helping the opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Infamous Child Molester Released From Jail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7-8th grafs, `News of...', with 3 grafs to CORRECT `impending parole' to `impending release,' clarify reasons why release was not a parole. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Stephen Bakker...'.
DOC.TEXT: A man imprisoned since 1984 for kidnapping and sexually assaulting a 3-year-old girl and then leaving her for dead in an outhouse pit was released from prison today. Robert Thiret, whose release Gov. Roy Romer tried in vain to block, did not speak as he and his attorney emerged from the facility and got into a van. His destination was not known. Colorado law requires Thiret to be set free - no parole, no probation, no restrictions, even though authorities have said they still consider him a menace, and psychologists say he's made ``minimal'' progress in therapy. Thiret, 28, was convicted of snatching a 3-year-old girl in Sheridan in 1983. She was found alive three days later in an outhouse pit at a campground 20 miles west of Denver near Genesee. She had been sexually assaulted and left for dead. Thiret has been at the Jefferson County Sheriff's Complex, where he was serving a six-month sentence for telephone harassment after getting out of the state penitentiary where he served six years of a 10-year sentence for attempted murder and sexual assault on a child. Onlookers who had shown up at the jail to watch Thiret's release were urged to leave by sheriff's officials. News of Thiret's impending release had angered residents and led Romer to criticize state parole law. Thiret was up for parole in 1989, but public pressure pushed authorities to continue to hold him. In May, the Colorado Supreme Court ruled that because of the delay, under the law in effect at the time of the attack Thiret had to be freed - not paroled. On June 23, Thiret was transferred from state prison to the Jefferson County Jail to serve the harassment sentence. Stephen Bakker, a rescue volunteer who carried Thiret's shivering victim from the outhouse pit, questioned why he should be released from jail. ``I just don't believe anybody who could do something like that to a little girl is going to change just by being in jail,'' Bakker said. Bakker said he still can see the 3-year-old girl, wearing only her underwear, shivering in the outhouse pit where she had been left for dead. ``I don't see how anybody could do that to a child - just leaving her in a pit like that,'' he said. ``She was disoriented. She was just looking for something warm to hold onto. As soon as I touched her, she grabbed me and held on until I pulled her out.'' The girl recovered.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Parliament Endorses Saddam Request To Free Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2 grafs after 3rd pvs, `It freed...' to UPDATE with Washington asking Iraq to waive visa requirements. Pickup 4th, `At the...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American hostages raised beer mugs to toast their impending freedom today after parliament overwhelmingly approved Saddam Hussein's decision to free all foreigners trapped by the Persian Gulf crisis. The 250-member National Assembly, which has no record of ever defying Saddam, passed the measure with a vote of 232-18, reporters said. It freed more than 8,000 Westerners, East Europeans and Japanese stranded by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Officials said foreigners would be allowed to begin leaving as early as Saturday. In Washington, State Department officials said they have asked Iraq to waive the exit visas but hadn't heard a response. The officials say they are also awaiting answers from Baghdad regarding other departure arrangements for the Americans. Contingency plans have been made to charter airplanes, but no schedule has yet been made. At the downtown Mansour-Melia Hotel, which has become known as Hostage Central, 50 American and British hostages hugged and kissed each other and clinked their beer mugs together to celebrate their impending release. ``This is it. We're all free,'' one hostage shouted when a reporter told him of the Parliament vote. In the past, hostages have been gathered at the Mansour-Melia Hotel before transportation to strategic sites to serve as ``human shields.'' It is also where they have been taken to meet visiting relatives. About 600 Americans, Britons and Japanese have been held at strategic sites to deter attack by the 350,000-strong, U.S.-led multinational forces arrayed against Iraq in the Persian Gulf to force Baghdad from Kuwait. ``It is a monumental occasion,'' said Robert Vinton, a businessman from Santa Fe, N.M. He was taken to the hotel Wednesday to see his wife, Sue. She had flown in with several American and British women to appeal for the release of their husbands, sons and fathers. Vinton, 58, said he was picked up in Kuwait and taken to a military installation 20 miles south of Baghdad. He said he and other hostages there were treated ``as well as may be expected.'' Ronald Ginn, 49, a computer consultant from Seattle who had been living in Kuwait before the invasion said: ``My main complaint was the loss of freedom.'' He said he had been held at two communications centers in Baghdad. Ginn said his house in Kuwait was stripped clean after the invasion and estimated he had lost $80,000 worth of property. An estimated 2,000 foreigners remain in hiding in Kuwait for fear of detention as ``human shields'' at potential targets. The National Assembly decision meant the foreigners could apply for exit permits, a process that could take several days to complete. Iraqi officials said, however, the evacuation might begin as early as Saturday, indicating authorities planned to speed up the procedure. ``If they waive the (exit) visa requirement, I guarantee we'll get them out as fast as we possibly can,'' U.S. Charge d'Affaires Joseph Wilson said after the parliament vote. Officials said flights would be added to the daily Iraqi Airways trip to Amman, Jordan, the airline's only regular destination since the United Nations imposed economic sanctions on Iraq because of the invasion. Countries wishing to send special flights to Baghdad to retrieve their nationals must first get clearance from the U.N. sanctions committee, the officials said. A British Airways jet stocked with champagne left London for the Middle East today to pick up hostages. Planes were also being prepared in Denmark and Japan. Dutch officials said they expected to send a flight next week. In London, a spokesman for British Airways said the plane had left for Baghdad but was awaiting approval to land from the U.N. Sanctions Committee and Iraqi officials. Without approval the plane would be diverted to Amman. In New York, Iraq's U.N. ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari said Baghdad wants all the hostages it has been holding to be home by Christmas. The Iraqi ambassador said it might speed the release of detainees if the United States sent planes to Jordan to pick them up. ``It is a matter of logistical things,'' he said. Saddam on Thursday urged parliament to end the travel ban on foreigners in a letter to assembly speaker Saleh. Saddam said their internment was meant to ``delay war'' and give the Iraqi troops occupying Kuwait time to complete mobilization. Now that they have done so, Saddam said, there was no longer any need for the hostages. He also noted that recent diplomatic overtures indicated ``positive changes'' in the international standoff against Iraq, and said the release of hostages would encourage such trends. In all, there are 2 million foreigners in Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Asians and Arabs who make up the majority of the foreigners who were free to leave. Meanwhile, nearly 250 Soviets freed from Iraq arrived aboard an Aeroflot jetliner in Moscow today. Iraq freed Soviet nationals after the Kremlin indicated it might use force against Iraq if its citizens were harmed.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Gabel, A Figure In Bess Myerson Case, Dies at 77
DOC.TEXT: Hortense Gabel, a prominent judge and social reformer whose career was marred by her involvement in the Bess Myerson conflict-of-interest case, died early today. She was 77. Mrs. Gabel, who died at her Upper East Side apartment, had long been in poor health and had suffered a number of minor strokes this year, according to her accountant, Edward Speer. She was a leader in the fight against racial discrimination in housing in the years after World War II, serving as executive director of the Committee on Discrimination in Housing, a coalition of religious and civil rights groups. More recently, she was a judge in state Supreme Court - New York's trial-level court - from 1976 until her resignation in 1987. The following year, a federal jury acquitted her of charges that she improperly helped her daughter get a job in the office of Ms. Myerson, the city's cultural affairs commissioner. Gabel had been accused of influencing Ms. Myerson, a former Miss America and prominent New York political figure, by making rulings favorable to Ms. Myerson's boyfriend in a divorce case. Despite her anger that the case came to trial, ``She was very gratified by the result,'' a friend, Roma Connable, said today. ``She felt she had been vindicated.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel and Latvia to Initiate Charter Flights
