DOC.TEXT: Israel and Latvia are planning to begin twice-monthly charter flights for tourists between Riga and Tel Aviv, the Tass news agency said Friday. Sponsors of the project on the Latvian side include the Latpas production and marketing association, the U.S.S.R. Ministry of Civil Aviation, and Latvian civil aviation officials, Tass said. Other sponsors are the Israeli companies El Al and Marpaz, with assistance from Link-Service of the United States, the news agency said. Tass said there are plans for two charter flights per month until next spring.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion Destroys Vacation Apartments
DOC.TEXT: A dozen masked men tied up three people at a a vacation complex early Friday and blew up 10 apartments, police reported. No group claimed responsibility, but the attack bore the hallmark of the separatist Corsican National Liberation Front, which views tourism as colonization by mainland France. Police reported that the gang shook the owner Robert Monvosin, his son, and the superintendent out of their sleep and tied them up in the back of a van. The men, wearing ski masks, then scattered about 60 bottles of gas throughout the complex and exploded them, destroying most of the apartments. There were no vacationers present. The attack took place at Lumio, south of Bastia, the second-largest town on this French island in the Mediterranean. The separatist movement has engaged in a decade-long campaign of bombing villas, hotels and vacation complexes, especially those owned by non-Corsicans.

DOC.HEAD: Thai Airways Employees Seized with Heroin
DOC.TEXT: Two employees of Thailand's national airline were arrested Friday with about 100 pounds of heroin hidden in two suitcases, police said. The two were arrested in the parking lot of the domestic terminal of Bangkok's airport, according to the Narcotics Control Board. The suspects were identified as Prakai Thongdee, 33, and Suthep Chuenchoop, 36, but their exact positions with Thai Airways International were not given. Narcotics officials say a vast amount of heroin is smuggled from Thailand by air and sea to the United States, Europe, Australia and other Asian points. Most of the narcotics originate in the so-called Golden Triangle of northern Thailand, Burma and Laos where warlords refine opium into heroin and smuggle it out through numerous illegal connections.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Astronauts Resume Troubled Star-Gazing Mission, Talk To Classes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to fix typo in `and.' SUBS 12th graf, `The other...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with detail from Q-and-A session. Picks up 13th graf, `Meanwhile, the...'. SUBS 17th graf pvs, `That's what..', to delete now-redundant first reference to Parker.
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's astronauts were back star-gazing today after scientists on the ground fired up the $150 million Astro observatory, which has been crippled by repeated malfunctions. While two astronomers aboard the shuttle helped ground teams guide the telescopes, two other crew members conducted a live science lesson this morning for middle school students at two NASA centers. ``You may have heard of some of the problems we've been having,'' astronaut Jeffrey Hoffman told the youngsters. ``It's been quite an interesting and dynamic mission.'' Troubles have persisted throughout the mission and have forced the astronauts to skip more than 100 planned observations. About 250 celestial targets were to have been studied. The latest problem occurred Thursday when a backup computer terminal aboard the spacecraft that had been running the observatory's three ultraviolet telescopes overheated and shut down. The other computer terminal failed Sunday. Lint, which can accumulate from such items as astronauts' clothing, paper products and hand towels on the shuttle, was found clogging the air vents of the first failed terminal, flight director Gary Coen said. He said the second terminal hadn't been fully inspected yet. Coen said the cause of the computer failures has not been determined and he didn't know if it was connected to the lint buildup. Despite the setbacks, the crew proceeded with today's lesson, the first in what NASA hopes will become a regular science series for youngsters. Hoffman and Sam Durrance, before starting 12 hours of observation work, talked to the students for more than a half-hour about star formation and the many different kinds of radiation emitted from celestial objects. To mark his debut as a teacher, Hoffman wore a dress shirt and tie - the first tie ever worn in space ``as far as I know,'' he said. ``I can tell you it works quite well. You have to be a little careful in zero gravity, as you can see,'' Hoffman said, pushing down his floating tie. The other astronomers on the seven-man crew - Robert Parker and Ron Parise - answered questions from the students later in the morning at the end of their work shift. Parise, in response to an Alabama boy's query, said it has been ``quite tedious and time-consuming'' trying to operate the observatory. Twelve students were at Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., and 29 were at Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. Other students were able to watch the presentations in their classrooms via cable television services. Meanwhile, the Astro observatory is being run by commands sent from the ground that guide the telescopes toward their desired targets. The astronauts, using a joystick and aided by information from the ground, can then zero in on an object. The process succeeded several times Thursday night and early today, giving scientists hope that many more observations can be made before Columbia's 10-day flight ends Tuesday. ``Our attitude here is that we've got a mode we feel is going to work and we're going to go get the science,'' mission manager Jack Jones said. But he added he didn't know yet how efficient the operation would be. Spacelab Mission Operations Control's John David Bartoe congratulated the astronauts this morning for obtaining ``fantastic'' observations of a quasar, one of the most distant objects in the universe. All three ultraviolet telescopes focused on the quasar for 51 minutes, three minutes longer than planned. ``That's what happens when you have good, old-fashioned astronomy ... and a little bit of help from your friends,'' Parker told Bartoe. A total of 187 observations were planned between late Sunday and Thursday morning, but only 70 were completed because of the computer malfunctions and other problems, said NASA spokeswoman Cindy Sanderson. Earlier this week, the astronauts missed precious viewing time because of trouble with the observatory's instrument-pointing system, which guides the three ultraviolet telescopes. The four astronomers on the flight often had to resort to manually guiding the telescopes. The observatory's X-ray telescope, which is operated by computer commands sent from Goddard Space Flight Center, was unaffected because it has its own pointing system. Moments before the backup computer terminal shut down Thursday, the crew smelled a burning odor similar to one that filled the cabin Sunday when the other terminal shut down. NASA tried to restart the first terminal after the lint was vacuumed from its filters, but the smell reappeared and Hoffman quickly shut it down. Controllers have not decided whether to try to restart the second terminal, Coen said. The problems were the latest for the mission, which had been delayed for six months this year because of shuttle fuel leaks and other telescope problems. The mission had originally been scheduled for 1986 but was postponed after the Challenger accident.

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Steal Diplomatic Pouches from U.S. Consulate Van
DOC.TEXT: Thieves hijacked a van carrying U.S. Consulate documents and stole eight diplomatic pouches, police said Friday. Police spokesman Helio Mazzeo said 12 men armed with shotguns and submachine guns intercepted the van Wednesday on its way to the consulate from Rio's Galeao Airport. The driver and two consulate employees were released unhurt, he said. The van, missing the diplomatic pouches, was found the next day in a street on Rio's poor north side. ``We're working with two hypotheses: either it was a simple robbery or it had other, possibly political, motives,'' Mazzeo said. He did not elaborate. Mazzeo said the pouches, containing documents, were part of a routine diplomatic shipment from Brasilia, the nation's capital. The content of the documents was not known, he said. The U.S. Consulate refused to comment on the robbery. The local press speculated the robbers were looking for dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Train Crashes Into Truck; 30 Injured
DOC.TEXT: A train crowded with students going to school crashed into a truck at an unmarked crossing Friday, injuring about 30 people, none seriously, officials said. It was the second accident in two days involving school children. On Thursday, a military jet crashed into a high school in a suburb of Bologna, killing 12 students and injuring 87 other people. Friday's incident occurred at an unmarked crossing on the outskirts of this city on the southern coast of the Italian island. Police said the train was carrying 374 passengers, many of them students. The locomotive and one of the four passenger cars derailed following the impact. About 30 people were taken to hospitals, and nearly all were released after treatment.

DOC.BYLINE: Wood or Plastic? What's an Environmentalist Supposed To Trim? ^By CHARLES CAMPBELL
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists are facing their annual Christmas quandary: reusable plastic or recyclable wood? ``The artificial Christmas tree represents a bit of a dilemma for green consumers,'' said Joel Makower, publisher of the monthly Green Consumer Letter. ``It seems phony and far from ecological, but it is a reusable thing and eliminates cutting a tree and sending it to a landfill.'' Some people, of course, have no doubts about which tree to choose. ``A real tree equals a real Christmas,'' said Jeanne Weiss, spokeswoman for the National Christmas Tree Association in Milwaukee, Wis. ``Real trees are recyclable, they're a renewable resource and biodegradable, whereas fake trees are generally made out of petroleum byproducts and metal,'' she said. Christmas trees are farmed on about a million of acres of land in all 50 states, taking seven to 15 years to grow to suitable height, the association said. Seedlings are planted to replace each year's harvest of about 36 million trees, very few of which come from wild forests any more. ``Personally, I wish people would buy more plastic trees because that's what I sell,'' says Meyer Stopol, vice president of New York's James A. Cole Inc., a major importer of artificial Christmas trees, nearly all of which come from the Far East. ``People today decorate much earlier at home. By the time Christmas comes, the (real) tree's dried out,'' he said, adding that the trees are put out as garbage after the holiday. Artificial trees, Stopol says, can last for many years. The truly committed may opt for a living, potted Christmas tree, plantable outdoors after the tinsel comes down. But that can be a lot of trouble, especially in parts of country where the ground may freeze by late December. ``Something like that takes planning,'' Ms. Weiss said. ``In some areas, it's not a viable option.'' Makower suggested hat a living indoor holiday tree need not resemble a towering forest pine. ``There's no question that having a live Christmas tree is the greenest thing to do,'' he said. ``A small potted plant will do.'' But not everyone will be ready to settle for trimming the schefflera or hanging spider plant. Environmentalists say the most important thing is making sure the tree doesn't just go into the trash after the holidays. Pine needles are good conditioners for some soils. The trunks can be cut up for garden stakes or shredded for mulch. And more and more nurseries and county parks departments are eager to accept dead Christmas trees to get the mulch. The Ikea home furnishing chain, which has six stores mostly on the East Coast, is even willing to lease a Christmas tree for $20. Mark Wells, operation manager for Ikea's outlet in Dale City, Va., said customers who bring back their tree on the first or second Saturday in January will get either a $10 refund plus their own mulch, or $20 toward a $100 purchase if they leave the mulch for Ikea to donate to the local parks department. ``We lose money on the deal,'' he said. ``But we're proud that we try to do something to help the environment.'' Makower said no one should think one tree a year is too small a matter to make a difference. ``If we've learned anything in the environmental movement, it's that we should celebrate the earth in everything we do, whether it's in celebrating Christmas, Hanukkah, or even the winter solstice,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Detroit Mayor Recorded Discussing Transfer of Secret Millions
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Coleman Young was recorded discussing how to legally declare as income millions of dollars he owned in real estate, diamonds and precious metals, according to a published report. He talked about the holdings in tape recordings secretly made by Kenneth Weiner, a former deputy police chief on trial for his alleged role in a scheme to defraud investors in a precious metals business, The Detroit News reported Thursday. Young and Weiner were partners in Detroit Technology and Investments Inc. Weiner also is a central figure in a federal investigation into the disappearance of more than $1 million from a Detroit Police Department fund. Police Chief William Hart has accused Weiner publicly of stealing from the fund. The tapes focus on Young's efforts to have the assets transferred to the company so they could be declared on his income taxes as income. The tapes don't indicate how Young acquired the assets or whether the transfers took place. ``No comment,'' Young spokesman Bob Berg said when asked about the tapes. Weiner made 75 secret recordings in 1986-87 while acting as an informant for FBI and Internal Revenue Service investigators in an effort to receive leniency for his role in the investment scheme. Federal agents later said Weiner was an unreliable informant and broke off their relationship with him in 1987. Young, who's black, has claimed repeatedly during his administration that he is the target of racially motivated government attempts to entrap him. He was first elected mayor in 1973. The tapes reveal that Young, 72, owned land worth more than $4 million at the time, and more than $1 million in gold coins, the newspaper said. U.S. District Court Judge John Feikens has given copies and transcripts of the tapes to lawyers in the fraud case and has said he will let some of the tapes be played in court. In one tape of a Feb. 19, 1987 discussion, Weiner asked Young what he wanted to do with up to $300,000 worth of gold coins he had in safety-deposit boxes. ``Hold it until such time that we can take credit for it,'' Young said according to a transcript printed by the news. ``You mean bringing it through the corporation?'' Weiner said. ``Mm-hmm,'' Young replied in affirmation.

DOC.HEAD: Whistle While You Work ... Walk ... Sleep ...
LaserPhoto NY31
DOC.TEXT: You know how to whistle, don't you? Just put a dome-shaped skyscraper together and let the wind blow. Case in point: the 72-story Cityspire. Wind whipping around the louvered top of the building, 800 feet above the street, emits a high-pitched wail that echoes for blocks through Manhattan's concrete canyons, city officials said Friday. ``From Third Avenue, down to the 40s, up to the 60s, over on the West Side - the calls have come from all over,'' said Ian Matthews of the city Department of Environmental Conservation.'' ``The callers said basically there's a noise, and it's driving me batty, and I don't know where it's coming from.'' On Wednesday, department investigators solved that last problem. After more than a month of searching, they zeroed in on the Cityspire at Seventh Avenue amd West 56th Street, went up to the roof, and found the eight-sided dome was wailing away. A summons was issued for violating the city noise control code. If the building is found guilty, a fine of $220 to $880 can be imposed. ``With the right winds, it becomes a big whistle,'' said Matthews. ``I don't know the acoustics, but it's a very loud, very big whistle. And if you lived in the neighborhood, it could drive you insane.'' Just ask Anthony Mazzola, editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar who lives two blocks from the building. The siren call sent him scurrying around the neighborhood, desperate to find its source. ``I've been all over the street trying to find the noise,'' said Mazzola. ``You think you're in a loony bin. You can't get away from it.'' Mazzola was not alone. The department received hundreds of complaints durring the past five weeks about the aggravating reverberation, Matthews said. This was news to the building's developer and its architect, who knew nothing of the alleged noise pollution. ``When somebody calls and says, `Your building's whistling' - I mean, hey, come on,'' said Howard Hornstein, the lawyer for building developer Ian Bruce Eichner. Hornstein said his side is waiting for a copy of the complaint before responding, although architect Sam Saccia of the architecture firm Murphy-Jahn in Chicago believes the whistling - if it exists - can be stopped. The sound doesn't occur every day; the wind must be coming in at the right speed. The largest number of complaints occurred around Veteran's Day, when the wind gusted to 30 mph, said Matthews. On Wednesday, gusts reached 23 mph. Reporters heard no buildings whistling on Friday, when the air was nearly calm. It's not the first time the Cityspire has drawn unwanted attention. When the building was completed, it stood 814 feet tall - 11 feet above a city-imposed limit. The ensuing controversy ended when developer Eichner agreed to construct more than 7,000 feet of dance space for non-profit groups in his building. Hornstein is beginning to wonder if it's all worth it. ``The point is, first we had the height issue, now we've got the whistling building, and I've been lawyering it through the whole thing,'' said Hornstein. ``I mean, really. The city approved these plans.''

DOC.HEAD: Troops Welcome Decision to Release Hostages, But Insist Kuwait Be Freed
With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's decision to release hostages is welcome news for U.S. troops, but they said Friday the Persian Gulf crisis won't be settled until Kuwait is freed and Saddam Hussein is stopped. ``I think it's all well and good, but I don't think we should leave here until this thing is resolved,'' said Senior Airman Ken Hardwick, 23, of Charleston, S.C. ``It's not about hostages. It's about Kuwait. If we don't get Kuwait back, then this guy's going to have the power to run over other countries. We've got to stop him before he goes any further,'' Hardwick said. Any progress toward a negotiated settlement is cheered by the troops who were first ordered to the Saudi Arabian desert four months ago by President Bush. But they noted that the hostage issue was only one of the conditions Bush set to resolve the crisis. ``I think the hostages were a bad side effect of this whole thing,'' said 1st Lt. Brian Ratchford, 26, of Spartenburg, S.C., and a member of the 39th Tactical Air Squadron. ``I don't want to go to war, but if we have to, I think it's better than the alternative of letting (Saddam) develop his nuclear weapons capabilities, which I see as the ultimate evil,'' he said. Most troops are suspicious of Saddam's motive and timing, especially since he once referred to hostages as ``guests'' and deployed them around military targets as human shields. ``Is it a signal that he is caving in or is it that he's trying to buy additional time to get support from someone else?'' asked 1st Sgt. Jerry Carlton, 37, of Warsaw, N.C., and a member of the Army's 82nd Airborne Division. However, Carlton added, ``I think it's a good gesture at Christmas time to give some hopes for all the troops and the families back home that we may be able to get back home.'' Other members of the 82nd Airborne, the first ground troops to arrive in Saudi Arabia, also distrusted the announcement. ``The majority of the people think it's a ploy to stall for time,'' said Spec. Mark Mattson, 30, of Port Huron, Mich. ``We need to play some hardball. If you don't knock him down, he's going to be even stronger.'' Soldiers who came here primed for battle have ridden a roller coaster of shifting emotions while diplomats have tried to settle the crisis with talk instead of bullets. ``If we can get the mission done without firing a shot, great. We'll pack up, he'll move out and we'll go home. Plain as that,'' said Army Sgt. Anthony Sikora, 24, of Chester, Pa. And Air Force Staff Sgt. Chester Smolarczyk, 28, of Jacksonville, Ark., said he's willing to wait a while longer for diplomacy - even if the hostage release is just a stalling tactic. ``Which is cheaper, blood or oil?'' asked Smolarczyk.

DOC.BYLINE: IWF Study: Reinforcing Sexual Stereotypes? ^By W. DALE NELSON
DOC.TEXT: Sponsors of a International Women's Forum study which concluded that female managers lead differently than men denied on Friday charges that the report contributed to sexual stereotypes. The study said that women manage, to a greater extent than men, by personal interaction with their subordinates. It says men are more likely to manage on a more authoritarian, reward-and-punishment system. ``We are not blaming them. We are not saying it's better or worse. We are just saying it's different,'' Judy B. Rosener, a professor in the graduate school of management at the University of California in Irvine, said at a news conference. ``We don't want an interactive leader in Saudi Arabia at the moment,'' said Ms. Rosener, the author of the report. ``I would think we want a command and control type.'' Cynthia Maduro Ryan, a Washington lawyer and former corporate executive who is president of the IWF, said `We are not here in any way to discredit the command and control or authoritarian style.'' ``It was basically appropriate and well done for purposes of the industrial era,'' she said. ``We are going through rapid changes in the information age and a period of adjustment. Women are not having to unlearn the other style because they never adapted to it in the beginning.'' The International Women's Forum is an organization of prominent women leaders in 16 countries, including astronaut Sally Ride, former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. Ms. Rosener said she has received about a hundred telephone calls about the study since her article on its findings appeared in the November-December issue of the Harvard Business Review. ``People are saying, `Gender has nothing to do with it. You are really enforcing gender stereotypes','' she said. But, she said, ``We are not saying that all women behave one way and all men behave another way.'' The Harvard Business Review will run a dozen or so letters on the subject, many of them critical, along with the author's response, in its January-February issue, Ms. Rosener said. The study was based on responses from 355 members of the forum and 101 men in similar positions. It says the typical woman surveyed ``prefers the use of personal power, that is, power based on her charisma, work record, and contact, as contrasted with structural power based on the authority that comes with organizational position, title, and the ability to reward and punish.'' It says the women make the same amount of money as men in comparable positions but ``appear to lead differently than their male colleagues; they are likely to be more transformational than their male peers.'' Most of them are married, the report said. ``The story the findings tell is that it is possible to combine family and career, earn a substantial income, and not act `masculine' in order to succeed,'' the study said.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Bok May Join Think Tank; Louis Sullivan a Possible Successor
DOC.TEXT: Harvard University President Derek C. Bok is expected to join an independent think tank after stepping down in June, according to a published report. The Boston Globe quoted unidentified sources in a report Thursday that Bok would become a member of the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences. The center is on Stanford University's campus but is independent of the school. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan is one of the candidates reportedly being considered to succeed Bok. A spokesman in Sullivan's office said Friday he had no comment. Harvard refused to confirm both reports. Others reportedly being considered to succeed Bok are James O. Freedman, president of Dartmouth College; Nan Keohane, president of Wellesley College; and Adele S. Simmons, president of the MacArthur Foundation. A spokesman for the think tank said: ``At regular intervals, through lengthy evaluations, awards of eligibility are made. Bok has been eligible for some time, and not everyone who is eligible does come.'' Philip Converse, the center's director, said it was founded in 1954 ``to strengthen the behavioral sciences by providing time for interdisciplinary communication in a residential setting.'' Bok, 60, announced last June that he will step down as Harvard's 25th president. He was named president in 1971 after serving as dean of Harvard Law School. Bok grew up in Beverly Hills, Calif., and graduated from Stanford in 1951. He also is a graduate of Harvard Law School.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Study Says Medicaid Formula Outdated
DOC.TEXT: The nation's poorest states lost $3.2 billion in federal health-care dollars for the needy in 1989 because of an outdated formula for distributing Medicaid funds, the General Accounting Office said Friday. The GAO said the formula, which bases payment on an average of per capita income, should be eliminated because it fails to account for the actual number of people living in poverty in a state and the ability of that state to raise revenues. ``The formula does not target most federal funds to states with the greatest needs ... those with weak tax bases and high concentrations of poor people,'' GAO researcher Janet L. Shikles told the House Government Operations subcommittee on human resources and intergovernmental relations. The hearing was called to investigate the growing strains on the federal-state program that is supposed to provide health care to the poor, serving 26 million people this year. ``Perhaps the most significant weakness of per capita income as an indicator of a state's ability to finance program benefits is that it does not reflect all the income states are potentially able to tax,'' she said. The federal government pays 55 percent of medical expenses under Medicaid; states pay the rest. The GAO said the combined expenditures totaled $61 billion in 1989. Shikles specifically mentioned taxable business earnings that don't get counted when calculating per capita income. If poverty levels and ``taxable resources'' had been used in tandem with reducing the federal share to 40 percent, nine states would have received more than $100 million in additional payments in 1989, Shikles said. States that would have benefited are Arkansas, California, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, New York, Tennessee and Texas. The 55 percent federal cap allows richer states to collect more than they need, she said. Per capita income represents an average of income, so a high percentage of wealthy individuals would raise the average even though large numbers of people live in poverty, as in New York or California. A dozen states, mostly in the Northeast and Midwest, each would have had payments reduced by more than $100 million, she said. Those states are Connecticut, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, New Jersey, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. The overall difference would have been $3.2 billion, according to GAO estimates. GAO, the government investigative agency, first proposed eliminating the formula in 1983. Since then, Congress has allowed use of the formula in the distribution of grants for mental health and substance abuse treatment programs. The idea has been resurrected because of the crisis in Medicaid funding brought on by the expansion of types of coverage required and soaring medical costs, as well as the growing number of poor elderly and of children born into poverty. Friday's hearing focused on that crisis, and included testimony from Democratic Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. Clinton, chairman of the National Governors' Association task force on health care, said after the hearing that he favors the change but could not speak for all 50 overnors. ``There's no unified position they could take on that,'' said Alicia Pelrine, group director for human resources at the governors's association. ``There isn't a state in the union that can afford to take less money and still do what they're being asked to do.'' Clinton said Congress has rapidly expanded the numbers of people eligible for coverage and raising their income limits, replacing options with mandates. The coverage of poor women and children and of nursing home residents are areas that have grown in the last four years, he said. ``I have no problems with the mandates, but the practical impact has been to wreak havoc on a lot of state budgets,'' he said. He said Medicaid is growing faster than any other state program, rising from 10 percent of state budgets in 1985 to 14 percent in 1990. It's projected that portion will increase to 17 percent in 1995. Sara Rosenbaum of the Children's Defense Fund, a children's rights group, said there ``are better measures,'' but that the revised formula overlooks the varying costs of medical care from state to state should be considered. Massachusetts, which would have received $437 million less under the GAO formula, has very expensive medical care. Attention, she said, should be focused on ``lapses of federal policy,'' such as a lack of health insurance for more than 30 million Americans, that push people into poverty.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
US to Withdraw Diplomats from Kuwait Embassy
DOC.TEXT: The United States will withdraw its diplomats from the beleaguered U.S. Embassy in Kuwait once they finish helping all Americans who wish to leave the country, the State Department said today. The embassy will remain open but unstaffed, said spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. The United States expects the Iraqis to safeguard the premises once the Americans leave, she said. Despite Iraq's order to shut down the embassy, the United States had insisted on leaving it staffed, partly as a symbolic gesture of defiance against the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. Eight American diplomats have been virtual prisoners at the embassy in Kuwait City since the end of August. They have been subsisting on meager rations, with their water and electricity cut off, and prevented by Iraqi troops from leaving the compound. President Bush expressed repeated anger at the treatment of the diplomats, saying it violated all international norms of diplomatic behavior. But Tutwiler said that once all Americans who wish to leave Kuwait are allowed to do so, the embassy ``will have fulfilled its major remaining task.'' The diplomats' main job was to keep in touch with the estimated 300 Americans still in Kuwait, some of them in hiding from Iraqi troops. Since the United States doesn't recognize Iraqi control of Kuwait, ``we are not going to be doing normal routine government business with Iraqi occupation forces,'' she said. Two British diplomats have also been holding out at their own embassy in Kuwait. The United Nations Security Council adopted a resolution several weeks ago calling for the two embassies to be provided with food. But the world body was unable to make arrangements for restocking the two missions. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is allowing all foreigners to leave Iraq and Kuwait, and the Americans are expected to start leaving as early as Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Dole Plans Tax-Relief Bill for Military
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole said Friday he will introduce a bill early next month to grant some tax relief for military personnel serving in the Persian Gulf area. His bill would waive interest charges for failing to pay any taxes due by the April 15 deadline. ``If soldiers can't be expected to obtain and complete all their necessary paperwork in a foreign desert, they shouldn't be penalized by their government,'' Dole said. The Kansas senator made the announcement after the Internal Revenue Service noted that any member of the armed services serving in the Persian Gulf on April 15 would automatically have an additional 60 days to file a return and pay any tax due. However, the agency said it had no authority to waive interest charges on taxes not paid by the filing deadline. Dole's bill would provide that authority. The IRS said most of the military personnel, like three-quarters of all Americans, will be due refunds and would not face the prospect of paying interest.

DOC.HEAD: Phoenix Rising? A Laser Is
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `The beam...' to clarify how air affects visibility.
DOC.TEXT: A 6-mile-tall beam of turquoise light will stab the sky, and laser images will cavort on fabric screens as a way for this city to project a high-tech image and celebrate its downtown revival. In a ceremony Saturday night, Mayor Paul Johnson is scheduled to touch a console to publicly open a permanent laser show in Patriots Square Park. After the weekend festival ends, anyone with 25 cents will be able to manipulate the beam or activate random selections from up to 150 computer-driven images. The 2.1-acre park is in the city's civic center, near where a new high-rise commercial block called the Arizona Center already is bringing new life downtown for the first time in years. But it is the laser action that boosters see as the crown of downtown renewal. ``What this evolved into,'' said architect Ted Alexander, the park and laser concept's creator, ``was a very strong statement stylistically for Phoenix, a Number 1 entrepreneurial hotbed. This symbolizes Phoenix as a high-tech city that looks to the future.'' The park caps a five-level underground parking garage - a combined $15.4 million project that began in 1981 and officially opened in December 1988. The laser portion - delayed by City Council's reluctance to provide financing - cost $355,000, half of it in donations, and will take an estimated $40,000 a year to keep up. One laser can be moved to slice the sky from the vertical to the near-horizontal, though one high-rise north of the park limits the effect in that direction. The beam ranges in width from 3 to 5 feet. Visibility depends on the air - particles of dust and moisture help reflect the light. The other laser operation projects images on one of the five sail-like triangular screens intermeshed with the park's 115-foot central spire of steel rings and rods. These images - holiday messages, representational shapes like ornaments, submarines and spaceships, and abstract designs - can be made to zoom larger or smaller, stretch or fatten, spin and tumble and flicker. Alexander and former Mayor Terry Goddard say the laser show can come to symbolize Phoenix, a desert city of sometimes searing heat that has as its logo the fable fire bird rising from ashes. It can be ``our own version of the arch in St. Louis or the Space Needle in Seattle,'' said Goddard, the Democratic candidate in Arizona's still-contested gubernatorial election. Like Alexander Eiffel's tower in Paris, the park's spire debuted to critics' sneers. One called the park ``a boil that needs to be lanced.'' Even Goddard suggested the evolving park looked like a landing pad for UFOs. ``We're trying to create a symbol here that reflects Phoenix's growth,'' Alexander said during the earlier stages. ``And anytime you make a bold statement for a community, there's no way to please everybody.'' Alexander spent six months studying what makes urban spaces work before he began his redesign of what was a grassy area crisscrossed by concrete walkways with a fountain where transients bathed. The new park has about 160 trees, lighted low columns of glass bricks and curving rose-brick planters and walls. Every horizontal surface is designed for sitting, making the park popular for office workers' lunches. At its heart is a 45-foot-high dome shading an 800-seat amphitheater. The park, was designed ``to delight the spirit,'' Alexander said. At night, the glass-brick columns and white globes atop twisted lamp poles add illumination to the glow of colored lights and the sparkle of fountains. The argon lasers, though powerful beams of light, won't slice the wings off planes, skewer people or punch holes in nearby buildings, Alexander says. The beams are computer-controlled to stay above the skyline, but even if a beam dipped out of control it would do no more than cast shadows, officials say. ``The heat dissipates very quickly as a function of distance,'' Alexander said. ``You'd have a real hard time lighting a cigarette at 10 feet.'' And the beam will be shut off by a technician if a plane flies within 500 to 1,000 feet, he added. ``It will not shine into people's homes, nor will it light up the night sky and interfere with astronomers,'' Alexander said. ``It reflects Phoenix ready for the 21st century.''

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Forestry Consultant Named to Ag Post
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter on Friday named an Oregon forestry economist as his new deputy assistant secretary for natural resources and the environment. John Beuter, who works for a forestry consulting company in Portland, Ore., will become the top assistant to Assistant Agriculture Secretary James Moseley. The appointment is expected to be criticized by environmental leaders, who earlier this year accused Beuter of exaggerating timber-industry job loss tied to protection of the northern spotted owl. Beuter, 54, will help Moseley manage the U.S. Forest Service and Soil Conservation Service. Moseley led a White House task force on the threatened northern spotted owl earlier this year. Yeutter made the announcement while attending international trade talks in Brussels.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Announces New Series By ``China Beach'' Makers
DOC.TEXT: ``Under Cover,'' a new series about U.S. government spies, will succeed the low-rated ``China Beach'' on Saturday nights, starting Jan. 12, ABC said Friday. The new series, previously called ``The Company,'' was created by William Broyles Jr. and John Sacret Young, co-creators of ``China Beach.'' Co-starring John Denison and Linda Purl as spies who are married to each other and have a family, ``Under Cover'' will have a two-hour premiere on Monday, Jan. 7, then start its regular Saturday night run. ``China Beach,'' about Army nurses during the Vietnam war, is temporarily going off the air after its Dec. 15 telecast. But it will return later in the season, ABC said.

DOC.HEAD: Cigars, Big Bucks and More Mother Teresa: The Keating Hearings
With AM-Keating-Senators
DOC.TEXT: The Keating Five hearings are supposed to be focused on ethics, not cigars. So why was Senate Ethics Committee Chairman Howell Heflin holding up that four-pack of cheap stogies? Heflin, D-Ala., was simply comparing his cheap cigars to the $91.45 cigar bill on the tab at a dinner attended by former chief savings and loan regulator Edwin J. Gray. The cigar issue was raised by William Taylor III, attorney for Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. He was demonstrating that Gray and other regulators were wined and dined with thrift industry money. One dinner bill for Gray and others totaled $1,158.63, including the amount for cigars. Committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett piped up that chairman Heflin also liked good cigars. Heflin responded by showing everyone his lowly smokes. --- An insight into big thinking in fund raising was provided at one point by Cranston, one of the five senators whose conduct in connection with major contributor Charles H. Keating Jr., the former savings and loan owner, is being investigated. The other four senators are Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich.; John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz. In a written deposition released by the committee, Cranston said: ``Many people trying to raise money can never bring themselves to ask for really large amounts. Yet, for those you are soliciting, it's a compliment, a compliment to ask someone for a large sum. If they're capable of giving big and you ask small, some potential donors will be insulted.'' Referring to Keating, Cranston said, ``You know he's given lavishly to others; you don't ask a guy like him for peanuts and you ask frequently.'' However, at another point, Cranston lamented, ``Personally and politically, I wish to God I'd never heard of Charles Keating.'' --- Several references have been made to Keating's contributions to the famous advocate for the poor, Mother Teresa. The latest mention came when Cranston fund-raiser Joy Jacobson was explaining that it wasn't unusual for a conservative Republican - Keating - to contribute to voter projects that registered the poor, even though they might be expected to vote most often for Democrats. After all, she said, Keating gave to Mother Teresa. Bennett said, ``I'm beginning to feel I'm going to have to call the mother as a witness.'' He paused, then added, ``As of right now, I don't intend to.'' --- Five of the six committee members are Southerners: Heflin; Trent Lott, R-Miss.; David Pryor,k.; Terry Sanford, D-N.C. and Jesse Helms, R-N.C. Heflin, who usually speaks in a slow drawl, told one fast-talking witness to slow down. Committee Vice-Chairman Warren Rudman, R-N.H., who speaks at a fast clip himself, told the witness he could understand him just fine. --- The hearings have featured several alumni of the U.S. attorney's office in Washington. Charles F. C. Ruff, representing Glenn, was the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia. His assistant in the ethics case, Carol E. Bruce, was an assistant U.S. attorney who specialized in prosecuting terrorists. Bennett also is a former assistant U.S. attorney. So is Raymond Banoun, who represented witness M. Danny Wall, the chief thrift regulator after Gray left office. --- The hearing also features former journalists including Gray; Bennett's assistant, Amy Sabrin, and Cranston, who covered events in England, Germany, Italy and Ethiopia in 1937-38 for the old International News Service. --- Heflin and Rudman have several times chided defense lawyers for their lengthy questioning of witnesses. So when Riegle's lawyer, Thomas Green, began cross-examination of a witness 10 minutes before one day's adjournment, he began with a preemptive strike. ``You just give me the hook when it's time to go here,'' Green told Heflin. Heflin did, 10 minutes later, just as Green was working himself up to a fever pitch to confront a witness.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Beefing Up Force in Kuwait As He Frees Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5 graf, `Despite Iraq's...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. Embassyin Kuwait to be closed. Pickup 6th, `Pentagon spokesman...' TRIMS at bottom.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY7,12,15,BX2
DOC.TEXT: The Iraqi parliament today overwhelmingly endorsed Saddam Hussein's decision to free thousands of Western hostages, meaning the 900 Americans held captive in Iraq and Kuwait might be home for Christmas. The more than 8,000 Westerners, East Europeans and Japanese stranded in Iraq will be allowed to leave beginning Saturday, Iraqi officials said. Iraq said the hostages could start applying for exit visas immediately. It said they would be flown on special Iraqi Airways flights to Amman, Jordan. In Baghdad, a group of American and British hostages hugged and kissed each other and raised beer mugs today to celebrate their impending release. The State Department, meanwhile, said that once the Americans in Kuwait have left, the eight diplomats in Kuwait City's U.S. Embassy will be withdrawn. The embassy will remain open but unstaffed, and the United States expects the Iraqis to safeguard the empty premises, the State Department said. Iraq had surrounded the embassy and cut off its supplies, making the diplomats virtual prisoners and angering the Bush administration. But State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said that once American civilians have left Kuwait, the embassy ``will have fulfilled its major remaining task.'' U.S. officials also said today that Baghdad has sent 30,000 more troops to the Arabian desert in recent days, indicating Baghdad has no intention of abandoning Kuwait, which it invaded on Aug. 2. Pentagon spokesman Bob Hall said the troop reinforcements brought the Iraqi buildup in Kuwait and southern Iraq to 480,000 soldiers. An additional 10,000 U.S. troops have also arrived in the Persian Gulf, Hall said. The 350,000-strong multinational force now includes about 250,000 Americans, most of them dug into the Saudi Arabian desert facing Iraqi troops. President Bush has said 440,000 American soldiers will be in the gulf by mid-January. The U.N. resolution approved last week authorizes the use of force to drive Iraq from Kuwait if Baghdad has not withdrawn by Jan. 15. Saddam on Thursday instructed his rubber-stamp parliament to free the captives, saying he no longer needed them to deter attack. He said his troops were fully deployed in Kuwait, seized in a dispute over oil, land and money. ``Iraqi armed forces should maintain the highest degree of alert and vigilance,'' Saddam said, ``because the forces of aggression remain on our sacred soil in Saudi Arabia, fanning the flames of fire.'' At Baghdad's Mansour-Melia Hotel a group of 50 American and British hostages toasted their release by the Iraqi parliament. ``This is it. We're all free,'' one hostage shouted when a reporter told him of the parliament vote. Robert Vinton, a businessman from Santa Fe, N.M., said: ``It is a monumental occasion.'' Bush welcomed Saddam's decision Thursday to free Americans and other foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq, but said the United States must still demand withdrawal. ``We've got to continue to keep the pressure on,'' he said. Prime Minister John Major of Britain said he hoped the hostages would be coming home soon with no conditions placed on their departure. But ``Saddam Hussein has a lot more to do in terms of U.N. Security Council resolutions and the international community will require him to do it all,'' he said. In Saudi Arabia, U.S. troops also had a message for Saddam: It's great the hostages may be home for Christmas but the GIs are not prepared to go home until Kuwait is free. First Sgt. Jerry Carlton, 37, of Warsaw, N.C., said the hostage release could signal Saddam was caving in, or be an effort ``to buy additional time.'' First Lt. Brian Ratchford, 26, of Spartanburg, S.C., said: ``I think it's great they're going home ... But it's not about the hostages. I think the hostages were a bad side effect of this whole thing.'' Iraq's National Assembly has no record of vetoing decisions by Saddam, but reporters counted 18 of 250 delegates voting today against Saddam's request. The assembly speaker, Sadi Mehdi Saleh, said he counted only 15 hands. ``Definitely, we would like to see everyone with his family by Christmas, because that is a very joyous and happy occasion, and it is time for family reunions,'' said Iraq's ambassador to the United Nations, Abdul Amir al-Anbari. A British Airways jet stocked with champagne left London for the gulf today to pick up hostages. Planes were also being prepared in Denmark and Japan, while Dutch officials said they didn't expect to send a flight until next week. Among the foreigners who have been barred from leaving Iraq are about 90 Americans and hundreds of others held as ``human shields'' at military and other strategic sites. Many more have remained in hiding. In a message for broadcast to the region over Voice of America, the U.S. State Department said that until Iraq made clear how such releases take place, ``Stay where you are, stay in touch with the U.S. Embassy and monitor the VOA closely. We will let you know as soon as we have more information.'' The British Foreign Office, meanwhile, also advised Britons in hiding in Kuwait to stay there. ``Basically, the situation is still unclear,'' a Foreign Office spokesman said. ``The ambassador is obviously in close touch with Iraqi authorities to clarify what will happen, but until plans become more clear we are advising people to stay where they are.'' Out of an estimated 3 million foreigners in the two countries before the invasion, about 2 million are still left, most of them Asians and Arabs who had the option of leaving. The U.N. Security Council may meet today to discuss a U.N. draft resolution that approves a world conference on the Palestinian problem. Bush, who is touring South America, said his administration did not support any immediate Middle East peace conference, renewing his rejection of Saddam's attempt to link resolution of the crisis with the Arab-Israeli conflict. Washington has said, however, it approves in principle the idea of a peace conference, at an ``appropriate'' time. Diplomats have said that because of a possible appearance of linkage with Kuwait, now is not an appropriate time.

DOC.HEAD: Grenada To Emphasize Tourism
DOC.TEXT: Grenada's prime minister would like another invasion by Americans. But this time, he wants them carrying beachbags and cameras instead of rucksacks and automatic rifles. ``Grenada's economic future depends considerably on tourism,'' Nicholas Brathwaite said in a interview during the 14th annual Conference on the Caribbean, which ended Friday. He said his government is looking to tourism as the quickest way to get badly needed foreign exchange and give jobs to thousands of unemployed youths. The days when the verdant island of 100,000 people was worldwide news are gone. Now Brathwaite, who steered the island's transition to democracy six years ago, is back as its elected leader and facing an economic mess. Brathwaite, a former educator, headed the interim government installed after the Oct. 25, 1983, U.S. invasion overthrew a radical military junta that had seized power in a bloody split of the leftists who had staged a 1979 coup. He had returned to private life after a government was elected a year later, but he headed the winning Grenada National Congress in elections last March after Prime Minister Herbert Blaize's death. During the same month, he concluded that the island's economy was in bad shape. A recent International Monetary Fund-World Bank study team found the budget deficit and debt-servicing problems were staggering, he said. ``We were not aware of the true magnitude of the problem,'' he said. Grenada's year-end economic report for 1989 showed a $48.7 million foreign debt, $35.9 million domestic debt, a trade deficit of $59.7 million and 20 percent unemployment. Grenada's hopes of increasing tourism, which has traditionally lagged behind most other Caribbean islands, has been helped by the recent inauguration of regular flights from the United States. The island, which has a 10,000-foot runway airport largely built by the past leftist government's Cuban allies, is working on broadening its tourist appeal beyond its myriad white-sand beaches, Brathwaite said. The government hopes to develop nature trails into its mountainous rain forests, he said. Brathwaite said the high esteem most Grenadians had for Americans after the invasion has barely ebbed. ``There were high expectations, and there have been some disappointments since, but I think Grenadians realize the problems have been with their own government. The United States helped a lot with infrastructure,'' he said. Overwhelmingly, he said, Grenadians have warm feelings toward Americans. The U.S. government still sends $110 million a year in aid to Grenada.

DOC.HEAD: Interim President Rescinds Emergency Powers
DOC.TEXT: Bangladesh's interim president said Friday he is rescinding the emergency powers that ousted President Hussain Muhammad Ershad gave himself in an unsuccessful effort to save his collapsing regime. Shahabuddin Ahmed, the former Supreme Court chief justice who took power when Ershad resigned Thursday, also said he will move quickly to set up Bangladesh's first free parliamentary election in a decade. Ershad, who seized power in a 1982 coup, resigned under pressure following seven weeks of street protests led by university students and opposition parties. An independent newspaper, The Bangladesh Observer, said at least 60 people were killed by police and government forces during the protests. Opposition leaders said more than 100 died, while the government admitted only six dead. Mosques were crowded on Friday for the weekly Moslem holiday and shops were open as Dhaka, the capital city of seven million people, began to resume an air of normalcy after almost two months of protests. A committee of political leaders who led the campaign against Ershad called on Ahmed to seize Ershad's passport, freeze his bank accounts and put him on trial for corruption. The recently formed liaison committee of three former opposition alliances accused Ershad of ``brutal killing, illegal use of arms and misuse of power'' during his eight-year rule. It also charged him with ``illegally accumulating wealth,'' which he allegedly sent abroad. A statement released by the committee demanded the arrest of Ershad's wife Raushan. Unlike the wives of previous statesman in this Moslem country, Mrs. Ershad was a public figure who was widely disliked for taking advantage of her position. ``We definitely want a trial of those who have committd crimes and atrocities in the past eight years,'' said Khaleda Zia, an opposition leader. Ahmed, in his first televised address to the nation, did not respond directly to the appeal, and said his interim administration would make no decisions on basic policies. ``The main task of my caretaker government will be to conduct a free and fair election. The people will elect a parliament and my duty will end after the parliament is formed,'' he said. Ahmed said he would appoint a council to help him administer the country until elections, which should be held within 90 days. None of the members of the caretaker council will be allowed to stand for election, he said. He said that within 24 hours he would sign the ordinance repealing the Special Powers Act, which Ershad invoked Nov. 27 when he declared a state of emergency. The laws suspended personal liberties and empowered the government to make arrests without pressing charges. Ershad lifted the emergency restrictions and dissolved Parliament shortly before he resigned on Thursday. Also to be rescinded are other controversial laws which allowed the regime to arbitrarily close universities and to change the structure of health services, Ahmed said in his 10-minute speech. He praised the armed forces, which he said ``made a commendable contribution to the democratic movement by showing respect for the hopes and aspirations of the people.'' Sources said senior army officers helped persuade Ershad to bow to the public demands for his resignation. Ahmed called on the military to help maintain order for elections, which in the past have often turned violent. Ershad held parliamentary elections twice during his regime. Opposition parties boycotted the 1988 election, and the 1986 vote was widely regarded as rigged by Ershad's Jatiya party. Bangladesh, formerly East Pakistan, became independent in a civil war with West Pakistan in 1971. Until Ershad took power it was ruled by a succession of presidents installed by the military.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Reports 48th Accidental Death in Operation Desert Shield
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A 20-year-old Army private was accidentally crushed to death by an Army truck in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday, the Pentagon said Friday. The victim was identified as Dustin Craig LaMoureaux, of Bremerton, Wash. He was deployed to the Persian Gulf with the 20th Engineer Brigade of Fort Bragg, N.C., as part of Operation Desert Shield. The accident occurred about 6 p.m. local time on Wednesday. While participating in a construction project, LaMoureaux was crushed between the truck and a pallet of construction materials, the Pentagon said. The incident is being investigated. His was the 48th accidental death in Desert Shield. The Pentagon also said it has determined that the previously reported death Tuesday in Saudi Arabia of Lt. Col. Joe Hancock, a Tennessee National Guard commander, was a suicide. Hancock died of a gunshot wound while in his tent. The Pentagon said there have been three Desert Shield deaths due to natural causes and one earlier suicide.

DOC.HEAD: Overwhelming Victory for Mubarak's Party In Elections
DOC.TEXT: President Hosni Mubarak's ruling party won an overwhelming majority in violence-marred parliamentary elections, according to final results released Friday. A second round of voting was held Thursday. Figures announced by the Interior Ministry and reported by the government-run Middle East News Agency gave the governing National Democratic Party 348 out of the 444 seats being contested in the People's Assembly. The small leftist National Unionist Progressive Party won six seats and independent candidates took 83. The ministry's statement said elections for seven seats will be repeated in four districts because of irregularities. It said the date would be announced later. At least 10 people were reported killed and close to 100 wounded in clashes related to the two rounds of voting. Trouble in Thursday's runoff round, some involving police, left at least five dead and 54 wounded. Major opposition parties boycotted the vote, charging that a new election law lacked adequate guarantees of free balloting. Some National Democrats who were not chosen by their party as candidates also ran as independents. The final results show that the seats they won were counted in favor of the ruling party, even though they ran as independents. In the first election round on Nov. 29, independents won 38 seats. Runoffs were necessary for almost 60 percent of the seats, a record for a parliamentary election, beacuse almost 2,700 candidates ran. Candidates who failed to get a first-round majority had to face a second round. Mubarak, riding a crest of popularity because of his strong stand against Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, opens the new Parliament on Dec. 15 with a keynote adress expected to focus on the Persian Gulf crisis. The National Democrats controlled more than 350 seats in the outgoing parliament, which had 458 seats. Only 13 women ran in this election, the smallest number in republican Egypt's 34-year history. Five won in the first round, but it was not clear how many were elected in the second.

DOC.HEAD: 18 Cities Search for School Superintendents
DOC.TEXT: Despite generous perks and salaries often exceeding $100,000, 18 of the nation's largest school districts are trying to fill superintendencies - jobs educators increasingly see as ``doomed to failure.'' Urban superintendents are quitting, or being fired, in droves because they are expected to perform miracles, fail to do so, then get blamed by politicians, business heads, parents, and increasingly meddlesome school boards. The average tenure of big-city superintendents is now only 2.5 years, compared with nearly five years in the 1970s, said Samuel Husk, executive director of the Council of Great City Schools in Washington, D.C. ``Part of it is our fault. I think superintendents tend to agree they can do everything, then the house of cards falls when they can't deliver,'' said San Francisco's Ramon Cortines. Cortines plans to step down as superintendent in August, two years before his contract expires. Budget pressures are worsening the odds of reform and adding to the job strains of big-city school chiefs, said superintendents and educators interviewed this week. ``Urban centers are getting to the point where the job is impossible. With the political climate, the dwindling financial support and unrealistic expectations, you know when you go i that you're doomed to failure,'' said Ken Underwood, president of Harold Webb Associates, a Winnetka, Ill., search firm specializing in placing school administrators. In an average year, six to eight major school districts find themselves searching for new superintendents, according to Husk. But currently there are 18: Atlanta and Savannah, Ga.; Boston; Detroit; Columbus and Toledo, Ohio; San Francisco; Austin, Houston and El Paso, Texas; Indianapolis; Milwaukee; St. Louis and Kansas City, Mo.; Hartford, Conn.; Tucson, Ariz; Charlotte-Mecklenburg, N.C., and Washington, D.C. Webb and others say there are still enough good candidates to fill the vacancies. But educators worry that it will become harder to fill jobs that promise little security, and almost guarantee failure. Salaries in districts with more than 25,000 students averaged $95,735 in the 1989-90 school year, according to the Educational Research Service, a private, non-profit firm in Arlington, Va. Many offer generous annuities, housing allowances and pensions. Salaries in several of those top $100,000: $125,000 in Houston, $116,000 in San Francisco, $112,000 in Atlanta, $110,000 in Milwaukee, $109,180 in Austin, Texas, $109,000 in Detroit, and $101,237 in St. Louis. But more and more urban superintendents seem to be saying that no amount of pay can compensate jobs that are being made political scapegoats for decades of urban school failure. -Six weeks ago, Memphis' Willie Herenton quit the $96,304 superintendency he'd held for 11 years because of disputes over school funds. -Washington, D.C.'s board fired superintendent Andrew Jenkins last week. He accused school board members of going around him in dealing with teachers and others on curriculum and other matters. -San Francisco's Cortines said board interference in personnel matters was one reason he had decided to quit by August, though his contract runs through 1993. -In Boston this week, the city council voted to abolish the school committee after a fruitless six-month search to replace outgoing superintendent Laval Wilson. Wilson, who is black, was fired from the $95,000 Boston post last February just weeks after the school committee had given him a highly favorable job evaluation. Supporters contend race played a role in his dismissal. ``The people who have the background in the trenches don't seem to be giving up on the possibilities,'' said Jeremiah Floyd, associate executive director of the National Association of Secondary School Principals. ``They just know that once you take on the mission, you have to do it in a hurry, because the longevity is not there at all.''

DOC.HEAD: Opening of Indoor Golf Course Delayed by Weather
DOC.TEXT: Bad weather won't be par for the course once a domed golf course is finished, but inclement conditions have proved to be a bogey for its scheduled opening. Michael Thompson, president of American Golf Domes Inc., the company building Turfdome-One, said Friday the covered links probably will be ready by Dec. 20. The opening originally was set for next Monday. ``We have to inflate the bubble, and everything has to be absolutely perfect,'' Thompson said. The $2 million Turfdome-One is a nine-hole course with a dozen sand traps and hills up to 12 feet high. Its longest hole is about 75 yards, and all nine will be separated by nets. Thompson said his company worked with Michigan State University to develop a system allowing grass to grow under the dome. He said the turf is a hybrid of rye and bent grasses. A special underground heating system and dome material letting in 71 percent of the sun's ultraviolet rays will be used. The course will be open 8 a.m. to 9 p.m., seven days a week, from December through April. Golfers will be allowed to carry only four clubs per bag. Spike shoes will be banned. Two more nine-hole courses and a driving range of artificial turf are planned for the site next year, Thompson said.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Governor Defends DeConcini
With AM-Keating Five-Notebook
DOC.TEXT: Arizona Gov. Rose Mofford defended Sen. Dennis DeConcini at ethics hearings Friday, testifying that his help for Charles H. Keating Jr. came when the businessman was held in high esteem. Mofford, who knew the Arizona Democrat as a 10-year-old altar boy, was a character witness for DeConcini - one of five senators under investigation for their intervention on behalf of former S&L owner Keating. She testified Keating was ``considered a very successful businessman and very charitable'' in 1987, when the senators discussed his complaints with thrift regulators. Keating's American Continental Corp. of Phoenix, parent of California-based Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, employed 3,500 people in 1987, Ms. Mofford said. The corporation was a major lender in Arizona and considered a solid company in which to invest. Federal regulators closed Lincoln, a failure that's expected to cost taxpayers $2.3 billion. The committee is trying to learn whether the $1.3 million raised for the five senators by Keating and associates influenced the conduct of DeConcini or Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz., Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., John Glenn, D-Ohio, and Alan Cranston, D-Calif. A theme in the defense of all five senators is that they provided normal constituent service to Keating, who complained that Lincoln was unfairly treated by thrift regulators. ``His work with constituencies certainly was a hallmark'' of DeConcini's career, Mofford said. ``A problem was never too big or too small,'' she said. ``Any time there was a problem with the federal government, everyone would say, `Call Dennis DeConcini's office.''' One of DeConcini's accomplishments, Mofford said, was getting President Bush's anti-drug coordinator, William Bennett, to make the Arizona-Mexico border a high priority area for drug interdiction. Bennett, recently named Republican national chairman, is the brother of Robert S. Bennett - the Ethics Committee's special counsel in the Keating case. After Mofford's testimony, which lasted less than 20 minutes, the hearings adjourned until Monday.

DOC.HEAD: After Three Years, Uprising Has Become A Way Of Life
DOC.TEXT: When army jeeps approach this hilltop Palestinian village, old women blow a warning with whistles hanging from their necks. Wanted men slip into hiding, and iron courtyard gates slam shut. After three years, the uprising against Israeli rule has become a way of life for the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Many are exhausted by the daily hardships, disappointed that their struggle has brought no political gains, and aware that the Persian Gulf crisis has overshadowed their revolt. But most say there is no turning back. ``The world has heard our voice and we must continue,'' said Amal, a 27-year-old woman from Kufr Nama whose quiet village life was turned upside down by the revolt that erupted on Dec. 9, 1987. A day earlier, four Arabs had been killed in a crash with an Israeli truck. Rumors spread that the accident was intentional, and the violence escalated after that. Before the uprising, Amal's husband Nassif, 29, worked in an Israeli aluminum factory and made enough money for such luxuries as fancy dresses for their two daughters, ages 3 and 5. Today, Nassif is an activist on the run from the army, sleeping in the hills at night and sneaking home only briefly. He raises chickens, barely eking out a living. Amal, who is pregnant, said she lies awake many nights worrying about her absent husband. ``I always expect a knock at the door thinking it's the army,'' she said. Her fears are not without reason. In the stone houses along Kufr Nama's steep, winding streets, hardly a family has been untouched by the intefadeh - Arabic for uprising. The village, 10 miles northwest of Jerusalem, has 2,500 residents. Two have been killed and 50 wounded by troops, one has been deported and some 200 have been jailed. The story is much the same throughout the West Bank and Gaza. In the last three years, more than 770 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis and about 300 others have been slain by fellow Arabs, mostly as suspected informers. Fifty-two Israelis have died in the violence. At least 60,000 Palestinians have been jailed at one time or another in the uprising. In mid-November, 10,009 were in custody, including 790 held under emergency regulations allowing detention for up to a year without charges. The army also has demolished or sealed 620 Palestinian homes to punish suspected militants, ignoring Western protests that the practice violates human rights. Today, the massive demonstrations of the uprising's early days have shrunk to small, stone-throwing attacks on soldiers. Deaths and injuries are fewer. Lately, in fact, more Palestinians have been killed as collaborators by fellow Arabs than have been slain by soldiers. A senior military official said that after three years, the army is better prepared for uprising riots. Army jeeps are protected by steel mesh, and soldiers often avoid such obvious hot spots as mosques and schools. ``The uprising is by no means over, but we have taken a lot of steam out of it,'' said the official, who cannot be named under military rules. To try to prevent violence linked to the uprising's third anniversary over the weekend, the army beefed up its forces in the occupied territories Friday and confined more than 735,000 Arabs to their homes. Lately, the most fearful aspect of the revolt for Israelis has been a wave of stabbing attacks that followed the Oct. 8 Temple Mount riots in Jerusalem, in which 17 Palestinians died in police gunfire. Israelis responded to the stabbings with revenge attacks of their own, and demands that Palestinians be blocked from working in Israel. Authorities say they expect to deny working permits to more than half the 110,000 Palestinians with jobs in Israel. The move comes as Israel is trying to find work for thousands of newly arrived Soviet Jewish immigrants. But some Israelis argue that denying jobs to Palestinians already bitter and frustrated by Israel's occupation could backfire into more violence. ``We have passed from the era of the stones to the era of knives. I'm afraid that soon we'll reach the era of guns,'' said Israeli lawmaker Yossi Sarid of the liberal Citizens' Rights Movement. For their part, the Palestinians admit to being discouraged by diminished hopes for peace. Israel's new government, formed last June, is dominated by right-wingers who oppose giving up any of the land Israel captured in the 1967 Middle East war. Palestinians also have lost international sympathy by supporting Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in the gulf crisis. Uprising leaders say their job now is to make a reality of the Palestinian state proclaimed on paper by the Palestine Liberation Organization's parliament-in-exile on Nov. 15, 1988. In Kufr Nama, Nassif and his friends are working toward economic independence by organizing the village's more than 100 chicken farmers, who provide most of its income, into a cooperative. The three years of revolt have also allowed young activists to smash the rule of traditional clan leaders. Kufr Nama is now run by a ``popular committee'' of the four major PLO factions, who mediate land disputes and organize defense against army raids. Elderly women in Palestinian embroidered dresses are the early warning system. They watch the two winding roads into town and listen for sounds of military convoys, blowing their whistles at any sign of trouble.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: First they were accused of stealing somebody else's voice. Now they're accused of stealing somebody's melody. Lip synchers Milli Vanilli are being sued for alleged copyright infringement by Blood, Sweat and Tears' David Clayton-Thomas. Clayton-Thomas says the melody of the song ``Spinning Wheel,'' which he wrote in 1968, was used without his permission in ``All or Nothing'' from Milli Vanilli's hit album ``Girl You Know It's True.'' ``This suit is about the song they didn't write on the album they didn't sing,'' said Clayton-Thomas' lawyer, Robert Marcus. The duo, Rob Pilatus and Fabrice Morvan, were forced to give back a Grammy they won for best new artist after it was revealed they did not sing the album's songs and were lip-synching the words in concerts. The suit, filed Thursday, seeks $120 million and names as defendants Pilatus, Morvan, producer Frank Farian and EMI Music Publishing Inc., which holds Clayton-Thomas' music copyrights in trust. EMI executive vice president Harold Rosenbloom did not return a call seeking comment. The whereabouts of Farian, Pilatus and Morvan were not immediately known. A call to Arista Records, where the album was recorded, was referred to lawyer Michael Pollock, who did not return messages. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Actor Corey Feldman's latest run-in with the law is over traffic tickets. The 19-year-old star of the movies ``The Lost Boys,'' ``Gremlins'' and ``Stand By Me'' was arrested late Thursday, said Sgt. Pat Findley of the Los Angeles Police Department's Hollywood division. Officers had spotted his BMW blocking a driveway and discovered there was an outstanding traffic warrant for his arrest, Findley said. They also determined that Feldman had a suspended driver's licens, Findley said. Feldman was released early Friday after paying $528 in outstanding tickets and fines, Findley said. He was to appear in Los Angeles Traffic Court on Jan. 2, the sergeant said. It was Feldman's third arrest this year. On March 9, officers said they found balloons containing heroin and cocaine in his car. Feldman also was arrested Sept. 20 in connection with unpaid traffic tickets. Officers said they found a small amount of heroin on him during a search at a North Hollywood police station and the actor underwent drug treatment. --- LONDON (AP) - Actress Joan Collins says she wants people to see her play roles other than ``the glamorous vixen type,'' so she's filming eight Noel Coward comedies for British television. Collins is best known for playing the decidedly vixenish Alexis Carrington Colby on the TV series ``Dynasty.'' She currently is starring in a London stage production of Coward's ``Private Lives.'' ``I don't always want to be perceived as the glamorous vixen type,'' Collins said. The television project, entitled ``Tonight At 8:30,'' will begin airing in April on the British Broadcasting Corp., Collins told reporters Friday. The new series will cast her in roles that range from a fading music hall star to an elegant femme fatale. ``I've been an actress for a very long time,'' she said. ``I'm quite adventurous. I love challenges.'' Once the project is done, Collins said, she hopes to return to the stage, taking ``Private Lives'' to Broadway next fall. Its London run ends Jan. 26. --- CHICAGO (AP) - A rocker used by Barbara Bush fetched $60 at a charity auction. A chair once used by Madonna got $225. And an orange plastic stadium seat once thrown by Indiana University basketball coach Bob Knight sold for $150. Thursday night's celebrity furniture auction raised $5,085 for the non-profit Greater Chicago Food Depository, which distributes 20 million pounds of food a year to 500 soup kitchens, pantries and shelters in northeast Illinois and northwest Indiana. ``I was amazed. I didn't think we'd do so well,'' said auctioneer Leslie Hindman, who held the event in a fifth-floor gallery of her downtown Antique Center. ``You can never tell how it will go with a charity auction.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Dispatches Extra Forces For Uprising Anniversary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with details on curfew. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `The strike...'
DOC.TEXT: The army sent reinforcements to the occupied lands Friday and imposed military curfews on towns and villages in an effort to thwart attacks marking the third anniversary of the Palestinian uprising. Underground uprising leaders called a two-day general strike for the weekend, and a Marxist PLO faction, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, urged ``massive martyrdom'' to mark the anniversary. ``The Palestinians in the West Bank have every good reason now to carry out spectacular attacks in the territories,'' a senior army officer was quoted as saying in the Maariv newspaper. ``The prime minister is in the United States, (U.S. Secretary of State James A.) Baker is about to meet with the president of Iraq, the third anniversary of the uprising is approaching, and there is a feeling that because of the gulf crisis the uprising has been removed from the headlines,'' the unidentified officer was quoted as saying. An army spokesman said reinforcements have been sent into the West Bank and Gaza Strip and that ``special measures,'' including covert operations, were ordered to thwart violence. The army also clamped curfews on the largest of the territories' towns - Gaza City, Nablus and Hebron - and many refugee camps. It declared other sectors ``closed military areas,'' barring journalists from entering. The curfews essentially mean that an estimated 735,000 Palestinians living in those areas are ordered to stay home. The strike Saturday was called to mark two months since the Temple Mount riots in which at least 17 Palestinians were killed by Israeli police. Uprising leaders said the second day of the strike would mark the anniversary of the uprising - which broke out Dec. 9, 1987. The results of a newly published poll, meanwhile, showed that the uprising has made 42 percent of Israelis more hawkish. It said opinion was divided on how to solve the conflict. The survey of 1,200 Israeli Jews said only 6 percent had become more dovish, while 25 percent had experienced no change of opinion. Seven percent were undecided, according to the poll conducted by the Smith Research Center for the weekly Jerusalem Report news magazine. On the question of how to solve the conflict, 21 percent wanted to expel all or some of the Palestinians from the territories, and 20 percent thought Israel should withdraw from the Gaza Strip, regarded as the most troublesome occupied area. Twenty-five percent favored some sort of statehood for the 1.7 million Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza, the poll said. Six percent favored annexing the West Bank, 9 percent opted for preserving the present situation, and 19 percent had no opinion, it said. Since the uprising began, 776 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians. Fifty-three Israelis have died in the violence. In addition, 316 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Astronauts Stargaze With Help From Ground
With AM-Space Classroom, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's astronauts, with help from scientists on the ground, pushed forward with their stargazing Friday in a rush to make as many observations as possible with the shuttle's telescopes. The four astronomers aboard Columbia talked about their problems operating the $150 million Astro observatory during a live lesson from space for middle school students and a question-and-answer session. ``Unfortunately, we've had some failures with computer terminals which have caused us to have to redo the way that we operate this mission.
