So it's been quite tedious and time-consuming to figure out how to do that,'' astronaut Ron Parise told 41 youngsters at NASA centers in Alabama and Maryland. ``But we're slowly working around everything and we're getting science data and doing our job,'' Parise said. Added astronaut Jeffrey Hoffman, ``We've shown that in space flight you have to be extremely adaptable and be able to accommodate things that fail and ways of operating which we never even planned before.'' Observations were halted for half a day Thursday when a flight deck computer overheated and shut down. The only other on-board computer for operating Astro's three ultraviolet telecopes failed in a similar manner Sunday. Lint, probably from clothing worn by the seven-man crew, was found clogging the air vents of the computer that failed Sunday. After the lint was removed Thursday, the terminal was turned on but immediately turned off when a burning odor once again filled the cabin. Flight director Bob Castle said it was not known whether the lint was the cause of the problem and whether that made the other computer fail. The lint will be analyzed after the flight to determine its source, he said. Following Thursday's failure, NASA hurriedly devised and implemented a plan in which ground teams aim and turn on the telescopes, with the astronauts using a joystick to zero in on the targets. The telescopes were tested successfully one by one and by Friday were producing results surpassing scientists' expectations. Parise and fellow astronaut Robert Parker, for example, focused all three telescopes on a quasar for 51 minutes, three minutes longer than planned. ``That's what happens when you have good, old-fashioned astronomy ... and a little bit of help from your friends,'' Parker told Spacelab Mission Operations Control in Huntsville, Ala. Other high-energy targets observed Friday included numerous galaxies and a supernova that exploded in 1987. Arthur Davidsen of Johns Hopkins University, principal investigator of one of the telescopes, said the results demonstrate ``this is not a failure by any stretch of anybody's imagination.'' He likened the 10-day mission to a football game. When the second computer failed, ``we went in and changed the game plan entirely ... and now we're making so much progress it's unbelievable. Almost every play is a first down,'' Davidsen said. ``I think we're winning this game now.'' Some scientists, includng Barbara Pfarr of the ultraviolet imaging telescope team, even were enjoying the new method of operation because of their increased participation. ``Commanding from the ground is rather fun,'' she said. One of the more exciting findings of the day came from Astro's X-ray telescope, which was unaffected by the computer problems. The instrument has its own pointing system and is controlled by computer commands sent from Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. Goddard scientist Peter Serlemitsos, the X-ray telescope's principal investigator, said he found conditions to be right for a black hole to exist in a Seyfert galaxy - one with a bright, compact center - 325 million light years away. That, in turn, ``tells us that indeed there are likely to be giant black holes at the centers of these galaxies,'' he said. The mission, which ends Tuesday, has been plagued by instrument problems since Columbia blasted off Sunday. In addition to the failed computers, the crew has had to contend with a faulty instrument pointing system. Because the astronauts had to manually steer the ultraviolet telescopes rather than use the automatic pointing system, only 70 of 187 observations were accomplished before Thursday's computer failure, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said. Scientists had hoped to study about 250 objects, including some of the hottest, most violent stars in the universe. Ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted from such objects is absorbed by Earth's atmosphere and thus invisible from the ground. Deputy mission scientist Gene Urban said it was not known how many of the targets will have to be scrapped because of the delays.

DOC.HEAD: Tolling of Bell Honors 2,403 Americans Killed in Japanese Attack
DOC.TEXT: David T. Best's journey to honor a childhood friend killed 49 years ago at Pearl Harbor ended Friday at the stark limestone facade of the Indiana World War Memorial. Best, 72, traveled from his Hayward, Calif., home to join other World War II veterans at a service honoring the 2,403 Americans killed in Japan's assault on the Pacific Fleet. Best glanced at a photograph of Paul B. Free, whose life ended at 20 as he climbed into his airplane on Dec. 7, 1941. ``Few things stir man's compassion so deeply as remembering the supreme sacrifice of an old buddy. Sleep, comrade, sleep in peace,'' Best said. Veterans alternated reading 10 names a minute while tolling a large, silver bell from the USS Indianapolis one time for each American who died. Similar ceremonies took place elsewhere, including in Hawaii, where dignitaries boarded the USS Arizona Memorial for wreath presentations, a 21-gun salute and echo taps. At the Pearl Harbor Naval Base, a ``missing man'' flyover by Hawaii Air National Guard jets ended a minute of silence marking the time of the attack. Best, a self-described ``loyal, patriotic American who gets choked up when `The Star-Spangled Banner' plays,'' grew up in Williamsport, Pa., and returned there in 1988 to unveil a plaque commemorating Free as the city's first resident killed in World War II. ``We made a pact that he would enlist in the Army Air Corps and I would try to get aviation experience. Of course, then he was killed,'' said Best, who later trained B-17 radar bombardiers and navigators in Florida. ``When I got the terse telegram (about Free's death), I was just a 21-year-old kid. I was in shock, I didn't know how to cope. So then I enlisted. I have never forgotten him, and I never will.'' That was a feeling shared by about 100 people who stood in 28-degree weather as a bugler from Fort Benjamin Harrison in Indianapolis played taps. Yellow ribbons decorated the bare branches of trees around the monument on the downtown American Legion Mall. The USS Indianapolis was sunk between Guam and the Philippines by a Japanese submarine July 30, 1945, two days after it unloaded parts and nuclear material used in the atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. The bell later was recovered from the ship. ``We're not here to refight the war or verbally bash the Japanese. On a lovely Hawaiian morning 49 years ago, Americans who saw the sun rise did not see it set,'' said the Rev. Russell Blowers, minister of the 91st Street Christian Church and veteran of the Eighth Air Force. ``With the tolling of the bell, remind us that someday the bell will toll for us.'' ``We are hoping this will lead to bells tolling all over the country next year on the 50th anniversary,'' said Elbert Watson, chairman of the World War II National Commemorative Association, which sponsored Friday's service. Watson asked the Japanese government to apologize for the attack that drew the United States into World War II. Some Japanese are trying to persuade their leaders to apologize before President Bush visits Japan next spring. Japan has apologized to South Korea and China for its military actions in the 1930s and 1940s. No official apology has been issued to the United States. ``An apology by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu or Emperor Akihito would go a long way toward helping both countries put the war behind them, and get on with properly commemorating the 50th anniversary of World War II,'' Watson said.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Cites Gulf Readiness at Pearl Harbor Anniversary
With AM-Pearl Harbor Memorial
DOC.TEXT: An influential Democratic senator marking the anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor referred Friday to the Persian Gulf crisis and warned it is unwise to ``tempt tyrants with messages of weakness.'' Sen. Daniel Inouye of Hawaii did not mention Iraqi President Saddam Hussein by name in his speech. But the chairman of the Senate Democratic Steering Committee predicted ``this tyrant in the desert'' will be turned back by American resolve. Inouye said the United States entered World War II and the Korean War unprepared because of public demands to dismantle the military. ``Today we once again find ourselves with a tyrant ready to test the will and resolve of the American people,'' Inouye said. ``But, this time, this tyrant knows that our barricades have not been torn down and that our swords and spears have not been permitted to rust, and that the people of America, if circumstances force them to do so, are willing to send their sons and daughters to stop this tyrant,'' he said. ``Many of us who solemnly gather this morning have felt the hot sting of shrapnel and seen our bodies torn by bullets,'' said Inouye, who lost his right arm during World War II combat. ``Though we sing the many songs of glory, we know that war is ugly, dirty, painful, and deadly.'' But to make certain American men and women need not go into combat, ``we should always listen to the wise words of the ancient ones who counsel our people not to tempt tyrants with messages of weakness,'' he said. ``We should always remember this moment of infamy.'' The ceremony aboard the USS Arizona Memorial included wreath presentations by veterans, patriotic and civic organizations, a 21-gun salute and echo taps. One minute of silence was observed throughout the Pearl Harbor Naval Base at 7:55 a.m., the time the Dec. 7, 1941, attack began. The moment of silence ended with a ``missing man'' flyover by Hawaii Air National Guard jets. The gleaming, white memorial spans the sunken battleship, which still contains the remains of 1,102 crewmen who died in the attack. Author Ted Mason, a survivor of the Pearl Harbor attack, was keynote speaker at a concurrent ceremony held at the Arizona Memorial Visitor Center. Ceremonies also were held at several other Oahu military bases during the day. Honolulu city officials used the occasion to dedicate a gift from the city of Nagasaki, Japan, which provided a replica of a cathedral bell that survived the atomic bomb blast on Aug. 9, 1945.

DOC.HEAD: Final Payments Bring States' Share of Forest Sales to $346 Million
DOC.TEXT: Final payments totaling about $100 million are going out to states as their share of 1990 national forest sales receipts, the Agriculture Department said Friday. F. Dale Robertson, chief of the Forest Service, said the money is in addition to a preliminary payment of $246 million which went to the states on Sept. 19, bringing the total for the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30 to more than $346 million. By law, 25 percent of the revenues collected by the Forest Service for the sale of timber and other use of national forest resources must be returned to the states where the forests are located. Actual receipts in fiscal 1990 totaled $1.38 billion. The states are required to use the funds for schools and roads. Oregon is the biggest recipient of total forest receipts for 1990 with $150 million, followed by California, $64 million, and Washington, $37 million.

DOC.HEAD: Series of Quakes Shake Central Japan
DOC.TEXT: A series of six earthquakes registering up to 5.5 on the Richter scale shook central Japan on Friday. There were no immediate reports of damage or casualties. The first quake was reported in the Nagano and Takada areas, about 110 miles northwest of Tokyo, and around Niigata, about 160 miles northwest of the capital, the Meteorological Agency said. Five more temblors were reported within two hours in the general area. The agency said the earthquakes' epicenter was at a depth of less than three miles in western Niigata Prefecture. Police in Nagano and Niigata reported no injuries or damages. The Richter scale measures ground motion, with each digit representing a ten-fold increase in magnitude. A reading of 4 can cause moderate damage, and a 6 can bring severe damage in populated areas. The quakes were apparently too small to satisfy a prediction by Iben Browning, a New Mexico physicist and self-professed climatologist, who predicted a high probability of a severe earthquake in Tokyo, Missouri or California between Dec. 2-4. Few officials reacted to the report in Japan, one of the most earthquake-active nations in the world.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Allows Peace Camp on Saudi Border, Activists Say
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has authorized a group of Western pacifists to set up a peace camp at the Saudi border between the anti-Iraqi multinational force and Baghdad's troops, a British activist said Friday. Pat Arrowsmith, the leader of the group calling itself the Gulf Peace Team, said the first 100 volunteers will establish their camp Dec. 17. She said hundreds of others will follow. She said the group asked to be camped on the Iraqi-Saudi border to show it does not mean to side with Iraq. ``We are a neutral, autonomous group who offered to be between the two sides to stop war getting started,'' Arrowsmith said. ``We are telling them that if they want to fight, they will do that on our own bodies.'' She said Adnan Dawoud Salman, head of the Iraqi Friendship and Solidarity Society, had informed her Thursday of the official decision to allow the camp. Adnan, a senior government official and acting head of the presidency office, was not available to comment. The pacifists also intend to ask Saudi Arabia to allow a similar camp on its side of the border with Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomacy, Hostage Release Portend Peaceful Resolution of Gulf Crisis
An AP News Analysis
With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's decision to release all its hostages is the latest in a flurry of diplomatic steps that could lead to a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis. The question now is whether each side is prepared to retreat on enough other issues to reach a settlement that would let everyone save some face. Any such resolution would force all parties to step back from original aims, leaving none completely satisfied. But war could be avoided. Since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, President Saddam Hussein has proclaimed Iraq's determination to fight, if necessary, to hold onto the annexed emirate. Led by President Bush, a 26-nation allied force has massed in the gulf in readiness for a possible military strike to liberate Kuwait. Secretary of State James A. Baker III's diplomacy won Security Council approval last week for a military campaign after Jan. 15 if Saddam does not withdraw his troops from Kuwait. With both sides digging in for the Jan. 15 deadline, diplomatic initiatives suddenly burst forth, beginning the day after the Security Council's approval of the use-of-force resolution. Bush invited Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to come to Washington for talks on the crisis, and proposed sending Baker to Baghdad to meet with Saddam. Iraq accepted the proposal within days. Even more dramatically, Saddam on Thursday proposed the release of all hostages, and the Iraqi parliament approved the action Friday. Iraqi officials predicted they would all be home by Christmas. The hostage release fulfills one of the three key demands of the Security Council. Iraq still must withdraw from Kuwait and restore the emir's government. Saddam, for his part, has said that any withdrawal from Kuwait must be discussed in conjunction with an overall Middle East peace settlement that would result in a homeland for the Palestinians. Bush and the U.S. State Department have emphasized that there is no linkage between the gulf crisis and the Palestine issue. However, the United States has been allowing the Security Council to give ``a nod'' in the direction of a Middle East peace conference this week, as one high-ranking U.S. diplomat put it privately. The United States has a longstanding policy of supporting an international Middle East peace conference ``at an appropriate time,'' but has never let the Security Council come out in favor of such a high-level meeting - which Israel bitterly opposes. This week, however, the United States agreed in principle with the other Security Council members with veto power - the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China - to let the council endorse such a conference. A comprehensive Middle East peace settlement would necessarily have to settle the Palestinian homeland question, Saddam's key demand. With all these elements falling into place, an overall diplomatic solution to the crisis begins to emerge. No one would get everything they want, but war could be averted. A solution could evolve following the Baker-Saddam talks and Bush's meeting with Aziz. Iraq might decide to begin discussions, the U.N.'s mid-January deadline could pass, but there would be no rush to war while talks continue. Some of the issues that would have to be dealt with in such talks are: Saddam's eventual withdrawal from Kuwait; restoration of the emir's government; and Baghdad's grievances about oil revenues and access to the gulf. Two uninhabited islands off the Shatt-al-Arab waterway to Iraq might prove to a key bargaining point - if Kuwait were to agree to lease the islands to give Baghdad security over access to the Shatt. According to some reports, Baghdad might consider withdrawing from Kuwait if it retains the southern end of the Rumailah oil filed straddling their border, thus gaining more oil revenues. Baghdad had accused Kuwait of tapping oil that was rightfully Iraq's. If talks are initiated, the Security Council might take the first steps toward a Middle East peace conference to be held ``at an appropriate time'' and ``with the participation of the parties concerned.'' But Israel would have to agree to the convening of the conference, and this is far from certain. ---
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Peter James Spielmann has covered diplomatic affairs at the United Nations for three years.

DOC.HEAD: Senior Forest Service Appointments Made
DOC.TEXT: A number of appointments to senior jobs in the Forest Service were announced Friday by the Agriculture Department. Assistant Secretary James Mosely said the appointments included: -Ronald E. Stewart will be the new regional forester of the Pacific Southwest Region headquartered in San Francisco, Calif., succeeding recently retired Paul F. Barker. -Gray F. Reynolds will be the regional forester of the Intermountain Region, headquartered in Ogden, Utah, replacing Stan Tixier, who is retiring. -Barbara Weber will replace Stewart as acting director of the Pacific Southwest Station in Berkeley, Calif. -Joan M. Comanor will replace Reynolds as staff director of the agency's land management planning staff in Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Between Hindus and Moslems in Southern India
DOC.TEXT: Violence between Hindus and Moslems broke out in southern India Friday and at least 16 people were killed in stabbings, news reports said. Four others were killed elsewhere in the nation. Authorities clamped an indefinite curfew on the southern town, Hyderabad, confining people to their homes. Press Trust of India said the violence started in the morning and continued throughout the day despite the curfew. Fighting between followers of the two faiths also erupted in northern Aligarh, where at least three people were killed and 12 injured, Press Trust reported. A curfew was also imposed in Aligarh, it said. And in Ayodhya, the flashpoint of a lingering dispute between the religious groups, a Moslem man was burned to death after Hindu fundamentalists accused him of trying to disrupt their campaign to replace a mosque with a temple. The identities of victims were not given. Indian news media do not identify the victims or perpetrators of sectarian violence for fear it might exacerbate tensions. At least 380 people have died in Hindu-Moslem violence in the last two months since Hindu fundamentalists announced plans to pull down a disputed mosque in Ayodhya and replace it with a temple. At least 22 people were killed when police opened fire on Hindu militants attempting to storm the mosque on Oct. 30 and again on Nov. 2. On Thursday, the militants resumed their campaign to storm the temple. But they did not resist when police blocked them from reaching the disputed shrine, apparently because of an understanding the event would be more symbolic than real. The religious crisis ignited by the Hindu campaign brought down the government of former Prime Minister V.P. Singh last month. Singh's coalition lost its parliamentary majority after a Hindu fundamentalist party withdrew support over the prime minister's Ayodhya policy. Singh was replaced Nov. 10 by Chandra Shekhar, who has said he will attempt to defuse the issue by holding talks with Moslem and Hindu leaders. The talks began in New Delhi earlier this week but have made no real progress. The dispute over the mosque has lingered for more than 100 years. Hindus say Moslem invaders built the small mosque atop a temple marking the birthplace of Rama, a Hindu god. Moslems say it is impossible to say where Rama was born. Hindus comprise 82 percent of India's 880 million people. Moslems make up 12 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Credit Growth Slows
DOC.TEXT: Growth in consumer credit slowed to a seasonally adjusted $1.47 billion in October, the government reported Friday. Analysts said it was another sign of a weakening economy. ``That is minuscule, a very, very small increase,'' said economist Sandra Shaber of the Futures Group, a Washington management consulting firm. ``It mostly reflects that we have a real softening in the kinds of purchases that people usually use credit for - cars, furniture, appliances.'' ``Consumer spending is weak and it's not surprising that consumer credit is weak,'' she said. ``Consumers are much more leery about using credit given the business and economic environment.'' The Federal Reserve said consumer credit grew at an annual rate of 2.4 percent, down from a revised 4.6 percent rate posted in September. The September rate was even slower than the 4.9 percent advance originally reported. ``Growth in revolving credit slowed in October from September,'' the central bank said. ``Auto loans outstanding declined further in October as did loans for mobile homes.'' Revolving, or credit card, debt increased $1.56 billion, or an annual rate of 8.6 percent. That was down from a 12.9 percent gain in September and a 13.3 percent advance a month earlier. Automobile loans declined $785 million, a 3.3 percent annual rate. Auto loans, which fell 0.1 percent in September, have declined every month this year except for January and March. Ms. Shaber said the auto loan component is more evidence that relatively strong car sales in October were due more to fleet sales than purchases by ``ordinary consumers.'' ``It verifies that it was not ordinary consumers who were buying cars in October,'' she said. Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose $880 million, a 5.0 percent rate which was up slightly from 4.9 percent the previous month. Borrowing for mobile homes fell $188 million, or a 10.0 percent rate, after declining 15.8 percent in September. The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of October at $736.7 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Students Get Space Lesson From Astronauts As NASA Battles Shuttle Woes
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Shuttle astronauts reviving the teacher-in-space dreams of Christa McAuliffe beamed a celestial lesson to 41 middle school students Friday, allowing the problem-plagued Columbia mission to create the first ``space classrooms.'' ``You may have heard of some of the problems we've been having,'' astronaut Jeffrey Hoffman told the youngsters watching him on television screens at two NASA centers. ``It's been quite an interesting and dynamic mission.'' The shuttle's $150 million Astro observatory, crippled by computer failures, was put back in operation Friday with the help of commands sent from the ground. But possibly more significant, the lessons beamed from 218 miles above Earth to American schoolchildren helped the space agency regenerate some of the goals struck down in the Challenger disaster. ``We weren't trying to take the place of what they were going to do on Challenger,'' said Karen Widenhofer, a Madison County, Ala., teacher on temporary assignment with NASA who assisted in the classroom Friday at Marshall Space Flight Center at Huntsville. ``But this shows that NASA is still interested in education and encouraging students in science and math. ``NASA still plans to put a teacher in space.'' Friday's space lesson, conducted by four of the seven astronauts aboard Columbia, took place nearly five years after the Jan. 28, 1986 explosion of Challenger that killed all seven aboard that shuttle, including Mrs. McAuliffe, a New Hampshire schoolteacher. Denny Elkins, a ninth-grader from Snellville, Ga., was one of the 12 middle school students from four southeastern states who sat at a horseshoe-shaped desk in the space classroom at Marshall. He said he was watching on TV when Challenger's liftoff turned into a fireball in the sky. ``I saw it live because I already was interested in space travel,'' he said. ``The explosion with the biggest impression of my life. I really wanted to be an astronaut, but when I saw that, I said, `No.''' ``Now,'' he said, ``I'm reconsidering.'' During the opening 35-minute lesson, which was about 15 minutes late because of a communications linkup problem, Hoffman wore a dress shirt and tie. Usually astronauts wear casual clothes except for the space suits put on for takeoffs and landings. ``When I started thinking about giving a classroom talk in space, I thought back to my own school days and I realized that all of the men teachers I had wore ties,'' Hoffman said. ``As far as I know, nobody's ever worn a tie in space. I thought I'd give it a try and see what it looks like in celebration of this space classroom occasion, and I can tell you it works quite well. You have to be a little careful in zero-gravity as you can see,'' Hoffman said, pushing down his floating, burgundy patterned tie. After Hoffman and astronaut Sam Durrance conducted their lesson, focusing on star formations and celestial radiation, Ms. Widenhofer gave students at Marshall about an hour-long class. Another 29 students took part in a similar space classroom at Goddard Space Fllight Center in Greenbelt, Md. The space schoolhouse concluded with astronauts Ron Parise and Robert Parker fielding questions from the students on Earth. ``I'd like to know what is the most tedious and painstaking part of your mission so far?'' said Mario Trimble, ninth-grader from Montgomery, Ala. ``When you fly a mission, most of the time is scheduled very tightly and there are a lot of things to do,'' responded Parise. ``Unfortunately, some failures with computer terminals have caused us to redo the way we're doing our mission. We're slowly working around everything.'' Bart Doran of Glen, Miss., wanted to know how the problems had affected the Columbia's missions. ``Very greatly,'' astronaut-astronomer Parker said, explaining that some of the telescope operations had to be done by hand instead of by computers. Troubles persisting throughout the mission have forced the astronauts to miss more than 100 planned observations. About 250 celestial targets were to have been studied. The two computers able to run the observatory's three ultraviolet telescopes both failed. Flight director Gary Coen said the cause of the computer failures has not been determined and he didn't know if it was connected to a lint buildup in the equipment. On Friday, the Astro observatory was being run by commands sent from the ground to guide the telescopes toward their desired targets. The astronauts used a joystick and, aided by information from the ground, zeroed in on objects. The success of this process Thursday night and Friday gave scientists hope that many more observations can be made before Columbia's 10-day flight ends Tuesday. ``Our attitude here is that we've got a mode we feel is going to work and we're going to go get the science,'' mission manager Jack Jones said. But he added he didn't know yet how efficient the operation would be. Spacelab Mission Operations Control's John David Bartoe congratulated the astronauts Friday morning for obtaining ``fantastic'' observations of a quasar, one of the most distant objects in the universe. All three ultraviolet telescopes focused on the quasar for 51 minutes, three minutes longer than planned. ``That's what happens when you have good, old-fashioned astronomy ... and a little bit of help from your friends,'' Parker told Bartoe. The space classroom programs will be available via some cable television companies to classrooms. To illustrate the importance of studying all types of radiation emitted from celestial objects, Durrance played two versions of the theme from the film ``Star Wars.'' Low and high-frequency notes were filtered electronically from the first version, and the taped music was unrecognizable. The same measures then were played with all the notes. ``As you can see, you need to hear all the notes to recognize the song to appreciate its full musical quality,'' Durrance said. ``Studying the universe is the same way. The universe is playing a kind of symphony in the light that its produces. ``Up here in space, our telescopes can see al the radiation to better understand the universe. That's why some other astronomers and I are in the shuttle this week using an observatory called Atro to study the stars.'' The youngsters will tour Marshall and talk with its scientists and control team members by the time their visit ends Sunday. Marshall is the location of Spacelab Mission Operations Control, which is in charge of Columbia's astronomy work. Willie Carter, an eighth-grader from Memphis, Tenn., said the country ``is sort of regaining from the Challenger explosion. This has probably put more hope in all of us. I feel better now that we've got something going compared to the explosion.''

DOC.HEAD: Abu Nidal's Group Pays for Defense of Accused Kahane Killer
DOC.TEXT: The Palestinian guerrilla group headed by terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal said Friday it would pay for the defense of El Sayyid Nosair, who is accused of murdering Rabbi Meir Kahane in New York. ``Fatah-Revolutionary Council declares it has decided to foot the defense bill of Sayyid Nosair, who has carried out the death sentence against the racist terrorist Meir Kahane,'' the group said. ``This will be a modest gift for this Arab hero,'' said the terse typewritten Arabic statement that was released in Beirut. Nosair, 35, is accused of shooting Kahane after the extremist rabbi delivered a speech at a Manhattan hotel Nov. 5. On Friday, a judge in New York suspended a $300,000 bail for Nosair and set new bail arguments for Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Campaign Ends; Church Endorses Walesa
DOC.TEXT: Poland's first popular presidential campaign officially ended Friday with Lech Walesa enjoying a big lead and underdog challenger Stanislaw Tyminski being booed at his own rally. Two days before Sunday's vote, the Solidarity chairman was awarded a strong endorsement from the head of the country's Roman Catholic Church, to which more than 90 percent of the population belongs. ``The Polish church will side with Walesa,'' Cardinal Jozef Glemp announced. The unusually explicit statement came after a meeting in Rome with Polish-born Pope John Paul II. ``This is not a political decision but a decision based on certainty of ... the common good for the whole country,'' Glemp said. Tyminski was trying to recapture the momentum that allowed him to upset Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and capture second place in the first round Nov. 25. He conducted a strong first-round race even though he was a previously unknown businessman who had just spent 21 years in Canada and Peru. However, the last state television election poll, conducted Monday and Tuesday, showed Walesa with a 73 percent to 16 percent advantage. Two other polls put the margin at 58 percent to 23 percent and 61 percent to 20 percent. On his final stop of the campaign, Tyminski told supporters in Szczecin he would not leave Poland again, regardless of the election outcome. Szczecin, a northwestern harbor city, traditionally has been a center of opposition to Walesa. But Walesa supporters made up much of the 4,000 people at the rally. They booed Tymisnki and shouted ``Back to Peru!'' One banner called Tyminski ``Tarzan from Peru.'' The rally was Tyminski's last chance to release supposedly compromising materials of Walesa that he repeatedly claimed to have in a black briefcase, but he held off, claiming disclosure ``would be harmful for our country.'' Walesa had insisted no compromising documents existed. Walesa, who rose from shipyard electrician to lead Eastern Europe's first postwar independent labor union, stayed at Solidarity headquarters Friday. Aides said he planned no public appearances before the vote. By law, electioneering was banned from noon Friday. A campaign news blackout was observed by Polish newspapers and broadcasters. Polls open at 6 a.m. Sunday and close at 8 p.m. for the country's 27 million eligible voters. If official results are not challenged, a president could be sworn in by week's end to replace President Wojciech Jaruzelski. In the first round, Walesa obtained 40 percent of the votes, compared to Tyminski's 23 percent and Mazowiecki's 18 percent. Tyminski concentrated his campaign on disaffected farmers and miners worried about their future under a shock economic program. He blamed Walesa and Mazowiecki for the hardships of the past 18 months, and promised to improve living conditions within one month. In recent days, however, Tyminski himself became an issue. Reports highlighted his long absence from Poland, links to former members of the Communist Party, reported visits to Libya, accusations he used hallucinogenic drugs in Peru and one couple's allegation that he abused his wife in Canada. ``The mobilization against Tyminski ... unfortunately resembles a witch hunt,'' the newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza commented Friday. ``Even when the cause is right, such efforts should not be organized. That is why we welcome with relief the end of the presidential race.''

DOC.HEAD: Origin is Disputed as Enola Gay Log Goes on Block
DOC.TEXT: A log chronicling the B-29 mission that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima did not sell at auction Friday after Christie's announced it could not guarantee it was the original record kept by the navigator. Auctioneer Stephen Massey opened bidding at $40,000 after saying the auction house did not doubt the authenticity of the log. ``There may be another authentic document,'' he said. No bids were offered and the auctioneer did not go lower. Before the doubts about the authenticity, the auction house had estimated the log would sell for $100,000 to $150,000. The auction house said it was a coincidence that the document was offered on Pearl Harbor Day. The navigator, Theodore J. Van Kirk, told Christie's auction house in a telephone call last week that he still has the log he wrote on the mission, Christie's manuscript specialist Chris Coover said. Christie's officials spent a week investigating the claim, then decided to back away from the catalog description of the log put on the auction block Friday, said Coover. The log had been described as ``the original manuscript navigator's log of the B-29 bomber the Enola Gay.'' Christie's considered withdrawing the log from the sale, but ``we have confidence that we're selling an authentic record of the mission,'' Coover said. Auction house officials said in a statement released late Thursday that they still believed the log was ``an authentic record ... made contemporaneously with the mission.'' Another sale item generating interest Friday was a letter written by Ethan Allen, which the University of Vermont hoped to buy to keep the historical manuscript in the state. Christie's put the log on the block for Eileen Lewis, widow of Capt. Robert A. Lewis, Enola Gay's co-pilot. Mrs. Lewis hoped to use the sale proceeds for her retirement, said Coover. Its estimated selling price was $100,000 to $150,000. The log put on sale records basic flight information, such as position, altitude, air speed, and compass direction, on three yellow, oblong sheets. The 9:15 a.m. entry of the document chronicling the 12-hour roundtrip mission from the U.S. base in the Marianas Islands to Hiroshima simply says, ``Bomb-Away.'' The bombing, which marked the world's introduction to nuclear weapons, left 130,000 casualties. On Friday, The New York Times quoted the navigator as saying during a telephone interview from his home near San Francisco, ``I am quite confident that the log which I have in my possession is the one I kept on the airplane.'' Van Kirk plans to donate his log to an as-yet-unidentified American institution, Coover said. The University of Vermont, meanwhile, sent a bidder to the sale in hopes of buying the 1787 letter by Ethan Allen, which discussed a possible trade agreement between then-independent Vermont and Canada. The university raised about $15,000 from individual collectors and small foundations to buy the letter, which was valued at $15,000 to $20,000. ``It would be a terrible shame if the letter ends up outside Vermont,'' J. Kevin Graffagnino, curator of the university's Vermont collection, said recently. ``It belongs in Vermont.'' Vermont became part of the United States in 1791. Allen led the Green Mountain Boys in a famous raid on Fort Ticonderoga during the American Revolution. The university has the most extensive collection of Allen papers in the world and this year paid $13,000 for a 1775 Allen letter.

DOC.HEAD: Coke Says Contest Winners Aren't the Real Thing
DOC.TEXT: A woman who thought she won $25,000 in a Coca-Cola USA contest said she was heartbroken to see her expected windfall vanish after being told her entry was invalid. Cheryl Hoch, 43, of Traverse City, is one of four people in Michigan who thought they won $25,000 grand prizes in the Diet Coke Super Bowl contest. They each claim to have collected all five game pieces from bottle caps and cardboard packages. But officials of the soft drink company say all of the players' game pieces are not the real thing. Hoch met Thursday with representatives from Coca-Cola and D.L. Blair Corp., the Nebraska company that judged the contest. The representatives tried to explain to her why she had not won. ``I'm not convinced,'' she said after the meeting. Coca-Cola spokesman Bob Bertini said the dispute centers around game pieces marked ``XXII,'' of which only five were printed. He said the XXII pieces the would-be winners had were not authentic. ``There, by and large, is a situation where people don't fully understand how the game operates or accidentally cut out the game piece in the wrong way,'' he said. Traverse City attorney David Kipley, who also believed he had won, said the extra XXIIs may actually be XXIII with the last digit missing - either accidentally left off by the printing machine or cut off by the contestants. Hoch, who is married with two sons, said she did not cheat by cutting off the last digit of the game piece. ``I would never even think of doing anything like that,'' she said. Bertini said there are ``a miniscule number'' of similar rejected prize claims, but he refused to specify how many. He rejected Kipley's speculation that some game pieces could have been misprinted. ``It is not a misprint problem,'' Bertini said. ``If it were a misprint, with 225 million game pieces out there, you would have widespread problems, and that is just not the case.'' He said it is coincidence that three of the cases are in Traverse City. Terry Brechbill, vice president of D.L. Blair, which informed each player that their entries were invalid, did not return phone calls Thursday and Friday. Hoch said contest representatives showed her a photocopy of her game ticket Thursday and tried to show her the beginning of the extra digit. She said she did not believe them. ``It's heartbreaking,'' she said. ``It's not nice. And it's not right.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Begin Shipping Food Reserves From Berlin
DOC.TEXT: Soviet soldiers on Friday began hauling away what used to be West Berlin's Cold War food reserves for shipment to the Soviet Union. In all, the German government is sending the Soviets 250,000 tons of food and other supplies by rail, sea and air to help ward off shortages this winter. Organizers are seeking private donations from ordinary Germans to back the relief efforts. Some Germans have even taken to the streets with tin cans, seeking contributions for the Soviets from passersby in Potsdam. A telethon on Germany's ZDF television has helped to raise $21 million dollars to date, while companies are rushing to take part in the relief program. Some of the biggest contributions will come from the Berlin reserves, which were stockpiled with the aim of feeding West Berliners for several months in case of another blockade like that off 198-1949, when the Soviets tried to choke off the city. The stockpiles of food and other supplies are being given to the Soviets free of charge. Andreas Schuldenzucker of the government press office said Friday that the Berlin food reserves alone total 214,500 tons. All of it is being sent to the Soviet Union, she said. Shaking off freezing temperatures, Soviet soldiers and German workers began loading 100 tons of powdered milk onto Red Army trucks before sunrise Friday. The trucks bore the familiar red star and the initials ``CA,'' the Russian alphabet abbreviation for Soviet Army. Clearly emblazoned on the sacks of powdered milk were the words ``Made in the Federal Republic of Germany.'' Escorted by German police and army personnel, the first convoy of 16 trucks then drove to a Soviet military airfield about 20 miles south of Berlin. There, the cargo was loaded onto planes for the flight to the Soviet Union. Kremlin officials have said they badly need the powdered milk. The Soviets themselves will transport the goods by rail, sea and air, although the German military will make six flights later this month. The Germans are predicting that their humanitarian mission for the Soviets will continue at full pace, despite some questions as to the true extent of shortages in the Soviet Union. A civic group has also urged eastern Germans to invite Soviet soldiers to spend Christmas with them, to promote better relations between the two sides. There are still an estimated 360,000 Soviet troops stationed in former East Germany. They are to be pulled out by 1994.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Upholds Life Sentence for Veteran Who Lost Legs
DOC.TEXT: A state appeals court upheld a life-without-parole murder sentence for a Vietnam veteran who lost his legs in the war, saying it had sympathy for his wounds but could not excuse his killing of a policeman. ``Most severely wounded Vietnam veterans have managed to deal with their anguish without committing murder,'' the court's presiding judge, Clinton White, said in a ruling Thursday. Stanley Verketis, who lost both legs in a land mine in 1968, returned home suffering from drastic personality changes and became addicted to heroin and alcohol, according to testimony at his trial. He was convicted of fatally shooting police officer Arthur Koch, who had responded to a report of gunfire at Verketis' home in Fairfield northeast of San Francisco in July 1984. At his appeal, the defense argued that a life sentence was cruel and unusual punishment because of Verketis' background. The 1st District Court of Appeal agreed that Verketis would not have been waiting for the officer with a gun had he not suffered a ``life-transforming injury,'' but said that fact did not make the sentence disproportionate to the crime. ``To that extent, we feel sympathy for (Verketis) because he was, in fact, the victim of events beyond his control,'' White said in the 3-0 decision. White said the same argument could be made for black criminals from the inner city - that they are victims of poverty and racism. He said society's responsibility for those conditions would not make an otherwise valid sentence cruel and unusual punishment.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Speeding Aid to El Salvador After Rebel Missile Attacks
DOC.TEXT: The United States is speeding up millions of dollars in military aid to El Salvador to help fight off attacks by guerillas who have acquired sophisticated, Soviet-made missiles and used them to shoot down two Salvadoran warplanes, the State Department said Friday. Administration officials said a spent canister from a Soviet-made A-14 surface-to-air missile has been found near the area where one of the aircraft was destroyed. Margaret Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said the $48.1 million in aid will allow the Salvadoran government to replace equipment, including aircraft, damaged or destroyed in the guerilla attacks that began Nov. 20. The attacks have caused some 500 casualties in seven of the country's 14 provinces, the department said. The administration officials, speaking on condition they not be named, said the guerillas used a Soviet missile to shoot down a Salvadoran A-37 fighter bomber Nov. 23. A guerilla missile brought down an AC-47 fixed-wing gun ship on Dec. 4, they said. The officials said it had been known at the time of a guerilla offensive last year that the rebels had received A-7 surface-to-air missiles and possibly American-made Redeye missiles as well. The officials said they now have evidence that the guerillas have obtained and are using computer-guided A-14 missiles, a weapon with longer range and greater capability than the A-7. ``It would appear that the FMLN (guerillas) have recently introduced into El Salvador a new, very sophisticated generation of surface-to-air missiles, one official said, referring to the A-14. The officials said a canister from a Soviet missile has been found in ``approximately the same location'' in eastern El Salvador where the A-37 was shot down. An official said the canister was Soviet-made. He said A-14 missiles are known to exist in the Western hemisphere only in the arsenals of Cuba and those still maintained by Nicaragua's Sandinistas. Salvadoran forces discovered 24 SA-7 missiles and one U.S. Redeye on a Cessna aircraft that crashed in El Salvador last year. The official said that flight was organized by Cuba and the Sandinistas. He said the Redeye could have been captured by the Sandinistas from the now-disbanded Contra resistance forces inside Nicaragua. He noted that the Salvadoran guerillas recently have claimed that they now possess A-7, A-14 and Redeye missiles. ``We have information arms shipments do continue from Nicaragua both by land and by sea,'' the official said, But he said he is confident they are being organized without the assistance or knowledge of Nicaragua's democratically elected president, Violeta Chamorro. And he said that hundreds of the A-14 missiles are known to be in arsenals still controlled by the Sandinistas. Of the $48.1 million total in aid, $10.6 million will come from money left from the $81 million Congress appropriated for the Salvadoran armed forces in fiscal 1990. The remaining $37.5 million will be drawn from the $85 million appropriated for fiscal 1991. Under conditions imposed by Congress, the final 50 percent of the 1991 appropriation can be released only if the guerillas undertake an offensive that threatens the survival of the Salvadoran government. The department spokeswoman said that Secretary of State James A. Baker III ``has approved accelerated disbursement of fiscal year 1991 military assistance to help the government of El Salvador face the serious new escalation in FMLN guerilla offensive actions. Some military assistance funds remaining from fiscal year 1990 also will be disbursed.''

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Three Blacks in Township Shooting Spree; Six Others Killed
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen with automatic rifles fired on pedestrians, motorists and into homes in a black township outside Johannesburg, killing three people, police said Friday. Six more blacks died in other township unrest overnight, officials said. The conservative Inkatha Freedom Party told black township residents Friday they could quell the upsurge in black-on-black violence by cooperating with officials and rejecting mass action tactics such as rent strikes. At the same time, the leader of the militant Pan Africanist Congress opened a meeting of his group with a harsh appraisal of the government's reforms. Clarence Makwetu told congress delegates meeting in Soweto that President F.W. de Klerk's racial reforms were of ``no consequence.'' ``They are merely intending to reform apartheid. We say apartheid cannot be reformed but must be totally destroyed,'' said Makwetu. In its home base of KwaZulu, Inkatha supporters urged township residents to pay their rent and pay for other local services, saying this would help bring peace. Rent boycotts and other mass actions are supported by Inkatha's main rival, the African National Congress of Nelson Mandela. Factional fighting between supporters of the two groups has killed nearly 1,000 people in the Johannesburg townships since August. ``There are non-violent, democratic means of achieving results which no boycott action will ever achieve,'' said a statement from Inkatha President Mangosuthu Buthelezi. The latest violence included an assault by gunmen armed with automatic rifles in Evaton, south of Johannesburg, that killed three people Thursday night and injured seven. Police Capt. Piet van Deventer said the gunmen, who were believed to be using AK-47s, shot at motorists and pedestrians. The slain men were fired on inside their homes, the said. Also Friday, five men were found hacked and stabbed to death at Bekkersdal, southwest of Johannesburg, police said. A ninth death occurred in Natal province, according to the police report. Of South Africa's major black political groups, Inkatha is the most conservative. Buthelezi supports capitalism, opposes sanctions against South Africa, and has condemned violence as a way of fighting apartheid. He has said he is ready to participate in talks with the government on ending apartheid. The militant Pan Africanist Congress opposes sharing power with the white minority and refuses to negotiate with the government. It has had little influence in the anti-apartheid movement, overshadowed by the much larger African National Congress and Inkatha. In other developments: -African National Congress leader Mandela released a letter Thursday saying his group was reviewing its stand on sanctions but wanted them to remain in effect for the time being. The letter was to leaders of the European Community, which has indicated member countries may relax sanctions. -A judge refused bail Friday to a right-wing extremist who claimed responsibility for bombing offices of the governing National Party. Piet Rudolph faces six charges of terrorism and was arrested in September after months of evading the authorities. While in hiding, he sent a videotape to news media declaring war on the government for its racial reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Asks NATO Allies to Send Combat Troops to Gulf
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney asked the NATO allies on Friday to send combat troops to the Persian Gulf and make more ships and planes available for transporting American troops and weaponry. He said Iraq's decision to free all foreign hostages will not alter plans for increasing the U.S. deployment in the gulf to more than 400,000 troops over the next few weeks. ``We don't think (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein deserves any praise,'' Cheney said after a two-day meeting of the NATO defense ministers. The meeting reaffirmed NATO's pledge to continue work on a post-Cold War defense strategy based on a reduced U.S. presence in Europe, smaller and more integrated forces and a continued mix of conventional and nuclear arms. ``Our future force posture will be based on smaller, more mobile and flexible active forces, able to respond to aggression from any quarter,'' the ministers said in a communique. They said the gulf crisis was an example of the ``continuing risks of aggression'' from outside NATO territory that affect the allies' vital security interests. The gulf crisis figured prominently in the talks at NATO headquarters, during which British Defense Secretary Tom King also appealed for more logistical and combat help from the allies. King said Thursday he asked for ammunition, medical equipment and staff, and chemical warfare gear for Britain's gulf force, which will soon total 30,000. Although Cheney did not mention a need for protective chemical warfare gear, U.S. officials cited such a need in comments to reporters. Cheney asked the allies for help in transporting America's ``massive flow of men and equipment'' to the gulf, which includes about 100,000 troops now stationed in Europe. He also urged them to send ``heavy combat troops'' and air defense forces. ``If nations wish to commit more forces ... we'll be happy to have them,'' Cheney said. But he stressed, ``We are not dependent on that kind of assistance to get the job done.'' He reported a ``generally favorable response'' but no immediate commitments. The United States and 25 other nations have deployed troops in the Persian Gulf after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. A United Nations resolution passed on Nov. 29 gave Iraq until Jan. 15 to get out of Kuwait or face military action. The NATO allies restated their goal of a full retreat from Kuwait. Allowing Saddam to partially withdraw was reminiscent of ``appeasement of dictators in the past,'' Cheney said. To date, all NATO allies have contributed to the Persian Gulf effort with money, troops or equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Wants Own Convertible Ruble in Two Years
DOC.TEXT: The assertive Russian republic plans to make the ruble convertible on currency exchange markets in two years and promised new protection for foreign investors, officials said Friday. The statements, however, offered little assurance the vast republic could carry out its proposals in the turbulent political climate that has nearly paralyzed power in the country. The comments were made during a seminar on the Russian economy. The Russian parliament also gave preliminary approval Friday to a resolution on transition to a market economy, but then became bogged down in debate on amendments, the official news agency Tass reported. Economy Minister Gennady Filshin told participants at the seminar the ruble would be made convertible slowly in foreign exchange markets, in order to avoid a sharp drop in value that would leave the U.S. dollar the dominant currency, Tass reported. He offered no other details of the plan at the seminar, attended by financial experts and would-be investors. The dollar already has become the currency of choice for a range of transactions, from taxi rides to joint venture investments. Soviet officials have taken measures to try to boost the ruble's value by outlawing foreign currency transactions to halt ``dollarization.'' Some of the 15 Soviet republics also have said they want to create their own convertible currencies as part of their drives for independence. Participants at the conference expressed doubt that even Russia, the largest republic with 90 percent of the country's energy resources, could sustain a convertible ruble on its own, Tass reported. Russia's justice minister, Nikolai Fyodorov, also said the republic's parliament will begin debate soon on a bill to equalize foreign and Soviet business under Russian law, remove limits on foreign business activity in Russia, and allow foreign capital to be brought freely in and out of Russia. ``Taxation and customs privileges will be granted to enterprises with 100 percent foreign holdings and joint ventures that are ready to re-invest or invest in economically backward regions of Russia,'' Fyodorov said, according to Tass. He said 30,000 ``revenue inspectors'' would be hired to make sure taxes are paid by the emerging private sector businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Gabel Dead at 77; Reformer Tarred By Daughter's Charge of Nepotism
DOC.TEXT: Hortense Gabel, a judge and social reformer whose reputation was tarnished when her daughter claimed she pulled strings to get her a job with Bess Myerson's office, died Friday. She was 77. Mrs. Gabel, who died at her Manhattan home, had long been in poor health and had suffered several minor strokes this year, friends said. A leader in the fight against racial discrimination in housing after World War II, Mrs. Gabel was a justice for the trial-level state Supreme Court from 1976 until 1987. In 1988 a federal jury acquitted her of charges that she secured a job for her daughter, Sukhreet, with Ms. Myerson, the city's cultural affairs commissioner, by ruling favorably for Ms. Myerson's male companion in a divorce case. The charges were based on a report commissioned by then-Mayor Edward Koch. The report concluded that in 1983 Ms. Myerson, Koch's friend and political ally, swayed the judge to rule favorably for Carl Capasso. In exchange, the report asserted, Ms. Myerson hired Sukhreet Gabel for a $19,000-a-year job. Capasso had sued his estranged wife for divorce, and Mrs. Gabel was deciding child support and alimony payments. Mrs. Gabel insisted she knew nothing of Ms. Myerson's relationship with Capasso. Sukhreet Gabel was a key witness against her mother, who was tried along with Ms. Myerson and Capasso. She recorded telephone calls for the prosecutors and gave them bags full of documents from her mother's files. Hortense Wittstein grew up in the Bronx. A graduate of Hunter College and Columbia University Law School, she married Dr. Milton Gabel, a dentist, in 1944. In 1986, she was named ``judge of the year'' by the National Association of Women Judges, an organization she helped found. Mrs. Gabel stepped down from the bench in 1987, citing health problems. She was indicted later that year, and never returned to work after her trial. Milton Gabel died earlier this year. Besides Sukhreet, Mrs. Gabel is survived by a sister.

DOC.HEAD: Jamaican Narcotics Gang Toppled
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of federal and local agents dismantled an ``absolutely vicious'' gun-running, murdering Jamaican narcotics ring in overnight raids in New York and Texas, the FBI said Friday. Residents of the Brooklyn neighborhood where the group - called the Gulleymen Posse - was headquartered greeted the raiders as a liberating army, authorities said. James M. Fox, head of the FBI New York office, estimated that the gang took in more than $100 million in the last five years and carried out at least 10 murders on orders of its leader, Eric Vassell. The raids were conducted at several sites in Brooklyn, and in Hempstead, Uniondale and Albany, and in Dallas. Vassell escaped arrest and was believed to be in the New York area. Eighteen of 42 alleged posse members were arrested. If convicted, all face life in prison on narcotics conspiracies and racketeering charges that include murder, said Andrew J. Maloney, the federal prosecutor in Brooklyn. They also are accused of money laundering and obtaining fraudulent passports and green cards. Besides the suspects, the raiders seized more than $150,000 in cash, six buildings and 15 guns. The case was broken with information provided by several gang members now serving life sentences on guilty pleas to various crimes, including murder, Maloney said. ``Among their own, they were vicious, absolutely vicious,'' Fox said. ``This guy Vassell would kill his own people for a serious reason or for a trivial reason. He killed someone because that person said something nasty to his sister.'' Maloney described Vassell as a 31-year-old Jamaican who has fathered 14 to 18 children by various women and has ties to the ruling People's National Party in Jamaica. Vassell ``used part of his money to contribute to the PNP and it's very likely he'll flee back to Jamaica hoping for some kind of protection there,'' Maloney said. ``Every time Vassell returned to Jamaica, he took a lot of television sets and he usually had three or four guns stashed inside of each set,'' Fox said. In the complaint filed by Maloney's office, an informant is quoted as saying that guns shipped to Jamaica inside TV sets in February were ``vote-getters'' to be used in a runoff on the island. ``Whenever there is a major event in Jamaica ... Vassell sends a shipment of guns,'' the complaint said. Maloney told reporters he was not alleging that Jamaican Prime Minister Michael Manley knew what was Vassell was doing. Federal officials said the Gulleymen Posse got its name from the McGregors Gully section of Kingston, where its members were from. The posse was a heroin wholesaling and distributing operation in Brooklyn during the last decade and branched into crack in the late 1980s, when it expanded to Dallas, officials said. The posse spent hundreds of thousands of dollars in car rentals to run crack from Brooklyn to Dallas and return with guns every week, the government said. Fox said posse members offered virtually no resistance when they saw the SWAT teams descend. He said one of the arrested men said to an agent: ```You think we are a posse? You 200 cops, that's a real posse.'''

DOC.HEAD: Peanut Total to Fall Slightly, USDA Says
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: Questions about the determination of the 1991 peanut quota may be directed to: Director, Commodity Analysis Division, USDA-ASCS, Room 3741 South Building, P.O. Box 2415, Washington, D.C. 20013; facsimile machine 202-447-8261. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Peanut farmers may expect a marketing quota of 1.55 million tons in 1991, a drop of 10,000 tons from this year, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Keith Bjerke, administrator of the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, said a final quota determination must be made by Dec. 15. The law requires the annual peanut quota to be no less than 1.35 million tons. The quota is supposed to be equal to the quantity of peanuts needed to meet domestic edible, seed and related needs during the year. It represents the maximum that farmers may sent to market under eligibility for the most favorable price supports.

DOC.HEAD: New Premier Elected to Head Transition Government
DOC.TEXT: The surprise election Friday of a politically independent judge to succeed Premier Andrei Lukanov filled Bulgaria's leadership void, but the economic troubles that helped topple Lukanov persist. ``I don't want to offer the nation a cruel program,'' said Premier Dimitar Popov, head of Sofia's municipal court, ``but I don't promise anything rose-colored.'' Popov, 63, who does not belong to any political party, was nominated earlier Friday by President Zhelyu Zhelev to succeed Lukanov, who resigned Nov. 29 following protest strikes and demonstrations. Popov will head a transition government until elections next summer. His election by the 400-seat Grand National Assembly settled the lingering question over who would run the country. Parliament ordered him to present his government to the chamber within seven days. Meanwhile, foodstuffs and electricity are rationed. Many other everyday needs are in very short supply. The government announced last spring that it was unable to service the country's $11 billion foreign debt and has been seeking assistance from the West. Since Lukanov's resignation, Bulgaria has been run by Lukanov's Socialist government of former Communists on a caretaker basis. ``My activity resembles a painful operation in order to save a state and a people,'' said Popov, who helped run Bulgaria's first free elections in June. ``This is an attempt at a strong government of professionals and politicians.'' Popov also told Parliament he was accepting the job provided he gets broad support from legislators and the public. Assembly chairman Nikolai Todorov announced Popov was elected by a ``large majority,'' but did not give the number of assembly deputies who voted for him. He said 15 deputies voted against Popov and 29 abstained. His unexpected appointment came after Ginyu Ganev, the deputy chairman of parliament, refused the post. Sources said that Todor Valchev, an economics professor, also had turned it down. ``We must all realize that the issue of political power is not the most important one, but that ... of whether Bulgaria can survive,'' said Alexander Tomov, deputy chairman of the Socialist Party. ``Dimitar Popov is a suitable candidate, both as a personality and as a neutral figure,'' Lukanov said. He lauded Popov as ``a man with character ... who has shown in complicated situations that he can be non-partisan and objective.'' Popov, the son of an Orthodox priest, was born in the northern Bulgarian city of Kula. He studied law and worked for 35 years as a lawyer for transport companies and later as a judge. ``I am neutral as regards my non-membership in a political force, but I am strongly committed to the ideals of democracy,'' Popov said. ``I appeal to all political forces and labor unions to support this (future) government within the framework of the political agreement that has to be signed within the next few days,'' Zhelev told deputies. He referred to an accord being negotiated under his auspices to establish a transitional government, set a timetable for future legislative work and the drafting of a new constitution. But in his speech, Zhelev introduced the new premier without a word on his qualifications. Rather, he heaped praise on the outgoing Lukanov. ``Andrei Lukanov stepped down, not because he did not have the necessary qualities of a politician,'' he said. ``He is one of Bulgaria's most capable politicians and the most outstanding one in his party.'' ``His political drama is not of a personal nature, it is the drama of a political party doomed to separate from state power,'' the president said. He also said that ``politicians of Lukanov's caliber and abilities must not disappear from the political life of the country. His knowledge, relations and know how are necessary for the country. Bulgaria does not have so many capable politicians.'' But analysts said Lukanov was unlikely to join Popov's Cabinet. Zhelev had tried hard to set up a coalition government under Lukanov, but the Union of Democratic Forces, the main opposition alliance, rejected it. The alliance asserted that Lukanov was compromised by his Communist past. The Union of Democratic Forces was shaken this week by revelations that its chairman, Petar Beron, was a police informer under the former regime of Communist dictator Todor Zhivkov. Beron's resignation was accepted Thursday. He admitted he informed on foreign visitors while working at the Natural History Museum. But Beron said he reported to a department other than the dreaded domestic secret police.

DOC.HEAD: Germany, France Call for Common European Citizenship, Security
DOC.TEXT: Germany and France, seeking to set the tone for an European Community summit, on Friday urged that Europe create common citizenship and defense policies. But Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand said EC leaders ``should respect the obligations already made'' to the North American Treaty Organization. With the Cold War over, there has been growing discussion over the role of the U.S.-dominated NATO in Europe. Many have proposed strengthening Europe's own defenses. Kohl and Mitterrand made the proposals in a letter to Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, the host of the EC summit Dec. 14-15 in Rome. ``The political union should embrace a genuine common security policy, which at the end should lead to a common defense,'' they said. The letter was released in Bonn as NATO defense ministers announced tentative agreement on a new defense strategy. The defense ministers, meeting in Brussels, called for a reduced U.S. presence in Europe, smaller forces and maintaining a mix of conventional and nuclear arms. West Germany and the newly united Germany have been NATO's staunchest supporters, while France is not a part of the alliance's military command. The meeting of the 12 EC leaders will launch an effort to rewrite the 1957 treaty that set up the community. The new treaty will strengthen Europe's efforts toward political, economic and monetary union. Kohl and Mitterrand made a strong plea for a variety of issues that should be made part of the EC process. One proposal was to lay the foundation for ``a real European citizenship.'' The letter also mentioned greater European cooperation on immigration, drug policy and organized crime prevention. The two leaders said the EC should be ``deepened and expanded'' in the field of environmental, health, social and energy policies. Kohl and Mitterrand met Wednesday in Paris to coordinate strategies ahead of the Rome summit, the second meeting of EC leaders in two months. Italy currently holds the rotating presidency of the EC. In October, EC leaders, with the exception of Britain, agreed on a timetable, conditions and content for a gradual move toward transferring national sovereignty over currencies to a common authority.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Sentenced to Prison
DOC.TEXT: A former Salvadoran army intelligence agent who said he participated in ``death squad'' operations in his homeland was sentenced to six months in prison Friday for illegally entering the United States. Cesar Vielman Joya-Martinez was sentenced by U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton. Joya-Martinez, convicted Sept. 19, could have received a two-year prison term. The 27-year-old Joya-Martinez has said he took part in death squad operations of the Salvadoran army's First Brigade. Joya-Martinez, who had been deported from the United States in 1983, was arrested last spring after he appeared at an administrative hearing to determine if he were eligible for political asylum. Joya-Martinez's attorney, Daniel S. Alcorn, said his client returned to the United States because he feared Salvadoran soldiers were plotting to kill him to make him a scapegoat for death-squad killings.

DOC.HEAD: Low Turnout Seen in Mauritanian Elections
DOC.TEXT: Low voter registration indicated a small turnout Friday for local elections, which drew heavy participation in the first multiparty races in four years ago. The local council elections are the only political choice in the military-ruled North African nation, which gained independence from France in 1960. The 1986 vote changed the makeup of local councils, but power still rested with the central government's military committee. Soldiers patrolled the streets as polls opened early Friday. But few people lined up to cast ballots. ``I'm not voting,'' said Aly Ahmoud of Nouakchott, who walked past a polling station. ``It's better to stay home and rest. The local council for me means high taxes.'' Only 90,000 people in the capital of 700,000 had registered to vote. Authorities blame part of the problem on apathy, but residents complain of bad organization and their disdain for the bureaucracy. The authorized parties competing in Nouakchott include Marxist, Islamic fundamentalist, black nationalists and the ruling pan-Arab nationalists. The elections will not affect the military government led by Col. Maawiya Ould Sid'Ahmed Taya. The vote comes after authorities arrested as many as 300 civilians and military personnel in an alleged coup attempt Nov. 27 organized by black Mauritanians. Arabs make up about 70 percent of country's 1.5 million people and control the government and military. The rest of the population is predominately black.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect Charged in Theft of Impressionist Masterpieces
DOC.TEXT: A 30-year-old Corsican was charged Friday in connection with the 1985 theft of nine impressionist masterpieces from a Paris museum. The works, including Claude Monet's ``Impression Sunrise,'' which gave the movement its name, were stolen Oct. 27, 1985, from the Marmottan Museum. During the daytime theft, five masked gunmen held about 40 visitors and guards at bay while making off with four Monets, two Renoirs and three other works. The stolen works were recovered by police this week. The suspect, Pierre Comiti, was arrested in Corsica and flown to Paris, where he was charged Friday with receiving goods stolen in an armed robbery. Judge Catherine Courcol ordered him held indefinitely. Police questioned Comiti after finding photographs of the stolen paintings at his home in Corsica, a French-controlled Mediterranean island. He reportedly led investigators to an unoccupied villa where the paintings were being kept. The combined value of the stolen works was estimated at $20 million.

DOC.HEAD: Officials End Round of Talks on U.S. Military Bases
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Filipino officials ended a third round of talks on the future of U.S. military bases Friday without agreeing on the extent to which Philippine laws should apply to the facilities. ``Both sides understand the importance of satisfactorily addressing this vital component of the prospective bilateral defense relationship,'' a joint statement said. ``Any agreement entered into by both sides will fully reflect Philippine sovereignty as well as the full measure of equality and partnership ... the U.S. has with its other allies and partners around the world,'' the statement added. The United States controls Clark Air Base and Subic Bay Naval Base, which are among the largest American overseas military facilities, and four smaller installations under an agreement that expires in September 1991. A new treaty is required to keep the facilities after that. Philippine panel spokesman Rafael Alunan said discussions on the status of forces agreement, which defines the extent to which Philippine laws apply to the bases, will continue in January. U.S. chief negotiator Richard Armitage left Manila Friday shortly after the latest round of talks with Filipino officials led by Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus. Manglapus has said the Philippines will take over Clark and the four minor facilities after 1991, but will allow continued American access on a commercial basis. He said the Philippines was open to extending the U.S. stay at Subic Bay for five to seven years. Manila has insisted that Philippine laws be applied to the bases in economic areas such as tariffs, income taxes, duties, and licenses, and wants criminal jurisdiction over the U.S. servicemen there. But this has met with stiff resistance by the Americans. U.S. spokesman Stanley Schrager stressed that the United States does not intend to disregard Philippine laws, particularly those concerning criminal charges against any U.S. service member. He said the United States has arrangements with more than 30 other countries ensuring that U.S. base personnel facing charges do not escape prosecution. Schrager said that although the decades-old alliance between the United States and the Philippines had served both countries well, the United States accepts that the new relationship ``is not going to be the status quo.'' Alunan said the Philippines, a former U.S. colony, wants to continue the alliance with the United States but without the ``vestiges of our colonial past.'' ``We would like to ensure that the United States respects Philippine laws, and until such time that we are satisfied that they will be in fact respecting Philippine laws, which we equate to respecting Philippine sovereignty, ten I don't think we can ever sign a treaty,'' Alunan said. A new treaty on the bases has to be approved by two-thirds of the 23-member Philippine Senate. A recent poll of Senate leaders showed at least 12 opposed a continued U.S. presence on the bases, enough to vote down a proposed treaty. Critics claim a continuing U.S. presence is an affront to Philippine sovereignty.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Lawmakers Demanding Power Meet in Kremlin
DOC.TEXT: Hard-line lawmakers who want to take emergency control of the country met with legislative leaders Friday, but a powerful right-wing politician called the meeting unconstitutional and boycotted it, news reports said. The organizer of the meeting in the Kremlin played down any serious divisions, indicating he hopes the increasingly assertive hard-line politicians can be unified in the fractious political climate enveloping the country. In a separate development, a lawmaker reportedly said his faction would demand that parliamentarians vote on the ``professional aptitude'' of Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze for supporting the possible use of force against Iraq. Five groups making up the self-declared National Salvation Committee met in the Kremlin on Friday with chairmen of both chambers of the national Supreme Soviet legislature. The leaders had been expected to discuss the committee's call this week for a nationwide state of emergency, suspension of new political parties and transfer of control to the committee itself, according to an agenda carried earlier by the independent news agency Interfax. The meeting was closed to reporters, and no other details were immediately available. Vladimir Voronin, a leader of an umbrella organization of 20 groups called the Centrist Bloc of the national parliament, also had said President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``is willing'' to meet with the lawmakers later, Interfax reported. It gave no other details. The meeting with the National Salvation Committee in the Kremlin was held without a leading member of the Centrist Bloc - the ``Soyuz'' group of parliamentarians. The group claims about 500 members in the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies. Victor Alksnis, leader of Soyuz, called the self-declared committee unconstitutional and refused to take part in its meeting Friday, according to Interfax and the state news agency Tass. Instead, Alksnis reiterated his call for the central government to take ``extraordinary measures'' to halt the fragmentation of the country. ``The logic of the recent developments is really bringing home to us the need (of) creating an extremely strong authority with the broadest possible powers,'' he said, according to Tass. ``However, I believe that this authority should be created in a constitutional way,'' Alksnis told Tass. ``Otherwise, its creation will mean the usurping of power by political groups which do not represent the nation.'' Voronin, organizer of the meeting, acknowledged the differences with Alksnis, but said in a telephone interview his attitude toward Alksnis was ``definitely positive'' and he hoped for cooperation. Alksnis said last week that he will call for a vote of no confidence in Gorbachev if the president fails to show concrete progress on his plan to hold the country together with a new Union Treaty. The country is riven by autonomy-minded republics, independence movements, and a crumbling economy. Also Friday, a lawmaker identified as Col. Nikolai Petrushenko was quoted by the independent news agency Postfactum saying that Soyuz would demand parliamentarians take the vote on Shevardnadze. Petrushenko reportedly criticized the Soviet Union for taking a ``pro-American course'' in voting in the United Nations to authorize the use of force to eject Iraq from Kuwait. However, it was not clear if he spoke for the group.

DOC.HEAD: Dad Gets 30 Years For Repeated Rapes of Three Daughters
DOC.TEXT: A judge rejected a plea for mercy Friday from a man who raped his three daughters over nine years, describing the father's crimes as ``so perverted, so vile'' before sending him to prison for 30 years. The mother was sentenced Thursday to 15 years for complicity. The victims, now aged 17, 20 and 23, conceived 10 times.
