The mother took them for abortions each time, the prosecutor said. ``I suffered as well. I can't say I suffered as much as my daughters,'' the father, 43, told the judge. ``For me to do something like this to someone I love is like sticking knives and daggers into my own body. ``I would hope justice in my case would be tempered by some mercy,'' he told Baltimore Circuit Court Judge Kenneth Lavon Johnson. The judge replied that ``the defendant asks mercy and leniency - the same mercy and leniency he could not see fit to give to his own daughters.'' He sentenced the Baltimore man to three life terms for rape and 45 years for child abuse. All but 30 years were suspended. He pleaded guilty Oct. 29 to three counts of rape and three counts of child sexual abuse to avoid a trial on 30 counts of rape and child sexual abuse. The names of the parents were withheld to protect the victims' identities. The judge said he was unswayed by letters from the daughters, who asked that he receive less than 30 years. ``The acts of the defendant, the father, are so perverted, so vile and so inhumane, it requires the response of the law to the full extent,'' Johnson said. The two oldest girls are children of the mother from a previous marriage. The youngest is a child of both parents. None testified Friday. The man's wife, who described the family as ``very close, very religious,'' brought the girls to him and he raped them, Assistant State's Attorney Wanda Keyes Robinson said. The mother feigned sleep or faced the wall while the daughters screamed and fought their father, Robinson said. The mother, 43, pleaded guilty Oct. 29 to three counts of first-degree rape and three counts of sexual child abuse. Under Maryland law, a person who helps someone else commit a felony can be charged as if the person committed the crime. The abuse, which began in 1981, remained a family secret until March when the youngest victim wrote at the bottom of a history test: ``I hate life. I hate school. I hate people. I hope to die. Soon ...!!!'' Social workers were notified and the father confessed two days later. In a letter to her eldest daughter, the mother said she justified her complicity by saying that the children had two parents, were succeeding in school and ``neighbors and school officials all lauded us as a perfect family.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet Economy and AM-Germany-Soviet Food
DOC.TEXT: Six senior House Democrats urged President Bush Friday to provide emergency food, medical and technical help to the Soviet Union to help in its current crisis. ``The United States has a profound duty as the leading democracy ... of the world to demonstrate its commitment to the reform of the Soviet Union and to the eventual democratic prosperity of the peoples of the Soviet Union,'' the group wrote in a letter to Bush. Deteriorating conditions have led to shortages and long lines for food and consumer goods in Moscow and throughout the Soviet Union. On Wednesday, the Soviet ambassador to France, Yuri Dubinin, began asking for charity, distributing a list of items his countrymen need. The list included powdered milk, meat, vegetable oil, flour and other food items, as well as medicines and some consumer goods. On Friday, Soviet troops began hauling away what used to be West Berlin's food reserves of 214,500 tons, stockpiled in anticipation of a repetition of the Soviets' 1948-1949 land blockade of the city. The German government is giving the food to the Soviets. The Bush administration has said that it does not believe the Soviet Union faces famine, and that the Soviet economy will muddle through the winter. ``We would remind you that the United States remains the richest agricultural producer in the world,'' said the letter to Bush signed by Majority Leader Richard Gephardt of Missouri and these committee and subcommittee chairmen: Leon Panetta of California, Budget; Kika de la Garza of Texas, Agriculture; Tony Hall of Ohio, Hunger; Lee Hamilton of Indiana, Joint Economic and Dan Glickman of Kansas, the grains subcommittee of Agriculture.

DOC.HEAD: National TV Says Post-Earthquake Promises `Unfulfilled'
DOC.TEXT: State television, showing tear-streaked faces and ramshackle tents, said Friday on the anniversary of the 1988 Armenian earthquake that thousands of Armenians remain homeless despite government promises of help. ``We didn't fulfill our duty,'' a somber correspondent reported from Armenia on the national nightly newscast ``Vemya.'' Panning across whole blocks of idle construction equipment and tent cities, the correspondent described the failed rebuilding effort after the quake that killed 25,000. He stopped short of outright criticism of the government on its own national newscast. ``The 2-year-old state program for restoring the area of the earthquake is frustrated completely. Only a few have received new apartments. And thousands of others are doomed to spend their third winter in tents and railway cars,'' said the correspondent, identified only as an Armenian. Hundreds of people, some crying and most appearing sullen, were shown gathering in a central square in Yerevan, the capital, to honor the dead as bells tolled between 11 a.m. and noon to mark the earthquake. The first shock had hit at 11:41 a.m. exactly two years ago. The earthquake, measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale, immediately leveled hundreds of prefabricated apartment buildings and trapped tens of thousands of people under tons of rubble. Homes of 500,000 people were destroyed. Top government leaders, including President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, made widely publicized trips to the devastated areas and promised a sweeping rebuilding campaign. But two years later only about 25-33 percent of the damaged homes and buildings have been rebuilt, Soviet media reported. ``Two years to restore the house was only a promise, made from the bottom of our hearts, but still a promise,'' the correspondent narrated. The newscast showed concretes blocks, apparently intended for new housing, standing in piles on the sides of pits. Poorly clad people were shown lifting corrugated steel onto the top of tents to use as roofs. ``To this national grief is added today's troubles: empty shelves,'' said Eduard Shaknazaryan of the Armenpress News Service, referring to the worsening Soviet economy. ``There is nothing in the shops but bread and mineral water,'' Shaknazaryan said. Despite a system of rationing, food is difficult and expensive to obtain in the capital of Yerevan, he said, with a three-hour wait in line for milk, no eggs for sale, and a chicken at private markets costing about $13, or about one-tenth of a month's salary. Church bells tolled Friday across Armenia, calling survivors back to their ruined homes to lay flowers and mourning wreaths on the anniversary of the earthquake. In the villages of Leninakan and Spitak, which were hit hardest by the quake, memorial services were held to remember the hour when disaster struck. Shaknazaryan said relatives of those killed returned to the villages to place flowers or wreaths at the sites where loved ones died. Mourners reflected grimly that Friday was brilliant and sunny - the same weather as when the quake hit. The Communist Party newspaper Pravda sent four reporters across the republic to survey the lingering effects of the quake, and they came back with grim findings. ``During our present tour of Armenia, we have come to see for ourselves once again that it is impossible to write about the revival of life in the quake-flattened land with cold rationality,'' they wrote in Friday's editions. ``The tragedy of Armenia is still felt.'' In Spitak, where virtually every house was destroyed and 48,000 people were homeless, only 46 percent of the planned reconstruction has been completed, Pravda quoted Communist Party official Sergei Grigoryan as saying. Only 7-8 percent of the planned housing has been rebuilt in Leninakan, where 120,000 lost their homes, Pravda said. The newspaper Respublik Armenia published an invitation for Gorbachev and Ryzhkov to return to Armenia on the anniversary to ee the status of the reconstruction effort, but neither went to the republic. Armenian Construction Minister Gagik Martirosyan said the rebuilding was hampered by difficulties with supplies of material and equipment, as well as the increased political and social tension in the region. The TV correspondent said more than 300,000 people were flooding into Armenia from neighboring Azerbaijan to escape ethnic problems there. Armenia has been embroiled in a bitter ethnic conflict with adjacent Azerbaijan, which has blocked railways to its neighbor. Meanwhile, the government's Children's Fund chose Friday to bestow its honorary Leo Tolstoy award on Mother Teresa, the missionary who came to Armenia after the quake to help its victims.

DOC.HEAD: Lockerbie Inquiry Adjourns for Christmas
DOC.TEXT: A Pan Am official on Friday told an inquiry into the 1988 terrorist bombing of Flight 103 that one of the flight crew who died on the doomed jet should not have been on board. The inquiry then adjourned for the Christmas holidays until Jan. 22. Pan Am's director of flight services, Michael Sullivan, said Flight 103, with 246 passengers on board, should have had 12 flight attendants instead of 13. All passengers and crew died when the flight exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland, on Dec. 21, 1988. Falling debris from the jumbo jet that orginated in Frankfurt, Germany, killed 11 others on the ground. Marina Larracoechea, whose sister was a flight attendant on the Pan Am jet, asked about the discrepancy. Sullivan said he could not explain it and that the only one who could, the pursar, died on the flight. ``No one saw the extra person arrive,'' said Sullivan. The inquiry, in its 10th week, has heard evidence from 150 witnesses.

DOC.HEAD: Former State Lawmaker Pleads Guilty in Statehouse Scandal
DOC.TEXT: A former state lawmaker pleaded guilty Friday to charges of conspiring to accept a bribe and tampering with a witness in a Statehouse corruption scandal. The plea by former Rep. Tom Limehouse averted a trial set for Monday. In return for his plea, the government dropped a third charge that he took a $2,000 bribe to support legislation legalizing betting on horse and dog racing in South Carolina. Limehouse, who appeared before U.S. District Judge Falcon Hawkins, faces a maximum sentence of 30 years in prison and a $500,000 fine. The dropped charge had a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. The Summerville Republican withdrew from the Nov. 6 election but did not resign his seat like several other lawmakers under indictment. The federal probe at the Legislature has led to bribery charges against nine lawmakers and drug charges against a tenth lawmaker and a Statehouse lobbyist. Earlier this week, former state Sen. Rick Lee and former state Rep. Luther Taylor became the first of that group to be sentenced. Lee, R-Boiling Springs, got six months at a halfway house and five years' probation. Taylor, D-Columbia, was given 6{ years in prison. Lee had pleaded guilty to accepting a $2,000 bribe from lobbyist Ron Cobb for his work on behalf of the pari-mutuel betting bill. Taylor, the first to go on trial, was convicted by a jury in October on six counts of violating the Hobss Act, a federal anti-bribery law. He was charged with conspiring to solicit bribes and with accepting a total of $4,300 from a lobbyist-turned-FBI informant for supporting the betting bill. Also this week, former state Rep. Donna Moss got three years probation and a $2,500 fine on a cocaine possession charge. She was not connected with the bribery scandal, prosecutors said. Three other former House members have pleaded guilty to bribery charges and await sentencing. Meanwhile, three House members charged with selling their votes for cash await trial next month; they all won re-election to the House in November. The lobbyist charged with marijuana possession died of a lung disease in late November. A federal grand jury indicted Limehouse on Sept. 21 on the three charges stemming from ``Operation Lost Trust,'' an FBI probe of Statehouse corruption.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Airlift Begins With a Sputter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with plane waiting in Amman, CLARIFY that Amman was a stop on route, not where plane was diverted. Picks up graf 6 pvs, `Iraq's Parliament...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Western hostages in Iraq may have to wait a bit longer for the beginning of the final airlift and for the bubbly to celebrate it. A British Airways jet stocked with chilled champagne took off Friday bound for Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, to begin the exodus of remaining hostages promised by President Saddam Hussein. But the plane got stuck en route in Jordan after confusion arose over its clearance rights to land in Iraq. The British Airways flight was being closely watched by other nations hoping to send planes to evacuate their trapped citizens. Iraq's civil aviation authorities gave clearance, a British Airways spokesman said, but the airline kept the flight in Amman because a news report from Iraq quoted an unidentified official as saying permission had been denied. A British Airways spokesman said Iraqi civil aviation authorities had given permission for the plane to land in Baghdad. ``In light of what is being reported, we'll put the plane in Amman until the situation is clarified,'' the British Airways spokesman said on condition of anonymity. ``We've received no official notification of a denial.'' ``We're in touch with the Foreign Office and asking them to press for a reconfirmation of the landing permit,'' he said. Iraq's Parliament on Friday confirmed Saddam Hussein's decision to release about 8,000 Westerners, East European and Japanese hostages who have been held since the Persian Gulf crisis began with the Kuwaiti invasion of Aug. 2. Iraq said Westerners would be free to leave starting Saturday and could apply for exit permits immediately. Japan, Denmark and Italy prepared flights to carry citizens home. The Dutch reportedly were readying an Airbus jet to fly to Baghdad on Tuesday to pick up some of the 133 Dutch nationals remaining in Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Switzerland and Norway also were arranging flights to bring home seven Swiss and five Norwegians from Iraq. In New York, Pan Am spokeswoman Pamela Hanlon said the U.S. State Department had inquired about available planes. ``We're still looking into that. December is a busy travel season, but we would of course do whatever possible,'' she said. The U.S. State Department said contingency plans had been made to charter aircraft, but that nothing was scheduled until specifics about the release were known. Officials said they asked Iraq to waive exit visa requirements for the 900 U.S. citizens and other hostages held. The British Foreign Office also was pressing Iraqi authorities to expedite departures, and also were having problem getting details. The Foreign Office on Friday warned Britons hiding in Kuwait to stay put until departure logistics were clear. A similar message was broadcast in the region over Voice of America on Thursday. The Iraqis said Friday that the release offer was genuine. A spokesman at the Iraqi embassy in London said all hostages had ``the right to leave immediately'' regardless of whether they were in hiding or being detained. The spokesman said on condition of anonymity that Iraq had decided to release the hostages because ``The holy festival of Christmastime is coming and we feel that people should be with their families.'' Hoping to ferry some of this Christmas spirit, the British Airways flight carried 400 Christmas cakes, 400 bottles of champagne and 200 clean sweatsuits. ``I should think that the atmosphere on board on the way home will be euphoric, to say the least,'' said Gil Gray, pilot of the flight. British Airways said the airlift of Britons would be boosted by other aircraft, if needed. Virgin Atlantic also planned to send an aircraft to aid the evacuation. Janet Edwards, whose husband Stephen is in hiding in Kuwait, said he will wait until it is absolutely safe to emerge. ``People have an awful lot at risk and they won't give themselves up until it's been confirmed that it's safe to do so,'' Mrs. Edwards said. The Britons in hiding will listen to the BBC World Service or hear by word-of-mouth that it is safe to go, she said. It is expected to take days, at least, for Iraq to process the hundreds of Westerners held in Iraq and an estimated 2,000 others believed hiding in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Ted Turner Confirms He and Jane Fonda Officially Engaged; No Date Set
DOC.TEXT: Media magnate Ted Turner confirmed Thursday that he and actress Jane Fonda will be married, about a year from now. ``We're engaged. We are going to wait a year,'' Turner said during a private reception before a Variety Club of Atlanta dinner in his honor. Ms. Fonda shyly displayed the engagement ring given her by Turner, chairman of Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting System Inc., the parent company of Cable News Network. ``I've been married twice, but I never had one before,'' she said of the ring, an opal set between two diamonds. Turner bought the ring at Tiffany's last month in Los Angeles. At the time, a publicist for Ms. Fonda said he planned to give it to her on her birthday, Dec. 21. The marriage would be the third for both Ms. Fonda, 52, and Turner, 51. She has two children, he has five. Turner and Ms. Fonda were among 420 guests at the dinner, where Turner received the club's humanitarian award.

DOC.HEAD: Deposed Chadian President Prefers Exile in United States
DOC.TEXT: Chad's former president, ousted by rebels last weekend, hopes to find refuge in the United States, his entourage reported Friday. But Hissene Habre would like to remain in Yaounde as long as possible while searching for a country to grant him permanent asylum, the sources said. A U.S. Embassy spokesman in Yaounde reported Friday that Habre had not been in contact with its diplomats to request asylum and referred further queries to the State Department in Washington. Habre, 48, has reportedly been negotiating asylum in Zaire. But members of his entourage report that he would ultimately like to take up residence in the United States. Habre fled by aircraft on Saturday to Maoura, about 400 miles northwest of the capital, just ahead of a rebel advance into the Chadian capital of N'Djamena. He arrived in Cameroon's capital on Wednesday. The rebels were led by Idriss Deby, Habre's one-time chief mllitary adviser, who will head an interim government until promised democratic elections can be organized. Habre and Deby fell out in April 1989 over allegations that Deby was plotting a coup. Deby fled to Libya and then to eastern Sudan. There, he organized the rebellion that toppled Habre in a three-week offensive that began with border raids on Nov. 10 and ended Sunday when Deby entered N'Djamena as conqueror.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Deploys More Troops, Mobilizes Reservists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf `The U.S...' to CORRECT spelling of Schwarzkopf sted Shwarzkopf. Pickup 20th pvs, `You've got...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein has deployed some of the seven new army divisions he said he was forming to reinforce his troops in and near Kuwait, Arab sources said Friday. Also Friday, Iraq's Defense Ministry ordered all reservist farmers to report to their military units starting Dec. 17. It said those who don't will be listed as deserters and risk execution. The announcement on state radio came as U.S. military officials reported a steady buildup of Iraqi troops in occupied Kuwait. The developments indicated Saddam has no plans to relinquish Kuwait, despite upcoming talks with U.S. leaders and his announcement that all hostages will be free to leave. The Arab sources, speaking on condition of anoynmity, said it was not known whether the seven new divisions, drawn mainly from the reserves, were in Kuwait or have joined the Iraqi strategic reserve force in southern Iraq. That force includes Saddam's best troops, 120,000 of the elite Republican Guards. An Iraqi division usually has around 12,000 members. Pentagon spokesman Bob Hall said Thursday that 30,000 additional Iraqi troops detected in or near Kuwait in the last week had been moved there from the Iranian border. He estimated Iraqi forces in the area at 480,000, with 2,700 artillery guns and 4,000 of Saddam's 5,500 tanks. Saddam has been reducing his divisions on the 730-mile Iranian frontier since mid-August, when he agreed to Tehran's demands for a peace treaty to formally end the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. The Iraqi leader announced last month that he was forming the new army divisions and mobilizing another 150,000 reservists to strengthen his force in the emirate Iraq conquered Aug. 2. Saddam said they included 60,000 farmers who had been demobilized to boost food production because of the U.N. embargo imposed on Iraq. With the harvest season over, he said those men were now eligible for mobilization. The Defense Ministry announcement said the farmer reservists have three days from Dec. 17 to report in or be listed as deserters. In Iraq, deserters are executed. Thousands of the reported 100,000 men who deserted during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war were shot by firing squad, often in front of their families and neighbors. Saddam's move to beef up his forces was in apparent response to a new deployment by U.S. forces in the gulf. More than 250,000 American soldiers are now in the gulf as part of a multinational force arrayed against Iraq. By mid-January, 200,000 more troops will be in the region to boost U.S. strength to around 450,000. The U.N. Security Council has passed a resolution authorizing the use of force to drive the Iraqis out of Kuwait if they do not leave by Jan. 15. The Iraqis have built a formidable, three-layer defensive system along Kuwait's coastline and along the Saudi border. They have been reported to be extending that defensive line westward from the Kuwaiti border. The U.S. commander in Saudi Arabia, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, said early this month that the Iraqis have apparently positioned their least capable troops in the first of the three defensive layers. ``You've got the worst troops forward,'' he said. ``(This force) doesn't have very much will to do much of anything. The second level of troops ... are better. I think you've got the best troops all the way to the rear. ``I think that they're arrayed that way for the reason they they'd like us to take them head-on, dissipate our force as we go through each belt and when we're considerably weakened, the strongest force would hit us.'' An 11,000-member U.S. Marine amphibious force in the gulf has been conducting landing exercises in preparation for a possible seaborne attack on Kuwait from the east. That would presumably be launched simultaneously with sustained air strikes and a ground offensive from the south.

DOC.HEAD: Animal Rights Activists Toss Juice on Fur-Wearers at La Scala
DOC.TEXT: Animal rights activists caused a stir at the opening of the La Scala opera season Friday night when they hurled tomato juice at women wearing furs. The trio - two women and a man - hurled juice at plainclothes police who surrounded them, turning their shirts and jackets red. At least two women's furs were splattered red by the juice. ``This is not the temple of `bel canto' (beautiful song) but an exhibition of furs which drip blood!'' the man shouted as he was dragged out of the theater. The demonstrators slipped through tight security into the main entrance to attack the women in furs. Police said the three demonstrators were released without charge. La Scala's gala night, inaugurating the opera season of Italy's most renowned theater, has a long tradition of protests. However the most feared demonstrators, striking metalworkers, did not show up. Dozens of riot police quietly patroled the theater area, near the cathedral square in downtown Milan. Despite freezing temperatures, about 200 onlookers standing behind iron barriers commented on and applauded the entrance of smart theater-goers. On the artistic side, the gala night was enlightened by a rare performance of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's Idomeneo. The opera's main characters were played by Swedish tenor Gosta Winbergh and by three American singers - Delores Ziegler, Carol Vaness and Patricia Schumann. Riccardo Muti conducted the opera.

DOC.HEAD: Report: U.S. Trained Libyan POWs in Chad as Anti-Gadhafi Commandos
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Embassy said Friday it is helping Libyan prisoners of war in Chad who don't want to return home, but declined comment on a report that hundreds were trained to operate as anti-Libyan commandos. Agence France-Press, the French news agency, reported that 200 Libyan POWs were evacuated from N'Djamena on Friday aboard a U.S. Air Force plane. It said the Libyans left because of the ouster of pro-Western President Hissene Habre by a rebel movement that received much of its weaponry from Libya. According to AFP, about 700 Libyan soldiers of the 2,000 captured during 1983-87 fighting had received commando training from U.S. military advisers. AFP said the first batch of evacuees was loaded aboard a C-141 Starlifter plane and reportedly flown to Lagos, Nigeria. Barbara Shell, a spokeswoman at the U.S. Embassy in Chad, said the United States was assisting a number of Libyan POWs who did not wish to return to Libya. She said she could not comment further. According to AFP, the Libyans who received commando training initially agreed to assist the Chadian army. Later, they reportedly were placed under the command of a Libyan colonel and given commando training at a camp near N'Djamena, Chad's capital. AFP quoted unidentified sources as saying the commandos had laid mines and staged some attacks in southern Libya in recent months. After Habre's ouster a week ago by the forces of rebel leader Idriss Deby, a delegation of Libyan officials flew into N'Djamena. They arranged for the bulk of the Libyan POWs to return to Libya and reportedly sought to obtain custody of those who turned against the government of Col. Moammar Gadhafi. Libyan television reported Friday that the POWs who came home were greeted with festivities at the Tripoli airport. Rebel leader Deby has been installed as interim president, and Habre has taken refuge in Cameroon.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards $12.4 Million in `Gun For Hire' Case Against Magazine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs with reax, details on verdict; picks up 8th graf pvs: Savage's classified ... SUBS last graf, `Robert Brown ...' to DELETE now redundant first reference to Brown.
DOC.TEXT: A jury Friday found Soldier of Fortune magazine liable for $12.4 million in damages for running a ``gun for hire'' ad blamed for the 1985 killing of a businessman. Robert Brown, the magazine's founder and publisher, said he would appeal the award to the slain man's two sons. ``I'm not surprised by the verdict,'' he said. ``I think we'll see it overturned on appeal.'' Steve Glassroth, a lawyer for the sons of Richard Braun, said the judgment by the U.S. District Court jury sent a warning that ``publishers have to exercise a measure of responsibility when dealing with an ad of this nature.'' Attorneys for the magazine had argued in the First Amendment case that the publication should not be held liable and that publishers have no duty to research the background of their advertisers. The lawsuit was the second such case against the magazine to go to trial. In the previous trial seeking damages in a woman's slaying in 1985, a jury in Houston returned a $9.4 million verdict. That award was reversed on appeal last year and the U.S. Supreme Court let the decision stand. In the Alabama lawsuit, the jury heard 4{ days of testimony before deliberating for just two hours Friday. Brothers Michael, 21, and Ian Braun, 26, both of Montgomery, blamed their father's death on a ``gun for hire'' classified ad in the magazine's June 1985 issue by Richard Savage of Knoxville, Tenn. The Brauns contended their father's business associate, Bruce Gastwirth, used the ad to arrange to have Braun killed. Michael, then 16, was wounded in the Aug. 27, 1985, attack in the family's driveway in Atlanta. The jury awarded $10.4 million to Michael Braun and $2 million to the brothers jointly. Ian Braun said the verdict would never undo the emotional damage to his brother, who he said is afraid to express emotion to family members since seeing his father killed. Brown ``was certainly within his right to publish his magazine, but what goes in you've got to be responsible for,'' Ian Braun said. Michael Braun declined to comment. Savage's classified ad read: ``GUN FOR HIRE: 37-year-old professional mercenary desires jobs. Vietnam veteran. Discrete and very private. Body guard, courier and other special skills. All jobs considered.'' In 1986, the magazine stopped running such ads. Gastwirth, Savage and two associates were convicted of Braun's killing. Savage already had been convicted in a similar murder-for-hire case in West Palm Beach, Fla., as well as several attempted assassinations that went awry. They are now serving prison sentences. In closing arguments, defense attorney Jim Garrett told the jury, ``A publisher has no duty to investigate'' every advertiser, but if the magazine had checked Savage, it would have found he served in Vietnam and was a courier under Gen. William Westmoreland. Trial testimony showed Savage had no felony police record when he placed the ad, and Garrett said the ad ``did not contain a clearly identifiable risk that it is an offer to commit murder.'' A Braun family attorney, Steve Glassroth, said Soldier of Fortune should have been aware of news stories about a series of unrelated crimes in the early 1980s tied to its classified ads. Those stories should have stopped the magazine from running the personal services ads long before 1986. Brown denied seeing any of those stories. He said he ran the ads to help Vietnam veterans find jobs using their military skills.

DOC.HEAD: Valium Issued by U.S. to Combat Chemical Weapons Threat
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military is issuing injectable Valium to Persian Gulf soldiers to protect them against chemical weapons, a Navy doctor said Friday. Valium, the brand name for the drug diazepam, helps ease convulsions from severe nerve gas exposure, said Cmdr. Thad Zajdowicz, the doctor in charge of readiness and training for chemical weapons decontamination at Navy Fleet Hospital Five. The doctor said the military decided to use Valium as an anti-chemical weapon agent before the troops were deployed to Saudi Arabia in August, but the drug is only now beginning to get to the soliders. Zajdowicz said Fleet Hospital Five received its first Valium shipment last week. The drug presently issued to all service personnel along with their protective suit can reverse peripheral symptoms of nerve gas exposure - sweating, lung congestion and increases in body fluids, said Zajdowicz. Valium is commonly used as a tranquilizer and muscle relaxant. Zajdowicz, 42, said Valium was added on the advice of Col. Michael Dunn, of the Army Medical Research and Development Command. The 10-20 milligrams of Valium being issued to soldiers is a slightly higher dosage than given to patients in order to calm anxiety, said Zajdowicz of Norfolk, Va. ``The intent of the distribution will be that it will be carried as personal protection by the individual soldier, sailor or airman,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Brilliant Pre-dawn Flash of Light Was Fireball
DOC.TEXT: A dazzling blue-green flash that lit up the pre-dawn sky across much of the Midwest on Friday was a fireball burning up as it entered the Earth's atmosphere, an astronomer said. ``That blue-green flash was a fireball and anyone who saw it, well, that was great, because as long as I've been here I've never seen one. They're fairly rare,'' said April Whitt, an astronomer at the Adler Planetarium. A fireball is similar to a meteor, Whitt said, except that fireballs are made up of larger particles, pebble-sized rather than dust-sized. Dozens of people in Illinois, southern Michigan, Kentucky and Ohio called police departments, radio stations and the planetarium after witnessing the flash at 5 a.m. William Spencer of Southfield, a Detroit suburb, said he saw the light on his way to work. ``It was a big bluish-green ball of light and it had a train of yellow sparks behind it,'' he said. ``I thought it was a helicopter, it was moving fast ...Then it just disappeared. I thought it had crashed.'' In Ohio, the flash was reported by callers from Cincinnati to Toledo. Reports also were received in Louisville, Ky. Whitt said the planetarium received calls from motorists who saw the flash while driving on Chicago-area expressways. Whitt said astronomers expect a meteor shower starting Dec. 13 as Earth travels through ``a trail of junk left by a comet.'' ``That trail of junk just happens to take the orbit that the earth takes as we travel around the sun,'' she said. ``So we get to sweep through this dust pile every December.'' Officials at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., and the U.S. Naval Observatory in Washington said they had no information about satellites or other manmade space objects crashing to Earth. Maj. Thomas Niemann, a spokesman at the U.S. Space Command in Colorado Springs, Colo., said the agency also believes the object was of ``other-than-Earth origin.'' He said the center tracks about 6,700 satellites, none of which was responsible for the flash.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 25 grafs new with quotes, toasts; one graf transition; picks up 12th graf: ``That's made,'' May stand for AMs
DOC.TEXT: The White House warned Iraq Friday ``there's no lessening in the threat of war'' even with release of American hostages. But, ``Things are moving in the right direction,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater as President Bush arrived on the last stop of his South American tour. Bush came to Caracas to thank Venezuela for easing this fall's global oil crunch with increased production of crude. Fitzwater said the U.N. vote authorizing military action against Iraq ``forced this series of events. It forced Saddam (Hussein) to make concrete changes.'' Iraq still must comply with United Nations demands for its withdrawal from Kuwait and fulfill all other conditions set forth by the world organization, Fitzwater said. Bush received a 21-gun salute as he arrived in Caracas for talks with President Carlos Andres Perez. As it has on each stop of his week-long trip, the Persian Gulf crisis overshadowed events the day. Iraq's parliament overwhelmingly endorsed Saddam Hussein's order to release more than 8,000 foreign hostages. Among them are 900 Americans. ``We hope that some Americans will be able to come out tomorrow,'' Fitzwater said. Yet, Fitzwater said the crisis had not eased. ``There's no lessening in the threat of war,'' he said. ``That threat exists just as strong as ever.'' On the hostages, Fitzwater said said the United States proposed to Baghdad flying all Americans out on planes chartered from Iraqi Airlines or from other companies, the same way more than 2,000 other Americans have departed Iraq and Kuwait. As a backup, the government has been checking on the availability of U.S. airlines and charter planes, he said. Fitzwater said he believed that all Americans in Kuwait had been accounted for, and that the United States expects there will be no reprisals by Iraq against anyone who hid Americans in Kuwait. He expressed skepticism over Iraq's motives in freeing the hostages. ``They have concluded that the hostages no longer work for them and that the issue works against them,'' he said. He said Baghdad, in promising to release the hostages, was trying to divide the global coalition against Iraq and ``weaken the international will in the gulf.'' Caracas was the last stop on a week-long tour to salute the emergence of democracy and economic reforms throughout the region. As in Chile, where guerrillas set off half-a-dozen bombs and police tear-gassed anti-Bush student demonstrators, Bush's visit ignited traditional anti-American sentiments. Army and National Guard units took over the Andean city of Merida to prevent further violence from student protestors and eight people were injured in clashes between students and police in Caracas late Thursday. Several police officers were reported injred, one seriously. Students also marched against the Bush visit in Maracaibo, Venezuela's second largest city and its oil center, and in Valencia. Toasting Perez at a state dinner, Bush saluted the tide of democracy and economic reforms that have swept South America, ``leaving Cuba as the lonely totalitarian holdout in our hemisphere. ``So we are close, very close, to a democratic hemisphere, from Alaska to Argentina,'' Bush said. ``This era of peaceful change came about in no small part because of the unwavering leadership and example of a democratic Venezuela.'' In his toast, Perez said, ``Our solidarity is firm'' against Iraq. He said Venezuela supports the U.N. decisions and steps taken by the United States ``to safeguard mankind from a catastrophic war'' caused by Iraq's attempt to erase from the map ``a universally recognized state.'' As he arrived in Caracas from an overnight stop in Chile, Bush expressed disappointment over the collapse of global trade negotiations in Brussels. Bush blamed the collapse on the failure of the European Community, Japan and Korea to reduce farm subsidies, and said he hoped they would reconsider and negotiate ``real market-opening agreements while there is still time to do so.'' After Iraq invaded Kuwait, Perez joined with Saudi Arabia to lobby OPEC members to sustain production levels and stabilize prices, and increased his own country's output 20 percent to 2.4 million barrels a day. ``That's made a major contribution not just to our economy but particularly to energy-dependent economies in the developing world,'' a senior administration official said of the efforts of Venezuela and Saudi Arabia. The price of oil has fluctuated wildly since August, rising when Persian Gulf tensions increased and receding when peace prospects seemed to improve. Perez has called for talks among consumers and producers to see if a way can be found to stabilize prices. Officials said Venezuela advocates creation of a hemispheric oil reserve for emergencies, but that the United States has so far shown little interest in the idea. During his presidency, Bush has developed a warm relationship with Perez. The trip to Caracas marks the seventh time they have met. The two leaders were holding talks before a state dinner and they were to meet again Saturday before Bush returns to Washington. In a speech to businessmen in Santiago, Bush pledged that the events in Eastern Europe and elsewhere will not hamper U.S. relations with Latin America. ``We are not going to neglect Central or South America,'' Bush said. ``This is our hemisphere.'' Bush told a gathering of the Chilean-American Chamber of Commerce that with the restoration of democratic rule in Chile after 17 years of military government, ``our two nations are united as never before.'' He also said that economic reforms in Chile have led to a surge in foreign investment here and ``even better times lie ahead.'' The Chilean example, he added, demonstrates that ``market forces are the way to prosperity.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Extends Paper's Right To Employ Hawkers in Subway
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Friday said the strike-plagued Daily News could be sold by hawkers at subway and train stations for at least another 10 days. U.S. District Judge Miriam G. Cedarbaum of Manhattan continued her week-old order until Dec. 17. New York Newsday and the New York Post both applied to gain the same access and were awaiting an answer. Cedarbaum said the Daily News had shown irreparable harm, adding that its lawyers ``made a substantial showing'' that its First Amendment rights ``would be violated if I did not continue the temporary restraining order.'' The hearing was part of a lawsuit the Daily News filed last week after the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which operates the city's subway system and suburban commuter rail lines, barred hawkers. ``We are pleased with this ruling ... We are selling papers at over 100 locations in the transit system, and the judge has today affirmed our right to continue to do so,'' Daily News Vice President John Sloan said. The ruling drew an irate response from the transit authority's unions, which announced a Monday meeting with News strike leader George McDonald to determine a collective response. ``We are angry and disgusted at the court's decision on the use of hawkers,'' said Sonny Hall, president of Transport Workers Union Local 100. ``We'll have a definitive plan of action to announce on Monday.'' The lawsuit claims the Daily News depends on hawkers to distribute the paper in the transit system because virtually all newsstands there stopped carrying the paper after the Oct. 25 strike. Cedarbaum agreed the hawkers were legal. New York Newsday renewed its request Friday to place hawkers in the same stations where the News is allowed, said spokeswoman Chiara Coletti. The Post did the same, although spokesman Gary Lewi said the tabloid will not use hawkers where it already has newsstands handling the paper. MTA spokesman Tito Davila said the agency had not ruled on the Newsday permits. The Daily News has published every day during the six-week strike but distribution has been a major problem cutting circulation in half from the pre-strike 1.09 million copies daily. Newsday and the Post have made major circulation gains during the strike. A transit authority lawyer, Susan Weiner, argued the Daily News had alternative means to distribute the paper, citing vending machines. She said the MTA revoked permits originally given to hawkers because of passenger safety concerns and the fear of service disruptions. But News attorney Herbert M. Wachtell dismissed Weiner's arguments as ``frivolous.'' He claimed the MTA rescinded the hawkers' permits because of pressure from transit unions who threatened a work stoppage if hawkers were allowed to sell the paper. In extending the temporary restraining order, Cedarbaum noted that the transit authority had not provided specific examples of violence or disruptions of service.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS embargoed grafs 17-20: ``Interviewed by,'' Aziz comments
DOC.HEAD: US to Pull Diplomats From Besieged Embassy If Americans Freed
DOC.TEXT: The United States announced Friday it will pull all diplomats out of its besieged embassy in Kuwait once American hostages leave the occupied sheikdom. The top-ranking U.S. envoy in Baghdad asked Iraq to waive exit formalities to speed hostage departures. The embassy in Kuwait City, cut off from food and water for months, has been kept staffed in defiance of Iraqi orders that all embassies there shut down. And it will be considered officially open even after the eight diplomats leave, said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. ``We will expect Iraq to safeguard the premises until the legitimate government of Kuwait and our embassy staff return,'' she said. U.S. officials denied the decision was a concession to Iraqi demands that all embassies in Kuwait close. ``This is a withdrawal in body, not in spirit,'' said one State Department official. ``Our people there are humans, not symbols. We're doing what's best for them.'' On Friday, immediately after Iraq's National Assembly approved the dearture of more than 8,000 foreigners from Iraq and Kuwait, U.S. envoy Joseph Wilson asked that Americans be allowed to start leaving immediately on available commercial flights, Ms. Tutwiler said. ``He urged the government of Iraq to dispense with exit visa and passport formalities, so that people do not encounter needless bureaucratic delays,'' she said. But Iraqi Foreign Ministry officials told him they will only respond to the U.S. requests on Saturday, she said. They gave no reason, she said, but other officials noted that Friday is Islam's sabbath and government offices are closed. Tutwiler said the State Department was arranging for Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz's visit, probably on Dec. 17. But a date for his meeting with Bush won't be set until Iraq sets the date for a subsequent meeting between Secretary of State James Baker and President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad, she said. She declined to explain why the administration was setting such a condition. The United States proposed flying all the Americans out on planes chartered from Iraqi Airlines or from other companies it has used before, she said. The main task of the diplomats in Kuwait, led by Ambassador Nathaniel Howell, was to keep in touch with Americans and work for their safe release, Ms. Tutwiler said. Once that mission is accomplished, and all Americans who wish to leave Kuwait do so, ``the embassy will temporarily not be staffed because we would then have no business to do with the Iraqi occupation forces.'' The diplomats will remain accredited to the Kuwaiti government exiled in Saudi Arabia. Two British diplomats have also been holding out at their own embassy in Kuwait. The Foreign Office in London said the two British diplomats would stay in Kuwait, regardless of the U.S. withdrawal. President Bush has repeatedly expressed anger at the treatment of the U.S. diplomats, saying it violated international norms of diplomatic behavior. They have been subsisting on meager rations, with their water and electricity cut off, and prevented by Iraqi troops from leaving the compound. The United Nations Security Council adopted a resolution several weeks ago calling for the two embassies to be provided with food. But the world body was unable to make arrangements for restocking the two missions. As part of his proposal to the Iraqi Foreign Ministry, Wilson urged that water and lights be turned on at the embassy in Kuwait and the diplomats allowed to come and go freely so they can help in the evacuation operation, Tutwiler said.
DOC.NOTE: For Release at 11:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Interviewed by ABC Television's ``Nightline'' program, the Iraqi foreign minister said of the diplomats in Kuwait, ``If they leave, they will be given all the guarantees they are asking for. The building would be secure ... we take the responsibility for that, you see.'' As for Americans who have been in hiding, ``They can appear, and leave,'' Aziz said. He said Iraq was still considering the State Department's proposal that Baker's visit to Baghdad should take place on Dec. 20, 21 or 22, or else Jan. 3. Aziz repeated Iraq's position that all Middle East problems must be attacked together, including the Palestinian issue, and said that if Bush intends simply to explain U.N. resolutions and U.S. troop deployments to him, then ``I think that that's not going to be a very useful meeting. Of course, I will listen to him''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv 11:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Wilson proposed sending U.S.-chartered planes to pick up Americans in Kuwait, Tutwiler said. From Kuwait they would be flown to Baghdad and from there to Europe, she said. The State Department has also sent additional consular officers to Jordan and asked Iraq that they be allowed to go to Baghdad and help with the departure operation, she said. The State Department has been informing Americans in Iraq and Kuwait, through broadcasts of the government's Voice of America radio station, to stay tuned for further instructions on departure. The VOA has served as a channel to the Americans since the Aug. 2 invasion, when many were in hiding from Iraqi troops. The State Department has evacuated some 2,000 Americans since the invasion began, many of them women and children. Among the 750 Americans left, some may have dual citizenship - both Iraqi and American - and may not want to leave, Tutwiler said. Iraq is also holding 88 Americans at key installations as ``human shields'' against U.S. attack. On Capitol Hill, House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., appointed Intelligence Committee Chairman Anthony Beilenson, D-Calif., to lead a 20-member delegation next week to Saudi Arabia and Israel. The group will meet with Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of U.S. forces in the region, and hopes to meet with Saudi officials. The trip is from Dec. 11 through Dec. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Scatter Cold Rain Across Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms scattered cold rain from Mississippi and Louisiana to the southern Atlantic Coast on Friday as a cold front curved through the Southeast. Temperatures in most areas dipped into the 40s Friday afternoon, but warm weather continued ahead of the cold front, with temperatures rising into the 60s and 70s across the Florida Peninsula. Sunny skies also prevailed across the southern Plains states. In the areas touched by the cold front, heavier rainfall totals for the six-hour period ending at 1 p.m. EST included three-quarters of an inch at Key West, Fla., and half an inch at Albany, Ga. Elsewhere in the nation, gale warnings were in effect along parts of the western Gulf Coast, including the Galveston, Texas, area, and lake wind advisories had been issued across much of south Texas. Brisk westerly winds prevailed throuhhout the central Plains and upper Great Lakes regions. High temperatures Friday afternoon were in the 20s and 30s in much of the West, and in the 30s and lower 40s from the Great Lakes region and northern sections of the Ohio Valley to northern New England. Readings were in the 40s and 50s along the Pacific Coast and were warming into the 60s and 70s in the southwestern deserts. Yellowstone Park in Montana was the cold spot in the nation Friday with a low of 12 degrees below zero.

DOC.HEAD: Actress Margot Kidder Sues Over Injuries on Set
DOC.TEXT: Actress Margot Kidder on Friday sued the producers of a television series, claiming she may have suffered permanent injuries in a car accident during filming. In a statement of claim filed Friday in British Columbia Supreme Court, Ms. Kidder claims she has continuous muscle spasms in her neck and back, numbness and lack of circulation in her left leg, and nerve damage to her left arm, left shoulder and neck. The suit seeks damages from Toronto-based Nelvana Ltd. and N.D. Productions B.C. Ltd. of Vancouver. Ms. Kidder, 42, is also seeking damages for breach of contract and lost salary because she was allegedly fired from the series after she was unable to work. Ms. Kidder, who was herself an executive producer in the series, was to be paid $21,666 a week for 24 weeks of filming. The suit does not specify an amount for damages or other claims. Ms. Kidder claims she was injured in October while driving in a car during filming of the first episode of the series, based on the Nancy Drew mystery books. The car's brakes locked and Ms. Kidder and actress Polly Bergen were ``thrown forward in the unsecured seat, then backwards, then forward again,'' said Ms. Kidder's lawyer, Jack Finlay. Spokesmen for the defendants were not immediately available for comment. The producers wrote Ms. Kidder late last month, saying they were not responsible for her contract because she was unable to perform for seven consecutive days, according to the document filed in court by Finlay. The Canadian-born Ms. Kidder is best known for playing Lois Lane in the ``Superman'' movies.

DOC.HEAD: Brando Daughter Ruled Incompetent by Tahiti Court, Lawyers Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with judge tentatively setting trial for Jan. 14, Christian Brando not showing up in court, and comment from defense attorney. Picks up 11th graf pvs: `Shortly after ...'
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers in the murder case against Marlon Brando's son told a judge Friday that the prosecutors' star witness - the actor's daughter - was ruled mentally incompetent by a court in Tahiti. Prosecutors pressed on with efforts to get her testimony. Superior Court Judge Joel Rudof tentatively ruled that he would issue an international document requesting French assistance in returning Cheyenne Brando to the United States to testify in her brother's trial. But Rudof didn't make that ruling final and gave lawyers until Dec. 19 to file documents on the issue. Christian Brando, 32, is charged with first-degree murder in the shooting of his sister's Tahitian lover, 26-year-old Dag Drollet, at Marlon Brando's mansion May 16. Later in the day, Christian Brando's lawyer appeared in court without his client and said he was unaware the defendant had been ordered to appear for trial setting. Superior Court Judge Robert Thomas, who was to preside at the murder trial, ordered Christian Brando to be in court Tuesday for the setting of a new trial date. He said he was tentatively planning to start the trial Jan. 14. Outside court, defense lawyer Robert Shapiro reiterated that he is eager to settle the case without a trial, but indicated there has been no progress in that direction. ``We are open to sitting down with the district attorney and discussing a fair resolution to the case that would be fair to Christian, fair to the prosecution and acceptable to the public,'' Shapiro said. At the earlier hearing concerning Cheyenne Brando, Deputy District Attorney Steven Barshop said that in her last court appearance in the French Polynesian territory last September, Miss Brando said she would be willing to return and testify if her doctors allowed it. ``We are operating under the assumption that she will return voluntarily if she is subpoenaed,'' Barshop said. Attorney Michael Nasatir, who is representing the 20-year-old Miss Brando, told the judge he was informed by lawyers in Tahiti that she was placed under the guardianship of her mother, Tarita Tarapia Brando, after a hearing in Tahiti on Thursday. ``She has been declared incompetent to handle her own affairs and her child also has been put under guardianship,'' Nasatir said. He suggested that she should not be ordered back to the United States because she is an unsuitable witness. Barshop, meanwhile, said he had no direct information yet on what had occurred in Tahiti and wanted to press forward with the effort quickly to get Christian Brando's trial started. The international tangle over Miss Brando has delayed the murder trial, which was scheduled to start Nov. 5. Shortly after the shooting, she returned to Tahiti, where she had Drollet's child, was confined to a mental hospital and at one point was treated for a drug overdose, according to the Brando family. There also was a report from a Brando family spokesman in Papeete in November that she tried to commit suicide by hanging and was hospitalized. She has refused to return to California to testify. Authorities in Tahiti also have barred her exit, charging her as an accomplice in Drollet's slaying. Defense attorney Robert Shapiro maintains Christian Brando and Drollet fought over a gun that accidentally went off. He suggests Drollet's death was no more than involuntary manslaughter.

DOC.HEAD: Widow Says Surgeon Killed by AIDS Felt Risk of Infecting Patients was Small
DOC.TEXT: A surgeon who died of AIDS continued to treat patients with breast cancer after learning he had the disease because he felt the good he did them outweighed the chance he could infect them, his widow said. Dr. Rudolph Almaraz, a widely respected surgeon at Johns Hopkins died Nov. 16 of AIDS, never telling his patients or the hospital of his illness. ``The risks (of infecting patients) are minimal,'' said his wife, Betty Almaraz. ``My husband saved many, many lives, weighted against the infinitesimal risk.'' Johns Hopkins is sending letters to about 1,800 patients on whom Almaraz operated, offering them AIDS testing and counseling, but cautioning them that the chance of infection is very small. The case also has prompted the hospital to consider supporting a new state law requiring health care workers to tell their supervisors or hospitals if they are infected with communicable diseases. Betty Almaraz said her husband feared ``his loss of dignity, his loss of practice'' if he revealed that he had AIDS. But he consulted federal health officials and doctors who cared for him and followed their recommendations for continuing to practice safely. ``He was concerned about creating mountains out of molehills,'' he said. ``There was no need to alarm these people.'' Almaraz's lawyer, Marvin Ellin, has said the doctor got the disease during an operation on an AIDS patient at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City in 1983. The patient's blood squirted into Almaraz's eyes and mouth, Ellin said. The hospital says he never reported the exposure during the six months he was there. AIDS is most commonly transmitted through homosexual contact, the sharing of needles in intravenous drugs or in a blood transfusion. Betty Almaraz said her husband didn't contract AIDS by any of those means.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter Sent to Jail Over Refusal to Disclose Unpublished Information
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for 10th graf, `She was ...' to UPDATE with reporter moved to jail cell and INSERT comment from reporter; picks up 11th graf pvs, `Nine media ...
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reporter was handcuffed and taken to jail Friday for refusing to answer certain questions about her interviews with a capital murder defendant. The Texas Court of Criminal Appeal refused later in the day to consider an appeal, and gave no explanation. Earlier, an apologetic State District Judge Eric Brown gave Libby Averyt of the Corpus Christi Caller-Times one last chance to answer the questions before he signed an order to jail her for contempt of court. The 26-year-old reporter again refused. ``Miss Averyt, it appears we are both actors playing our parts,'' Brown told the reporter before sheriff's deputies led her off to jail. ``We are both doing our jobs.'' Brown ordered Averyt jailed Thursday, but did not sign the order until Friday. The judge found her in contempt of court at a pre-trial hearing in the murder trial of Jermarr Arnold. Ms. Averyt was found in contempt after she defied an ordered to testify. Instead she invoked the First Amendment and similar provisions of the Texas Constitution in refusing 12 times to answer questions about her interviews with Arnold in October and November. Averyt and the newspaper's attorney, Jorge Rangel, maintained that journalists should not be compelled to reveal information obtained from news sources if that information was not published. But Brown said the rights of a man on trial for murder outweigh press' privilege to withhold material. Attorneys for the newspaper were seeking to have Ms. Averyt released on bond. Initially the judge ordered Ms. Averyt placed in the custody of a bailiff in his court at the Nueces County Courthouse. She was later moved to a county jail cell. ``Right now, today, I'm prepared to spend the weekend in jail,'' Ms. Averyt said after her appeal was refused. ``I have not changed my mind about answering the questions ... I still have a strong belief that if this is allowed to happen, then fewer people are going to talk to me.'' Nine media organizations opposed to the reporter's jailing filed a ``friend of the court'' brief on her behalf Friday at the Criminal Appeals Court. Brown ordered Ms. Averyt jailed indefinitely until she answers a defense attorney's questions about her interviews with Arnold, who faces trial in the 1983 slaying of 21-year-old jewelry store clerk Christina Sanchez. In Ms. Averyt's reports, Arnold discussed the robbery and slaying and expressed a lack of remorse, his belief that he deserves the death penalty, his previous criminal activity and told how he manipulated the insanity defense in previous trials for other crimes. She conducted several interviews with Arnold at the jail and over the telephone. Lewis said without Ms. Averyt's testimony, the only way he could respond to the articles would be placing Arnold on the stand. That would violate Arnold's Fifth Amendment right not to testify.

DOC.HEAD: Galileo Spacecraft Making Earth Rendezvous on `Slingslot' Path to Jupiter
DOC.TEXT: The Galileo spacecraft makes a rendezvous with Earth on Saturday, using the planet's gravity like a slingshot to hurl it along on its six-year journey to the solar system's largest planet, Jupiter. Launched in October 1989, Galileo will swoop about 593 miles above the southwest Atlantic Ocean at 12:35 p.m. PST. The pass will be monitored by mission controllers at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. During the flyby, the spacecraft will measure gases that cause the ``greenhouse effect'' warming of Earth's atmosphere and will study high-altitude water vapor that helps create and destroy Earth's ozone layer, scientists said. Galileo will also be the first spacecraft with modern instruments to study the far side of the moon, which always faces away from Earth. On Oct. 18, 1989, Galileo was released from the cargo bay of space shuttle Atlantis. Then its own rocket booster launched the spacecraft on its long voyage, with arrival at Jupiter scheduled in 1995. In February, Galileo neared Venus for its first ``gravity assist'' maneuver, using the planet's gravity as a slingshot to help it reach Jupiter. Next Oct. 29, the spacecraft swoops within 600 miles of asteroid Gaspra, taking pictures and measurements. Then, on Dec. 8, 1992, Galileo zooms about 185 miles above Earth's surface in the third and final ``gravity assist'' maneuver needed to hurl it toward Jupiter. Galileo will arrive at Jupiter on Dec. 7, 1995. The spacecraft will orbit the planet and launch a probe to plung into its atmosphere.

DOC.HEAD: Costa Rica Seeks Extradition of Iran-Contra Figure
DOC.TEXT: Costa Rica asked Friday for the extradition of an Iran-Contra scandal figure charged with murder, arms and drugs trafficking and involvement in rebel operations. John Hull, 70, skipped $12,500 bail in July 1989 while awaiting trial. He has been living most recently in rented homes in Juigalpa, about 85 miles east of Managua. Hull, a millionaire U.S. emigre who became a naturalized Costa Rican in 1984, allegedly allowed the CIA use of air strips on his Costa Rican farms to resupply the Contra rebels in Nicaraguan in 1984 and 1985. A foreign ministry news release said the Costa Rican extradition request was turned over to the Supreme Court, which oversees such cases under a 1925 extradition treaty between the two countries. Hull, originally from Princeton, Ind., had been living in Costa Rica for 20 years. But Hull seemed to have disappeared again. Reporters could not find him at his home in Juigalpa, and some journalists were told he had recently left the country, traveling by land with his adopted daughter Emily. Hull was an open admirer of the U.S.-backed Contras while they fought for nine years with against the leftist Sandinista government. The Contras were disbanded in June, about two months after President Violeta Chamorro took office. During the guerrilla war, Costa Rica tried to remain neutral even though the rebels operated openly from camps near the Nicaraguan border. The charges against Hull stem from his alleged involvement in CIA operations to supply the Contras. The charges are listed in the news release as ``hostile acts against the state, premeditated homicide and illicit trafficking in drugs and weapons.'' Hull was also implicated in the 1984 assassination attempt against former Contra leader Eden Pastora. Five journalists, including an American woman, were killed and more than 20 people were wounded when a bomb went off in Pastora's camp at the border town of La Penca. Since he arrived in Nicaragua five months ago, Hull has avoided the media. Friends said he was planning to buy a cattle ranch. He was also organizing donations to the Juigalpa hospital, but otherwise kept much to himself. Costa Rican ambassador Carlos Aguilar said he last saw Hull in Managua on Tuesday ``by pure chance.'' ``He drove past me in his pickup truck,'' Aguilar said.

DOC.HEAD: Reputed Serial Killer Henry Lee Lucas Extradited to Florida
DOC.TEXT: Henry Lee Lucas, who once claimed he killed nearly 600 people in 26 states, was extradited to Florida on Friday to stand trial in four slayings. Lucas was brought from Texas, where he had been scheduled to die by lethal injection on Monday. The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals on Nov. 29 granted Lucas a stay in the 1979 slaying of an unidentified woman known as ``orange socks,'' the only clothing she was wearing when found. Lucas, 54, was indicted in May 1989 in the 1980-81 slayings of four people in the Florida Panhandle. ``We are gratified that this brutal case will finally come to trial, allowing the communities and families involved to once and for all put this matter behind them,'' said Commissioner Tim Moore of the Florida Department of Law Enforcement. No trial dates had been set. The Florida indictments accuse Lucas of first-degree murder in the Dec. 15, 1980, shooting of gas station attendant John P. McDaniel Jr. of Jackson County; the Feb. 10, 1981, shooting of Jerilyn Murphy Peoples at her Holmes County home; the March 25, 1981, strangulation and stabbing of Brenda Jo Burton in Holmes County; and the April 9, 1981, slaying of Mary Ruby McCary, Washington County. Besides the death sentence in Texas, Lucas was sentenced to six life prison terms, two 75-year sentences and a 60-year term for other convictions. Lucas said in a recent prison interview that he was anxious to deal with the other cases. ``They're just conspiring to get all the unsolved murders pinned on me,'' he said. ``I can't see why they're spending all this money on me and let guilty people run free.'' After the one-eyed drifter recanted his claims of nearly 600 murders, he said he actually was guilty of only one - that of his mother in Michigan in 1960. His former companion, Ottis Elwood Toole, 43, is imprisoned at Florida State Prison in Starke serving a life sentence on murder and arson charges. Toole accused Lucas in court documents of some of the Florida killings, while Frank Powell III, the brother of Lucas' former girlfriend, told investigators of the murder of Mrs. Peoples. Lucas has accused the pair of lying. ``I'd tell them to get their stories straight and quit lying about all these unsolved murders,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Giving Equipment to Allies to Upgrade NATO Forces
DOC.TEXT: The United States will give away thousands of tanks, armored vehicles and artillery pieces to help smaller NATO allies upgrade their forces, officials said Friday. The United States will give 2,000 M-60 tanks to Greece, Portugal, Spain and Turkey; 600 M-113 armored combat vehicles to Greece, Italy, Norway and Spain; and 180 M-110 howitzers to Denmark, Greece and Turkey. The equipment became available last month when NATO and the eight Warsaw Pact nations signed a treaty cutting conventional arms in Europe. The 16-nation NATO alliance will meet the treaty's arms ceilings through destruction of the older equipment. The transfers, part of a plan to standardize equipment across the alliance, were approved at a meeting of NATO defense ministers Friday. NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner said the donations were evidence of ``close cooperation'' within the alliance. Germany, the Netherlands and Italy - which also must reduce their forces under the conventional arms treaty - plan to make smaller transfers of sophisticated equipment to other NATO members. Officials said Germany will give 400 Leopard I tanks to Denmark, Greece and Turkey; 500 armoured vehicles to Greece and Turkey; and 150 artillery pieces to Greece, Portugal and Turkey. They said the Netherlands will transfer 130 armoured vehicles to Portugal and 100 tanks to Greece. Italy will give 100 armored vehicles to Turkey, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards $3.5 Million To Plaintiff in Suit Against Church Officials
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Friday awarded more than $3.5 million to a man who sued Roman Catholic authorities, saying he had been sexually abused by a priest when he was a boy. The man, who is now 24, was abused during his boyhood by the Rev. Thomas Adamson, who was pastor at a church in the Twin Cities suburb of Columbia Heights, according to undisputed testimony in the case. The man and his parents filed suit against the Roman Catholic archdiocese in St. Paul-Minneapolis and the diocese in the southeastern Minnesota city of Winona. The man has asked to remain anonymous. The Anoka County jury said the Archdiocese of St. Paul-Minneapolis and the Diocese of Winona together were 85 percent negligent and the man and his parents were each 5 percent negligent. Jurors decided on punitive damages against the archdiocese of $2 million and punitive damages against the Winona diocese of $700,000. The jury also decided on $855,000 in compensatory damages for the victim's past and future pain and disability, embarrassment and emotional distress, medical and therapy expenses and loss of earnings. Both the church bodies were deciding whether to appeal. Archbishop John Roach said he was disappointed with the verdict. The victim deserves some compensation but no punitive damages, Roach said. ``In the case of punitive damages, it's very clear to me there will be an appeal,'' Roach said. The plaintiff and his parents have alleged throughout the five-week trial that the archdiocese and the diocese showed willful indifference by failing to remove Adamson from duty when they knew about Adamson's 20-year history of abusing boys. Church attorneys had admitted the archdiocese and diocese were partly responsible for the plaintiff's psychological problems but denied they willfully employed an unfit priest. Adamson had admitted sexual misconduct with boys in the Winona Diocese beginning in 1961 and in the Twin Cities archdiocese after his 1975 transfer. The man's attorney, Jeffrey Anderson, had argued that Adamson's long-term and frequent abuse of the plaintiff ``irrevocably twisted and distorted'' the plaintiff's emotional growth. Anderson asked for more than $2 million in damages to compensate the plaintiff. He sought an additional $3.5 million dollars in punitive damages. The plaintiff, who was 13 when the abuse began, cried as the verdict was read and was still teary-eyed as he left the courtroom. When asked how he felt, he replied, ``Nervous.'' ``He's going through a vindication,'' Anderson said of his client. ``Now he's been told he's been vindicated. Having this over with will be very therapeutic.'' Anderson said the jury ``did what we asked, to compensate our client, and sent a message that (this kind of action) should stop.'' He added, ``I think the verdict sends a real significant message and I'm in no way disappointed.'' Roach, the spiritual leader of an estimated 665,000 Roman Catholics in the Twin Cities area, said the awarding of punitive damages ``ignores the actions w took nearly a decade ago'' to prevent similar cases of abuse. ``Our decisions certainly did not represent either willful indifference or reckless employment,'' Roach said. Kevin McDonough, chancellor of the archdiocese, said church leaders changed the way they screen candidates for the priesthood and have increased awareness of sexual abuse among priests.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Nominate Dan Blue for House Speaker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS in 2nd graf that Blue would be nation's fourth, sted third, black state speaker. Picks up 3rd graf, `The nomination ...'
DOC.TEXT: House Democrats Friday unanimously nominated Rep. Dan Blue to become the state's first black speaker. If elected on Jan. 30, Blue would become the nation's fourth black state speaker ever. The others are Willie Brown, California's current speaker, the Rev. S. Howard Woodson, who served as New Jersey's speaker from 1974-1975, and K. Leroy Irvis, who served as Pennsylvania's speaker from 1977 to 1988. The nomination by the Democrat-controlled House nearly ensures election. ``As I indicated during this campaign for speaker, I promise fairness to all members,'' Blue said after all 79 Democrats at the caucus backed his bid. ``And I do intend to fulfill that promise.'' He said Republican members ``will be accorded the respect and levels of leadership and responsibility commensurate with the many talents they bring to the Legislature.'' But he said Democrats, who control 81 of 120 House seats, will ``have the leadership positions to control and manage the flow of legislation and assume the primary responsibility for the strengths and weaknesses of the House efforts during the next session.'' Blue, 42, is a 10-year veteran of the House from Wake County.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Iraq
DOC.TEXT:
``Definitely, we would like to see everyone with his family by Christmas, because that is a very joyous and happy occasion, and it is time for family reunions.'' - Iraqi U.N. Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari.
``If they waive the visa requirement I guarantee we'll get them out as fast as we possibly can.'' - Joseph Wilson, U.S. Charge d'Affaires.
``Old Glory never came down and by God it won't.'' - Hamid El Miloudi, an Arab-American from Tennessee who had been held at a military base near Baghdad.
Here are summaries of three separate court decisions Friday involving the print media and the First Amendment.

A jury found Soldier of Fortune magazine liable for $12.4 million in damages Friday because a ``gun for hire'' ad was linked to the 1985 killing of a businessman. In the U.S. District Court case, brothers Michael and Ian Braun pinned the death of their father, Richard Braun, on a classified ad placed in the magazine's June 1985 issue by Richard Savage. The ad offered Savage's services as a ``gun for hire.'' The Brauns contended their father's business associate, Bruce Gastwirth, used the ad to arrange to have Braun killed. In closing arguments Friday, the magazine argued the publication should not be held liable and that publishers have no duty to research the background of advertisers. Magazine founder and publisher Robert Brown pledged to appeal.

A newspaper reporter was jailed for contempt of court Friday for refusing to answer questions about her interviews with a murder defendant. Libby Averyt, 26, of the Corpus Christi Caller-Times, has maintained along with her newspaper that journalists should not be compelled to reveal information from sources if that information was not published. The state district court case concerns Ms. Averyt's interviews with Jermarr Arnold, who is accused in the 1983 slaying of a jewelry store clerk. In her newspaper articles, Ms. Averyt reported Arnold's discussion of the robbery and slaying, his lack of remorse and his belief that he deserves the death penalty. The defense argues that without Ms. Averyt's testimony, Arnold may have to take the stand. That would violate Arnold's Fifth Amendment right not to testify.

A jury awarded $6 million Friday to a state supreme court justice after finding The Philadelphia Inquirer defamed him in a reprint of a 1983 series about court conduct. The Common Pleas Court jury found the reprint, which included an editorial and a cartoon, was false and defamatory, but that the original series was not false. Justice James T. McDermott sued on grounds the articles, titled ``Above the Law,'' implied he fixed cases. The justice said that ``never, ever'' did he have financial ties, receive personal gifts or have any conflicts of interest with anyone involved in cases before the Supreme Court. It was the second libel judgment against the Inquirer this year. Last May, a jury awarded Philadelphia lawyer Richard Sprague a record $34 million over a 1973 story that criticized his handling of a homicide case when he was an assistant district attorney. The Inquirer is appealing both awards.

DOC.HEAD: University Fails to Keep Ethan Allen Letter
DOC.TEXT: The University of Vermont failed at an auction Friday to keep a letter by Ethan Allen in the state. The $38,000 winning bid for the 1787 letter by the Vermont patriot was made by a New York dealer for a private manuscript library in Santa Barbara, Calif. A 10 percent commission brought the price to $41,800 at Christie's. Montreal antiquarian book dealer Helen Kahn said she bid just over $30,000 on the school's behalf but could not go higher. ``We were quite disappointed,'' she said. ``We thought it belonged in Vermont.'' Bart Auerbach, the New York dealer, said he bought the manuscript for the Karpeles Manuscript Library, a private institution owned by Dave Karpeles. The library is open to the public. The letter had a pre-sale catalog estimate of $15,000 to $20,000. The university raised as much as $15,000 from individual collectors and small foundations in Vermont to buy the letter, in which Allen discusses a possible trade agreement between independent Vermont and Canada. Vermont became part of the United States in 1791. Allen had led the Greem Mountain Boys in a famous raid on Fort Ticonderoga during the American Revolution. Thelletter shows a blending of Allen's personal and public goals, said Kevin Graffagnino, curator of the Vermont collection at the university. Because Allen and his brother, Ira, owned 300,000 acres in Franklin and Chittenden counties, the Allens wanted to make sure Vermont could trade timber and goods freely to the north, he said. Allen encouraged trade concessions between Vermont and Canada because his land would rise greatly in value, Graffagnino said, and also because that was what he thought was right for Vermont. In the letter, Allen makes it clear that Vermont is an independent republic and thus is free to make its own international decisions. ``I belong to this republic, which is not connected with the United States of America,'' Allen wrote to Guy Carleton, Lord Dorchester, former British military leader and Britain's governor of Quebec at the time. The British never did give the trade concessions and the Allens fell into debt with Montreal businessmen. The university has the most extensive collection of Allen papers in the world and officials were eager to buy the document and have it on display for the state's bicentennial next year. The university this year paid $13,000 for a letter Allen wrote in 1775.

DOC.HEAD: Celebrity Chair Auction Raises $5,000 for Chicago's Hungry
DOC.TEXT: Chairs touched by famous derrieres - from pop star Madonna to first lady Barbara Bush to Chicago White Sox catcher Carlton Fisk - went on the auction block in a benefit that raised more than $5,000 to feed the hungry. In all, 32 pieces of celebrity seating were sold Thursday night for $5,085 to support the Greater Chicago Food Depository, which distributes 20 million pounds of food a year in northeast Illinois and northwest Indiana. ``I was amazed. I didn't think we'd do so well,'' said auctioneer Leslie Hindman, whose Antique Center gallery was the site of the event. ``You can never tell how it will go with a charity auction.'' A seat on which Madonna sat during a dinner at Carlucci's restaurant in 1988 brought $225. And a black rocker used by Mrs. Bush when she read to children during a stop on her literacy campaign fetched $60. Fisk's leather-padded folding chair from the dressing room of historic Comiskey Park was the biggest money-maker. It prompted a bidding war won by Maggie Bobbitt, an accounting firm manager who plunked down $1,150 for it. Close behind the Fisk chair was a visitors' chair from the Chicago mayor's office dating to the era of the late Richard J. Daley. It brought $1,050 from Ron Onesti, 28, a Chicago sporting-goods store owner.
