DOC.HEAD: Oil Producing Nations Expected to Reject Production Ceiling
DOC.TEXT: OPEC is expected to reject attempts to cap production when the cartel meets next week, reaffirming an agreement to let oil flow while the Middle East crisis persists. Gulf sources said members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are producing about 23 million barrels per day, 500,000 barrels over the ceiling agreed to in late July just days before Iraq invaded Kuwait. Prices have fluctuated between $25 and $40 per barrel on rumors of war, well above the target price of $18 per barrel. Despite the increase, OPEC is expected to rebuff any calls to reduce production. At an emergency session in August, the 13 OPEC nations agreed to ignore the ceilings and quotas to make up for the 4 million barrel per day loss of Kuwait and Iraqi oil due to a United Nations embargo. Sources said the agreement will hold when representatives of the 13 OPEC nations open a formal meeting Wednesday in Geneva. Ministers are to begin gathering Monday for informal discussions. ``It is meaningless and harming OPEC and all its members to say oil is selling at higher than the stated price and we have to decrease production,'' a Saudi source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Saudi Arabia alone has pushed production up by about 60 percent, from 5.38 million barrels daily just before the invasion to 8.3 million barrels per day. Both Iraq and Iran will push for decreased production, a Gulf source said. Damage from the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war means Iran cannot increase production beyond its 2.64 million barrels a day quotaand it is eager for high prices to help rebuild its production. In addition, Iran has a backlog of about 40 million barrels of unsold heavy crude in Europe, the gulf source said. Iraq is expected to accuse Saudi Arabia of kowtowing to American interests at the OPEC gathering. ``They will make some noise but nobody is going to listen to them,'' the Saudi source said. ``The meeting will most likely reaffirm the August agreement that there is no quota, no ceiling until the crisis is over.'' OPEC members are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela. Iran also may push the organization to discuss cooperating with consumer nations on investing in increased production, the sources said. Saudi Arabia is likely to support the idea but argue it should be done through bilateral agreements. Saudi Arabia also is expected to reaffirm its commitment to a stable market, even in the event of fighting. Earlier this week, Saudi officials told U.S. Secretary of Energy James Watkins the country might lose up to 2 million barrels of oil daily if fighting breaks out as workers flee its northeastern fields near Iraq, industry sources said. Iraq is not expected to be able to damage the fields, but lack of personnel could force some fields to close, the sources said. Fighting alone, much less a shutdown, would likely send oil prices to unparalled heights due to market panic. Watkins told the Saudis the United States would be willing to draw down its 600-million-barrel strategic petroleum reserves to make up any shortfall during a war, the sources said. There is some question as to who will represent Iraq at the meeting. Acting oil minister Hussein Kamal, a close relative of Saddam Hussein, is unlikely to attend. A possible representative is assistant oil minister Sami Sherif Al-Takriti, who is from Saddam's native village. He was installed last year when Kamal, who also is minister of industry and military industrialization, wrested the refining industry into his domain, the Gulf source said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Estimates Milken's Crimes Worth at Least $4.7 Million
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for the government and Michael Milken are disputing the dollar amount that should be attached to the financial felon's admitted crimes. The two sides are more that $4 million apart. The number is important because an estimate of the total fraud involved in Milken's crimes will help determine when he will become eligible for parole. Milken, 44, was sentenced last month to 10 years in prison and three years' probation for his guilty plea to six felony counts related to illegal securities trading. He also agreed to pay $600 million in penalties. Under federal guidelines, if the losses from Milken's crimes exceeded $1 million he would get a recommended sentence of 40 to 52 months before qualifying for parole. If the losses totaled $200,000 to $1 million, Milken would face a recommended 24 to 36 months before parole. In letters to U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood on Thursday, prosecutors said Milken's crimes involved more than $4.7 million in fraud, while the defense placed the total at $326,000. But at a hearing, Wood said she may not include an estimate in her recommendation to the U.S. Parole Commission. She said she might instead offer parole officials guidelines to help them set a figure on their own. Parole commission rules are not precise about how to calculate wrongdoing in complex securities trading cases such as Milken's. The government said the commission should consider the illegal economic benefit to Milken and the consequences of his illegal relationships to the financial markets. Nonetheless, both sides offered their own version of Milken's admitted fraud. Assistant U.S. Attorneys John Carroll and Jess Fardella said that while it is difficult to calculate Milken's financial wrongdoing, his illegal dealings in seven transactions included in the guilty plea can be valued at a minimum of $4.7 million. The figure includes a $3 million financing fee paid to Drexel in connection with an illegal arrangement with admitted inside trader Ivan Boesky on trading in Fishbach Corp. securities. But Wood last week said the amount should not be included in the parole recommendation. On other transactions, prosecutors included $113,000 in commission income paid to Drexel related to stock manipulation of MCA Inc., plus an undetermined amount for the actual manipulation. The defense put the figure at $26,250. The government calculated damages of $862 million from fraudulent payments in an ilegal arrangement with money manager David Solomon. The defense said the total cannot exceed $300,000. Prosecutors claimed the government was defrauded of $483,000 in taxes evaded by Solomon with Milken's help through bogus trades in 1985. The defense said the figure is only $367,500. But it also claimed Drexel paid the taxes that Solomon didn't, so the government lost no money. Finally, prosecutors said Milken was to split at least $500,000 in unrealized gains with Boesky for trading in Harris Graphics securities. The defense said there is no evidence Milken ever received any gain or the money was the result of an illegality. The defense calculation amounted to $326,250 if the Solomon tax loss is discounted, and $693,000 if it is not. The discrepancies relate primarily to legal disputes over precisely what wrongdoing should be included in the calculations. Milken admitted to conspiracy, securities and mail fraud, helping Solomon file false income taxes and violating Securities and Exchange Commission regulations. Milken is to report to federal custody on March 4. No prison has yet been designated.

DOC.HEAD: Central Bank Took Hands-Off Dollar Stance Latest Period
DOC.TEXT: While the Federal Reserve didn't support the dollar during its precipitous August-to-September decline, officials at the nation's central bank say they remain concerned about the drop in the U.S. currency. The Fed said Thursday it took no action to support the dollar in the latest three-month period, when the U.S. currency touched new lows in foreign exchange trading. It was the second straight period the Fed didn't intervene. But Sam Y. Cross, an executive vice president at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said the decision not to step in ``certainly should not be regarded as any indication the United States is out of the intervention business.'' The Fed has the authority to buy and sell dollars to influence the currency's direction. The quarterly foreign-exchange report by the New York Fed showed the dollar declined 4 percent to 4.5 percent against the major European currencies in the period ended Oct. 31. Specifically, the dollar touched record lows against the German mark and Swiss franc and fell nearly 11 percent against the Japanese yen. The period was marked by a barrage of market-moving economic and political events, most notably the eruption of the Persian Gulf crisis, which had both a positive and negative effect on the dollar. On one hand, the dollar benefited from the perception it's a safe-haven currency in times of world turmoil. Indeed, the dollar reached a peak during the period on Aug. 2, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, reaching 1.6215 German marks and 151.60 Japanese yen. But the Fed report said the dollar was later ``undermined by concerns that the U.S. economy was more vulnerable than other major economies to the steep rise in oil prices caused by the conflict.'' In addition, the dollar also was hurt by continued concern over the health of the U.S. economy and rising interest rates overseas. The Fed noted that hikes in Japanese and German interest rates - as U.S. rates declined - eliminated the dollar's interest-rate advantage. The dollar currently is trading at about 1.4885 German marks and 132.15 Japanese yen. The dollar steadied in September, when finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations met in Washington and issued a statement saying exchange rates were ``broadly in line.'' There were rumors that the Fed had intervened during the period, but that was not the case. Still, Cross said ``it should not be taken as an indication U.S. authorities are indifferent to movements in the dollar or are welcoming dollar declines. To the contrary, U.S. authorities are on record in a number of recent statesments indicating their concern over the dollar declines.'' He pointed to recent testimony by Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan, who said a weaker dollar is cause for concern despite the fact that a lower dollar makes U.S. exports more competitive abroad. One ``cannot conclude that the United States is prepared to see'' the dollar weaken, Cross said. The dollar ``is in a range where we have to be very watchful and concerned.'' But the Fed does not intervene solely because of market mechanics. Cross said the decision to step in is based on a number of factors, including ``the condition in the foreign exchange market and other financial markets, the size and speed of movements in foreign exchange rates, the assessment of market attitues and sentiment and (anticipation of) the reaction to'' any Fed move as well as the broad economic and politcal climate. The last time the Fed chose not intervene for two back-to-back periods was in late 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Bankrupt Developer Sentenced
DOC.TEXT: Former Hooker Corp. chairman George Herscu was sentenced Friday to five years in prison after being convicted of corruption charges involving a state politician. Herscu, once one of Australia's 10 richest men but now bankrupt, showed no emotion when Brisbane District Court Judge Pat Shanahan imposed a sentence that was two years less than the maximum. The 62-year-old Romania native was found guilty Thursday of paying $77,000 in 1983 to a cabinet minister to influence Brisbane officials to ease pedestrian and vehicle access restrictions to a failing shopping center. Shanahan told Herscu the money must be the most unwise investment he ever made, saying it led Herscu to court, to prison and to disgrace. The judge made no recommendation as to early parole. Earlier, the developer wept in court as several character witnesses, many of them longtime friends, testified on his behalf. Herscu had pleaded not guilty to two charges of official corruption. He claimed he made the two $38,500 payments to Queensland Cabinet minister Russ Hinze, who at the time was the state minister for main roads and local government, to buy him two racehorses. But the Brisbane District Court jury found him guilty after a four-week trial. A Romanian Jew, Herscu worked in Nazi labor camps during World War II until being liberated by the Soviet Army in 1944. He moved to Australia in 1950. As a 25-year-old in 1953, Herscu bought one small grocery store then others, including one at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. In 1959, he went into property development. The beginning of the end came in 1986 when Herscu took over Hooker Corp., Australia's premier property developer with substantial U.S. interests. Herscu took out loans and spent $1 billion, in part on up-market American retailers, including Bonwit Teller. After being steered into shopping-center developments in the United States, Hooker grounded on a $1.5 billion debt in July 1989. Both Hooker and Herscu's personal company, Hersfield Developments Corp., went into liquidation. In July, Herscu and his wife, Sheila, declared themselves bankrupt. The move came two days before a bankruptcy claim made against them was to be heard in a Melbourne Court.

DOC.HEAD: Bankrupt Continental Unveils Service to Frankfurt
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy protection this week, plans to begin daily non-stop service to Frankfurt from Newark International Airport on June 1. The announcement Thursday came just three days after the nation's fifth-largest carrier sought protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. At a news conference at the airport, Continental executive vice president John Nelson said the airline received approval for landing slots in Frankfurt about two weeks ago. The announcement was delayed, he said, until Continental made arrangements to lease a plane to service the route. ``Frankfurt has emerged as one of the key business centers of Western Europe,'' Nelson said in a release, ``and we anticipate continued growth as the European Economic Community reaches its 1992 unification.'' The new route requires U.S. Department of Transportation approval, but Nelson said it would be ``virtually automatic'' and come within the next few weeks. Frankfurt would become the airline's 54th international destination. Continental has been saying since Monday's bankruptcy filing that its operations will not be affected by the financial reorganization. The airline was forced into bankruptcy court by soaring fuel costs and mounting interest payments on its $6.2 billion debt. Nelson said performance has not suffered as a result of the filing. He said traffic flow and cancellations were running at normal rates, though he acknowledged that the airline's bookings have been soft. The airline released Department of Transportation figures showing that Continental had the fifth best on-time performance among major airlines in October and the third lowest rate of mishandled baggage. ``I've been amazed,'' he said. ``Our airline is running beautifully.'' Continental is Newark airport's largest carrier, and more than one-sixth of the airline's work force of 37,000 are employed in New Jersey. Newark is Continental's second-largest hub after Houston. New Jersey Gov. Jim Florio said he was concened for the 6,000 workers at the Newark airport and planned to meet with Continental President Hollis Harris and Richard Leone, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, to discuss how the state and the agency can help the airline. The Port Authority runs Newark, LaGuardia and John F. Kennedy International airports.

DOC.HEAD: NCR Keeps Up Verbal Battle With AT&T, But Offers No Alternative
DOC.TEXT: AT&T unveiled its financing plans for a hostile $6.1 billion takeover offer of NCR Corp., but the computer maker continued its verbal battle against the telephone giant's bid. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said Thursday that Chemical Bank would lead a group of financial institutions that would provide a $6 billion line of credit for the takeover. The credit line also would back up short-term notes that the phone company plans to sell to investors to help fund the takeover. AT&T also said it plans to fund the takeover in part with some of its cash on hand, which totals more than $800 million. Speaking at a computer industry symposium in Atlanta, NCR Chairman Charles E. Exley Jr. made a passing reference Thursday to the $90-a-share takeover attempt, saying that in the past few days he has learned more about mergers and acquisitions than he ever wanted to know. ``But nothing will deter us from pursuing our vision of a new era for computing,'' Exley said, referring to NCR's plans, announced in September, to replace its entire product line with industry-standard machines that use the same microprocessor. Exley jokingly suggested that American Telephone & Telegraph Co. would be launching a new advertisting campaign with the slogan ``Reach Out and Grab Someone.'' Exley has said repeatedly the Dayton, Ohio-based company will fight AT&T's tender offer, which expires Jan. 4. However, NCR has not disclosed how it will battle the bid. Industry analysts say Exley has few options. The most likely is to find another merger partner that offers more favorable terms than AT&T, or a partner that takes only a minority stake in NCR but still block's the phone company's bid. AT&T says it wants to buy the nation's fifth-largest computer company to bolster its lackluster and unprofitable computer business, which it launched six years ago. NCR's board on Wednesday turned down an AT&T bid in which the phone company would have exchanged $90 worth of its stock for each NCR share, calling it ``grossly inadequate.'' Late Wednesday afternoon, AT&T took its offer directly to NCR shareholders and changed the terms to cash. Including all NCR stock, both outstanding shares and those provided under stock warrants, the deal is valued at about $6.1 billion. NCR said it would be willing to discuss a merger if AT&T boosted its price to $125 a share, for a total of about $8.5 billion. But AT&T called the figure ``outrageous and totally unjustified.'' Industry analysts generally believe AT&T will end up the victor, with the selling price somewhat above $90 a share. An official of a major institutional owner of NCR stock, who spoke on condition on anonymity, said he believed many NCR shareholders would wait a week or so to see how the takeover battle develops before they would sell their shares to AT&T. ``They're looking for a higher offer, or for NCR to do something to create higher value,'' he said. ``The chairman of NCR seems very shareholder-oriented, or has been in the past, and I think he is one to continue to act that way,'' he added. Several credit-ratings agencies said Thursday they were reviewing their opinions on AT&T bonds and other debt in light of the NCR bid. Gray said the move was not unexpected. AT&T also said it filed federal lawsuits in Baltimore and Columbus, Ohio, seeking rulings that federal law concerning such takeovers will prevail over state laws in the NCR bid. NCR is incorporated in Maryland. Gray described the lawsuits as routine in takeovers. NCR spokesman Mark Feighery said the company would have no comment on the suits until it studied them. For its part, NCR filed a suit in U.S. District Court in Dayton seeking a declaratory judgment that its anti-takeover provisions are valid.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS for last item to CORRECT to heaviest trading since August sted more than a year.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market turned in a mixed showing Thursday in the heaviest trading since early August as oil prices fell. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.92 to 2,602.48. Bonds slipped. The dollar and gold fell. Grain and soybean futures prices rose, livestock and pork futures were mixed, and oil prices fell for a second straight session to levels not seen for months.

DOC.HEAD: VCR Maker Challenges MCA Buyout on Antitrust Grounds
DOC.TEXT: An Arizona consumer electronics firm has filed an antitrust lawsuit to block the merger of MCA Inc. and Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., claiming they are conspiring to sabotage sales of its videocassette recorders. The federal suit, filed in Phoenix, contends Matsushita's $6.6 billion purchase of MCA violates antitrust law. Matsushita denied the allegations in a statement that said: ``We have only had time for a brief review of the material. However, even on the basis of our brief review it is apparent the suit is totally without merit.'' The suit was filed by Go-Video Inc., a Scottsdale, Ariz., company which has marketed a videocassette recorder that can record two TV programs at the same time or play one tape while recording another. Talk that Matsushita needs MCA to stay competitive after arch-rival Sony Corp. purchased Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. is a smokescreen, said attorney Joseph Alioto. Alioto has represented Go-Video in a series of actions contending Matsushita, Sony and other Asian companies want to shut out all U.S. consumer electronics makers. He said he'd taken more than 70 depositions in Japan over a three-month period that support that allegation. ``We know that if you control the software, you cnntrol the hardware. ... Except for Go-Video, they already have a monopoly in the hardware. This is to make sure guys like us don't get in,'' Alioto said. He said the Japanese companies intend to use their domination of both sides of the entertainment business to ensure that ``Go-Video's products will not play their software, and anybody else (outside Japan) who makes HDTV won't either.'' The primary objective of the Japanese companies is to dominate the high-definition television market, Alioto said in a telephone interview from San Francisco. Buying MCA gives Matsushita movies, television shows and recordings to complement its consumer electronics products. By controlling both, the company assures itself a ready supply of programming compatible with any technological improvements that emerge. The strategy was much discussed last year when Sony purchased Columbia Pictures for $3.4 billion. Many analysts believe that Sony's Beta format for VCRs might have prevailed over Matsushita's VHS if Sony had owned Columbia when the Beta format first came out. Go-Video already is pursuing its conspiracy claim in an earlier lawsuit against Matsushita and its Panasonic division; Victor Co. of Japan Ltd. and its JVC Corp. subsidiary; Sanyo Electric Co. Ltd.; Sony; and NEC Corp. Go-Video contends those companies, unable to develop a machine that can compete with Go-Video's, conspired to block marketing of it and have formed a cartel to control such products as conventional VCRs, digital audio-tape recording equipment and high-definition television. Go-Video is seeking more than $1 billion from the companies in that action, originally filed in 1987. It settled part of the suit out of court for $2 million. The suit originally named 14 Japanese and South Korean companies, as well as the Motion Picture Association of American.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman of Troubled Child World Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the board of Child World Inc., which announced this week that it would delay payments to some of its suppliers because of money problems, has resigned. The company is holding discussions with potential buyers and plans to slash prices on the merchandise in its 182 stores this weekend to boost sales. Child World is an 82 percent owned subsidiary of CNC Holding Corp., the parent of Cleveland-based Cole National Corp. Child World Chairman Dennis H. Barron, who is alo president and chief executive officer of Cole National, said in a statement he was leaving both companies to pursue other interests. The company said earlier this week it would delay until Jan. 15 paying for merchandise ordered before Wednesday, and would suspend payments on the principal on $122 million of working capital. The toy retailer said it would make interest payments on its debt and would pay cash for all merchandise ordered between Dec. 5 and Jan. 15. Child World reported a third-quarter loss this year of $14.4 million on sales of $185.6 million, compared with a loss of $4.1 million on sales of $157.3 for the third quarter of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Offers to Resign as Director, Appears in Court
DOC.TEXT: Fallen businessman Alan Bond is ready to resign as a director of Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. subsidiary to keep the company from being placed in liquidation, lawyers said today. Separately, Bond appeared today in a Perth court in connection with a criminal charge filed against him Thursday over his role in the rescue of failed financial institution Rothwells Ltd. Bond was not required to enter a plea. His next court appearance was set for Jan. 31. Bond is a onetime flamboyant businessman best known for financing the Australia's stunning triumph over the United States in the 1983 America's Cup whose brewing and mining empire collapsed in a mountain of $6 billion in debt. Bond Corp. included interests in brewing, media, resources and property. It had a gold mine and telephone company holdings in Chile, and brewing and other mining interests in the United States. The proposal that Bond and two other directors of Bond Corp. resign was made by attorneys for the directors and J.N. Taylor Holdings Ltd., a Bond Corp. subsidiary. They wanted to stall a court recommendation that a provisonal liquidator be appointed to the company. A lawyer for shareholders said the proposal should be rejected. No decision was reached. South Australian Supreme Court Justice Bruce Debelle said Thursday the liquidation order was warranted in response to action from shareholders seeking to recover $140 million that Bond Corp. owes to J.N. Taylor. Bond Corp. admits it cannot repay the cash and wants J.N. Taylor to enter into a debt-for-equity swap. In his court appearnace, Bond was required to give investigators 24 hours' notice of any intention to travel abroard. Bond is charged under the Securities Industry Code with dishonestly concealing information during attempts in 1987 to rescue Rothwells, an investment bank. He was charged as a result of the investigations of a special government task force set up to pursue convictions after Rothwells collapsed in November 1988 with losses of about $200 million.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Talks End in Failure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from Yeutter, MacSharry, moves up background grafs. Pickup 12th graf, `The talks ...' TRIMS at end. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Attempts to restructure the world trading system were suspended today after negotiators failed to end an impasse between the United States and the European Community over reductions in farm subsidies. Squabbles between the Americans and the Europeans were so intense that some delegates feared worsening relations between the United States and the 12-nation community. The talks had been aimed at modernizing and expanding free-trade rules. Reaching an agreement could have doubled world trade from its current annual $3.8 trillion over the next decade, according to a U.S. estimate. Lowered tariffs could bring cheaper consumer prices on imported goods. Businesses and Third World farm exporters could benefit from more openings to foreign markets. Proposed new rules could provide better protection against patent and copyright theft. Some officials held out hope for an eventual accord. David Woods, spokesman for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, said the 107-nation group will pursue talks at a lower level in Geneva. The announcement was madeafter four days of unsuccessful efforts to overcome a dispute between the United States and the European Community over farm supports. U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said success in the next attempt ``is clearly going to require changes in the European position on agriculture. Without a significant and substantial change in that area, we cannot bring this exercise to a conclusion.'' EC Agriculture Secretary Ray MacSharry, without naming the United States, indirectly accused Washington of pushing early in the weeklong conference for suspension - in effect failure - of the most ambitious attempt ever to revamp the world trading system. ``I think too many people came here hoping to walk away,'' MacSharry said. He added that the European Community's position would not change: ``We have what we believe to be a very concrete proposal on the table.'' Indian Commerce Minister Subramaniam Swamy predicted a break of four to six weeks while an assessment of the situation is made at GATT headquarters in Geneva. ``The entire negotiations have been hijacked by one issue, which became a bilateral issue,'' Swamy said. The talks teetered between elation and despair Thursday as hopes rose for a compromise proposal before the session ended in a bout of acrimony. The key, as it has been all week, was farm subsidies. The United States and its trade allies want the European Community to make deep cuts in its farm supports, as much as 75 percent to 90 percent, while the EC offered 30 percent cuts in one area, seeking to protect the livelihood of 10 million farmers. A compromise by the Swedish chairman of the agriculture talks proposed 30 percent cuts in all areas. The United States accepted the idea but EC members called it a ``monstrous proposal'' and a ``shocking paper,'' said EC Agriculture Minister Ray MacSharry. Australian Trade Minister Neal Blewett, allied with the United States on the issue, said the EC position turned the session into ``a sort of farce.'' Delegates discussing trade in services gave up when they heard the farm talks had ended. Germany's economics minister, Helmut Haussmann, said it was ``very menacing'' to hear reports that the trade and economics dispute was spilling over into foreign relations between the United States and EC members. After talking with U.S. delegates, Haussmann said, there were ``fears that traditionally friendly European relations with the United States might suffer.'' Analysts fear that a complete failure of the GATT talks, called the Uruguay Round after the country where they started in 1986, could mean a surge of protectionism and the creation of inward-looking trading blocs. The Uruguay Round is the eighth round of talks to update trade rules since World War II. GATT was founded in 1947.

DOC.HEAD: Saturn Considering Compensation for Shorted Dealers
DOC.TEXT: Saturn Corp. officials are considering compensation for dealers who have received far fewer of the new cars than originally promised, an official of the General Motors Corp. subsidiary says. A group made up of dealers and Saturn production and marketing employees met Wednesday at the company's Spring Hill, Tenn., factory to discuss the launch of the line of small cars, which officially went on sale in October. Since production of saleable cars began this summer, Saturn's strict quality control system has resulted in a much slower production startup than originally planned. That, in turn, has resulted in dealers opening with as few as one or two cars on their showroom floors, and some dealers have been asked to delay opening their businesses from February to April. ``A lot of information was shared (at the meeting), but there was no decision made on any of the retailers' funding issues,'' Saturn spokesman Don Habarek said. ``It still remains under review.'' ``We left the meeting with a feeling our interests were protected,'' said Greg Sutliff, a Saturn dealer from Harrisburg, Pa. ``There's no (compensation) offer,'' said Henry Faulkner III of Philadelphia, one of the Saturn dealers who has delayed opening his business. ``It's a complex issue. I wouldn't say anything other than we had a real candid discussion on a variety of issues.'' Saturn is a $3 billion project by GM to develop a new way to build cars in the United States, borrowing heavily from Japanese and European manufacturing methods. The Saturn cars are designed to compete with small Japanese nameplate cars, including the Nissan Sentra, Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla. Also in that price range are GM's Geo Prizm and the Chevrolet Cavalier, both marketed by Chevrolet dealers.

DOC.HEAD: Fleet Plans To Layoff 500 Workers
DOC.TEXT: Fleet-Norstar Financial Group plans to cut about 500 jobs by the end of the year, an official of the banking company said today. The layoffs will be scattered among Fleet's 1,000 offices in 40 states, but will primarily affect workers in New England and New York, said bank spokesman Robert W. Lougee Jr. The cutbacks ``range from the top to the bottom of the organization,'' he said. Some workers have already been notified and the others will receive pink-slips in the next few weeks, he said. Fleet posted a small profit in the third quarter and was in the black for the first nine months of the year. The Providence-based bank-holding company is being hit by the recession plaguing the Northeast and blamed the slump for most of the layoffs. ``Obviously, since much of the Northeast, if not nationally, is in a recession at this point, some of them (the layoffs) can be attributed to that,'' Lougee said. Other reductions were part of an ongoing consolidation since Fleet Financial Group merged with Norstar Bankcorp of Albany, N.Y., in 1988. Shortly after the merger, Fleet-Norstar employed 19,500 people. Today, it employs, 18,000, Lougee said. ``Some of (the layoffs) would have been done in the best of economic times,'' he said. ``We have consolidated irrespective of the economy over the last few years.'' Fleet's third-quarter earnings plummeted 60.1 percent from the same period a year ago to $38.5 million, but it was enough to give the company a $434,000 profit for the first nine months. Fleet posted a $278.9 million profit for the January-through-September period in 1989. Lougee said he would not guess on Fleet's profitability for the fourth-quarter. The work force reduction was expected to save the company about $25 million next year before one-time costs such as severance and outplacement expenses. Fleet plans to eliminate an additional $75 million in overhead expenses, including marketing and advertising costs, Lougee said. He said he did not expect any additional layoffs.

DOC.HEAD: Medicaid Formula Underpays Poor States, Overpays Rich Ones, GAO Says
With PM-Medicaid-States List
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 4 grafs new with testimony delivered; picks up 4th graf pvs, The government ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The formula used to distribute federal health care money for the needy underpays poor states while favoring richer ones, the General Accounting Office said today. Janet Shikles of the congressional investigative agency told a House subcommittee that the current formula based on per capita income often fails to reflect the true level of poverty in a state. Shikles also said the formula does not account for the ability of states to raise revenues from business sources. ``The formula does not target most federal funds to states with the greatest needs ... those with weak tax bases and high concentrations of poor people,'' she told the Government Operations subcommittee on human resources and intergovernmental relations. The government should shift to a formula using the number of people in poverty in a state combined with the total availability of ``taxable resources,'' such as business earnings and dividends distributed to out-of-state shareholders, she said. Per capita income reflects the average of individual incomes. The subcommittee is looking into the ability of state governments to pay the costs of Medicaid, the joint federal-state program to provide health care to the poor. The federal government pays 55 percent of medical expenses, while states pay the rest. According to the GAO, the combined expenditures totaled $61 billion in 1989. If the federal share had been cut to 40 percent and a revised formula used, $3.3 billion of the federal share would have been shifted to the states, the GAO said. That represents a shift of 17 percent of all federal Medicaid payments for the year. Nine states each would have received $100 million or more in additional funds as a result of the shift: Arkansas, California, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, New York, Tennessee and Texas. A dozen states, mostly in the Northeast and Midwest, each would have had payments reduced by more than $100 million. They are Connecticut, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, New Jersey, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. The GAO first recommended changing the formula in 1983, and since then Congress has authorized a substitute formula for allocating mental health and drug treatment grants, said Shikles, director of health financing and policy issues at the agency. The subcommittee has resurrected the issue because of the soaring costs of health care, combined with the economic downturn and limited federal dollars. About 26 million people are eligible, according to subcommittee data, but 13 states are being sued by hospitals and nursing homes that allege Medicaid payment rates are too low to cover the cost of doing business. The GAO said five states - Alaska, Louisiana, New Mexico, Texas and Wyoming - have high taxable resources that are disguised by the per capita income figures. In five others - Florida, Maryland, New Hampshire, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island - taxable resources are not as high as the per capita figures would suggest, it said. ``The consequence is that the federal share of Medicaid in states whose financing capacity is overstated by using per capita income is too low,'' Shikles said. The current formula is also misleading because two states with the same per capita income can have differing poverty rates, she said. Per capita income in Utah and Arkansas is $11,000, but Utah has a 20 percent poverty rate and Arkansas has a 32 percent, according to GAO data.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Officials Deny U.S. Charge of Stockpiling Oil
Precede WASHINGTON
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with Japanese denial of hoarding charges. Moving on general news wires as PM-Gulf-Japanese Oil.
DOC.TEXT: Japanese officials today denied accusations by a senior U.S. Energy Department official that Japan has been hoarding crude oil in defiance of an agreement among major consuming nations to draw down stockpiles. ``This is a complete misunderstanding,'' a senior government official said. ``We are not stockpiling.'' Linda Stuntz, a U.S. Energy Department under secretary for policy and planning, told reporters in Washington that in the months following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Japan increased imports to meet additional demand instead of drawing down stocks. She noted that Japan imported 33 percent more oil in October than it did in July, and said such actions raised doubts about future cooperative activities among consuming nations in response to oil supply shocks. The United States and other consumer nations have sought to ease the immediate shock of losing 4.3 million barrels of oil a day as a result of the Iraqi invasion by minimizing imports. Stockpiling oil would contradict such efforts and would put upward pressure on oil prices. Officials in Japan's Foreign Ministry and the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said that instead of increasing stocks as planned, Japanese oil companies had actually drawn down stocks. Increased imports, however, were needed during cool winter months to compensate for higher demand for heating fuel. ``The amount of oil imported by Japan fluctuates by 20 to 30 percent every month, depending on seasonal factors. Every year it's exactly the same pattern,'' said the government official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Stuntz's charge that Japan was betraying other oil consuming nations by not drawing down its 142-day emergency supply disregarded the fact that the United States is the only country that has tried to rely on existing stocks, officials said. ``No other country has drawn from its emergency stock, and there's no reason why Japan should,'' the government official said. ``I can't imagine why she's saying that. It's a complete mistake,'' he said. ``Since August, our stocks have been kept at a 142-day supply.'' In fact, the level of the stockpile increased slightly between June and October, the most recent month for which statistics are available. But the growth, from a total of 33.7 million kiloliters to 33.9 million kiloliters, or about one-third of Japan's daily consumption, isn't considered significant. Japan also has increased crude oil imports to a certain extent to compensate for shortfalls in supplies of refined oil products due to the loss of Kuwait's refining system, industry sources noted. ``We've brought in more oil, but less product,'' said Naoki Kuroda, director general of the international trade and industy ministry's petroleum department. Japan imports nearly all the oil it uses, and 70 percent of its oil imports come from the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Attempt to Cut Grocery Giant's Debt Fizzles
DOC.TEXT: Kroger Co. says it has received so few responses in a bond-exchange program to reduce its $1.4 billion bond debt that it will extend the deadline for replies until Dec. 20. The program was to have ended on Tuesday. The grocery giant offered Nov. 5 to let holders of bonds that begin paying 15.5 percent annual interest in October 1993 trade them in for bonds that pay 13 percent immediately. Kroger, which owns supermarkets, convenience stores and food processing plants in 32 states, issued the bonds during a multibillion restructuring that began in 1988 after two hostile takeover attempts. Kroger said Thursday that bondholders had offered to trade in less than $150 million in bonds. The company said it had hoped to exchange $350 million in bonds. Bondholders appear to be avoiding the exchange because the higher-yield bonds have been increasing in value, said Ross Margolies, an analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton. ``Unless the market changes dramatically, I think most people are happy with the bonds,'' Margolies said. Kroger's interest costs for the $350 million in bonds it hoped to exchange would be $54.2 million at the higher interest rate in 1994. At the lower rate, the company's interest costs would be cut to $31.2 million.

DOC.HEAD: Failure of GATT Talks Send Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures opened lower this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade. The market is being pressured by the failure of the talks on tariffs and trade in Brussels, said Victor Lespinasse, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds in Chicago. The talks broke up yesterday after the two sides failed to agree on the size of European farm subsidies. There are fears a trade war could result, Lespinasse said. The market is also being pressured by a lack of progress in talks that may result in the United States extending export credits to the Soviet Union. Analysts say news that Brazilian soybean plantings surged this week will put added pressure on soybean futures. While Egypt's purchase of 200,000 metric tons of soft white wheat could support wheat futures. In early trading, wheat was unchanged to a { cent lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.47 a bushel; corn was a \ cent to 1 cent lower with December at $2.25{ a bushel; oats were a { cent to 1 cent lower with December at $1.10} a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 3} cents lower with January at $5.95 a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle futures were boosted by higher cash prices, and hog futures were lifted by perceptions the market is oversold. Live cattle were .10 cent to .43 cent higher with December at 79.65 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .38 cent higher with January at 88.60 cents a pound; live hogs were .12 cent lower to .45 cent higher with December at 49.45 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .35 cent to 1.30 cents higher with February at 64.15 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled higher and pork futures were mixed in Thursday's trading.

DOC.HEAD: Airport Contract Awarded to Japanese Companies
DOC.TEXT: Japanese companies were selected Friday for a contract to build a people-mover system at the new Kansai airport. The contract had been the focus of U.S. complaints over access to Japan's construction market. Kansai International Airport Co. said it awarded the $37.7 million contract to Niigata Engineering Co. and Sumitomo Corp. Under the contract, the two companies will build a system to carry passengers to faraway gates at the $7 billion airport, scheduled to open in 1994. AEG Westinghouse Transportation Systems, headquartered in Pittsburgh, had disputed the bidding for the contract, complaining that U.S. construction firms did not have fair access to the Japanese market. Westinghouse was one of the 13 bidders. The airport company announced in July that the contract for an automated guide-way transport system in the passenger terminal building also would be awarded to Niigata Engineering and Sumitomo. Westinghouse said there were irregularities in the decision to give Japanese bidders the people-mover contract. The airport company maintained that the procedure had been fair. As part of a long-standing trade dispute, Japan and the United States reached an agreement in 1988 on procedures to allow American builders to bid on construction projects in Japan, including the Kansai airport. U.S. officials said later Japan was making significant progress in allowing American companies to compete for construction projects.

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Finish Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished higher on London's Stock Exchange Friday after a calm session. Prices moved up on a good performance in the stock index futures market, but investors then became reluctant to take positions as the weekend approached, dealers said. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 5.9 points, or 0.3 percent, at 2,183.4. The Financial Times 30-share index was up 5.9 points at 1,723.8. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 2.46 points to close at 1,152.52. Volume came to 521.3 million shares, compared with 559.3 million shares Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Mortgage Rates Lower
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.81 percent this week, down from 9.9 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. The rate was the lowest since rates averaged 9.8 percent last January. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.04 percent, down from 8.08 percent last week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: Trailblazing Bank Cuts Prime Rate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to fix typos in Fidelity Bancorp; uppicks 3rd graf: Analysts said...
DOC.TEXT: A handful of banks took steps today to cut the prime rate by a quarter percentage point to 9} percent, marking the first time the key lending rate has been lowered in nearly a year. The biggest institution so far to trim the rate, which is a base for setting a wide range of loans like mortgages, was First Fidelity Bancorp, the nation's 20th largest bank and the largest bank in New Jersey. The lower rate will be effective on Monday. Analysts said they expected other major banks to follow. ``It's virtually certain the banking industry will go to 9} percent,'' probably by early next week, said William Sullivan, director of money market research at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The prime rate reflects a bank's cost of borrowing money and is used in calculating business and consumer loans. Major banks last cut the rate by 0.5 percent to 10 percent on Jan. 8. The cut came on the heels of an extremely weak employment report by the Labor Department in Washington, which showed a 0.2 percent increase in the civilian unemployment rate to 5.9 percent and offered particularly strong evidence that a recession has firmly taken hold. ``The employment report was extremely weak and suggests that the Federal Reserve will step up the pace of accommodation,'' Sullivan said. He also said that the report could trigger ``fairly sharp declines in short-term money market rates, and that translates to further downward pressure on the prime rate.'' Economists have been waiting for the Fed to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy. The Fed took some action today to notch rates lower by allowing the federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, to drift down by a quarter of a percentage point to 7\ percent. In addition, the central bank said it would inject money into the banking system later in the afternoon to encourage bank to make more funds available. Government officials have beseeched the nation's banks in recent weeks to broaden lending practices rather than continue to tighten credit and choke off customers in need of funds. Southwest Bank of St. Louis, which had carved out a reputation for taking the lead in cutting rates, was the first to announce it was lowering prime, effective Monday. Manufacturers & Traders Trust of Buffalo, a unit of First Empire State Corp., mimicked the move a few hours later. While known as a rate-cutting maverick of sorts, Southwest has not always been followed. In late 1989, for example, Southwest stood alone after trimming its prime rate from 10.5 percent to 10 percent. When no other banks followed, Southwest quietly notched the rate back up three weeks later. ``We think our commercial customers are entitled to some benefits from this recent trend toward lower interest rates,'' Col. I.A. Long, Southwest's chairman emeritus, said today.

DOC.HEAD: Samsung Says It Has No Plan to Buy Orion Pictures Corp.
DOC.TEXT: The Samsung Group on Friday described as ``groundless'' a media report that the South Korean conglomerate had made inquiries to buy Orion Pictures Corp., a U.S. film company. Samsung officials issued a denial when asked to comment on a report in Thursday's edition of the Los Angeles Times that Samsung had made inquires about Orion and wanted to buy it. Some people might have speculated that the Korean group would emulate Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. and Sony Corp., two Japanese Japanese consumer electronics giant who have made deals with Hollywood studios. Matsushita said last week it had agreed to pay $6.13 billion for MCA Inc., which owns Universal Picture and MCA Records. Last year, Sony bought Columbia Pictures Entertainmnet Inc. for $5 billion, including assumed debt. In denying the report, Samung officials noted that the group's trading arm, Samsung Co., has bought some videotape rights from Orion. Investors bid up the stock price of Orion Pictures Corp. on Thursday in response to the news report that the South Korean electronics company was interested in a takeover of the Hollywood movie studio. But after rising $2.25 a share on Thursday, Orion was down $1.62{ a share at $13.62{ by midafternoon Friday on the New York Stock Exchange. Orion's 800-title film library includes ``Amadeus'' and ``Platoon,'' which won Academy awards for Best Picture in 1984 and 1986, as well as the current box-office success, ``Dances With Wolves.'' TV series such as ``Cagney & Lacey'' also are in the vaults. Orion, founded in 1978, does not own a studio lot. Samsung, based in Seoul, was founded in 1938 as a food export company. Fortune magazine ranks it the world's 20th largest industrial company. Samsung sells televisions, VCRs and microwave ovens in the United States under the brand names of Sears, J.C. Penney and other stores.

DOC.HEAD: Lack of News On Aid to USSR Depresses Futures
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade as a lack of news on U.S. aid to the Soviet Union took its toll on the market. The market has been awaiting announcement that the United States will extend about $1.2 billion in export credits to the Soviet Union so that nation can buy U.S. farm products. However, nothing has come of talks between Soviet officials and the U.S. Agriculture Department. The talks broke up Thursday after the two sides failed to agree on the size of European farm subsidies. There are fears a trade war could result, said Victor Lespinasse, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. DOC.HEAD: Worst of the Gulf Oil Crisis is Over, Energy Secretary Says
With AM-Gulf-Oil Prices
DOC.TEXT: The oil crisis brought on by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has pretty much run its course, and there will probably be no reason for crude prices to jump even if war breaks out, Energy Secretary James Watkins said Friday. ``From an energy perspective, I believe we are through the worst of the crisis,'' Watkins said a day after returning from a visit to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. Watkins said a war with Iraq should not cause concern among oil buyers because he sees no military threat to Middle East production facilities and he plans to ask President Bush to tap into the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve if hostilities break out. The government recently conducted test sales of oil from the reserve that went smoothly, the secretary said. ``It works and works well,'' Watkins said in an address to the Jewish Community Relations Council of New York. Some oil experts have estimated that crude prices could shoot as high as $100 per barrel if war breaks out. But Watkins said that if hostilities develop, ``I hope players in the oil market will keep their hats on.'' A combination of higher oil production and conservation has virtually eliminated the shortfall of 4.3 million barrels per day created by the global boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude implemented after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, he said. After the invasion, fears of supply disruptions in the event of war pushed oil above $40 per barrel, although it has since fallen back to less than $30 as world production was increased and international leaders have adopted a more conciliatory stance in recent days. Light sweet crude oil closed Friday at $26.58 per barrel, up 18 cents, for January delivery contracts at the New York Mercantile Exchange. Watkins said he doubted the Iraqis could harm oil facilities, since they were unable to cripple Iran's oil production during their drawn-out war of the 1980s. The secretary, who is a retired admiral, said he went to the Persian Gulf for his visit of almost a week to get a first-hand look at the security of the oil supply. ``I do not believe the Iraqi air force is a threat to Saudi or UAE fields, nor can I imagine a successful Iraqi ground attack,'' Watkins said. Even if there were some kind of unpredictable cutoff, ``we would still have six weeks worth of oil in the water.'' He was referring to the lag time in shipping crude from the Middle East to the United States. Watkins said the world is already experiencing an oil glut that will only intensify after the crisis ends. He said it might provide an opportunity for the United States to expand the strategic reserve, where the government stores millions of barrels of crude oil in Texas and Louisiana salt caverns. ``We want to go from the current 590 million barrels in our Strategic Petroleum Reserve to a billion barrels,'' he said. During a session Friday afternoon with reporters, Watkins said the United States was continuing discussions with producing nations who might want to ``lease'' oil for the Strategic Petroluem Reserve once the crisis ends. Under that arrangement, the United States would pay a small fee as the producing nations put oil into the salt caverns. Later, the oil could be auctioned off by the government in the same manner existing reserves are set to be auctioned.

DOC.HEAD: Coffee-Trading Nations Fail to Make Progress on Price Pact
DOC.TEXT: Coffee-trading nations on Friday failed to make progress on a new international agreement to lift and stabilize depressed world coffee prices. Delegates said Colombia and several African countries renewed their call for a speedy start to negotiations on a new accord to regulate exports and prices. They provided figures showing a sharp drop in export earnings, said Nestor Osorio, Colombia's delegate to the International Coffee Organization's 16-nation executive board. But Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer and exporter, said it was not ready to enter talks on a new pact. The board thus decided it could not set a timetable for negotiations to begin, delegates said. The former International Coffee Agreement was abandoned in July 1988, opening the way to a flood of sales and a drop in prices. Coffee prices last year hit a 14-year low of 59 cents per pound - half the amount the agreement had tried to guarantee. On Friday, coffee was priced at 71 cents a pound. Figures released by the organization Friday showed a sharp rise in export volume, but a dramatic drop in earnings in the last international coffee marketing year. World shipments of beans between October 1989 and September 1990 rose to 78.89 million 132-pound bags from 70.87 million bags the previous year. Export earnings slumped to $6.52 billion from $9.15 billion the previous year. Earnings peaked at $14.36 billion in the 1985-1986 fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down Sharply
DOC.TEXT: The dollar registered a sharp decline Friday, shaken by a worse-than-expected U.S. unemployment report and falling interest rates. Gold prices also lost ground. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold fell $1.40 a troy ounce to settle at $370.30. Later, Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold at $369.30 an ounce, off $1.70. The dollar declined overseas and opened on a very weak note when trading shifted to domestic markets. A Labor Department report showing civilian unemployment jumped 0.2 percent in November to 5.9 percent, its worst level in three years, ``got the market moving,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. The report offered indisputable evidence the nation has slipped into a recession and prompted the Federal Reserve and a handful of banks to take steps to ease interest rates. Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable and therefore reduce investors' need for the U.S. currency. There were unconfirmed reports that the Fed stepped in to support the dollar against the German mark, Flanagan said, adding that the dollar did move up after the rumored intervention. But traders are expecting interest rate differentials to become more unfavrrable for the dollar, as U.S. rates decline while some key foreign rates remain steady. That would put further pressure on the dollar. Also pushing the dollar down was an easing of tensions in the Persian Gulf conflict following Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's offer to release all hostages. ``The war premium was wiped out this week,'' said Kevin Lawrie, a vice president at the Bank of Boston's office here. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 132.17 Japanese yen from 134.05 yen at Thursday's close. Later in London, it fell to 131.05 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 130.70 yen, down from 132.14 yen on Thursday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9510 from $1.9390 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.9535 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.9400. Other late dollar rastes in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.4720 German marks, down from 1.4885; 1.2532 Swiss francs, down from 1.2710; 4.9975 French francs, down from 5.0510; 1,110.00 Italian lire, down from 1,122.25, and 1.1580 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1621. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.4775 German marks, down from 1.4890; 1.2615 Swiss francs, down from 1.2725; 5.0161 French francs, down from 5.0540; 1.6675 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6805; 1,113.75 Italian lire, down from 1,122.25; and 1.1590 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1621. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $371.00 a troy ounce, up from $370.25 bid per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $371.50, up from $369.50. DOC.HEAD: Real Estate Misery Spreads and Worsens
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Like an invading virus, the regional real estate slump is now a nationwide affliction, making memories out of work-swamped California builders, 30-minute Seattle home sales and Florida condos crawling with prospective retirees. Further darkening the picture, property experts say, are indications that the sickly Northeast's real estate industry has slipped even further, with rentals now following the steep price declines once confined to for-sale units. New York is ``close to being a housing depression,'' said Robert Villanueva, economic forecaster for the National Association of Home Builders. Not everyone is dejected, of course - prospective buyers and renters can get great deals. Moreover, a few sections of the country, such as Texas, are just now bouncing back from earlier downturns. But the slumps in once prosperous holdouts has forced developers and real estate agencies to lay off thousands of employees and has stranded many homeowners with expensive properties they can't sell without taking a loss. The grim news is told in recent statistics and in war stories from participants. In its first decline in more than a decade of nearly uninterrupted growth, housing starts in California plunged nearly 30 percent this year, roughly twice the national rate, the National Association of Home Builders says. Auctions, once associated with debt-swamped farmers, now account for more than 50 percent of southern California home sales, by some reckonings. The problem, particularly in southern California, is that developers built too many luxury homes in their zeal to exploit the state's burgeoning population and affluence. ``It's a case of oversupply and not an equal demand,'' saidTerry Yapp, a real estate agent in Mission Viejo, an affluent suburb 60 miles south of Los Angeles. Thousands of California property brokers are expected to leave the business by the en of the year. Century 21, a leading homeseller, closed about 30 of its southern California offices this year. In its first auction of unsold housing units, Kaufman & Broad Home Corp., one of California's largest home builders, last month sold 36 luxury homes for roughly 25 percent less than their original asking prices of $350,000-$375,000. ``We're not exactly on the average broker's Christmas card list,'' said William Lange, president of Lang Financial Corp., which conducted the auction. Seattle's reputation as one of the nation's most livable cities drew tens of thousands in the last five years. But in 1990, housing prices plummeted 15 percent after rising 30 percent to 40 percent annually in recent years, said Charles Henderson, president of Henderson Homes, a major Seattle home builder. ``In January it took 30 minutes'' to sell a home after it was put on market, he said. Now it takes price cuts and months of waiting to lure wary buyers. Florida's boom has been zapped partly because Northeasterners are having so much trouble selling homes. This means the supply of people seeking to move to Florida upon retirement has dried up. Also hurting sales, Florida builders say, are recent state regulations requiring the building of roads, sewers and other infrastructures before housing is approved. Moreover, many banks have tightened credit restrictions making it exceedingly difficult for builders to finance new developments. ``We have felt it dramatically. A number of our banks have gone out of business,'' said Ronald S. Ellish, who owns a small Florida building firm. Ryan Homes, once one of the state's largest home builders, recently withdrew from the state because it wasn't making money, the suburban Washington D.C.-based company has said. In south Florida's Lee County, one of the state's fastest growing regions, ``in the last year alone we have lost over 1,000 employees in the construction industry,'' said Michael Reitmann, executive vice president of the county's Building Industry Association. One of the more visible signs of the times is the planned auction on Dec. 16 of units in Donald Trump's 32-story Trump Plaza in West Palm Beach, where bidding for the luxury condominiums and town homes starts at half of the original $300,000 asking price. The situation is familiar to many New Yorkers who for the past two years have grimly watched their Manhattan homes plummet in value. Joe Mandese, 32, a journalist, says he and his wife placed their Greenwich Village studio on the market in 1988 for roughly $125,000, two years after they bought it for $100,000. Now they would be grateful to get $89,500 for it. On the other hand, many Manhattan renters are benefiting from owner misery. For the first time since the Great Depression, rents in the five boroughs are dropping, driven down by an oversupply of rental units caused partly by owners renting out their property rather than selling at a loss. A luxury studio on swank Central Park south, for example, which rented in April 1988 for $1,900 a month, recently was let for $1,150, according to the Feathered Nest, a Manhattan property agency.

DOC.HEAD: Small Group of Banks Cut Prime Rate, Broader Ease of Credit Predicted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New grafs 1-10 to move up Fed and UPDATE with latest rates; picks up 11th graf pvs: ``The infusion...
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve and a handful of banks moved Friday to cut interest rates after the government reported the biggest jobless increase in three years, graphic evidence that a recession is sapping the nation's economic strength. For the third time in six weeks the nation's central took subtle steps to make more money available for banks to lend. The move also raised speculation that the Fed might take even more dramatic steps later to reduce the cost of borrowing to stimulate economic growth. In addition, three banks cut the prime lending rate for the first time in nearly a year, nudging it to 9} percent from 10 percent. The prime rate is a base used by banks for pricing a range of businesses and consumer loans, including many types of mortgages. A reduction in the prime means that many people who may have delayed the purchase of a home or car, for example, would reconsider because a loan is more affordable. The rate cut, effective Monday, raised anticipation that others would follow. William Sullivan, director of money market research at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. predicted the 9} percent ``will become the industry-wide benchmark by early next week.'' The largest bank to trim the prime was First Fidelity Bancorp, the nation's 20th largest banking company and the largest bank in New Jersey. Also announcing cuts were Manufacturers & Traders Trust of Buffalo, N.Y., and Southwest Bank of St. Louis, historically a maverick rate-cutter. Major banks last cut the rate by 0.5 percent to 10 percent on Jan. 8. Still, analysts said major banks remain concerned about their profit margins and were hesitating to mark rates down until they had a sense the Fed would act in tandem. Indications that the Fed was allowing rates to drift lower surfaced around midday. The federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, stood at 7 1-16 percent, down from 7 7-16 percent earlier in the week. The shift in Fed policy was confirmed a bit later when the central bank announced it was injecting $1.5 billion into the banking system, a move designed to encourage banks to make funds more available. `TThe infusion of reserves was a clear signal by the Fed'' that it has eased monetary policy, Sullivan said. But many economists criticized the Fed's reluctance to take stronger action immediately. They complained that the nation was sliding toward a needlessly severe recession because interest rates haven't come down quickly. ``There is a lot of dissension (within the Fed) about what the right policy is, and the Fed has been slow to accept that the economy is in recession,'' said Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. A Labor Department report issued Friday appeared to be the decisive piece of evidence that convinced recalcitrant observers that the nation is in the throes of a recession. The report showed the unemployment rate climbed 0.2 percent to 5.9 percent in November, the highest level in three years. ``No doubt this figure will resurrect the economy as a political issue,'' Sullivan said. ``It is clear from the employment report that the economy has lost a substantial amount of momentum ... The figure not only points to weakness in the job market, but also suggests deterioration in production and income growth.'' Government officials have beseeched the nation's banks in recent weeks to broaden lending practices rather than continue to tighten credit and choke off customers in need of funds. While cuts in the prime rate, which reflects a bank's cost of borrowing money, are expected to be held to a quarter of a percentage point, analysts say still lower rates are likely. Some economists believe the Fed will cut another key rate, the discount rate or the rate it charges on loans to member banks, by 0.5 percent sometime around the new year. That would be the first change in the discount rate since Feb. 24, 1989, when it moved from 6.5 percent to 7 percent, and it likely would result in a further prime rate cut by the nation's banks.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Fight $625 Million Eagle-Picher Settlement Plan
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for thousands of asbestos disease victims on Friday fought a compensation plan by Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. that would mark a key step in ending the biggest product liability mess clogging the courts. The lawyers charged the $625 million plan allocates too little money for workers suffering cancer and other respiratory diseases and could further delay payments to 65,000 claimants for five or more years. Eagle-Picher is widely considered a test case in efforts to resolve the ilemma of compensating American workers ill and dying from exposure to asbestos, a mineral used for decades in shipyards and construction. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein wants the company and plaintiffs' lawyers to reach a settlement so he can declare a class-action to handle all the cases at once, eliminating long and costly trials that are diverting money that could be used to pay victims. Under an agreement between the company and two plaintiffs lawyers, claimants would be paid from a trust funded with annual cash payments by Eagle-Picher and company stock. The total value of the trust over 20 years was placed at about $625 million, plus at least 25 percent of the company's shares. But other plaintiffs lawyers urged Weinstein to reject the plan, saying financially tottering Eagle-Picher might be worth more to victims if it declares Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection. ``I say there's too much delay in this agreement and not enough remedies,'' said Henry G. Miller, one of four attorneys appointed by Weinstein to represent claimants. Two backed the plan and two opposed it. The plan provides that payments to victims would begin in November 1993 at the soonest, and could be delayed by court appeals. Eagle-Picher would pay $460 million spread out over 20 years, $45 million for already negotiated claims and an estimated $120 million in proceeds from the company's operations. Eagle Picher Chairman Thomas E. Petry said if no settlement is reached, ``I believe we'll be in bankruptcy.'' ``We are within days of a cash squeeze, a cash crisis,'' he said. Eagle-Picher, a Cincinnati-based maker of automobile and industrial products, has said it cannot meet its asbestos liabilities, now estimated at $600 million. It already has spent $540 million in the last five years on asbestos obligations. But Miller told the judge that, in contrast to Eagle-Picher estimates, the estimated present value of the proposal for asbestos victims was at most $244 million while Chapter 11 could provide $296 million. He also said the plan lacked safeguards for victims should the company go under. Weinstein has supported a mass settlement to clear court dockets nationwide of about 90,000 asbestos lawsuits, which has put a severe drain on dozens of companies threatened by asbestos liabilities. But at a crowded hearing in federal court in Brooklyn, some attorneys accused Weinstein of trying to railroad a plan through the courts and said he was flouting judicial procedure. They also accused the court-appointed attorneys who devised the plan - Stanley Chesley of Cincinnati and David I. Shapiro of Washington - of selling out victims in exchange for a quick resolution. ``My clients will have more insults heaped upon them that the insults they have already received at the hands of Eagle-Picher,'' said Gene Locks, a Philadelphia plaintiffs lawyer who criticized the plan. Locks called the process for reaching a settlement ``publicly embarrassing'' and promised to fight a settlement through appeals. But Chesley told the judge the plan was far better than a bankruptcy filing because the long-term value to victims depended on Eagle-Picher's future success. Eagle-Picher has sold tens of millions of dollars in assets in recent years to meet asbestos payments. But the settlement's backers said the company has little left to sell, its insurance is running out and it woon won't be able to generate enough cash from operations to meet obligations. Dozens of former asbestos makers and users are scrutinizing the case, which could become a model for companies to resolve asbestos liabilities. Payments to victims have been delayed years and many workers have died before getting money. A separate case involves the Manville trust fund, created in the bankruptcy reorganization of Manville Corp. Earlier this year the trust ran out of money to pay new claims. A proposal to restructure the trust, which faces 130,000 claims, is pending before Weinstein.

DOC.HEAD: Troubled Cities Go All Out to Woo Investors
DOC.TEXT: When The Bond Buyer held a conference at the Manhattan's Plaza Hotel in honor of the financial publication's 100th anniversary last month, the black tie affair looked something like a mayors' convention. Government officials from roughly 30 municipalities ranging from Delaware to Detroit came to town in the hope they might woo investors to buy their municipal bonds. Such hard-sell scenes are becoming more and more frequent these days. With the nation's widely reported economic downturn placing many municipalities on shaky financial ground, government officials increasingly are renting out plush convention space and polishing their pitches to put their cities' best foot forward. They have their work cut out for them. In the first nine months of 1990 Standard & Poor's Corp. downgraded 285 municipal bonds and upgraded 111. ``The underlying concept is that it's better to hear it straight from the horse's mouth rather than to read an article scaring you. It's the only way you get a chance to personally assess the management qualities of a city or state,'' said Claire Cohen, executive managing director for government finance at Fitch Investors Service. For example, late last month New York City Mayor David Dinkins, head of the biggest municipal bond borrower in the world, feted potential buyers at a swank conference in a midtown Manhattan hotel. The affair came several weeks in advance of the city's $950 million sale of general obligation bonds needed to keep the government running, and investors had some hard questions on how the city proposed to balance its budget and pay its future debt. While Moody's Investor Service rates New York's bonds a fairly respectable A, the city's big budget deficit has prompted worries among investors that the rating could be lowered. But cities have quickly discovered the art of bond salesmanship is different than, say, selling used cars. ``They have learned that they had better be very, very honest and forthright because many investors and dealers can read a financial statement just as well as anyone in the administration can,'' said John V. Sebastian, chief economist for Clayton Brown & Associates, a Chicago-based public securities firm. Investors are sometimes reticent to have their biggest concerns addressed in public, so municipalities are looking for opportunities to maximize private interaction. At the conference sponsored by the Bond Buyer trade newspaper, ``you would have a casual opportunity during coffee breaks or between sessions to go up to public officials and have conversations about whatever was on your mind,'' said Ms. Cohen of Fitch. Another way cities are selling themselves is by sharpening their pencils. ``Ten years ago New York City would simply issue one to two sheets of paper telling what financing they are planning and what they are raising and their scheduling of repayment,'' said Sebastian, the economist. Now, many large cities are issuing sophisticated fiscal reports showing everything from cash flow to projected income, he said, not unlike the comprehensive annual reports corporations issue to stockholders. But sometimes all the slick salesmanship in the world can't change investors' minds. Last month, for example, Moody's Investor Service demoted two more series of Philadelphia's municipal bonds to junk-bond status. The move came after the city's general obligation bonds were dropped in September to junk-bond level by the rating services. ``We have conceded that we have no capacity to re-enter the market,'' said Betsy Reveal, Philadelphia's director of finance. The city now has the lowest credit rating of any major municipal borrower. Trying to avoid insolvency without the bond market's help, the city is trying to wrangle an unusual transaction that involves borrowing from local and state pension funds and local banks to secure short-term cash to keep the government running.
