DOC.HEAD: Inheritance Battle at Hispanic Food Giant Heads Into Court
Es: Also moved for PMs
DOC.TEXT: Maybe they should change the name to Goya Feuds. A 20-year-old family squabble has spilled into court at Goya Foods Inc., which grew from a small Puerto Rican rice, bean and spice business into a $300 million-a-year food empire. At issue is the will of Prudencio Unanue, the family patriarch who founded Goya more than 50 years ago. His son is suing other family members, and says hundreds of millions of dollars are at stake. After a tax dispute with other family members, Charles Unanue walked away from Goya in 1974 with a $4.3 million settlement and an agreement not to seek any inheritance from his father. Prudencio Unanue died in 1976, leaving his 18 grandchildren controlling interest in the company. But under Puerto Rican commonwealth law, parents are not allowed to disinherit their children. Charles Unanue says he agreed not to seek an inheritance while his father was living in Puerto Rico, so the will doesn't stand. ``There is no moral question here,'' Jan Brodey, Charles Unanue's attorney, said. ``Charlie believes that if he's entitled by right to inherit from his father, then he has a right to it, period.'' Attorneys for Goya and the other family members dispute the claim. A state Superior Court judge in Hackensack was to rule on the legality of Prudencio's will, but a decision was put on hold when Charles filed for personal bankruptcy in Puerto Rico in August. Under federal law, lawsuits involving people who file for bankruptcy are delayed until the court decides whether they can continue. The internal dispute at Goya appears to have done little to tarnish the success of the nation's largest Hispanic-owned business. Founded by Prudencio Unanue in 1936, Goya started out importing sardines, beans and olive oil. Now the family's frozen vegetables and canned goods are found from corner bodegas in Manhattan to swanky Miami supermarkets. Goya, which has operations in Chicago, Miami, Spain and the Dominican Republic, dominates the sale of Caribbean and Spanish foods in the eastern United States and Caribbean. Analysts said Goya, based in Secaucus, has been the largest Hispanic-owned company since rum manufacturer Bacardi Corp. of Puerto Rico and Banco Popular de Puerto Rico became publicly held operations. ``If there have been problems, they haven't hurt the overall success of the company,'' said Leonard Teitelbaum, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Co. ``It may have been more successful had it not been for the problems, but it has still done quite well.'' The dispute began nearly 20 years ago when Charles Unanue claimed Goya was cheating on its taxes. He threatened legal action. The family settled out of court, and Charles agreed to take $4.3 million and forsake any claim to an inheritance. Brodey said Charles Unanue was largely responsible for the company's success, and didn't want to be associated with any legal action against it. ``So they dumped him,'' Brodey said. ``But it wasn't like he was collecting any money that wasn't his. What he was given was what they determined his share of the company was.'' The alleged tax violations never were brought into criminal or civil proceedings. Unanue claims he only recently learned about the Puerto Rican law barring parents from disinherting children, and he has moved to have his father's will reprobated in Puerto Rico. Michael Griffinger, an attorney for Goya and the Unanue family, said Charles Unanue's claim that several hundred millions of dollars are at stake is exaggerated. But he conceded that a large amount of money is in dispute. Griffinger said the family ``has been absolutely harmonious and unified except for Charles.'' ``The family felt he wasn't pulling his load,'' he said. ``There were a number of meetings and discussions, and he said he wanted to be bought out. Every bit of litigation with Charles was settled, and now he's coming back looking for more.''

DOC.HEAD: Jump in Unemployment Sends Platinum Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Precious metals on Friday continued their slide on New York's Commodity Exchange, paced by a sharp drop in platinum prices that was caused by a jump in U.S. unemployment. Silver prices were also hard hit, at one point tumbling to contract lows. Both platinum and silver are heavily used in industry. On other markets, grain and soybean futures were mostly lower; copper futures dropped; livestock and pork futures were higher; and energy futures gained. The selloff in platinum came after the release of unemployment figures by the U.S. Labor Department showing joblessness in November reached a three-year high of 5.9 percent. Platinum settled $7.90 to $8.50 lower with the contract for delivery in January at $413.40 a troy ounce. Peter Cardillo, an analyst with Jesup Josephthal & Co. Inc. in New York, said the silver market also was sharply affected by the decline in employment. Platinum is used in the catalytic converters of automobiles and in jewelry. Silver is both a luxury item and is used in the photography industry. ``If you have a recessionary atmosphere, it dampens the future prospects of the metal,'' Cardillo said. The unemployment figures gave some support to the gold market. Gold is usually a safe haven in times of economic uncertainty. But the imminent release of hostages in Iraq and the resulting perceptions of peace weighed on gold futures, analysts said. Gold was $1.10 to $1.90 lower with February at $372.10 a troy ounce; silver was 6.2 cents to 7.8 cents lower with December at $4.055 a troy ounce. Recessionary fears also forced copper prices lower on the Comex. Copper was 1.45 cents to 3.10 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $1.1015 a pound. Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as a lack of news on U.S. aid to the Soviet Union took its toll on the market. The market has been awaiting announcement that the United States will extend about $1.2 billion in export credits to the Soviet Union so that nation can buy U.S. farm products. However, nothing has come of talks between Soviet officials and the U.S. Agriculture Department. Analysts also noted that the market was hurt by the failure of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks in Brussels. Wheat futures showed gains on aggressive buying by commercial houses and by Egypt's purchase of 200,000 metric tons of soft white wheat under the export bonus program, said Paul Sylvester, an analyst with Gerald Inc. in Chicago. Wheat was 2\ cents to 6 cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.53 a bushel; corn was 1\ cents lower to a \ cent higher with December at $2.26 a bushel; oats were a { cent to 1} cents lower with December at $1.10 a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 4 cents lower with January at $5.95 a bushel. Energy futures posted modest gains on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with traders citing the lack of new Middle East developments for quiet trading. Jim Ritterbusch, an analyst with PaineWebber Inc. in Chicago, said the huge drops in futures prices caused by expectations the Persian Gulf crisis will be resolved peacefully brought in some buying interest. Light sweet crude was 18 cents to 51 cents higher with January at $26.58 a barrel; heating oil was .54 cent lower to .60 cent higher with January at 79.17 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .20 cent lower to .40 cent higher with January at 66.47 cents a gallon. Livestock and pork futures were higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures were higher on perceptions of oversold conditions, and cattle futures climbed as cash prices continued strong. Live cattle were .20 cent to .75 cent higher with December at 79.92 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .08 cent to .75 cent higher with January at 88.87 cents a pound; live hogs were .15 cent to .57 cent higher with December at 49.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.17 cents to 1.85 cents higher with February at 64.70 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Takes Breather After Peace-Induced Dive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for AM-Oil Prices listed on news digest
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices showed little change Friday as traders paused to wonder what crude might do next, after a dramatic weeklong slide based on perceptions that peace could break out in the Persian Gulf. ``When the market moves like this one has, it tends to get a little bit overdone and then moves back,'' said Brian Tagler, an oil broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Light sweet crude oil rose 18 cents to $26.58 per barrel at the New York Mercantile Exchange on contracts for delivery in January. For the week, oil was down $2.27 per barrel for next-month delivery. After a big fall of $4.06 per barrel on Nov. 30, this week's losses dropped oil into a price range it had not seen since August, the month Iraq invaded Kuwait. Crude's fall also brought unleaded gasoline futures down to ugust levels. The dive began last week when President Bush offered to hold top-level diplomatic sessions with the Iraqis. Oil kept falling this week, first when Iraq accepted the offer, and later when Iraqi President Saddam Hussein announced plans to free all of his hostages. Oil traders said the market seemed due for its its slight bounce up on Friday, and some were surprised it didn't rise even more. ``We came down awfully fast over the past couple of days and this is a little bit of a correction,'' said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. ``Even though there's new peace hopes, you have to look at them with a grain of salt.'' Futures contracts for home heating oil and unleaded gasoline were mixed, though none of them moved by as much as 1 cent a gallon. Some traders were selling heating oil contracts and buying unleaded gasoline contracts just because gasoline seemed like a relative bargain at about 12 cents a gallon cheaper than the heating oil, Blakeslee said. Heating oil closed down .54 cent at 79.17 cents a gallon for January delivery. Unleaded gasoline was down .13 cent at 66.47 cents a gallon for January delivery. For the week, unleaded gasoline fell 11.11 cents a gallon for next-month delivery, while home heating oil fell 6.70 cents a gallon. Natural gas, which is not directly affected by fears of war in the Persian Gulf, also showed little direction Friday. The January delivery contract fell .1 cent to $2.350 per 1,000 cubic feet. For the week, gas dropped 9.5 cents for January delivery.

DOC.HEAD: Job Losses Soar as Recession Takes Hold
DOC.TEXT: The worst two-month stretch of layoffs since the 1981-82 recession pushed civilian unemployment to a three-year high of 5.9 percent in November, the govenment said Friday. Payrolls fell by 267,000 last month, the Labor Department said, after a 180,000-job loss in October. Since June, when the unemployment rate was 5.2 percent, nearly 1 million Americans have joined the ranks of the unemployed. Practically all the nation's industries have been affected. ``This report looks like a recession. It walks like a recession. ... It is a recession,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. ``And it's full-fledged, accelerating and widespread.'' In apparent response, the Federal Reserve moved to stimulate the economy by nudging interest rates lower. It pushed the rate charged among banks for overnight loans to 7 1-16 percent, down from 7 7-16 percent earlier in the week. A handful of banks trimmed their prime rate from 10 percent to 9} percent. A wide variety of business and consumer loans are tied to the prime. November's 5.9 percent jobless rate was the highest since unemployment was 6 percent in October 1987. Many analysts predict unemployment could hit 7 percent next year. ``The negative momentum is not yet spent. ... We are in the heart of the downturn now. There is no turning back. It cannot be reversed. The question is how deep and how long will it last?'' Sinai said. Added Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities Co.: ``This recession looks about as bad as any recession can look. ... It deepened in November; the pace has accelerated.'' ``We have a vicious cycle going here. The more people you lay off, the less they're going to buy, the less businesses can produce, the more people they lay off.'' With 7.3 million Americans looking for work but unable to find it, November's losses hit hardest in the manufacturing sector, which has been sliding downhill for months. Factory payrolls declined by 200,000, the biggest one-month drop since 1982. The automobile industry alone lost 55,000 jobs, reflecting temporary shutdowns to avoid excessive inventory buildups. Construction lost 62,000 jobs as the housing market continued to deteriorate. Over the last six months, that industry has seen jobs tumble by about 250,000. The service-producing sector, which until a few months ago had been enjoying healthy job gains and keeping the economy steaming ahead, showed widespread weakness too. Retail trade lost 70,000 jobs because general merchandise stores are falling short on their normal seasonal hirings. Employment also fell in wholesale trade and in finance, insurance and real estate. All the job-loss calculations are seasonally adjusted. Health services continued to boom, adding 80,000 jobs. Over the last year, that industry has added more than 600,000 jobs. Labor costs, frequently blamed for intensifying the nation's inflation problems, rose only slightly in November. The average hourly worker made $10.13 an hour last month, up one cent from October. Overall, total civilian employment was about 117.3 million in November, down about 450,000 from the 117.7 million employed in October. In another sign of weakness, the average manufacturing work week was 40.5 hours in November, down from the 40.7 hours in October. Manufacturing overtime was an average of 3.5 hours last month, down from 3.6 hours in October. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the United States, the November jobless rate was 5.8 percent, up from October's 5.6 percent rate.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Exchange Member Firms Report Loss
DOC.TEXT: Member brokerage firms of the New York Stock Exchange posted a combined loss of $124 million after taxes in the third quarter, the exchange said Friday. The loss compared with a profit of $471 million in 1989's third quarter. Brokerage houses have suffered this year as small investors have shied away from investing in stocks, due in part to uncertainty over the economy. Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait has increased investor concern over stocks, experts say. The firms have also seen a slowdown in mergers, takeovers and other big deals that generated fat fees in the 1980s. The NYSE said only 161 of its 334 firms reporting results for the third quarter were profitable during the period. Revenue in the third quarter fell 13 percent to $13.1 billion from $15.1 billion in 1989's third quarter, the NYSE said. For the year's first nine months, the brokerages reported a profit after taxes of $22 million, down 98 percent from $1.28 billion in 1989's first nine months. Revenue totaled $40.8 billion, down from $45.1 billion in the year-ago period, the NYSE said. The figures include revenue from all sources, including trading, commissions and interest. The exchange also said its specialist firms - those that only trade in the stock of one or a handful of companies and keep their trading orderly - posted a loss in the third quarter of $19 million, compared with an after-tax profit of $17 million in 1989's third quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Macy Reports $56.5 Million First-Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: R.H. Macy Co. Inc. said Friday it lost $56.5 million during its first quarter as the retailer's sales, hurt by the weakening economy and the Middle Eat crisis, tumbled nearly 10 percent. The closely held Macy, which is still paying the costs of a 1986 leveraged buyout, said its loss in the quarter ended Oct. 27 translated to $38.53 per share and compared with a shortfall of $33.1 million, or $23.92 per share, in the same period a year earlier. Macy's results in the latest quarter reflected a $10.2 million gain related to a repurchase of some of the retailer's bonds. The results, contained a quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, were expected after published reports said Macy's first-quarter loss nearly doubled from a year earlier. The company said its first-quarter sales declined to $1.55 billion from $1.71 billion. Macy suffered from the same drop-off in business that struck other retailers after the Middle East crisis erupted in early August. Consumers, already spending cautiously because of the weakening economy, put purchases of non-essentials such as clothing, appliances and furniture on hold as oil prices shot higher. Macy said its performance was also adversely affected by warmer-than-usual weather that slowed apparel sales. The company said its sales were particularly hard hit in the Northeast, where the economy has weakened considerably. The retailer has come under sharp scrutiny after it suffered a disastrous Christmas season a year ago. The current holiday season is proving to be difficult for all retailers, but Macy spokesman James Fingeroth said Friday the company so far has not been forced to make steep markdowns to bring in sales. Macy has taken a number of steps to reduce its debt load and its losses, including the sale of stock and buybacks of some of the junk bonds used to finance its $3.74 billion leveraged buyout. The company is also selling its credit operations to GE Capital Corp. In its filing Friday, Macy said it expected that sale to be completed by February. In the filing, Macy listed its debt at the end of the fiscal year at $4.32 billion. The retailer expects, after accounting for asset sales and bond buybacks, to be left with $3 billion in long-term liabilities.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Awarded $6 Million in Libel Case Against Inquirer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with reax from newspaper's lawyer, CORRECT that award was $6 million sted $6.6 million; picks up 3rd graf pvs; SUBS 10th graf, `The articles ...' and 12th graf, `In asking ...' to conform
DOC.TEXT: A jury Friday awarded $6 million to a state supreme court justice, saying The Philadelphia Inquirer defamed him in a reprint of a 1983 series about the court's conduct. The jury, which deliberated nine hours over two days following a seven-week trial, found the reprint was false and defamatory, but that the original series was not false. ``The verdict is bizarre because they said the articles themselves were true but they were false when they were reprinted,'' said William Hangley, the Inquirer's lawyer. Hangley suggested the jury may have considered an editorial and cartoon also included in the tabloid reprint. He said the paper will appeal. ``We are confident this result cannot stand,'' he said. The jurors refused to comment after the verdict. The award was the second libel judgment against the Inquirer this year. Common Pleas Court Judge John Lavelle had told the jury that Justice James T. McDermott had to prove the articles, written by reporter Daniel Biddle, were defamatory, false and published with actual malice, and that he suffered harm. The Inquirer has won 17 Pulitzer Prizes during the past two decades, including one by Biddle for another court series. Last May, a jury awarded Philadelphia lawyer Richard Sprague a record $34 million over a 1973 story that criticized his handling of a homicide case when he was an assistant district attorney. The Inquirer is appealing. The 64-year-old McDermott, a member of the state's highest court since January 1982, sued on grounds the articles titled ``Above the Law'' implied he fixed cases. The articles were published in May 1983 and reprinted in 1984 to distribute to journalism and law schools. The reprints, sub-headed ``the questionable conduct of the Supreme Court,'' claimed many of the justices ignored the Pennsylvania Code of Judicial Ethics, which the court adopted in 1974. The articles suggested McDermott shouldn't have participated in two cases involving lawyers from the Dilworth, Paxson, Kalish & Kauffman firm, which had been the largest contributor to his 1981 election, because it was a conflict of interest. The articles noted McDermott accepted $6,100 from the Philadelphia law firm, that one of the firm's lawyers had arranged a 1981 trip to the Pennsylvania coal region, and three months after the justice took his seat on the court he voted favorably for Dilworth clients. In asking the jury to find in favor of the newspaper, Hangley declared, ``We say that Justice McDermott did something wrong; that he didn't abide by the Pennsylvania Code of Judicial Conduct.'' ``Did we say he committed a crime? No. Has he fixed a case? No,'' Hangley said. ``But he did ignore the code that says he shouldn't have participated in cases where his partiality is questioned.'' McDermott's lawyer, James Beasley, argued that accusing the justice ``of being partial, that's accusing him of a crime.'' Besides the two cases involving Dilworth lawyers, McDermott also claimed he was defamed when the newspaper implied he had improperly used his judicial influence to get his son a job in the Philadelphia district attorney's office. The son still works for the prosecutor. Biddle testified his stories were fair, truthful and accurate, and insisted that what he wrote concerned the official actions, not only of McDermott, but of all justices. Only McDermott sued. ``The Code of Judicial Conduct, which I researched and used in my story, says in Pennsylvania a judge should not participate where his partiality might reasonably be questioned,'' Biddle testified. ``To act against that code ... is to engage in misconduct.'' While McDermott acknowledged that the reported facts were substantially true he insisted the inferences and innuendos they raised, and the way paragraphs were positioned in the paper, left the impression he was dishonest. He had demanded a retraction before he sued. ``All I wanted was for them to say that I was an honest man, and not corrupt,'' he testified. ``If they had done it, we wouldn't have to spend all this time and all this money, and be in this courtroom.'' The justice said that ``never, ever'' did he have financial ties, receive any personal gifts or have any conflicts of interest with anyone involved in cases before the Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: World Trade Talks Collapse, Raising Prospect of Trade Skirmishes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf pvs, `We need, to UPDATE with Bush comments. Picks up 8th graf pvs, The suspension; EDITS thereafter. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Trade Talk-Failure, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: World trade negotiations collapsed Friday when the United States and the European Community refused to back down and end a bitter dispute over reductions in farm subsidies. ``They must both have glass eyes because no one blinked,'' Canada's trade minister, John Crosbie, said after bargaining was suspended in the 107-nation negotiations, the most comprehensive trade talks ever. Uruguay's foreign minister, Hector Gros Espiell, halted five days of discussions after the EC rejected a compromise requiring deeper cuts in its extensive farm support program. Gros Espiell promised to restart the talks, possibly next month in Geneva, after further consultations to try to resolve the contentious farm issue. But no one seemed in a hurry to get together again. ``When it is clear that a basis exists for successfully concluding the round, the United States will return to the negotiating table,'' said U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. ``We need this cooling-off period to get a full evaluation of the situation,'' said India's commerce minister, Subramanian Swamy. President Bush, who was in Caracas, Venezuela, said late Friday the United States ``remains committed'' to completing the trade talks. ``Accordingly, it is our hope that participants, especially the EC, will take this opportunity to reflect upon their position on agriculture and develop the political will to negotiate real market-opening agreements while there is still time to do so,'' said Bush. The suspension occurred in what was supposed to be the final week of bargaining in the Uruguay Round, the negotiations begun in 1986 in the South American country. The talks were designed to overhaul the world trading system by rewriting the rules and lowering barriers to trade in 15 areas, including textiles, agriculture, manufactured goods and services such as banking, telecommunications and construction. Success, officials have said, will give an enormous boost to the world economy well into the 21st century. The agriculture fight attracted the most attention during the bargaining because the United States and others have insisted they won't budge on other areas without a deal on farm subsidies. The United States, backed by Australia, Argentina, Uruguay and others, insisted the community slash such assistance by 75 percent to 90 percent, with the deepest cuts in export subsidies. The EC refused, contending that hefty slashes would force some of its 10 million farmers off the land. Its original offer called only for a 30 percent cut in limited areas. Each side blamed the other for the failure. The community said the United States put too much attention on agriculture and was unwilling to negotiate in all other areas under consideration. ``We were prepared to continue negotiations ... We didn't walk out of the room,'' said Frans Andriessen, the community's top trade official. ``Unless and until they (the Americans) reduce their expectations ... there will not be progress on agriculture,'' said Ray MacSharry, the community's hard-line agriculture chief. Mrs. Hills and Clayton Yeutter, the American agriculture secretary, said it was up to the Europeans. ``The question is whether the community is out of step or whether the rest of the world is out of step,'' Yeutter told a news conference. The collapse was disappointing to developing nations, which would like to use the talks to pry open more markets in the rich countries for their products. Mexican Trade Secretary Jaime Serra, who presided over the negotiations on services, predicted a deal could have been struck had the officials won agreement on agriculture. The negotations are sponsored by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which was set up in 1947 as a forum and an agreement for promoting freer world trade.

DOC.HEAD: Metzenbaum Takes Aim At Gasoline Prices
DOC.TEXT: One of Big Oil's persistent critics, Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, lashed out at high gasoline prices Friday, demanding an explanation from a dozen major oil companies. ``Leaders of the oil industry in the United States owe the American people an answer - if not a refund or a discount,'' the Ohio Democrat said in a letter sent to Exxon Corp. Chairman Lawrence G. Rawl and the heads of 11 other oil giants. ``They cannot understand this situation and neither can we in Congress.'' Metzenbaum said that if oil companies do not start cutting gasoline prices immediately, he will look into the possibility of holding congressional hearings into their pricing policies. Metzenbaum said he was outraged to see that gasoline prices have stayed at high levels in recent weeks, even though crude oil prices have come down about $15 per barrel from the highs they hit during October. This week, the futures price of unleaded gasoline fell to within a penny of the price it commanded the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait, yet the American Automobile Association reported that gasoline prices at the pump were within a penny of the highest price it has ever recorded. ``Why is it that gasoline prices go up instantly when crude oil costs go up, but when crude oil costs come down, your gasoline prices do not?'' Metzenbaum asked the oil executives. The major oil companies say they do not control pricing, which is set by local service stations and eventually finds its appropriate levels through supply and demand. Exxon spokesman Bill Smith in Dallas said he had no immediate response to the letter Metzenbaum sent to Rawl. Metzenbaum said in a telephone interview Friday evening that he does not have high hopes for getting any kind of answer from the oil companies that he would consider satisfactory. ``Of all the industries in America, there are probably few, maybe with the exception of the tobacco industry, that has less a sense of community responsbility than the oil industry,'' the senator said. The industry, for its part, has characterized Metzenbaum as a demagogue. The senator's letters also went out to Shell Oil Co., Mobil Corp., BP America Inc., Texaco Inc., Chevron Corp., Amoco Corp., Marathon Oil Co., Atlantic Richfield Co., Phillips Petroleum Co., Unocal Corp. and Sun Co.

DOC.HEAD: Hit Six-Month Highs on Grim Economic News, Lower Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices recorded the biggest one-day jump in more than six months on Friday, propelled by grim employment figures and clear signs that the Federal Reserve moved to ease interest rates. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond leaped 1} point, or $17.50 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, plunged to 8.18 percent from 8.33 percent late Thursday. The sharp price rise in the long-term bond was the largest since June 1, when 30-year prices soared 1 27-32 points on a monthly government report showing a big increase in unemployment. Back then, yields on the 30-year bond dropped to 8.44 percent from the previous day's close of 8.57 percent. This time around economists were expecting bad tidings in Friday's monthly report, but the news was worse than expected. The nation's unemployment rate shot up to a three-year high of 5.9 percent in November, creating the worst two-month loss since the depths of the 1981-82 recession, the Labor Department said. Over five months, the number of jobless has swelled by900,000. Nearly all of the nation's industries lost jobs last month as payrolls fell by 267,000. ``Everybody was shocked. People got a touch spooked and said, `the Fed is going to ease on this,''' said Mike Casey, international economist at Maria Ramirez Capital Consultants in New York. The market jumped on speculation that the Fed would ease interest rates to stimulate the economy, a move that generally gives a lift to bond prices. Suspicions seemed confirmed around midday as word among traders spread that the central bank allowed the federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, to drift down by a quarter of a percentage point to 7\ percent. In addition, the central bank announced it would inject money into the banking system to encourage banks to make more funds available. By the day's close the federal funds rate traded at 7 1-16 percent, down from 7 7-16 percent late Thursday. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities rose 5-16 point to 17-32 point, intermediate maturities jumped 11-16 point to 1 point and long-term issues soared 1{ point to 113-16 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, was up 8.56 to 1,186.95. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.10 percent as the discount was down 11 basis points to 6.89 percent. Yields on six-month bills were down to 7.08 percent as the discount fell 12 basis points to 6.76 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.11 percent as the discount was down 12 basis points to 6.68 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose 1-16 point to 91 23-32. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.47 percent from 7.48 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Slow Deliveries Cause Defense Department to Cancel Part of Contract
DOC.TEXT: A company making $30 million in chemical protection suits for the government has lost half of the contract because it's way behind on deliveries, a Defense Department spokesman said Friday. Sac and Fox Industries was to have delivered 245,515 suits by now, but has only sent 13,350, said Frank Johnson, a spokesman for the defense Personnel Support Center in Philadelphia. ``That is the reason for the partial termination,'' Johnson said in a telephone interview. ``We've already modified two delivery schedules. They were still way behind.'' Johnson said Sac and Fox now is under contract to make 204,595 suits, down from 490,915 suits in the original contract signed in March 1989. Attempts to reach Sac and Fox president James Branum were unsuccessful Friday. Johnson said the bulk of the problems were with slow delivery of the chemical suits, which have been in demand since Iraq invaded Kuwait four months ago. The suits would be used to guard U.S. troops against chemical warfare. Johnson also said some suits did not meet government standards. Bruce Willingham, a company director, attributed part of the problem to the rising cost of raw materials, which increased following the invasion. ``Prices soared for raw materials, and so did the material suppliers, who changed the way they operated their credit,'' he said Friday. Sac and Fox officials have said the government would not reimburse them for the suits until they pass inspection, creating some cash flow problems and trouble paying employees. The company has plants at four locations in Oklahoma. Terri White, a spokeswoman in the Defense Personnel Support Center, said the government has extended various delivery dates for Sac and Fox for the remainder of the contract.

Following the grim news, the Federal Reserve and a handful of banks moved to cut interest rates. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Growth in consumer credit slowed to a seasonally adjusted $1.47 billion in October, the government reported. Analysts said it was another sign of a weakening economy. The Federal Reserve on Friday said consumer credit grew at an annual rate of 2.4 percent, down from a revised 4.6 percent rate posted in September. The September rate was even slower than the 4.9 percent advance originally reported. Revolving, or credit card, debt increased $1.56 billion, or an annual rate of 8.6 percent, down from a 12.9 percent gain in September and a 13.3 percent advance a month earlier. --- DETROIT (AP) - More than 30,000 auto workers, nearly all of them at General Motors Corp. plants, will have next week off as the auto industry wrestles with a recession. GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said Friday they plan to shut down all or parts of a dozen assembly plants for the week of Dec. 10, keeping 32,380 workers at home. The closures stem from slow dealer orders. GM also said it will lay off 50,470 workers when it shuts down 18 assembly factories in 14 states the week of Dec. 17, the last week before the industry's traditional shutdown between the Christmas and New Year's holidays. --- PHILADELPHIA (AP) - A jury Friday awarded $6 million to a state supreme court justice, saying The Philadelphia Inquirer defamed him in a reprint of a 1983 series about the court's conduct. Macy's results in the latest quarter, reported Friday, reflected a $10.2 million gain related to a repurchase of some of the retailer's bonds. --- PRVIDENCE, R.I. (AP) - Fleet-Norstar Financial Group plans to cut about 500 jobs by the end of the month in an austerity plan designed to save about $100 million next year, a company official said. The layoffs will be scattered among Fleet's 1,000 offices in 40 states, but will affect primarily workers in New England and New York, said bank spokesman Robert W. Lougee Jr on Friday The Providence-based bank holding company pinned most of the layoffs on the recession plaguing the Northeast. --- CINCINNATI (AP) - Kroger Co. says it has received so few responses in a bond-exchange program to reduce its $1.4 billion bond debt that it will extend the deadline for replies until Dec. 20. The program was to have ended on Tuesday. The grocery giant offered Nov. 5 to let holders of bonds that begin paying 15.5 percent annual interest in October 1993 trade them in for bonds that pay 13 percent immediately. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole says he will introduce a bill early next month to grant some tax relief for military personnel serving in the Persian Gulf area. His bill would waive interest charges for failing to pay any taxes due by the April 15 deadline. The Kansas senator made the announcement Friday after the Internal Revenue Service noted that any member of the armed services serving in the Persian Gulf on April 15 would automatically have an additional 60 days to file a return and pay any tax due. --- BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - World trade negotiations collapsed when the United States and the European Community refused to back down and end a bitter dispute over reductions in farm subsidies. Uruguay's foreign minister, Hector Gros Espiell, halted five days of discussions on Friday after the EC rejected a compromise requiring deeper cuts in its extensive farm support program. Gros Espiell promised to restart the talks, possibly next month in Geneva, after further consultations to try to resolve the contentious farm issue. ---

The stock market drifted lower and bond prices hit six-month highs on Friday amid gloomy employment news. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 12.38 to 2,590.10. The dollar declined sharply and gold also lost ground. Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower, livestock and pork futures were higher and energy futures gained.

DOC.HEAD: NCR Chairman Says Company Not For Sale Despite Board Setting Price
DOC.TEXT: NCR Corp. Chairman Charles Exley Jr. said Friday his company has no plans to sell itself to AT&T despite the fact his board of directors set a minimum price. Exley said his board set the $125-per-share minimum because it felt obligated to its shareholders to set a ``full-value'' price. He said NCR would fight any takeover by AT&T if that price isn't met. ``In the name of rationality and in recognition of its fiduciary responsibility to NCR shareholders, the board felt obligated to set a `full value' price for shares,'' he said in a statement. ``It would be preposterous for us to say there is no price we would accept.'' However, Exley repeated his vow to keep NCR independent. ``The fact that the board set a price does not mean that we want to sell the company - the company is not for sale,'' he said. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. launced a $90-a-share cash tender offer to NCR shareholders Thursday. On Wednesday, NCR's board rejected a takeover bid of $90 a share in AT&T stock, or a total of about $6.1 billion. NCR directors said Wednesday in their rejection that they would enter into discussions with AT&T over a merger if it increased the bid to $125 a share, or a total of about $8.5 billion. AT&T rejected the amount as ``outrageous.'' Exley said NCR would provide AT&T with non-public information about his company's finances that would justify the higher offer if AT&T would sign a confidentiality agreement and an agreement to halt further steps toward a takeover. Also Friday, AT&T said it would withdraw a request it filed in U.S. District Court in Columbus seeking a temporary restraining order against enforcement of the Ohio Takeover Act. The law sets out procedures to be followed and information disclosed in tender offers. Thomas B. Ridgley, a Columbus lawyer representing AT&T, told Judge James L. Graham the company would drop its motion as a result of an order issued by the Ohio Division of Securities. The order confirmed that the agency, based on documents provided by AT&T, would not suspend the company's bid for shares of NCR. AT&T's request for a restraining order was part of a lawsuit filed Thursday contending federal instead of state law should prevail in its bid for NCR. Although the request for expedited action was dropped, the suit is pending. The phone company says it wants to buy NCR, the nation's fifth-largest computer company, to bolster its own money-losing computer line.
